webTitle: Political donations made public for first time

fields.headline: Political donations made public for first time
fields.trailText: The first public list of people and companies who donate money to political parties was published today in a move to restore public confidence in campaign financing ahead of a general election.
fields.body:
The first public list of people and companies who donate money to political parties was published today in a move to restore public confidence in campaign financing ahead of a general election.

Any donation of more than £5,000 to a national party, or above £1,000 to a local constituency party, must appear on the list, or the offending political party will face a fine, possible imprisonment of the party treasurer - and scathing headlines from the press.

The new register comes as a result of the Neill committee into standards in public life and is administered by the independent Electoral Commission.

The chairman of the Electoral Commission, Sam Younger, said: "The aim is to establish openness and transparency in the financial affairs of Britain's political parties.

"We are delighted that the information will be freely available and easily accessible to all via the internet."

The register, the first of its kind in the UK, shows the Tories received almost £45,000 from private companies during February and March, with Labour clocking up just £3,360 in the same period - all of it from the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union.

The Liberal Democrats push the Conservatives a close second with exactly £30,953.39.

The Electoral Commission - a body which monitors elections in the UK and the fundraising of all political parties - was set up in the wake of the cash for questions allegations which dogged the John Major government.

Now all donations above £200 must come from individuals on the UK electoral roll, or companies registered in Britain or the European Union.

More than 100 political parties are registered with the Electoral Commission, although 88 of those have had no donations to report. Nine parties have complied with the regulations, and nine more have failed to comply.

The Commission is now chasing those nine parties, although they are thought to be small operations.

Labour was heavily criticised earlier this year after it was revealed they had solicited multi-million pound donations just before the February 16 deadline for gifts to be declared.

Lord Hamlyn, who gave £2m to Labour, was finally forced to come into the open after a two day media frenzy trying to uncover the identity of the mystery donor.

The Tories announced the biggest single political donation to a political party - £5m from spread betting millionaire Stuart Wheeler - within days.

The first edition of the register, which will be published quarterly, covers the period February 16 - the setting up of the Electoral Commission - to the end of March.

fields.headline: Redundant advisers face tougher rules
fields.trailText: The Treasury will next week make the biggest severance pay-out in British political history to ministerial special advisers and members of the Downing Street policy unit - worth nearly £500,000 - under revised Whitehall guidelines drawn up by the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson.
fields.body:
The Treasury will next week make the biggest severance pay-out in British political history to ministerial special advisers and members of the Downing Street policy unit - worth nearly £500,000 - under revised Whitehall guidelines drawn up by the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson.

Tony Blair's expected declaration of the election date will also signal tougher rules placed on the few advisers remaining in Whitehall and restrictions on those working in Labour's Millbank headquarters.

Most of Labour's 78 ministerial special advisers and members of the No 10 policy unit will receive between £10,000 and £49,000 in cash payments the moment parliament is dissolved. The total figure will be triple the amount paid out by the Tories in 1997 when there were only 24 advisers.

The former advisers will still be funded by the taxpayer if they work for Labour during the election campaign. The rules say they must return the severance cash minus a month if they are reappointed after the expected polling day. In the meantime they will be free to invest all the money and retain the interest.

The deal gives Alastair Campbell nearly £49,000 and other top advisers to Gordon Brown, Jack Straw and David Blunkett between £20,000 and £30,000.

The rules - which were placed in the House of Commons library yesterday morning - were accompanied by revised guidelines restricting the activities of advisers.

All government property, including mobile telephones, pagers, laptops, must be surrendered to the department on resignation, and all confidential IDs will be inactivated the moment the advisers leave Whitehall.

fields.headline: Extra worry for money site
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: A security loophole at online finance site moneyextra has left the financial details of its users open for public viewing.
fields.body:
A security loophole at online finance site moneyextra has left the financial details of its users open for public viewing.

The flaw in moneyextra's site exposes a user's log in name and password. It means that if a moneyextra customer accesses the service on a shared computer - at work or at an internet café or library - anyone who subsequently sits down at that computer would have access to their entire financial portfolio.

Moneyextra user Geoff Bowen discovered the flaw while checking his online portfolio.

"I was shocked that such a big company is enabling potential hackers to easily access users' personal details by simply looking at their history," he said.

Mr Bowen, the managing director of internet services company X-line, said that passing on a user's log in details through a URL, or internet address, is one of the most common security flaws around.

"They really should have known better," he added.

The areas of the site accessible by the password include a file which, depending on how a user has set it up, could display credit card, banking, mortgage and share details.

Even if users choose the high security option - which forces customers to enter a username and password every time the site is accessed - the username and password would be visible in the web browser's history.

The details are clearly identifiable, in plain text, in the address field of Internet Explorer browsers.

The flaw does not appear to affect users of Netscape.

Moneyextra acknowledged that user profiles should not be visible in this way.

"It was on high security? Bloody hell," said the deputy web producer, Damian Vincent. "It's because we are doing the URL in http rather than in secure https. Http is standard level security, but https is encrypted and secure."

Andy Pratt, the programme and IT director at moneyextra, said the problem would be corrected within two weeks with the launch of a new portfolio service. He added that all transactional services on moneyextra, such as online share dealing, already operate under a separate and encrypted security system.

fields.headline: Universal bank hits last-minute snag
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The government's plan for a post office-based universal bank tailored for social-security claimants hit last-minute hitches yesterday and may now be put back until after the general election.
fields.body:
The government's plan for a post office-based universal bank tailored for social-security claimants hit last-minute hitches yesterday and may now be put back until after the general election.

After long and difficult negotiations with the high street banks, the Department of Trade and Industry had been expected to announce a deal yesterday.

No announcement was forthcoming. One senior banking source said that an expected decision next Tuesday to call the election might stall the project.

Banks are being asked to contribute as much as £150m a year to the universal bank which is intended to offer services to about 4m claimants who do not have accounts. They will need an account when the benefits systems is automated in 2003.

The move is also regarded as an attempt by the government to try to plug the £400m in lost revenue which the Post Office will face when it no longer pays out benefits in cash.

The project is understood to involve two main features. There will be a post office-branded simple card account which will be little more than the equivalent of an electronic benefits book. The banks have also agreed to make very basic accounts available for use through the Post Office.

The DTI refused to say whether any of the major banks had officially signed a detailed memorandum of understanding which has faced scrutiny since Christmas.

Leading banks, particularly the Halifax, are thought to have resisted pressure to allow their basic accounts to be opened in post offices.

The DTI said: "The discussions are continuing and we hope to announce an agreement shortly."

The Post Office admitted this week that taxpayers could face a rising bill from the project.

fields.headline: Hamlet
fields.standfirst: Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford Upon Avon: ****
fields.trailText: Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford Upon Avon: ****
fields.body:
Having collaborated on a triumphant Richard II, the same actor-director team of Samuel West and Steven Pimlott now give us a strikingly similar Hamlet : cliche-free, anti-romantic, visually spare and politically vivid. Played on a thrust-forward stage, complete with Japanese-style walkway, it runs for four hours and is totally gripping.

What is startling is Pimlott's ability to create a plausible Elsinore through the simplest means. Alison Chitty's set is a white box that takes on contrasting colours through Peter Mumford's superb lighting. But we instantly know what kind of world we're in - an elective tyranny - when Larry Lamb's glad-handing Claudius is greeted with volleys of sycophantic applause by his name-tagged acolytes. And it's a measure of Pimlott's avid eye for detail that when, four hours later, a bandolier-bedecked Fortinbras claims "I have some rights of memory in this kingdom", he is greeted by the self-same Voltemand earlier despatched as ambassador to Norway.

Defining Elsinore instantly throws Hamlet 's dilemma into sharp relief: you don't just rush off and kill a protected presidential figure like Claudius. And the keynote of West's fine Hamlet is a mordant intelligence and sense of political impotence. This Hamlet has a built-in bullshit detector that enables him to see through his own, and other people's, rhetoric. And if he packs a pistol, he is more likely to use it against himself than Claudius: indeed, he points it at his own temple before invoking the divine injunction against self-slaughter. Effectively marginalised by Claudius, West's Hamlet turns inwards at one point he even shares a spliff with his old mates Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

Each actor creates his own Hamlet and West's is sardonic, clever and cruelly aware of his own powerlessness. When the First Player describes the immobilised Pyrrhus confronting Priam, West brilliantly echoes the phrase about the way Pyrrhus "did nothing". If I miss anything in his performance, it is the youthful sexual confusion vividly highlighted by Stephen Dillane but that is partly because Kerry Condon's slight, fey Ophelia seems an unlikely lover for this Hamlet , who would obviously be doing his PhD at Wittenberg.

It is, however, a rare piece of undercasting in an ensemble that bats all the way down. Lamb's Claudius is a brutally charismatic strong-arm politician Marty Cruickshank's Gertrude is a disenchanted sensualist who looks meaningfully at her husband when she makes a coarse joke in the midst of her threnody over Ophelia and Alan David's Polonius is a pompously nasty piece of work.

We have lately had a rash of depoliticised Hamlets. Pimlott puts power back at the play's centre and, with West, makes it enthrallingly clear that Hamlet 's tragedy is that he is the paralysed individual conscience in a world of realpolitik.

Until October 13. Box office: 01789 403403.

fields.headline: Premium boost for CGNU profits
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: CGNU, Britain's largest insurer, yesterday reported a 12% rise in operating profit for the first quarter of the year after it sharply pushed up premiums for car and household insurance and benefited from savings following the merger with Norwich Union.
fields.body:
CGNU, Britain's largest insurer, yesterday reported a 12% rise in operating profit for the first quarter of the year after it sharply pushed up premiums for car and household insurance and benefited from savings following the merger with Norwich Union.

Profits for general insurance at the end of last year had been dented by £285m in flood claims. To improve margins and provide a larger cushion against claims, premiums on household insurance policies have risen 4-5% in the last quarter, while motor insurance premiums have been pushed up 15%.

The company said record growth in its long-term savings business and improved performances in its continental subsidiaries bolstered results.

Richard Harvey, group chief executive, said: "Every line of our business has shown an improvement." He pointed to a 38% rise in profits in its general insurance business to £155m, which he said had been positioned to remain consistently profitable. While general insurance formed only 20% of the group's business, it provided much of the cash to underwrite sales of life policies.

A strong rise in pension sales prompted by the launch of the government's stakeholder pensions helped to boost life business profits by 13% to £444m.

The company says it wants at least 20% of the stakeholder market despite the impact on margins, which are restricted by a limit of 1% on annual management fees.

 Rises in car insurance premiums have failed to dent enthusiasm for new cars, according to the latest Alliance & Leicester car price index. While prices continued to drop, by 8.7% last month, the index reveals that they are beginning to steady. The price of nearly new and used cars showed the first year-on-year increases for two years.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: credit unions and loan sharks

fields.headline: There must be banks for the poor as well as the rich
fields.standfirst: The failure of credit unions plays straight into the hands of loan sharks
fields.trailText: The failure of credit unions plays straight into the hands of loan sharks.
fields.body:
A small tragedy is unfolding that could and should be prevented. A credit union held up as a famous model of self-help in one of the poorest places is about to crash. Some 3,000 people stand to loose every penny of their very hard-earned life savings.

At conferences on social exclusion, the Camberwell Credit Union has been presented as the exemplar, with its members testifying movingly to how it saved them from loan shark penury and above all, how it gave them pride in their local community as they banded together to create something for themselves. Credit unions have been extolled time and again by Labour ministers. But now its members face a shattering loss.

It was mainly West Indians who founded the union some 20 years ago when they were denied ordinary bank accounts. So they set up their own community bank on the North Peckham estate, (where Damilola Taylor was murdered), drawing in people from every background paying in some £5 a week.

They include the student single mother who scraped together £220 for her son's future, the Irish widow on benefits with two children who will lose £350, the 67-year-old West Indian chef who will lose £3,500 for his old age and the elderly woman whose son put £5,000 into her account as she had no savings; 24 people had £800 each put into their accounts by Southwark council for new furnishings when they were decanted while the estate is rebuilt.

They have all been told that due to bad debts, they will only get 50p in the pound back: if it is forced to close, the liquidators fees will take the rest.

The Financial Services Authority (FSA) discovered a shortfall of £200,000 and ordered the books to be frozen as an insolvent organisation. It was not fraud but over-lenient lending that destroyed them, as has happened before with these small, amateur run banks.

The very thing that makes credit unions so attractive to urban regenerators, encouraging social enterprise with deep community roots, is also what makes them perilously vulnerable. If Camberwell goes under it will send a frightening message to all the other 450 community credit unions. Expect a run on them by vulnerable people who simply cannot afford to take any risks. It could spell the end for many small community unions.

A rescue is being attempted by Harriet Harman together with Tessa Jowell, whose constituents are among the losers. The FSA is doing what it can to help. Southwark council has put in £20,000. The necessary £200,000 is not a large sum for the Treasury and big banks to stump up between them. But the Treasury has so far refused, claiming it would set a precedent for bailing others out.

However, as from July 2002 an excellent new law designed to strengthen credit unions will bring their members under the same umbrella as banks, protecting savers from any future collapse. So a Treasury rescue only risks a minor precedent for another year.

The British Banking Association has been asked for help too, but so far not a penny has been forthcoming. Banks have no interest in picking up 3,000 poor customers who cost more than they bring in. The only hope is that some might see this good cause will bring them better publicity than they could ever buy with a mere £200,000 of advertising. Particularly as the money would only be needed as a long-term guarantee and they would probably get it back.

"Financial exclusion" has much exercised this government - a big phrase for not having any money. With puritan fervour this chancellor is trying to create a savings culture to help the feckless poor who save too little.

There have been brainstorming seminars inside Number 11 and much research commissioned to delve into the savings habits of the poor. (Most were found to be "jamjarring".) Imaginative new schemes have been devised, such as baby bonds to give poor children a capital start in life. Or the new "savings gateway" where the government will match pound for pound any money the poor manage to save.

The other hope was the promised Universal Bank, to be set up within the post office. It should have been unveiled with a flourish yesterday, but at the last fence the deeply antagonistic banks balked again: so far not one of the 11 have signed the Memorandum of Understanding to bring it into being.

They have dragged their heels and succeeded in yet again trouncing the government, offering the minimum while contributing a minimal sum. The DTI has been frustrated in its negotiations by the Treasury forbidding them from threatening the banks with any hint of compulsion or punishment. "It would have been handy to have more cards in our hand," said one DTI negotiator ruefully.

Banks never wanted poor customers cluttering up their queues, paying in and out piffling sums at more cost than they were worth. Banks rarely lend sums under £1,000, so the poor needing small loans have only the loan sharks charging anything up to 150%, from whom they never escape. Now it emerges that the Universal Bank has partly stalled because all the commercial banks are arguing amongst each other, not competing for this new custom but each fighting to take on as little as possible.

When the Universal Bank was first announced, ministers talked boldly of the banks' "moral obligation" to compensate society for with drawing from rural and poor urban areas. Now it will probably be a puny thing, primarily a cheaper way for the government to pay out benefits and a support for post offices - no use at all in helping the poor avoid crippling loan shark debt.

Benefits will be paid into post office "card accounts", that do nothing else. Post offices will then urge people to go into banks and open basic accounts which offer almost nothing - and certainly no loans, though they can at least be accessed thereafter over post office counters. This is barely better than the jam jar: government claims that people can get discounts from paying utility bills by direct debit cut no ice with all those who can never afford to pay bills all at once.

Credit unions which require people to accumulate some savings before they qualify for small loans are a model of Brown prudence. However this admirable but pathetically small movement with just 100,000 community members and very shaky financial viability, usually only open for half a day a week, is not the answer for millions of people who need safe savings and loans with good financial advice.

Credit unions need to be professionalised, with government help. As for the Universal Bank, if Mrs Thatcher could windfall commercial banks, the chancellor could at least threaten it, unless they provide a decent savings and loan service for rich and poor alike.

webTitle: Halifax and BoS boards tie it up

fields.headline: Halifax and BoS boards tie it up
fields.trailText: The boards of Halifax and Bank of Scotland met last night to ratify the terms of their "nil premium" merger.
fields.body:
The boards of Halifax and Bank of Scotland met last night to ratify the terms of their "nil premium" merger.

The details of the £27bn deal are expected to be revealed today after a week of breakneck negotiations to clinch their "last chance saloon deal," according to one investor.

Both sides are thought to have wanted to avoid dragging the talks into the coming bank-holiday weekend after spending the past seven days locked in meetings to try to agree on the sensitive issue of the headquarters location of the combined entity, and the even more delicate issue of its name.

The negotiations have been especially tense because of the need to balance the demands of Scottish nationalists with local pressure on Halifax executives in Yorkshire.

It is widely believed that Halifax, the larger of the two banks, has agreed to the headquarters being in Edinburgh. The two banks are expected to try to keep job losses in the combined 57,000 workforce to a minimum.

The deal, which the banks agree will involve a one-for-one share exchange, is also thought to be structured to take account of the Halifax's share structure. Some 3.5m private investors hold Halifax shares - a legacy of its demutalisation from building society status just four years ago. Advisers are thought to have devised the deal in such a way that it will not need the consent of so many of the small shareholders.

Since the merger talks leaked, investors in Halifax have been able to watch their shares rise back above the 774p at which they made their stock market debut. Last night, Halifax ended 3p higher at 793p, while BoS closed at 811p, up 13p.

webTitle: Review: Playboy of the Western World

fields.headline: The Playboy of the Western World
fields.standfirst: Playhouse, Liverpool  **
fields.trailText: Playhouse, Liverpool **
fields.body:
When JM Synge's play premiered at the Abbey in Dublin in 1907, it caused riots; this revival is hardly likely to stir an audience at all. It is decent enough and tells the story, but fails to make it seem fresh-minted and holds no surprises.

At first, it looks as if it might do more. Simon Higlett's design doesn't offer the traditional bar in a tiny Irish backwater, but a mountainous arrangement of beer barrels that suggests the hills over which the locals scramble as fast as they can to Pegeen Mike's bar, to get a glimpse of Christy Mahon, father-slayer.

The design recalls the Giant's Causeway of Antrim rather than Mayo, but then the exploits of the giant Finn MacColl owe as much to self-invention as Christy himself, who stumbles into the bar one night claiming to have killed his father. Soon the locals are hailing him as a hero, keen to shield him from English law and the gallows, while Pegeen Mike is intent on throwing over her intended, dull Shawn Keogh, for this romantic fellow. Only the past very quickly catches up with Christy.

In some of the best moments in Robert Delamere's production, the bloody past lurches over the top of the barrels like some spectre in a slasher movie. But as a whole, the production lacks this immediacy, and indeed the humour that pervades the play. Watching it, you would hardly know the play is a comedy, albeit one in which bitterness is woven into the laughter.

Most of the performances lack focus too. Only Fiona Victory brings real definition to her role as the manipulative, smooth-tongued Widow Quinn, who tries to turn every situation to her own advantage. Aoife McMahon depicts some of Pegeen's desperation but rushes at the lines as if they might otherwise escape her. As Christy, Barry Ward opts for a hunched, low-key approach, always more of the "dribbling idiot" of his father's mind than the swaggering hero who has bought into his own myth.

Until May 19. Box office: 0151-709 4776.

fields.headline: Sabine Meyer
fields.body:
The German clarinettist Sabine Meyer is a formidable figure; an air of solemnity hovers round her. Making her long-awaited Wigmore Hall debut with the pianist Lars Vogt, she walked onto the platform wearing a sombre black dress with a stiff white collar. She looked, I thought at first, rather rigid. However, the severity of her appearance forms a sharp contrast with her playing, which is characterised by a sinuosity of line, matchless beauty of tone, and a subtle yet passionate expressiveness. She is widely regarded as one of the greatest instrumentalists of our time, and her reputation is entirely justified.

Berg and Brahms formed her programme, which focused primarily on the latter's two Clarinet Sonatas: late, dense, epoch-making works. Taken together, they form an essay in contrast as well as a radical exploration of classical structure. The First is expansive, almost symphonic in its sweep, passing from turbulence to florid ebullience and containing at its centre a slow movement of languid serenity.

The introverted Second is its exact opposite: classical structure is pared down to its barest essentials. An aphoristic compactness offsets a fluidly changing, almost overwhelming richness of mood and thematic development. Clarinet and piano carry equal weight in this music - there's no suggestion at any point of the pianist taking on the role of accompanist. Meyer and the equally remarkable Vogt seemed to function as an indivisible unit, each supremely alert to every flicker of meaning and mood, neither of them straying towards arid virtuosity. The audience sat through it all in awed silence.

Brahms's influence on the Second Viennese School was strong, and Berg's Four Pieces for Clarinet and Piano draw, to a certain extent, on the combination of formal terseness and wide-ranging expression in Brahms's Second Sonata. There are flashes forward to the curving melodic eroticism of Lulu - blatantly, almost shockingly done by Meyer - as well as the queasy ululations of Wozzeck. Here, Meyer cleaved the air with a sequence of lacerating, expressionistic shrieks.

Vogt, left to his own devices, also played Berg's Piano Sonata, perfectly judging the balance between its vast, architectonic one-movement structure, and the wild post- Wagnerian extravagance of its sentiments.

fields.headline: Ghost Ward
fields.standfirst: Almeida, London  ***
fields.trailText: Almeida, London ***
fields.body:
Cool, chic and challenging are words you would associate with the Almeida's output, but the words community and heart would not readily spring to mind. Until, that is, the arrival of this community-based participatory project about young lives possibly poised on the brink of death.

The journey begins at the Almeida's temporary King's Cross home; from there we are taken by bus across the city to a disused east London hospital. On arrival, we are led through the abandoned wards and corridors, now crowded with the spectres of those who worked there, children who were treated there and parents who worried there. All the text is based on interviews with those staying or working in paediatric wards.

The experience is fleeting, fragmentary and mysterious. You walk down a corridor that smells of cabbage, peer into rooms where a nurse sits next to a bed in which a striplight flickers faintly on and off, and pass another where a pair of child's shoes lie abandoned. In another corridor, we pass by ghostly children playing clapping games, overhear snippets of conversation between children isolated from each other by white curtains, and hear how surgeons cope with death and parents deal with its possibility.

The whole thing is rough and ready and a little too long. As with the NHS, you often find yourself waiting in a queue. But it has a wonderful element of surprise and an unaffected intimacy. It is like eavesdropping on real people's lives and is, at times, unbearably moving, not least because the children involved - all from local schools - treat the whole thing like a huge, crucially important game.

Many people will dismiss this kind of community-based theatre as having social rather than artistic importance. Ghost Ward is not high art, but it plays with our concept of what theatre can be. Its appeal may be limited to children, parents and those working in paediatrics, but as that covers most of us, it has a huge constituency. It is good to see the Almeida serving it.

Ends tomorrow. Box office: 020-7359 4404.

fields.headline: HBOS: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: The Bank of Scotland and Halifax merged this morning to create a new banking giant called HBOS. We explain why
fields.trailText: The Bank of Scotland and Halifax merged this morning to create a new banking giant called HBOS. We explain why
fields.body:
Why are the two banks merging?
According to Halifax and Bank of Scotland, the boards of the two banks involved, the merger is "a compelling business combination". Translated, this means the two banks hope to increase profitability by increasing their stake in the marketplace and cross-selling each other's products.

What's in it for Halifax?
Halifax converted from a building society to a bank in 1997 and, as a result, has felt the pressure of becoming a company answerable to its shareholders. The bank needed to look for new ways to make money and the merger with BoS means it will have a strong presence in the United Kingdom banking sector for the first time.

What's in it for Bank of Scotland?
The merger allows Bank of Scotland to expand its business from its home turf to the whole of the UK. The successful merger follows the Bank of Scotland's failed merger attempts with Abbey National and NatWest.

When did the two banks get it together?
The two banks surprised the City a couple of weeks back on April 25 when they announced their intention to merge. Since that time, there has been much speculation over who would head the new bank and where they would be based. The decision was reached today (May 4)) that James Crosby, chief executive of Halifax, would head the new bank and the headquarters will be based in the Scottish bank's home of Edinburgh.

How much will the new bank be worth?
The £28bn merger creates the UK's fifth largest bank, with 57,000 staff and more than 1,000 branches. The move is described as a "merger of equals", although Halifax is the larger partner with 37,000 employees and a market value of about £18bn. BoS has some 20,000 staff and is valued at more than £10bn.

What does the merger mean for shareholders?
It's too early to say, as the value of shares is largely dependent on the successful management of the new bank. Certainly, the merger has had little impact on the London market so far. However, Bank of Scotland chief executive, Peter Burt is optimistic saying he believes the deal will be "earnings enhancing" for the bank's shareholders.

How will customers benefit from the merger?
While the newly formed bank says the deal will offer "substantial benefits" for customers, most remain sceptical about the impact of the combined forces of the banks on its customer base. Certainly, the bank could well become a significant challenger to the "big four" high street banks, but this is dependent on skilful management of the new holding. The bank will hold a strong position in retail, corporate banking, small business banking and long-term savings and insurance.

How could customers lose out?
Mergers bring with them a narrowing of choice in the marketplace, which is not a good thing for customers. Existing Halifax and BoS customers are also likely to find themselves bombarded with junk mail from both banks as the two cross-sell each others products. An American study of bank mergers found that, in the majority of cases, cost cutting was achieved by redundancies, but less than half of the mergers improved the banks efficiency.

What does it mean for employees of the banks?
For many, it will mean redundancies. The bank says that over the next three years it is expected that there will be a reduction of about 2,000 jobs across the group. However, the good news for those remaining is that the new bank promises to retain existing employment rights, including accrued pension rights.

Will the bank's branches be affected?
The bank says that both Bank of Scotland and Halifax will remain as separate institutions and will continue to trade under the current brand names. However, it is likely that branch closures will ensue where Halifax and Bank of Scotland occupy spaces in the same street.

However, the good news for those remaining is that the new bank promises to retain existing employment rights, including accrued pension rights. Will the bank's branches be affected? The bank says that both Bank of Scotland and Halifax will remain as separate institutions and will continue to trade under the current brand names. However, it is likely that branch closures will ensue where Halifax and Bank of Scotland occupy spaces in the same street.

fields.headline: Big banks: are they good for you?
fields.trailText: HBOS has arrived at last, amid much excitement and fanfare this morning. But while the Halifax and BOS chiefs pat each other on the back after promising to love, honour and obey for the duration of their happy union, customers and shareholders will be waiting to see whether it's good news all round.
fields.body:
HBOS has arrived at last, amid much excitement and fanfare this morning. But while the Halifax and BOS chiefs pat each other on the back after promising to love, honour and obey for the duration of their happy union, customers and shareholders will be waiting to see whether it's good news all round.

Certainly, Bank of Scotland shareholders may have reasons for optimism following the announcement. Mergers can often mean good news for shareholders, and Bank of Scotland chief executive Peter Burt said the deal would be "earnings enhancing" for Bank of Scotland from day one.

However, the performance of the new holding is largely reliant on the management, with both banks seeming to have taken a considerable amount of time deciding who will run the show.

The merger has created a fifth giant force on the high street which could well pose a threat to Royal Bank of Scotland, if not Barclays, HSBC and Lloyds TSB. Again, success is largely dependent on how good a job Halifax's James Crosby makes as chief executive of HBOS. But the pressure on the big four is at least stepped up a notch.

One thing is certain, and that is that both Halifax and Bank of Scotland believe they will benefit from the deal. For Halifax, the decision to merge was driven by the realisation that it could no longer rely on the stronghold it had, as a building society, on the mortgage market to drive it forward.

Since its decision to become a plc in 1997, the bank has had to cope with the pressure of expectation from shareholders, and as a result it needed to look further afield for ways to develop its business. Its merger with BoS will, for the first time, make it a major player in the UK banking sector. For Bank of Scotland, the deal means it can extend its narrow customer base beyond its home turf.

But for the humble customer, it's a matter of wait and see. HBOS says that it will focus on "value, choice and convenience" for its customers but the merger gives the two banks an opportunity to cross-sell products to its combined customer base, and these products may not necessarily be the best on offer.

As a result, one thing Halifax and Bank of Scotland customers are likely to notice from the merger is the increase in the junk mail they already get from the two banks falling from their letterbox.

The benefits of consolidation don't always come off as planned either. In the case of Barclays' purchase of the Woolwich business last year, the bank disappointed its existing customers when it was unable to honour its promise to offer them Woolwich's highly popular Open Plan product.

Mergers inevitably reduce choice in the marketplace, which, despite the entrance of new players, remains a problem. And, in a fiercely competitive marketplace, customer service is often sacrificed at the expense of supposedly beneficial product innovation with branch closures and staff redundancies further casualties of a supposedly advantageous consolidation

webTitle: House prices are rising by £50 a day

fields.headline: House prices are rising by £50 a day
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Further evidence of a pick-up in the housing market came yesterday with figures showing the price of an average property rose 1.7% last month, equivalent to an increase of £50 a day.
fields.body:
Further evidence of a pick-up in the housing market came yesterday with figures showing the price of an average property rose 1.7% last month, equivalent to an increase of £50 a day.

Halifax said its survey, showing the largest rise since early last autumn, reflected the recent mortgage rate cuts and consumer confidence not damaged by the slowdown in the US economy and stock market falls.

The figures come days after Nationwide said prices rose 0.8% in April and the British Bankers' Association reported that mortgage lending had climbed to record levels.

Halifax said the average property now costs £89,295, compared with £87,784 a month ago. Since the start of the year a typical property has increased in value by more than £3,700.

The rise in March pushed the annual rate of price growth up from 4.1% to 5.7%. In January annual house price inflation was running at 0.9%.

A Halifax spokesman said prospects for the housing market over the coming months continue to be positive.

The improvement in prices it recorded was mirrored by inland revenue figures showing an increase in property sales in the past few months.

The number of transactions in the first quarter of this year was 3% higher than in the final quarter of 2000 on a seasonally adjusted basis.

"The recent strengthening in housing demand apparent in the pick-up in both house prices and activity since the beginning of the year has been aided by the cuts in mortgage rates," the bank said.

"Moreover, the increase in housing demand demonstrates that household confidence remains buoyant despite the deterioration in global economic growth and the fall in share prices since the start of 2001."

Some economists are predicting one or two more quarter-point interest rate cuts in the next few months, and Halifax said lower interest rates should ensure that housing demand remained robust.

fields.headline: BBC Philharmonic/Furst
fields.standfirst: RNCM, Manchester  ***
fields.trailText: RNCM, Manchester ***
fields.body:
The Royal Northern College of Music's international cello festival is now a flourishing institution in Manchester. This year it has commissioned five new works and there will be three European premieres of music by North and South American composers. With very few exceptions, this is a celebration of cello music that is firmly centred on the past 100 years, partly reflecting this year's American bias.

The two big orchestral concerts - the second of which is tomorrow night - offer a priceless opportunity to hear some of the world's greatest cellists lined up one after another. But anyone hoping to hear Elgar, Schumann or Shostakovich might well be disappointed: with the sole exception of the Dvorak, the most popular concertos have been rigorously eliminated from this year's programme.

What is left after the cull is an uneven but fascinating mixture. Victor Herbert's Second Concerto of 1894, which opened the festival, is a cellist's cello concerto: luxuriant, impassioned and so beautifully written for the instrument that its musical weaknesses shrink into insignificance. In Raphael Wallfisch's hands, it blossomed so gratefully that its neglect suddenly seemed a terrible injustice.

Others had less to work with. In what was his only performance in the festival, Janos Starker gave an impassive account of Dohnanyi's already uninspiring Concertstucke. Bernstein's Meditations are more seriously below par. They were beautifully played by the Canadian cellist Gary Hoffman, but ultimately unsalvageable.

The remaining works were rather more substantial. Boris Pergamenschikow was a dedicated soloist in Hindemith's rather hard-line Concerto, and Danish cellist Erling Blondal Bengtsson gave a veteran performance of the Walton, which he premiered in Manchester in 1958.

Listening to the BBC Philharmonic at full throttle in the 400-seater RNCM concert hall is the live equivalent of sitting in front of the hi-fi with the volume up: it is exciting in a way, but not without its problems. On this occasion, coordination was a serious issue, which it isn't usually with this orchestra. Whether this was due to a problem with the conductor or the acoustic is impossible to say.

The RNCM Cello Festival ends Sunday. Box office: 0161-907 5278.

fields.headline: Spooks pick up the Fugees' baton
fields.standfirst:
Spooks
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London ***
fields.trailText:
Spooks

Shepherd's Bush Empire, London ***
fields.body:
The surprising thing about the Fugees was not that three such ambitious characters coexisted long enough to make rap's biggest-selling album, but that they inspired so few imitators. It's been two years since they disappeared from radar screens, but only now has a group appeared that unarguably owes a debt to Lauryn Hill and company.

Spooks take up where they left off in both configuration (charismatic female crooner flanked by boisterous male MCs) and musical signature. Their positivist hip-pop has yielded one of this year's lushest singles, Things I've Seen, which poses one of those existential questions ("Emotion or reason, now which one do you obey?") that pre-Fugee rap didn't trouble its head with.

From the welcome they receive for their first UK headliner, the hip-hop public has missed this sort of gentle "edutainment". The five east-coasters, who refuse to divulge their exact origins, employ a little auto-suggestion by performing in front of a banner that reads "Spooks: hijacking the planet". It seems to spur on their well-oiled show, in which MCs Bookaso, Vengeance, Water Water and Hypno roar through most of their debut album, SIOSOS (Spooks Is on Some Other Script), like so many genial juggernauts, while vocalist Ming-Xia bends notes like a rap Ella Fitzgerald.

Each tune is preceded by a little homily. The whirling Karma Hotel comes with a warning from Bookaso about staying upright: "If you stab people in the back, it'll come back and squash you like a bug." Sucker MCs also get short shrift. "We know you're looking for something fresh and original," the four rappers taunt on Something Fresh, a big ensemble piece driven by a squawking saxophone. Most of the music is played live, with almost no recourse to samples, which is almost unheard of.

Ming-Xia, who flouts rap convention by being cuddly rather than glamorous, personifies their genre-hopping style by issuing chirps that build into full-blown jazz odysseys. Singing in Spanish on the salsa-fied Swindley's Maracas, she's quite something. If Spooks miss a trick, it's by not giving her enough to do.

Professor Griff, Public Enemy's long-departed Minister of Information, arrives to kick off Things I've Seen. Small and stooped, he could be the ghost of hip-hop past. As he high-fives the company, there's a sense of the torch being passed to the next generation.

fields.headline: David Sawer premiere
fields.standfirst: Wessex Hall, Poole  ****
fields.body:
Just five days after his opera From Morning to Midnight was unveiled by English National Opera, David Sawer had another premiere - this first performance of Musica Ficta, performed by the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra under Harry Christophers. Sawer was composer-in-residence with the Bournemouth orchestras from 1995 to 1997, when this piece was commissioned for the Bournemouth Sinfonietta. But, by the time he finished it in 1998, the Sinfonietta was no more, and it has languished until it was programmed by the full symphony orchestra. Sawer slightly bolstered the scoring for this performance, but it remains modest, requiring just classically sized forces.

Musica ficta is an early music term for the addition of accidentals, sharps and flats to avoid awkward intervals to sing or play, even though they were not indicated in the score. Sawer extends the idea, not just using it to switch his music between white notes and black, tonality and chromaticism, but to cross-cut ideas in the way that gives his music its pungency and fascination.

There are passages of an almost Copland-like pastoralism next to music far more sinewy and complex, but what propels the piece is the alert rhythmic invention. The strings are soon snapping away with Stravinskian vigour, and throughout the 10-minute course of the piece every idea seems to be drawn towards that kind of assertiveness.

One of Sawer's great gifts is his ability to make even the most straightforward gesture into something far more intriguing. In the second half a simple upward-scale movement fragment takes on a whole range of resonances until it finally evaporates in the last moments of the piece. It is faultlessly paced, and Christophers and the BSO gave a polished, neat performance. Sawer has provided the orchestra with an attractive addition to its repertory, and one that should also travel well.

fields.headline: Pistols and politics in Denmark
fields.standfirst:
Hamlet
Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon ****
fields.trailText:
Hamlet

Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon ****
fields.body:
Having collaborated on a triumphant Richard II, the same actor-director team of Samuel West and Steven Pimlott now give us a strikingly similar Hamlet: cliche-free, anti-romantic, visually spare and politically vivid. Played on a thrust-forward stage, complete with Japanese-style walkway, it runs for four hours and is totally gripping.

What is startling is Pimlott's ability to create a plausible Elsinore through the simplest means. Alison Chitty's set is a white box that takes on contrasting colours through Peter Mumford's superb lighting. But we instantly know what kind of world we're in - an elective tyranny - when Larry Lamb's glad-handing Claudius is greeted with volleys of sycophantic applause by his name-tagged acolytes. And it's a measure of Pimlott's avid eye for detail that when, four hours later, a bandolier-bedecked Fortinbras claims "I have some rights of memory in this kingdom", he is greeted by the self-same Voltemand earlier despatched as ambassador to Norway.

Defining Elsinore instantly throws Hamlet's dilemma into sharp relief: you don't just rush off and kill a protected presidential figure like Claudius. And the keynote of West's fine Hamlet is a mordant intelligence and sense of political impotence. This Hamlet has a built-in bullshit detector that enables him to see through his own, and other people's, rhetoric. And if he packs a pistol, he is more likely to use it against himself than Claudius: indeed, he points it at his own temple before invoking the divine injunction against self-slaughter. Effectively marginalised by Claudius, West's Hamlet turns inwards; at one point he even shares a spliff with his old mates Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

Each actor creates his own Hamlet and West's is sardonic, clever and cruelly aware of his own powerlessness. When the First Player describes the immobilised Pyrrhus confronting Priam, West brilliantly echoes the phrase about the way Pyrrhus "did nothing". If I miss anything in his performance, it is the youthful sexual confusion vividly highlighted by Stephen Dillane; but that is partly because Kerry Condon's slight, fey Ophelia seems an unlikely lover for this Hamlet, who would obviously be doing his PhD at Wittenberg.

It is, however, a rare piece of undercasting in an ensemble that bats all the way down. Lamb's Claudius is a brutally charismatic strong-arm politician; Marty Cruickshank's Gertrude is a disenchanted sensualist who looks meaningfully at her husband when she makes a coarse joke in the midst of her threnody over Ophelia; and Alan David's Polonius is a pompously nasty piece of work.

We have lately had a rash of depoliticised Hamlets. Pimlott puts power back at the play's centre and, with West, makes it enthrallingly clear that Hamlet's tragedy is that he is the paralysed individual conscience in a world of realpolitik.

Until October 13. Box office: 01789 403403.

fields.headline: One-match home ban for Lazio
fields.trailText: Lazio have escaped with a one-match ban from their home ground after their fans' racist behaviour at last Sunday's Rome derby.
fields.body:
The Italian champions Lazio have escaped with a one-match ban from their home ground for their fans' racist behaviour at last Sunday's Rome derby. The club were also fined 60m lire (£19,000), an Italian league spokeswoman said.

Lazio fans booed Roma's black players, the Brazilians Cafu and Aldair and the French-born defender Jonathan Zebina, whenever they had the ball in the 2-2 draw. They also held up a banner carrying the words "Black squad, Jewish home end".

The club have been fined many times for the racist behaviour of their fans, a hard core of whom are believed to have links with far-right political groups.

Lazio, third in Serie A and trailing seven points behind the leaders Roma, said they would appeal against the decision because of their efforts to prevent the displaying of the banners and punish those responsible.

The club chairman Sergio Cragnotti said he was "more embittered" by the league penalty than he was when he saw the banners. "I will battle to demonstrate to everyone that Lazio is not a team followed by racist fans," he said.

Roma were also fined 20m lire (£6,400) because fans threw bottles on the field.

Meanwhile, Lazio's Argentine midfielder Juan Sebastian Veron appears close to a transfer to Real Madrid. His agent Giuseppe Petrelli told reporters yesterday that the top Spanish club had made a "huge offer" to Lazio for the 26-year-old's services, an offer nearly double the 54bn lire (£17m) that Lazio paid Parma for Veron two years ago.

Along with Cragnotti, Veron testified yesterday in a court case in which he is charged with fraudulently obtaining an Italian passport to circumvent league limits on non-European players.

Veron denies any wrongdoing but said the controversy was beginning to weigh on him. Cragnotti said the Argentine's future "depends on the psychological state of the player".

England face France in the semi-final of the Uefa Under-16 championship at Newcastle this evening (kick-off 6.30pm), hoping to reach the final of the tournament for the first time.

Victory over Germany on penalties carried England into the last four and prompted Sven-Goran Eriksson to salute the team's "great mental strength". Croatia play Spain in the other semi-final at Middlesbrough and the top three sides will qualify for next year's world under-17 tournament in Trinidad and Tobago.

webTitle: Protecting children from the web of deceit

fields.headline: Protecting children from the web of deceit
fields.standfirst: The internet opens up  huge opportunities for children. But it also provides paedophiles with new routes to abuse. Time to educate the educators in the use of the web so children can be protected, says  John Carr
fields.trailText: The internet opens up huge opportunities for children. But it also provides paedophiles with new routes to abuse. Time to educate the educators in the use of the web so children can be protected, says John Carr.
fields.body:
Almost by definition children who are being looked after in institutional settings, or are in some other kind of temporary or long-term care away from the family home, are very likely to be needy children. Those who have responsibility for these children have a heavier duty of care, both morally and legally.

That duty extends not only to ensuring that the children are properly and safely looked after but also to ensuring that, as far as is humanly possible, the children can share in and benefit from as many of the advantages of modern society as their peers are likely to enjoy.

These days this means that we must address the issue of access to the new technologies - in particular, the internet, which is now becoming so pervasive both in the educational system and elsewhere.

The internet is becoming integrated in all sorts of ways in how we learn, live, work and play. It offers society and us as individuals huge opportunities. The great majority of kids love it and they are taking to it like the proverbial ducks to water. We have to make sure that the looked-after children we are responsible for are not missing out.

But sadly, as we all now know, the internet has also become a means by which sexual predators and others try to make contact with new victims - and this concerns not just children but also other vulnerable groups.

It is hard to quantify the risk or the probability that a child in your care might come into contact with an online paedophile intent on harming them. But, as the depressingly frequent number of court cases is now showing, indisputably they are active on the internet. And they seem to have an uncanny knack of identifying vulnerable children, in chat rooms, as in real life.

And it's not just chat rooms which can be a source of danger to children on the internet - the world wide web, email, news groups, and some of the other nooks and crannies can also hold threats, as well as opportunities. We have to know about them all.

A big problem, however, is that the great majority of professional childcare staff completed their training in pre-internet days. Many are now working for often impoverished organisations which don't have the funds to ensure that everyone they are responsible for can get access to the new technologies.

There's a wealth of information about protecting children out on the web - NCH children's charity, for example, has several pages of internet safety advice on its website. But not everyone feels comfortable about using the internet as a research or training tool, nor does everyone have the necessary search skills. Moreover, this virtual information, while useful, is not a substitute for proper professional training. Social workers need to be helped to develop awareness about how the internet works, how children use it - and how children can therefore come to grief. It should be integrated into their qualifying and post-qualifying training in the future.

The children's charities, the Association of Directors of Social Services and other groups who work with children are currently developing a proposal to address these questions. But the solutions will require a substantial input from government.

There are ways of making the internet safer children, but often these require advice and guidance from knowledgeable and confident adults. Developing such a cadre within the caring professions has to be a major policy objective. Otherwise an already dire digital divide and risks to looked-after children are set to worsen - and probably quite rapidly.

 John Carr is the associate director, children and technology unit, of the National Children's Bureau.

fields.headline: Governing London: the basics
fields.trailText: • London is run by 32 borough councils, the Corporation of London and the Greater London Authority (GLA), a strategic, regional tier of government.
fields.body:
 London is run by 32 borough councils, the Corporation of London and the Greater London Authority (GLA), a strategic, regional tier of government.

 The GLA was set up in 2000 to take on London-wide responsibility for policing, the fire service, planning, regeneration and transport.

 The mayor is not technically responsible for directly delivering very much. His powers are strategic, setting plans, targets and budgets and appointing people to implement them.

 The boroughs still run most of the services Londoners use on a day-to-day basis. They also retain important local powers over planning, transport and regeneration.

 The London assembly also forms an integral part of the GLA set up. The 25-strong body's main power is to block the mayor's budget on a two-thirds majority.

fields.headline: No 16. Ipswich Town
fields.trailText: What makes you so different?
fields.body:
What makes you so different?

Town at the moment are the symbol of what all clubs from outside the big cities who can't afford to spend comedy money on players strive for. All fans dream of their club being up their at the top of the league slugging it out with the big boys - which is what we are doing. The "well done"s have come from Swindon to Torquay, from Hartlepool to Bristol to even Bolton recently. We're everyone's favourite other team.

The high point

High points recently are quite numerous. Wins at Leeds, Liverpool, Everton, Middlesbrough and West Ham were all very welcome. Obviously Wembley last year was great as was the 1-1 draw with Manchester United in the first home game of the season. We had come into the Premiership being told we were rubbish and going down, that we were going to lose 8-0 every week (people employed to write about football actually wrote that) so a performance where we came close to beating the champions was particularly heartening.

The low point

The play-offs are the obvious choices, as were the two end-of-season games where had results had gone the other way elsewhere we would have been automatically promoted. The lowest point in the last five years, play-offs and ends of seasons aside, was a 3-0 loss at Charlton when we were so bad that a 2-0 defeat at home to Stockport a few days later was widely seen as an improvement.

What's going on at the moment?

Everything is rosy with Town everywhere. In Europe, new sponsorship deal worth up to £7m, manager's signed a new deal, FA Youth Cup semi-final, new stand virtually finished, new other stand being built over the summer, no debts, no need to sell players. The world is a lovely place.

Last fixture

Lost to Charlton, but were unlucky.

Next fixture

Manchester City. Ought to win really, oughtn't we? Should send them down.

Sore point

I can't think of anything really at the moment. Heard one bloke complain that two reserve games were 3pm midweek kick-offs.

The manager

George Burley is a Portman Road hero. He is now seen as taking on the mantle from Bobby Robson and Sir Alf Ramsey. With a Ramsey statue already up and Robson one on its way, Burley is currently seen as the next man to be immortalised in whatever it is they make statues out of.

The chairman

David Sheepshanks has developed a reputation as being careful with money, but not stingy, a difficult trick to pull off. His partnership with George Burley is seen as integral to Town's success up to now and it continuing. Burley runs the team on the pitch, Sheepshanks the team off it: they seem to be doing a pretty good job of it, don't they?

Rivals

Well, it always has been Norwich, but that is in doubt with things going so well for us and so badly for them. We also don't like Bolton after they attempted to turn the play-off at Portman Road last season into a bout of no-holds-barred fighting and then implausibly suggested afterwards we'd bribed the ref. If we had, we'd have asked for the money back.

Previously, Sheffield United and particularly Jan-Aage Fjortoft irked Town fans after some particularly underhand treatment of Suffolk's favourite Argentinian Mauricio Taricco.

Kit

The new kits are fine, but not the best. The classic Adidas 1978 Cup final kit was the greatest as was the white and black away alternative. We've had one or two bad ones. The one with a red strip from the mid-eighties was a bit naff while the "dipped in bleach" look from 1995 was gruesome. Away kits have been in purple and green in the past. It doesn't get much worse.

Most ridiculous piece of merchandise

Well, it's not an official piece of merchandise, but someone sent me a URL of a website selling Ipswich dogcoats the other day.

Mascot

We've got two, both horses who walk on their hind legs. There's Bluey and Crazee, although neither are particularly. There was controversy a few years back when the Old Bluey was sacked in favour of a rather effete new model, My Little Bluey as he became known. The old one was a fearsome punk rock beast with a blue mohican who was apparently sacked as he scared children. Plenty of opportunities for fanzine editors to use Old Bluey Turns to Gluey headlines. Ah, another one. Fans revolted and there were even Bring Back the Old Bluey gigs in town.

Players rated

At the moment the biggest heroes are Marcus Stewart and Hermann Hreidarsson. Both have had fabulous seasons, but then everyone has. All-time heroes are Kevin Beattie and John Wark. Whenever a poll asks for the favourite Town player of all-time, one of these wins.

Player hated

Pretty obscure ones really. Amir Karic has been given a bit of a hard time since he arrived from Slovenia. However, he has played virtually all reserve football and has said he has found his first year here hard. Of all time three names always crop up: Chris O'Donnell, Glenn Pennyfather and Graham Harbey. You don't want to know about any of them.

From other sides? Robert Fleck was always an unpopular fellow in these parts. This year's great anti-hero, though, is Ian Harte. A startlingly theatrical dive followed by 70s-style continental rolling about with him holding the leg that definitely wasn't kicked as opposed to the one that might have been was followed by a red card issued to Marcus Stewart. There are few more serious crimes in Suffolk these days. Matt Holland had words the next time the two met for Ireland duty.

Portman Road

It's like a building site at the moment. It's changing. It did look quite dated with stands from the early 60s, early 70s and early 80s. The new South Stand has updated things a little and the new North (arrival next season) will continue the refurb.

What's the atmosphere like?

It's pretty noisy. In fact, we were measured as the noisiest Premiership crowd by noise experts (not thought to be Napalm Death).

What to do when you arrive

Buy a copy of our fanzine from the stall behind the North Stand. Most places are pretty friendly in Town, but you'll be best off at the Station or the Drum and Monkey (named after Peter Reid was seen smoking roll-ups in there). A quick tip on burger vans though, if you are worried when you see the initials BSE on one, that just means they operate out of Bury St Edmunds.

Any other fanzines of note?

No other fanzines these days. Dribble! I'm told they may return at some point.

fields.headline: Dear reader, I binned it
fields.standfirst:
Fay Weldon has defended the enduring appeal of the romantic novel. Howard Jacobson disagrees

What do you think about the appeal of romantic fiction? Have your say on the talkboards
fields.trailText: Fay Weldon has defended the enduring appeal of the romantic novel. Howard Jacobson disagrees
fields.body:
A romantic novelist of my acquaintance religiously sends me every new book she writes, always with a quasi-secret note implying that she knows I am a covert reader of romances and will not own up to it for fear of losing my reputation as an unforgiving critic.

On Tuesday's women's page, Fay Weldon dropped a similarly knowing billet-doux for the over-fastidious to pick up. The romantic novel is "dangerous", she said, citing Someone Like You by Romantic Novelist of the Year Cathy Kelly, because "it's the junk food of the literary appetite", meaning that we know we shouldn't indulge but cannot help ourselves. Could it be this, she asks, that explains our dismissiveness of the genre?

It's not easy denying a weakness. You end up sounding strident. And so the voluminous romances with their saccharine covers keep coming, like virgins thrown to quiet some insatiable beast. The truth is, however, that I would rather be thrown on a pyre of burning livestock than have to read a line of one of those 700-page blockbusters packaged, like porno, to promise not a single deviation from the formula.

Nothing is so grindingly difficult to read as calculated inanity. And I know no one who has ever read a novel proper who feels differently. Except, that is, Fay Weldon, who confesses to having sat up half the night with Someone Like You and enjoyed it.

Weldon is not a writer one would dream of calling romantic, so what's she up to? Mischief? Or just showing that she, too, in these populist times, is all for eschewing high-mindedness?

Upwards of 200m romantic novels are sold every year. And 200m readers cannot be wrong, can they? Myself, I would have thought recent history teaches us that 200m anythings - readers, marchers, viewers, voters - cannot be anything but wrong.

But I agree with Weldon that love's the thing, that love is what we sometimes feel we have been put on earth to do. No reading beats reading about love. Anna Karenina, Jane Eyre, The Golden Bowl - twisted and upsetting love stories, but love is twisted and upsetting. And here's my quarrel with the romantic novel: by ironing out the twists, it makes a eunuch of desire. And where's romance without desire? It's not because I insist on high seriousness that I would like to see those 200m volumes trashed; it's because, by the very nature of their ambition - to keep love simple - they are never romantic enough.

Call me a softie but my eye still waters when I read Emma contemplating "the exquisite delight" of her future as Mrs Knightley. "Serious she was, very serious, in her thankfulness and in her resolutions; and yet there was no preventing a laugh, sometimes in the very midst of them." The seriousness not without a certain submissiveness, the laugh not without a certain spite, and the whole thing touching because all we know of the woman, her quickness and kindness, her impulsiveness and condescension (her eroticism is taken for granted), finds fulfilment in this finally awakened passion. What could be more romantic? She has hit upon the man of her dreams who just happens to be the man who's been there for her all along! Be still my beating heart.

So what of Hannah, Cathy Kelly's heroine? "She leaned over and kissed David firmly on the mouth. In an instant, his arms were around her and he was kissing her back furiously. He tasted wonderful ... Hannah felt herself melt in response." No need to labour the point.

But I have no desire to submit poor Kelly to a contest with Jane Austen. Austen isn't literature because she uses better or harder words; she becomes literature, becomes romantic literature if you like, by making her characters alive in love as in all their other endeavours, beings who think and judge, speak and laugh, and when they do melt, feel to their hearts the degree of their disintegration.

The other minor drawback of the romantic novel, Weldon says, is its refusal to countenance comedy. "No jokes, please, no irony. This is not, repeat not, the literature of alienation." Free the romantic novel from the bleak obligations of alienation and it can claim to address us where we are warm and at home? Poppycock. Whatever cannot make room for a joke has nothing to do with warm life.

This is another way in which romantic fiction resembles pornography. Neither can afford to allow mirth to break their trance. But at least pornography has the decency to make you feel bad. No shame, though, seems to be attached to the torpor induced by romantic fiction. You see women doing it in public places, on tubes and aeroplanes and buses, jiggling their feet and going blind, but otherwise not working, according to Weldon, the way you have to work at literature. These are the twin fallacies - that literature is graft and that torpor doesn't take its toll.

"There was something so masterful about him," Hannah remembers, "it gave her a frisson of erotic excitement to think about being in bed with him. Imagine how utterly in control he'd be then, that hard golden body driving into hers, naked skin on skin." Tell me you don't have to work yourself half to death to make a single detail of that come alive. Or feel romantic.

webTitle: Nasa anger grows over space tourist

fields.headline: Nasa anger grows over space tourist
fields.standfirst:
Special report: space exploration
Gallery: Dennis Tito's first holiday snaps
fields.trailText: History's first paid space tourist Dennis Tito got his trip to orbit in the "wrong way" and his Russian hosts may end up having to pay for it, the chief of America's National Aeronautics and Space Administration has said.
fields.body:
History's first paid space tourist Dennis Tito got his trip to orbit in the "wrong way" and his Russian hosts may end up having to pay for it, the chief of America's National Aeronautics and Space Administration has said.

Russian space officials, however, deny they had agreed to reimburse the United States for costs related to millionaire Dennis Tito's pioneering space adventure.

"There is no agreement" on such a reimbursement, said Russian Space Agency spokesman Sergei Gorbunov, adding that the agency was "in the dark" about the matter. Russian officials have dismissed US objections to Tito's trip as political in nature and see it as a precedent for making up for post-Soviet shortfalls in funding.

Nasa administrator Daniel Goldin told a House subcommittee that Dennis Tito, a California tycoon who ignored the objections of Nasa and paid Russia $20m to fly him to the space station, has caused anxiety among space workers who oversee the mission's safety.

"The current situation has put an incredible stress on the men and women of Nasa," Goldin told the committee. "Mr. Tito does not realise the effort of thousands of people, in the United States and Russia, who are working to protect his safety and the safety of everyone else."

Comments from Mr Tito, spending his fourth day aboard the international space station today, are guaranteed to annoy Nasa further.

Wearing grey trousers and a blue t-shirt used by Russian cosmonauts, Tito told reporters he had already visited the US sector of the station despite Nasa's insistence that he be escorted when venturing into it.

"I ended up seeing the American segment probably within an hour of arriving at the station," the 60-year-old California millionaire said.

US crew members James Voss and Susan Helms, he said, had ''gone out of their way to show me around, to give me some safety drills. They have done a great job.''

"One does not have to be superhuman to adapt to space,'' he added. "It's very do-able. It turned out it's very comfortable. I feel great. I have no feeling of space sickness. My face is a little puffy as are those of my crew members, because usually the adaptation causes the blood to go to your head from the rest of your body."

He described the flight as "everything and well beyond what I would have expected. Unfortunately, it's very expensive at this point, but there are others who can afford this and I would like to encourage it. That's what I hope to accomplish.''

He was launched over the weekend with two Russian crewmates aboard a Soyuz spacecraft and boarded the International Space Station on Monday for a six-day stay.

Russia had accepted $20m to fly Tito to the Mir space station, but switched him to the international space station after the Mir was junked and dumped into the ocean.

Nasa and other partners in the space station objected to Tito's plans, claiming that the Californian was not properly trained and that the station was not ready for amateur space trippers.

Nasa also objected to Russia selling tourist trips without the agreement of the other space station partners. An agreement was finally reached, but Goldin said Wednesday it may be costly for the Russians.

"In our agreement that we worked out with the Russians we will do an assessment and... get a reimbursement, I want to assure you," said Goldin.

Considering lost research time, extra safety measures and other expenses forced on Nasa, a congressman suggested the cost could be more than the $20m that Tito paid. Goldin said he would "reserve judgment" on the amount, but promised to report it to the committee.

The Nasa chief praised another rich Californian yearning to fly in space - Oscar-winning movie director James Cameron - for deciding to delay his trip until the space station is ready for tourists.

In what he called a "contrast" with Tito, Goldin said Cameron was "an American patriot who understood how to do this".

Cameron, who won the Academy Award for best director in 1997 for the film Titanic, approached him six months ago and asked about going into space, said Goldin, but was told the station program wasn't yet accepting tourists.

Goldin quoted Cameron as saying: "I am going to wait until the partners work things out and then go at an appropriate time and I'll even train." Goldin said Cameron understood "what is the right way and the wrong way to do things."

Nasa does not oppose trips by non-professional astronauts when the station is ready, he said.

"We think there is a place for researchers, educators, artists and other people to go into space," he said.

webTitle: Not enough professorships to go round

fields.headline: Not enough professorships to go round
fields.trailText: For the thousands of scholars who would like to be addressed as professor, there are a strictly limited number of chairs - and even fewer if you're a woman.
fields.body:
Chairs bring out the beast in academics. For the world off-campus, the word "professor" conjures up a mild and otherworldly individual, frequently paired with "absentminded". Anyone in a university knows different.

All the competitive urges that drive researchers to be first in their fields and get their names on those all-important journal publications come into play when a professorship is within their grasp. Basically, there aren't enough to go round. For the thousands of scholars who would like to be addressed as professor, there are a strictly limited number of chairs. Nobody knows quite how many - it's not a figure the funding council or the Higher Education Statistics Agency collect.

For funding purposes, "professor" is not a category - he or she could be paid almost anything or even nothing at all. It is up to each university to appoint as many or as few professors as it sees fit, and on whatever basis it wishes.

On the one hand, this has led to the suspicion that some new universities were being rather free with professorial posts and - this really annoys career academics - handing out "visiting professorships" to prominent local businessmen. On the other hand, strict rationing at Oxford and Cambridge led to considerable discontent. Researchers and scholars, used to being treated with a certain amount of deference for their standing in the discipline, despite being only senior lecturers or readers, are not pleased to encounter condescension when they go to conferences abroad. Everyone who's anyone is a professor abroad.

At Oxford, the university decided to create 162 "titular" professors, who got the title without the money. Cambridge opted to give extra money to senior lecturers, but created no more professorial titles.

The Oxbridge spats threw into relief the disturbing absence of women professors, something that was then taken up at a national level by the Bett inquiry into academic pay and conditions. Only 8.5% of professors are women, and only 2% of female academics are professors.

Gillian Evans, a redoubtable medieval historian at Cambridge, conducted a long campaign, to the fury of many of her colleagues, over the issue of how professors were appointed. She lost her case, which went to the High Court, but the university did move to make its procedures more transparent.

The lack of women professors, it became clear during the Bett inquiry, was a symptom of the unequal treatment women receive in the higher education sector when it comes to pay and promotion. An appalled David Blunkett made it clear in his 1999 funding letter to the sector that this was a priority. The vice-chancellors responded by setting up an equal opportunities office and ten institutions piloted an advisory service to improve policies and procedures.

The 59 women professors of nursing are unique in British higher education in that they are paid more on average than their male counterparts. A big pay gaps exists in almost all subjects, and at every grade, for lecturers and researchers.

Topping the list is anatomy and physiology, with an £8,000 difference in male and female professors' pay, closely followed by veterinary science, with a £7,000 gap.

Research by the lecturers' union Natfhe also revealed that, among permanent staff, there were no women professors anywhere in the UK in civil engineering, "other technologies" or central computing, and less than five in the entire country in almost half of the other subjects listed - including even such comparatively "women-friendly" subjects as catering, librarianship and continuing education.
