webTitle: Concern over crime may be misplaced

fields.headline: Concern over crime may be misplaced
fields.trailText: You are more likely to die from pollution or car crashes than as a result of homicide and the UK police's enforcement of the law is virtually a lottery, according to new socio-legal research.
fields.body:
You are far more likely to die from pollution or car crashes than as a result of homicide and the UK police's enforcement of the law is virtually a lottery, according to new socio-legal research due to be published at the end of summer from Ulster University.

Professor Paddy Hillyard and his colleagues are coming to the end of a three-year, £92,000 study into crime in England and Wales. They aim to produce an atlas offering comparitive information on the levels of harm suffered by people around the country and the work of individual police departments.

"Because of the autonomy of chiefs of police, we found huge variablity in the way the law is enforced. The statistics are not done, but we are finding 15%-20% differences in forces' use of their powers, for example in terms of stop and search," said Professor Hillyard.

Moreover, the research suggests that public concern and government spending on crime might be misplaced. Professor Hillyard said pollution was a key danger that kills many more people than crime. But while national crime statistics are compiled every year, there is no such programme for pollution.

Even if the reporting of crime receives more money than other social ills, Professor Hillyard and his colleagues have still had to contend with statistical problems. Each local authority gathers its own statistics, a procedure that leads to huge variations in quality.

Particularly, the Ulster team found crimes were being under-reported by some forces. Stop and search figures are a particular problem. But the researchers maintain that the new atlas will be the first authorative and compartive study of crime and social risk for the UK.

Even with the new crime atlas, the UK will be a long way behind the US in offering public information on levels of danger. At various American websites, individuals can see exactly what levels of crime have been experienced in their street.

To see a US crime map, visit: http://www.apbnews.com/resourcecenter/datacenter/index.html

fields.headline: Emeritus professors pay a price
fields.trailText: The success of Britain's emeritus professors is putting paid to the view that an academic's best work is over by 30. But retiring professors also have to take a severe pay cut and lose the use of basic facilities.
fields.body:
The late flowering of Britain's emeritus professors is putting paid to the traditional view that an academic's best work is finished by 30. But they have to pay a price: retiring professors have to take a severe pay cut and lose the use of basic facilities.

Five years after he retired in 1992, Alan Battersby, emeritus professor of organic chemistry at Cambridge University, won the prestigious Robert Alonzo Welch award, given in the United States for research in chemistry that benefits mankind.

"There is no doubt that I was far more able to concentrate on research once the load of administration was taken off of me. I could spend every day on it," he said.

With a team of five postdoctoral researchers, Professor Battersby detailed how organisms develop simple structures which are then combined to form the complex vitamin, B12. The process is akin to looking at a cathedral, and mentally working backwards to understand how simple bricks and mortar made the whole building.

Far from being the end of his career, retirement saw the beginning of some of his best work. "It was perfect, I was able to finish one of my major projects," he said.

Professor Battersby's experience is not unique. Other academics have discovered that, released from their administrative duties, they can get on with the work they have been wanting to do for years.

Emeritus professor of energy studies at Cardiff University, Brian Brinkworth recently completed a research assessment exercise. He realised that he had published 15 journal articles since he retired in 1996 - a significant increase on the pace he maintained pre-retirement.

But it has not been a fairy tale for everyone concerned. "My wife does ask about what happened to all that talk of retiring," he said.

It is not surprising that the young and the old do the most, according to Professor Brinkworth. They are the only people liberated from administration.

He remembers that towards the end of his career, "I was beginning to feel there was a lethal layer of administration between me and my work."

But maybe young academics have the advantage: they do not know what is impossible, and there is a resulting originality in their work.

This year's Reith lecturer, Professor Tom Kirkwood from Newcastle University, agrees that the issue is not that retired people are more creative, but rather that senior academics are overburdened.

"I have discussed with colleagues before whether there shouldn't be a more even distribution of the administrative drains across the age range, so people don't get hit so hard by it later on," he said.

But Professor Kirkwood believes that some retired academics are more original than their younger competitors. Young people can be more conservative, wanting a safe job, while older researchers feel they have already earned their spurs and can afford to take risks.

However, whatever the case may be, retiring academics certainly have to take their chances: in general, an academic's pension will be half what their salary was. Civil servants receive a pension worth around two thirds of their salary. There is widespread indignation about that inequality.

But then, people do not become academics for the money. The more fundamental loss is the use of facilities and research money. With departmental offices and budgets already overstretched, it is hard to justify expenditure on retired hangers on.

For his work, Professor Battersby had to make private applications and appeal to industry. Professor Brinkworth has been moved to a small office and has no budget. Neither complains. Well, not bitterly anyway.

Professor Battersby's website

fields.headline: MBA students are getting responsible
fields.trailText: A strategy game to encourage business students to be more socially responsible has been developed by the London Business School.
fields.body:
A strategy game to encourage business students to be more socially responsible has been developed by the London Business School.

Faced with the problems of a fictitious Eastern European pharmaceutical company "Chusco", the class has to work out how to deal with closing a local factory and the effects on all stakeholders.

Academics at the school worked with Accenture - formerly Anderson Consulting - to teach the need for businesses to engage with the rest of society in a positive way. The theory is that participants in the game discover that companies can contribute significantly to society without losing pocket.

Improving customer services, motivating staff, improving efficiency and reducing levels of waste and environmental pollution are all seen as ways of achieving this goal. Participants presumably discover whether or not life is really that simple after qualifying.

This game was first created as a way of preparing the staff of the Prince of Wales International Business Leaders' Forum for promoting responsible business practices around the world.

The University of North Carolina piloted the game last week (April 20th) - since they received good feedback they will be using it in August with their new MBA students.

Others who have played the game include consultants from the UKÕs Industrial Society and those attending the Business for Social Responsibility Conference in New York.

Vernon Ellis, International Chairman of Accenture believes: "CHUSCO reflects and encourages a more sophisticated and substantial approach to corporate social responsibility in which a business can legitimately pursue its own enlightened self-interest while benefiting society at large. This is the approach to corporate responsibility which I believe has the most chance of succeeding over the long term."

This game was first created as a way of preparing the staff of the Prince of Wales International Business Leaders' Forum for promoting responsible business practices around the world. The University of North Carolina piloted the game last week (April 20th) - since they received good feedback they will be using it in August with their new MBA students. Others who have played the game include consultants from the UKÕs Industrial Society and those attending the Business for Social Responsibility Conference in New York. Vernon Ellis, International Chairman of Accenture believes: "CHUSCO reflects and encourages a more sophisticated and substantial approach to corporate social responsibility in which a business can legitimately pursue its own enlightened self-interest while benefiting society at large. This is the approach to corporate responsibility which I believe has the most chance of succeeding over the long term."

fields.headline: Lecturers not hired to teach
fields.trailText: It is one of the paradoxes of being a university lecturer that lecturing scarcely figures in your chances of getting a job.
fields.body:
It is one of the paradoxes of being a university lecturer that lecturing scarcely figures in your chances of getting a job. Appointments are made almost entirely upon activity and quality as a researcher. There is a tension here which runs right through the system: subsequent promotion prospects and status within the profession rest ultimately upon academic publications, not on achievements as a teacher. A higher education staff made up of employees who are neither hired on the basis of teaching capability nor given much incentive to develop it surely gives some pause for thought.

The sector is now policed by the Quality Assurance Agency, but its Teaching Quality Assessments amount to no more than creating trails of documentation relating to students and their courses, rather than having anything to do with what is actually delivered in the classroom.

It should follow that most people who are fluent in and enthusiastic about their subject should be able to communicate it successfully to others. But this is not necessarily the case and there is very little formal teacher training built into the system of apprenticeship which nurtures future university staff. Experience as a tutor or demonstrator may be picked up over the course of a postgraduate career or during the period of post-doctoral fellowship now necessary to provide the bridge between studentship and lectureship. In addition, all universities require new recruits to attend a two-day course on teaching and learning methods before letting them loose on a class. But all this is scarcely adequate preparation for waking up one October morning to find 150 faces staring at you in a lecture hall.

In my case, nothing in my previous experience had prepared me for the small group tutorial class, which is the normal adjunct to lectures in most university courses. Standing up and delivering in front of a large class or engaging with individuals in one-to-one supervisions both impose their own demands and require their own skills, but incorporating 10 or 15 students into a group discussion which is going to be constructive and rewarding for all is, to my mind, the most exacting of teaching exercises. Such groups are inevitably comprised of students of varying backgrounds, qualities and levels of commitment. Increasingly, they will be composed of both a broad age range, as the number of mature students increases every year, and also a wide spectrum of educational experience, as the proportion of those from overseas (on Erasmus programmes or American exchange schemes, for example) grows. Finding a level which includes, but also stretches, and creating an environment which challenges, but also encourages participation, are skills which take most of us time to acquire.

Would I have become a university lecturer if I had known back then what I know now? Yes, probably, as I believe that academic research and the training of minds, young or old, both make extremely important contributions to our society. But as the son of two university lecturers, my expectations of the profession were based on the life as it was a generation ago, much of which has now gone for good.

Student numbers have increased progressively in recent years, creating both more teaching and more of the administration that necessarily goes with it. At the same time, the pressure to produce research grows ever more intense in a world overshadowed by the Research Assessment Exercise. A recent candidate for a temporary post in my university quite reasonably asked at the end of the interview what the relative balance of the work load was, to which the Professor replied, without hesitation: "Fifty percent research, 50% teaching, and 50% administration".

Meanwhile, salaries have been progressively undermined in real terms over the last 30 years, so that younger lecturers in particular are not really paid enough to live on, especially in the south of England. My own PhD supervisor advised me long ago that if I was serious about going into this business I needed a partner with a well paid job. Without this it becomes necessary to seek paid work outside the university sector - consultancy, paid reviewing, media work - in order to make ends meet, but this consumes time which should really be spent in improving those tutorials or getting on with the next article in a refereed journal. To an extent it has always been thus. Of course, one never expected to earn anything like one's contemporaries, though it is perhaps a tad sobering to find oneself paid the same as their secretaries.

This is no more than one dimension of a wider context in which demands increase while the resources to meet them dwindle: people leave and are not replaced; research budgets are slashed; departments are "rationalised". It comes as a bit of a shock to find oneself working in what feels like a sinking ship, and the knowledge that there are many people in far worse boats does not altogether assuage the sadness one feels for what this impoverished environment says about the values in today's Britain.

 Adam Fox lectures in social history at Edinburgh University.

fields.headline: No flies on lady flycatchers
fields.trailText: Female flycatchers have conned males from another species of bird to help look after the youngsters.
fields.body:
Female flycatchers have conned males from another species of bird to help look after the youngsters.

Normally mating between two different species results in sterile offspring, such as mules, the union of a horse and a donkey. The study, published in Nature, has shown that in the Czech Republic female collared flycatchers have taken to mating with male pied flycatchers.

The females are able to produce relatively fertile male hybrids, and fertile, pure collared flycatcher babies as, when the male pied flycatcher is not looking, the females mate with male collared flycatchers. The pied stepfather helps raise the fledglings, most of which are not his.

fields.headline: Plants glow to Mars
fields.trailText: Scientists have engineered plants to glow blue on the red planet.
fields.body:
Scientists have engineered plants to glow blue on the red planet.

A team headed by Rob Ferl, from the University of Florida, have created mustard plants (Arabidopsis) capable of communicating with scientists by splicing genes from jellyfish into their cells, which produce an iridescent blue protein. The plants fluoresce when they are stressed; different versions of the genetically engineered plants signal different problems, be it water deprivation, heat intolerance or a reaction to heavy metals.

In 2007, Arabidopsis seeds will be planted in Martian soil and grown inside a mini-greenhouse on the landing vehicle. The long-term goal is to terraform Mars by using plants to reduce the carbon dioxide and produce oxygen to help make the planet habitable for humans.

webTitle: Looking back at the old Caral

fields.headline: Looking back at the old Caral
fields.trailText: The oldest city in the Americas has been dated using reeds.
fields.body:
The oldest city in the Americas has been dated using reeds.

The ancient Peruvian site of Caral was built in 2627BC at the same time as the pyramids, according to the journal Scientist. The date is highly accurate as it was derived from radiocarbon dating bags made from reeds.

The reeds only lived in the wild for a year; workers transported stones in these reed bags before placing them, rocks and all, inside the structures' retaining walls.

fields.headline: Lotus revolution
fields.standfirst: Research into self-cleaning leaves has spawned a new generation of 'smart' building materials and coatings, writes  Peter Forbes
fields.trailText: Research into self-cleaning leaves has spawned a new generation of 'smart' building materials and coatings, writes Peter Forbes
fields.body:
Our notions of clean and dirty are very traditional. Smooth surfaces are easy to keep clean and rough surfaces with lots of crevices and interstices harbour dirt. Right? In an important way, we now know that this is wrong. Nature abounds in self-cleaning surfaces and they achieve this by being bumpy. Most people will have noticed a globule of water sitting on a leaf, glistening like mercury. Lupins show the effect well. If you have ever noticed this you were a hair's-breadth away from making a major scientific discovery. Because self-cleaning plants employ a mechanism that can be mimicked in paints and other surface coatings. The phenomenon is called the Lotus Effect.

The great sacred lotus (Nelumbo nucifera) is the prince of all self-cleaning plants. And although the mechanism by which it does this has only recently been discovered, the plant has been revered for millennia as a symbol of purity: it is sacred to Hinduism and to several other Asian religions, especially Buddhism. Its leaves never seem to get dirty unless interfered with by human beings, by spraying detergents on them for instance. Any dirt that attaches during dry spells is carried off by rainwater. How does it work? By a combination of chemical repulsion and a bumpy surface. The highly waxy corrugated surface of the leaf does not allow a water drop to wet and cling to it - there is no flat area to cling to, so the drop rolls off carrying the dirt which has a greater attraction for the surface tension of the water than it does for the leaf.

The microstructure of the leaves that allows this phenomenon to occur was observed in the course of an exhaustive electron micrographic study of plant structures by Wilhelm Barthlott, a biologist at the University of Bonn. This was the kind of fundamental research that usually seems hopelessly obscure to the layperson. What possible use could it be?

But the surface of the lotus leaf is bobbly like the uncut pile of a carpet. Thanks to the wax, water never gets further than sitting on top of the bobbles, wetting any dirt that it comes into contact with. Barthlott's first work was published as far back as 1976. Development work on possible applications began in 1997, and Barthlott himself was involved in the technical development and was awarded the Philip Morris Research Award in 1999.

The first application, an exterior silicone coating for houses, Lotusan, was introduced by ISPO Gmbh in March 1999. In October of that year, Erlus AG introduced Lotus Effect roof tiles. Many companies in Germany are working on Lotus Effect applications, including BASF. The big prize is a self-cleaning car. Given the bobbly nature of the Lotus surface there may have to be a tradeoff between appearance and practicality. Perhaps car owners will always want their highly polished enamel surfaces even if they need a lot of maintenance, but then again a satin effect with microbobbles might do the trick.

When self-cleaning exterior paint will arrive in this country is anyone's guess but self-cleaning glass is already with us. Pilkington - one of the UK's few world class manufacturing companies - has introduced ActivTM glass which uses a very fine layer of two coatings, one hydrophilic and the other photocatalytic, to enable rainwater to keep the glass clean. Intriguingly, ActivTM glass is almost a mirror image of Lotus Effect paint. Lotus Effect coatings are bumpy and hydrophobic, ActivTM glass smooth and hydrophilic. The glass works by preventing droplet formation: rain "sheets" on the surface and carries away any dirt. The photocatalytic layer is needed to oxidise organic matter such as bird droppings which otherwise would be impervious to the rainwater. The glass is being trialed in Ireland, Austria and the US and will reach the British market by the end of the year. Of course, like non-stick frying pans, the glass is only as good as its coating; if it is damaged the effect is lost.

ActivTM glass and Lotus Effect paint are two examples of the burgeoning trend towards "smart" building materials. The phrase "smart buildings" usually conjures up an image of a wired-up computer-controlled house in which all the services can be activated by computer or a remote control, but this other kind of smartness, eliminating maintenance in the materials themselves is likely to be just as important.

There is an almost Zen-like satisfaction to be gained from the idea of making buildings incorruptible by the usual agents of decay. Traditional building materials such as brick and stone always weathered well but the use of reinforced concrete and all kinds of synthetic cladding in the 20th century led to a catastrophic deterioration in weathering properties. But now, our coatings technology is catching up and today's new building no longer has to be tomorrow's rust-streaked eyesore.

fields.headline: Too many savers, no saviours
fields.standfirst:
In Japan's incredible shrinking world the bargains are abundant but the shoppers scarce

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The Honda salesman was offering the deal of a century, but Yayoi Iwaki was not buying. The price of the new car had been knocked down so far it was cheaper than the same model second-hand. He was even throwing in a free minidisc player, airbags and anti-lock brakes.
fields.body:
The Honda salesman was offering the deal of a century, but Yayoi Iwaki was not buying. The price of the new car had been knocked down so far it was cheaper than the same model second-hand. He was even throwing in a free minidisc player, airbags and anti-lock brakes.

There was no catch. She knew he was desperate for a sale. That much was obvious from the fact that he had called at the client's house three times in less than a week to give gifts to the children - and to sweeten the deal.

"It's a great offer, but it would be a mistake to buy now," the 34-year-old suburban housewife said. "No matter how cheap it is at the moment, the price will be even lower in 12 months."

Mrs Iwaki is the Japanese government's worst nightmare. A diligent saver, cautious consumer and avowed pessimist, she is an unwitting agent of the country's declared enemy: deflation.

Over the past 10 years, she has gone from spending money like there was no tomorrow to squirreling it away like there was no today. Where she once thought nothing of splashing out on an Hermès bag for £600 in Tokyo's upmarket Ginza shopping district, she now thinks twice about buying bargain clothes at the local discount shop.

Disbelieving government promises about the security of the pension and healthcare systems, she is hoarding money. She does not trust banks or stockbrokers either so she stashes the family savings - thousands of pounds worth - under the tatami flooring of her house.

Economic Wonderland

Such behaviour might be laughed off as eccentric in Britain, which has known only rising prices for decades. But in Japan, the first developed country since the 1930s to be gripped by deflation in peacetime, Mrs Ezaki's actions are eminently sensible and extremely worrying.

Japan is in a disorienting economic Wonderland. Like Alice after nibbling the "eat me" cake, the country grew miraculously for most of the postwar period. During the peak of the bubble economy in the late 1980s, Tokyo's imperial palace, which is about the same size as Hyde Park, was valued at the same price as the state of California. Japan was worth four times more than the entire United States.

Since 1989, Japan has been shrinking as if it had glugged the entire contents of Alice's "drink me" bottle. Stock prices and land values have fallen by two-thirds from their peaks. According to former economics minister Taro Aso, 1,300 trillion yen (£7.6 trillion) has been wiped off of Japanese assets over the past 10 years - equivalent to almost 10 times the annual output of the British economy.

Put simply, Japan is worth less - a staggering lot less - than 10 years ago and every day, the value of its land, citizens, companies and products contracts a little more. Personal assets have nosedived. The Ezakis are among the millions of Japanese families who have seen the value of their home fall by more than a third in five years.

Wages are shrinking. Spending is down. Last week, the government reported that consumer prices fell by a record 0.5% in the 12 months to March 31. This met the definition of deflation, which is two consecutive years of decline.

No one is sure what comes next because no one has been here before. Even with the depression of the 1930s, the United States did not suffer such a sharp rise and protracted fall. Opinion is split about whether Japan's deflation is good - like an overweight person slimming - or represents the onset of a terrifying downward spiral. Economists are watching Japan with the same horrified curiosity as a doctor observing a new pathogen.

In this incredible shrinking nation, housewives such as Mrs Iwaki - controllers of the family budget in Japan - have to rely on instinct because previous rules do not apply. Deflation creates a looking-glass world in which common sense turns upside-down, inside-out and the wrong way round. It is also reflects the dark conviction that things can only get worse.

How else to explain the rise to power last week of Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, on a promise of two years of recession, unemployment and bankruptcy? Defying conventional political logic, his pledge to inflict pain has earned him a record support ratings of 86%, whereas his predecessor, Yoshiro Mori, scored 6% for suggesting that good times were just around the corner.

How else to explain why the Bank of Japan is unable to encourage borrowing even though it almost gives cash away? The central bank's zero interest rate policy attracts few takers for loans.

In the looking-glass world of deflation, nothing ventured is something gained. If you expect prices to fall rather than rise, procrastination becomes a virtue. By stashing her cash under the tatami, Mrs Iwaki effectively earned a deflation-adjusted return of 0.5% on the family's nest egg last year -much better than stock market punters, who lost 35% on the Nikkei index.

But Japan is beginning to realise that the "bubble" was not merely a case of wind that can be cleared by with a deflationary belch. In the 1980s, it was monetary steroids, not hot air that pumped up prices. Their growth has created a tumour of bad loans and decayed assets.

In this view, deflation is a symptom of disease, not a cure. The fear is that it could spiral out of control, feeding on itself like a cancer, unless huge and painful surgery is carried out by the government.

The attempts of the past 10 years to deal gently with the problem clearly have not worked. Instead the country has had to run faster and faster to stand still. Despite running up the world's biggest public debt, of 130% of gross national product, government stimulus spending has only enabled Japan to create growth of just over 1% a year. Corporations have been repaying ¥20 trillion more than they borrow each year, but they are barely making a dent in their debts because their property is worth less and the fall in prices is hurting their profits. Banks have written off ¥54 trillion, but the amount of non-performing loans has increased because assets are deteriorating even faster.

Sense of proportion

Mrs Iwaki is no economist, but she sees the same reflection in the looking glass and realises that drastic measures are necessary. In 1995, the Iwakis' two-bedroom "mansion" cost them ¥58m. Last year, their neighbour sold up for ¥38m. She knows that much of the money she is hoarding might one day have to be used to clear the family's loss on the house. Until then, they are trapped in negative equity.

"My husband and I often talk about what we'd do if it wasn't for this debt. A new car, a bigger house, another child... But it can't be helped. Until we shake off this debt, we're stuck."

For her, coping with deflation means accepting that things have to get worse to get better. Like Alice, she sees the solution to her problems in terms of restoring a sense of proportion to a confused world.

"It may sound as if I have an inferiority complex, but it feels as if Japan is not worth what it was. That's not necessarily a bad thing. My hope is that our children will have different expectations, that they will value things differently. We have to teach them that price isn't everything."

Opinion is split about whether Japan's deflation is good - like an overweight person slimming - or represents the onset of a terrifying downward spiral. Economists are watching Japan with the same horrified curiosity as a doctor observing a new pathogen. In this incredible shrinking nation, housewives such as Mrs Iwaki - controllers of the family budget in Japan - have to rely on instinct because previous rules do not apply. Deflation creates a looking-glass world in which common sense turns upside-down, inside-out and the wrong way round. It is also reflects the dark conviction that things can only get worse. How else to explain the rise to power last week of Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, on a promise of two years of recession, unemployment and bankruptcy? Defying conventional political logic, his pledge to inflict pain has earned him a record support ratings of 86%, whereas his predecessor, Yoshiro Mori, scored 6% for suggesting that good times were just around the corner. How else to explain why the Bank of Japan is unable to encourage borrowing even though it almost gives cash away? The central bank's zero interest rate policy attracts few takers for loans. In the looking-glass world of deflation, nothing ventured is something gained. If you expect prices to fall rather than rise, procrastination becomes a virtue. By stashing her cash under the tatami, Mrs Iwaki effectively earned a deflation-adjusted return of 0.5% on the family's nest egg last year -much better than stock market punters, who lost 35% on the Nikkei index. But Japan is beginning to realise that the "bubble" was not merely a case of wind that can be cleared by with a deflationary belch. In the 1980s, it was monetary steroids, not hot air that pumped up prices. Their growth has created a tumour of bad loans and decayed assets. In this view, deflation is a symptom of disease, not a cure. The fear is that it could spiral out of control, feeding on itself like a cancer, unless huge and painful surgery is carried out by the government. The attempts of the past 10 years to deal gently with the problem clearly have not worked. Instead the country has had to run faster and faster to stand still. Despite running up the world's biggest public debt, of 130% of gross national product, government stimulus spending has only enabled Japan to create growth of just over 1% a year. Corporations have been repaying ¥20 trillion more than they borrow each year, but they are barely making a dent in their debts because their property is worth less and the fall in prices is hurting their profits. Banks have written off ¥54 trillion, but the amount of non-performing loans has increased because assets are deteriorating even faster. Sense of proportion Mrs Iwaki is no economist, but she sees the same reflection in the looking glass and realises that drastic measures are necessary. In 1995, the Iwakis' two-bedroom "mansion" cost them ¥58m. Last year, their neighbour sold up for ¥38m. She knows that much of the money she is hoarding might one day have to be used to clear the family's loss on the house. Until then, they are trapped in negative equity. "My husband and I often talk about what we'd do if it wasn't for this debt. A new car, a bigger house, another child... But it can't be helped. Until we shake off this debt, we're stuck." For her, coping with deflation means accepting that things have to get worse to get better. Like Alice, she sees the solution to her problems in terms of restoring a sense of proportion to a confused world. "It may sound as if I have an inferiority complex, but it feels as if Japan is not worth what it was. That's not necessarily a bad thing. My hope is that our children will have different expectations, that they will value things differently. We have to teach them that price isn't everything."

fields.headline: As cool as the cosmos
fields.standfirst: People expect meteorites to land in a blaze of heat, but they are in fact icy cold, says  Duncan Steel
fields.trailText: People expect meteorites to land in a blaze of heat, but they are in fact icy cold, says  Duncan Steel
fields.body:
Recently a woman walking her dog in York heard a whiz and a bang, and then spotted a smoking hole in the ground. Assuming it was a meteorite impact, the police cordoned off the area and a curator from the York Museum was called in to dig up the supposed cosmic rock.

However, it was obvious, even from the sparse initial report, that this was not a visitor from space. Meteorites are cold when they land, and generally remain intact on the surface. It proved to be an exploding underground power cable.

The chance of an extraterrestrial rock reaching the ground depends critically on its dimensions, different things happening in distinct size regimes. Every year the Earth accumulates about 40,000 tons of cosmic detritus, mostly as billions of tiny flecks ranging in size from sand grains to peas. Travelling at typically 20 miles per second, these are heated and then evaporated by friction with the upper atmosphere, and in their death throes they appear to us as meteors, or shooting stars.

Smaller particles - less than a tenth of a millimetre in size - decelerate without being destroyed. This is possible because their relatively high surface areas enable them to lose their energy by radiating it away, whereas larger bodies cannot do this quickly enough, and so are melted and vaporised. The small grains slow to a halt, and then gradually fall from altitudes of some tens of miles until they reach the Earth's surface. Such minute dust particles are termed micrometeorites.

This drop from altitude can take a surprisingly long time: years, in the case of the tiniest interplanetary dust. Flying research jets in the stratosphere, Nasa scientists have collected samples by employing sticky plates that project from the wings. Another way such cosmic dust has been gathered for analysis is by melting and sieving large volumes of snow and ice in the Antarctic and Greenland, where it has accumulated over millennia.

Actually, there are micrometeorites all around. In a typical house, about one in a thousand dust particles on the mantlepiece may be of extraterrestrial origin , depending of course on how often it is cleaned, and how polluted your neighbourhood might be. A good repository of metallic micrometeorites is the gutter on your roof, because they are gradually swept down by the rain, and their high density makes them more likely to remain in the sludge that builds up there.

Much larger meteoroids - say between the size of an orange and a basketball - produce extremely bright meteors, called fireballs. These can light up the night sky, producing daylight conditions for a second or two. Then the object is gone, its atoms added to the atmosphere. In a small fraction of cases, though, it is possible that some solid lump may reach the ground intact. That is what we call a meteorite.

For it to survive in this way, the incoming lump needs to be lucky. First, it is more likely to escape destruc tion if it is strong, made of metal or solid rock as opposed to a loose, fragile structure.

Next, there is a greater chance of avoiding vaporisation if the object has an entry speed close to the minimum possible: that is about seven miles per second, identical with the Earth's escape velocity.

Finally, the survival probability of a meteoroid is much enhanced if it happens to arrive at a fairly oblique angle. Under that circumstance it decelerates slowly, over a prolonged period rather than just a couple of seconds. The same applies to re-entering space probes such as the Shuttle, or the Apollo lunar capsules. Come in at too steep an angle and you burn up; but if the approach is too shallow, you bounce off the top of the atmosphere like a flat stone skimmed across a pond.

Meteorites, then, are rare. But what is their temperature? Arriving on a suitable trajectory, they are slowed from their phenomenal cosmic velocity to essentially zero in 10 or 20 seconds. As they do so, their outer layers are intensely heated, and ablate away. The melted exterior of a meteorite, called a fusion crust, is obvious. But the interior is unchanged. During its fiery plunge there is simply not enough time for the heat to be conducted into its centre.

As a result, when meteorites reach the ground their interiors are still at the temperature they had in space, around minus 30C. If the Earth had no atmosphere, that would be the planet's temperature at our distance from the Sun. It is only the natural greenhouse effect that gives our home its pleasing ambient temperature. (The scientific debate over global warming concerns whether manmade emissions are enhancing the greenhouse effect by a small but significant proportion.)

One can think of the effect of atmospheric entry on a meteorite as being similar to throw ing a deep-frozen joint of meat into a fire. Five minutes later the outside may be charred, but the middle is still icy.

Just-fallen meteorites, then, are cold. It is not unusual for an observed fall, someone reaching the object within a few minutes, to produce a report of ice on its exterior. Water vapour in the air first condenses on to the meteorite and then freezes.

Do meteorites make craters? The multitude of scars on the Moon is obvious, but there are also about 250 recognised impact craters on the Earth. The best known is Meteor Crater in Arizona. That massive hole, 1,300 yards across, was formed 49,000 years ago when a nickel-iron projectile about 40 yards in size slammed into the ground, releasing on impact energy equivalent to about 20 megatons of TNT. The atmosphere does not brake such a body by much.

Little boulders from space are different, though. The atmosphere slows them down in one way or another. They are either totally destroyed, or else brought to a halt. An orange-sized rock would be decelerated by the time it reaches a height of 20 miles. From there it gets to the ground under free fall: it plummets at the same rate as an object dropped from a plane, reaching a terminal velocity of about 200mph.

Compared to the hypervelocity impact of a very large body like an asteroid or a comet, that is a low speed. As a result, small meteorites do not form craters. If one were to land on soft ground, it might bury itself a bit, but that is all. In 1947 a large metallic body broke up on atmospheric entry over the east of Siberia, and many of the fragments weighing over a ton managed to penetrate the earth by a metre or so. The 60-ton meteorite that landed in Namibia in prehistoric times - the largest known intact meteorite - sits on the surface, although it did cause a bit of a dent.

If you should hear a loud bang and find a smoking crater, suspect that someone has been playing with dynamite. To excavate an impact crater a projectile from space has got to be large, and would make a hole far too big for the police to cordon off. Mind you, they would have other things to worry about.

 Duncan Steel works at the University of Salford. His most recent book is Target Earth, published by Time Life

webTitle: Mark Lawson on art as extreme sport

fields.headline: No pain no gain
fields.standfirst: If you want to be taken seriously in the arts these days you've got to do things on an epic scale - witness Peter Hall's Tantalus, or the RSC's programme of Shakespeare's history plays. Mark Lawson explains how doing art became an extreme sport
fields.trailText: If you want to be taken seriously in the arts these days you've got to do things on an epic scale - witness Peter Hall's Tantalus, or the RSC's programme of Shakespeare's history plays. Mark Lawson explains how doing art became an extreme sport.
fields.body:
There was widespread surprise when the novelist Irvine Welsh took part in the recent London marathon. This incredulity was partly specific to Welsh - whose life and work have been associated with heroic ingestion of narcotics - but reflected a more general sense that artistry and athleticism rarely go together.

Biography and anecdote show that creators and consumers of culture have often been the sick-note kids at school, tactical sniffles permitting them to be in the library with a book while others slither in the mud outside. In later life, we continue to assume this simple opposition between book in study and studs in boots. There were astonished articles when it emerged that an England cricket captain, Mike Atherton, read serious modern novels. Culture is seen as the soft option.

Troubled by this perception in the masculine culture of the US, 20th-century American novelists created literary machismo: Ernest Hemingway hunted, Norman Mailer boxed, John Irving wrestles. And now, in England, the off-games squad are levelling the playing field through the growth of endurance culture and marathon art, led by the macho theatre-going offered to those who attempt in one go - when three or more evenings are staged on a single day - the current RSC productions of Tantalus and Shakespeare's history cycle.

Packing my bag on the morning of the British premiere of Tantalus in Salford earlier this year, I realised - as I arranged the six bottles of Lucozade Sport and the high-protein snacks of chicken pasta salad beside my notebook - that high art had now merged with extreme sports.

The 12-hour, single-day span of Sir Peter and his son Edward Hall's variations on classic Greek drama was a genuine test of physical and mental endurance: theatre with the Krypton Factor. During the final two works of the 10-play sequence - 10 hours after entering the theatre - I was swigging my isotonic drinks between scenes like a marathon runner or a salesman driving through the night. Among theatre critics, there is now a tacit moral division between the one-dayers and the three-nighters with regard to Tantalus. Those in the first group are the Everest men.

When chancellors of the exchequer impose a fiscal squeeze, they tend to rebuff objections with the line: "If it isn't hurting, it isn't working." This seems to be becoming the creed of British theatre. If you still have blood in your buttocks at the final curtain, it isn't a true theatrical experience. Because the Salford opening of Tantalus happened to coincide with a media scare over deep vein thrombosis (DVT) on long-haul flights, there were tangible fears among the audience that these all-day plays might actually prove fatal. In the intervals, you could see playgoers doing the leg-flexing exercises which newspapers advised as a long-haul flyers' precaution against DVT.

Apart from the psychological drive to deny the idea that art is for wimps, there are two reasons for the rise of these dramatic marathons. The first is visibility. In the last two decades, theatre has undeniably become obscured by screens. Cinema and television - both now increasingly multi-screen - have severely reduced the status, audiences and newspaper space once given to live plays. So-called Event Theatre - epic productions which make audiences work for their works of art - is one obvious solution to this problem. If the RSC had staged one Greek classic or a couple of Shakespeare's Henrys, they would be lucky to get the bottom columns of the arts pages.

Long-haul art also has the effect of turning one of theatre's weaknesses into a strength. A serious problem for drama companies is that play-going is the most inconvenient of all the art forms. It requires far more travel, time and expenditure than any of its cultural rivals. One response to this has been to offer the easy evening: there's a current vogue for 90-minute plays (Art and Mouth To Mouth, for example), often staged in theatres where drinks can be taken to your seat. But there's a risk with these productions of the night out feeling flimsy and expensive for the trouble and money you put in to be there. Events such as Tantalus and the history plays stretch the inconvenience to the point where there is a feeling of heroism and virtue in having survived them.

Rather as it makes more sense in terms of cost-per-mile and travel hassle to fly to New York than to Paris from London, these shows say that, if theatre-going is hard, let's make it satisfyingly, exhilaratingly tough.

But, ultimately, the major motive is to make art a form of sport. In game-obsessed America, several novelists - Mailer again, Don De Lillo, John Updike - have published single novels or fiction sequences amounting to 1,200 pages or more. There is a clear artistic impulse in these works - the drive to summarise a huge nation in a single work - but it's also about the bookworm's riposte to the jocks at school. Reading one of those volumes in bed becomes physical effort. Literature is like going to the gym. You turn out the light with your arms aching. Tipping empty cans of energy drinks into a bin as you leave the theatre is part of the same fight. The sick-note kids hit back.

fields.headline: Lord Morris of Castle Morris
fields.standfirst: A poet, critic and professor of literature, he became Labour's deputy chief whip and education spokesman in the Lords
fields.trailText: A poet, critic and professor of literature, he became Labour's deputy chief whip and education spokesman in the Lords.
fields.body:
Lord Morris of Castle Morris, who has died aged 70 from leukaemia, was a leading specialist in English literature, for 10 years professor of English literature at Sheffield University, having made his name as a critic and editor of English plays of the Elizabethan, Jacobean and Caroline periods. He was also a fine poet, whose Collected Poems, his fourth volume, was published only recently.

His personality concealed a certain puckishness. When he became a life peer in 1990, he expanded his name - to distinguish it from an earlier Lord Morris - by adding "of Castle Morris", a grand-sounding hamlet with a ruin on a side road to Haverstockwest, on the main road between Fishguard and St Davids. Although he was then principal of St David's University College, Lampeter, he had no connection with Castle Morris - "I live in the middle of the Peak District, in Derbyshire," he cheerfully admitted.

His death is a loss to Wales, with which he identified, despite working away from it most of his life. Because he was Cardiff-born, his Welsh linguistic ability was limited. But he backed completely the effort to give the Welsh language full equality with English, while pleading for effective simultaneous translation in court cases.

Although he only became a peer at 59, he acclimatised "in about a week", justifying his appointment by pointing out "Manchester United football team isn't chosen by popular vote". He worked arduously for the Labour party, using his considerable administration skills as deputy chief whip under Lord (Ted) Graham from 1992 and doubling up as Labour's active main spokesman on education from 1994.

He lacked the trained politician's ability to debate extemporaneously or from notes. But his essayish speeches - more subtle and less pompous than those of Lord "Roy" Jenkins - were beautifully prepared and well-read, sprinkled with quotations from Shakespeare, Goldsmith, Juvenal and Alexander Pope. When Morris reminded the Tories of the saying "Whom God wishes to destroy, he first sends mad," he delivered it first in the original Latin. But in 1997, the ageist Blair incomers dismissed him, along with Lord Graham, as too old and too "Old Labour".

Curiously, his decade in the Lords overlapped with that of an old teacher. "In the year of our Lord 1939, I was Master Brian Morris, aged eight, a pupil in Marlborough Road elementary school, Cardiff. My form master was a brilliant young teacher from the Rhondda Valley called George Thomas, later to be known as the noble viscount, Lord Tonypandy. We boys were always perfectly able to distinguish right from wrong. If Mr Thomas said it was right, it was right: if he said it was wrong, we did not argue." From that school, where "fewer than 20% of us passed the 11-plus", Brian, who was one of them, went on to Cardiff High School, where he excelled in Latin.

After national service with the Welsh Regiment, he went to Worcester College, Oxford, where he read English. He was also a handy bantamweight boxer, but having fought for money at a fairground, he was not eligible to box for the university. He stayed on at Oxford as a tutor in Old and Middle English while doing his doctorate on John Cleveland, the Cavalier poet.

After serving a two-year fellowship at the Shakespeare Institute, in 1958, he went to Reading University, where he co-edited new editions of 16th- and 17th-century plays. At York University as a senior lecturer, he gave the first display of his Anglican social conscience, hunger-striking for seven days in protest against the spending of charity money on buildings rather than feeding the poor.

His major promotion came in 1971 when he began his decade as professor of English literature at Sheffield University, in succession to William Empson. From 1964 to 1986, he was general editor of the New Mermaid dramatists, and from 1974 to 1982 of the New Arden Shakespeare. He also edited the poems of Cleveland and the plays of John Ford, while using his acquired administrative skills on the board of the National Portrait Gallery.

These skills were fully tested when, in 1980, he was named principal of St David's University College, Lampeter, the smallest and most endangered part of the University of Wales. He fought off the Thatcherite squeeze on college finances, while simultaneously resisting cuts as chairman of the Museums and Galleries Commission. He also served on the council of the Prince of Wales Institute of Architecture, the council for national parks and the board of the British Library, as well as being a trustee of the National Portrait Gallery.

He began to find life at Lampeter somewhat constricting, displaying his frustration by naming to the college a Muslim divine with no knowledge of Welsh.

Although he dismissed the Houses of Parliament as "a huge, beautifully dying whale beached on the banks of the Thames," he undoubtedly saw it initially as a larger stage for his wide talents. It was his tragedy that the Blairites did not recognise those talents, and his illness deprived him of deploying them elsewhere.

He leaves a wife of 45 years, Sandra, a son and a daughter.

 Brian Robert Morris, Lord Morris of Castle Morris, university educator and politician, born December 4 1930; died April 30 2001

Although he was then principal of St David's University College, Lampeter, he had no connection with Castle Morris - "I live in the middle of the Peak District, in Derbyshire," he cheerfully admitted. His death is a loss to Wales, with which he identified, despite working away from it most of his life. Because he was Cardiff-born, his Welsh linguistic ability was limited. But he backed completely the effort to give the Welsh language full equality with English, while pleading for effective simultaneous translation in court cases. Although he only became a peer at 59, he acclimatised "in about a week", justifying his appointment by pointing out "Manchester United football team isn't chosen by popular vote". He worked arduously for the Labour party, using his considerable administration skills as deputy chief whip under Lord (Ted) Graham from 1992 and doubling up as Labour's active main spokesman on education from 1994. He lacked the trained politician's ability to debate extemporaneously or from notes. But his essayish speeches - more subtle and less pompous than those of Lord "Roy" Jenkins - were beautifully prepared and well-read, sprinkled with quotations from Shakespeare, Goldsmith, Juvenal and Alexander Pope. When Morris reminded the Tories of the saying "Whom God wishes to destroy, he first sends mad," he delivered it first in the original Latin. But in 1997, the ageist Blair incomers dismissed him, along with Lord Graham, as too old and too "Old Labour". Curiously, his decade in the Lords overlapped with that of an old teacher. "In the year of our Lord 1939, I was Master Brian Morris, aged eight, a pupil in Marlborough Road elementary school, Cardiff. My form master was a brilliant young teacher from the Rhondda Valley called George Thomas, later to be known as the noble viscount, Lord Tonypandy. We boys were always perfectly able to distinguish right from wrong. If Mr Thomas said it was right, it was right: if he said it was wrong, we did not argue." From that school, where "fewer than 20% of us passed the 11-plus", Brian, who was one of them, went on to Cardiff High School, where he excelled in Latin. After national service with the Welsh Regiment, he went to Worcester College, Oxford, where he read English. He was also a handy bantamweight boxer, but having fought for money at a fairground, he was not eligible to box for the university. He stayed on at Oxford as a tutor in Old and Middle English while doing his doctorate on John Cleveland, the Cavalier poet. After serving a two-year fellowship at the Shakespeare Institute, in 1958, he went to Reading University, where he co-edited new editions of 16th- and 17th-century plays. At York University as a senior lecturer, he gave the first display of his Anglican social conscience, hunger-striking for seven days in protest against the spending of charity money on buildings rather than feeding the poor. His major promotion came in 1971 when he began his decade as professor of English literature at Sheffield University, in succession to William Empson. From 1964 to 1986, he was general editor of the New Mermaid dramatists, and from 1974 to 1982 of the New Arden Shakespeare. He also edited the poems of Cleveland and the plays of John Ford, while using his acquired administrative skills on the board of the National Portrait Gallery. These skills were fully tested when, in 1980, he was named principal of St David's University College, Lampeter, the smallest and most endangered part of the University of Wales. He fought off the Thatcherite squeeze on college finances, while simultaneously resisting cuts as chairman of the Museums and Galleries Commission. He also served on the council of the Prince of Wales Institute of Architecture, the council for national parks and the board of the British Library, as well as being a trustee of the National Portrait Gallery. He began to find life at Lampeter somewhat constricting, displaying his frustration by naming to the college a Muslim divine with no knowledge of Welsh. Although he dismissed the Houses of Parliament as "a huge, beautifully dying whale beached on the banks of the Thames," he undoubtedly saw it initially as a larger stage for his wide talents. It was his tragedy that the Blairites did not recognise those talents, and his illness deprived him of deploying them elsewhere. He leaves a wife of 45 years, Sandra, a son and a daughter.  Brian Robert Morris, Lord Morris of Castle Morris, university educator and politician, born December 4 1930; died April 30 2001

fields.headline: Peter Maag
fields.standfirst: Swiss conductor who sought the spirit in the score
fields.trailText: The Swiss conductor Peter Maag, who has died aged 81, was as accomplished in the opera house as on the concert platform.
fields.body:
The Swiss conductor Peter Maag, who has died aged 81, was as accomplished in the opera house as on the concert platform. In an international career of distinction, he conducted in most of the world's major opera houses and was in charge of many of the greatest orchestras. A number of his recordings have stood the test of time. Even so, he did not quite achieve the fame that his talents deserved.

His first appearances in opera in Britain came in 1959, when he conducted The Magic Flute at Covent Garden and Le nozze di Figaro at Glyndebourne. And it was, indeed, with Mozart that he won his spurs, his interpretations combining natural grace and lyrical brio. But he was also accomplished in the Italian and French repertory, as he showed when he returned to conduct Faust at Covent Garden in 1977. Opera magazine reported that he "gave each and every bar its due, allowing the orchestra to unfold the gentle, familiar melodies, but he made the shaping of the work as a whole his primary consideration".

The following year, he returned to Covent Garden to conduct Meyerbeer's L'Africaine, with Placido Domingo in the role of Vasco da Gama. The production added to Maag's reputation as a conductor of the French repertory.

His recording of Verdi's Luisa Miller, with Montserrat Caballé in the title part, showed his skills in yet another area. His readings always preserved the verities and therefore avoided exaggerated effects.

His orchestral posts included stints with the orchestra of RAI (Italian radio), with the National Orchestra of Spain and latterly with the Berne Symphony Orchestra. Maag was a particular advocate of Mendelssohn, Dvorak and a number of 20th-century composers.

Born in St Gall, Switzerland, Maag studied theology and philosophy at the universities of Zurich, Basle and Geneva, and the piano with Alfred Cortot. From 1943-46 he was engaged at the Biel-Solothurn Theatre as a coach helping the music director there. After working as an assistant to Furtwängler and Ansermet, he became principal conductor at the Düsseldorf opera house (1952-55), then music director at Bonn (1955-59), the period when he began to attract international attention. At Bonn he encouraged the performance of neglected works such as the opera Genoveva by Schumann, another composer whom Maag championed. From 1964-68, he was music director at the Vienna Volksoper. His debut at the Metropolitan Opera, New York, came in 1972.

Thereafter he tended to concentrate his work in Italy, where he made his home, including appearances at La Scala, Milan. In consequence, he received the Toscanini Medal at Parma (1969), the Verdi Medal (1973) and the Toscanini "Presentation Baton" (1975).

Also in the 1970s, he took two years off to meditate in a Tibetan monastery. He later averred, "I was having too much success. Those two years spent meditating and praying in a small cell purified my soul."

In his last years he took charge of a workshop for young composers and conductors at Treviso, which he formed with his friend, Maurizio Jacobi.

His recording career was long and fruitful, beginning in the 1950s with a series of LPs with the Bamberg Symphony, followed by admired discs of Mozart and Mendelssohn with the LSO and the Suisse Romande Orchestra for Decca in the 1960s. In 1995, he ended his career in the studios with a much-admired set of the Beethoven symphonies with the Orchestra di Padova e del Veneto, for the Arts Music label. They evince the wisdom of accumulated experience in the classics.

Maag was twice married, and is survived by his second wife, Marika, a son from his first marriage and a daughter from his second.

 Peter Maag, conductor, born May 10 1919; died April 16 2001

fields.headline: Threatened by a herb
fields.standfirst: Researchers are trying to discredit St John's wort. They are funded by a pharmaceutical company
fields.trailText: Researchers are trying to discredit St John's wort. They are funded by a pharmaceutical company.
fields.body:
What a gullible lot depressed people are. In America they spend $400m a year on the anti-depressant herb St John's wort that has as much effect as a sugar pill. So says a study published in the prestigious Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) last month. A trial, involving 200 people who'd suffered from a "major depression" for at least four weeks, found the herb was no better than a placebo. Time magazine's follow up last week devoted two pages to the news, including an interview with a self-appointed "quack-buster" who declared that he wasn't surprised.

Several other things about the trial are not surprising. The researchers received "unrestricted funding" from the drug company Pfizer, who also manufacture the pre scription anti-depressant Zoloft, along with a "me-too" herbal product containing St John's wort. It is also the latest in a series of drug company sponsored drug trials that have raised doubts about efficacy or safety of St John's wort. The researcher advises people currently taking the herbal extract to consider one of the "two dozen prescription medications whose effectiveness has been proved".

Protecting the public from harmful or useless medicines is of course a laudable aim. But, quite apart from the fact that more than 20 other studies have found St John's wort to be beneficial for "mild to moderate" depression, the drug companies credentials in this field are not exactly impressive. For a start, as the recent South African court battles over patents and generic drugs for Aids illustrated, the companies are prepared to go to great lengths to protect their profits. The rising spending on St John's wort and other herbal remedies is certainly a threat. Even more pertinent is the growing concern, by both academic institutions and top medical journals, about the way drug companies are prepared to conceal or manipulate results that put their own products in an unfavourable light.

Last autumn JAMA announced that the results of a trial into the effectiveness of an immune boosting drug were incomplete, because the unnamed drug company involved were withholding them. The trial had showed the drug to be ineffective and the company wanted the results suppressed.

It was far from an isolated incident. Only last month the Lancet published a letter from a doctor claiming that the drug company Bayer, when asked for supplies of a certain drug so that he could run a trial on it, demanded he sign a letter promising not to reveal any results without their permission. The journal made this damning comment: "The efforts by the drug companies to suppress, spin and obfuscate findings that do not support their commercial purposes was first revealed to their full lethal extent during the thalidomide tragedy. [Since then]... the insidious tactics of the big pharma have changed very little."

What has changed is that many more researchers have drug company links. A study published last December found that only one of the top 10 medical schools in the US has clear regulations forbidding researchers from having a financial involvement in the companies they are supposedly impartially testing. Dr Ian Chalmers, director of the Cochrane Collaboration, an organisation dedicated to promoting evidence-based medicine, believes that secrecy has led to tens of thousands of unnecessary deaths because doctors were not alerted to the dangers.

The impartiality of drug-company funded research into herbal medicine must be called in to question. The problems created by herbal medicines are minuscule by comparison, even allowing for some under-reporting. The worst recent case of damage from a herbal product involved 30 people who developed cancer as a result of being prescribed a Chinese herb, in error, in Belgium.

Even if herbs can occasionally prove harmful, abuse of medicinal herbs (with the exception of marijuana) is unheard of. The same is not true of prescription drugs. A report out in April, but not covered at length in Time magazine, revealed that an estimated 4m Americans were abusing them - compare that with the official figure of 5m hard-core street addicts.

The pharmaceutical approach to medicine, for all its undoubted scientific brilliance and health benefits, is far from the final word in treatment. A study published last month found that 40% of Aids patients who are receiving the best pharmaceutical companies can offer - protease inhibitors - are also using a range of complementary medicines.

Instead of occasional bits of research aimed at damaging a competitor, what is needed is a serious and properly funded programme to discover how the obvious benefits of herbal and other complementary treatments can best be put to work. Only 40% of news stories about drug breakthroughs reveal the financial links between drug companies and the researchers involved. Perhaps the really gullible are those who don't take drug company claims with a big pinch of salt.

 Jerome Burne is editor of the newsletter Medicine Today. www.medicine-today.co.uk

webTitle: DNA inventor slams plans for database

fields.headline: DNA inventor slams plans for database
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The scientist who invented DNA fingerprinting, the genetic technique which has revolutionised the fight against crime, has condemned the government's plans to keep the DNA profiles of innocent people on its criminal database.
fields.body:
The scientist who invented DNA fingerprinting, the genetic technique which has revolutionised the fight against crime, has condemned the government's plans to keep the DNA profiles of innocent people on its criminal database.

In an interview with today's New Scientist magazine, Professor Sir Alec Jeffreys says it would be fairer for the police to take the DNA profiles of every Briton at birth than to mingle the fingerprints of the guilty with those of the innocent.

"I'm totally opposed," he said. "It's discriminating, inconsistent with privacy laws and an example of ad hoc sloppy thinking."

Prof Jeffreys, a researcher at the University of Leicester who announced the discovery of the genetic fingerprinting technique in 1985, said suspects who were cleared of any crime should have the right to remove their profiles from police databases.

The police have pooled more than a million DNA samples from convicted criminals at a store near Birmingham, with 3,000 more arriving each day. That number is due to rise to 3.5m within three years.

Most controversially, the criminal justice and police bill now going through parliament would allow the police to keep DNA samples from suspects who are later found to be innocent.

Other geneticists told New Scientist of their concerns. David Balding, of the University of Reading, said: "It goes against fundamental principles of justice. If you're acquitted and found not guilty, you shouldn't have to pay any kind of penalty, no matter how small."

The fears of scientists add to a chorus of dissent over the government's plans from civil liberties organisations.

Lady Helena Kennedy, chairwoman of the government's genetics watchdog, the human genetics commission, warned last month that the proposal would create a class of people who were permanently under suspicion, even though they had never been convicted of any wrongdoing.

"Being on a database of potential offenders which might be regularly trawled by the police means that... one is on a list of suspects and that surely very subtly alters the way in which the state sees, and we see, our fellow citizens," she said.

DNA profiling is based on the discovery of a set of regions of human chromosomes where the same DNA sequence is repeated. The number of times the sequence is repeated varies from person to person. By analysing the number of repeats in several sequences, forensic geneticists can come up with a short string of numbers which identifies an individual.

Forensic scientists check 10 sequences, reducing the chance of a mismatch to one in a billion - and, in theory, making it all but impossible that an innocent person's DNA from the database could be flagged up by a search.

However, the reality is different. Often the crime scene sample of DNA is of poor quality, and sometimes only three or four sequences are available, greatly increasing the chances of a mistake.

Defending the planned change, Ben Gunn, chief constable of Cambridgeshire police and the Association of Chief Police Officers' spokesman on forensic issues, said DNA profiling was the most significant forensic crimefighting advance since fingerprinting.

webTitle: Da doo Ron Ron, da doo Ron Ron...

fields.headline: Da doo Ron Ron, da doo Ron Ron...
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown lets returning train robber Ronnie Biggs in on what he's missed in dear old Blighty during the last 30-odd years
Photo gallery: the Ronnie Biggs story
fields.trailText: Derek Brown lets returning train robber Ronnie Biggs in on what he's missed in dear old Blighty during the last 30-odd years
fields.body:
Our guest today - or quite soon at any rate - is Ronald Arthur Biggs, Britain's senior villain. Let's have a big round for Ronnie.

In 1963, in an era when redistribution of wealth was still a popular notion, you decided to redistribute quite a lot of it in your own direction. The great train robbery made you a folk hero. It also made train driver Jack Mills very ill indeed, following the beating he got at the hands of your gang. In fact, he died not very long afterwards. But don't let's get maudlin - after all, you are an icon, as we now say.

In 1964, you got put away for 30 years. However, tiring of a career in the public sector mailbag industry, you went over the wall from Wandsworth nick only 15 months later.

You probably didn't have time to take in the Swinging Sixties. You never had the chance to appreciate the new world created by the likes of Mary Quant and Twiggy. After all, fashion probably wasn't your bag, any more than mailbags were your fashion.

As you fled these shores, Ronnie, Britain was undergoing a cathartic change. It wasn't just the music and the clothes - it was life itself. As the poet Larkin merrily put it:
Sexual intercourse began
In nineteen sixty-three...
Between the end of the Chatterley ban
And the Beatles' first LP.

So at least you'd started having it away before you had to go away (pause for laughter), but what you didn't get to experience was the flower-power thing, the summer of love , and the wretched song that started it all.

You didn't get to go through the heady excitement of the 1966 World Cup final. You missed the ferment of new ideas pouring out of our universities.

You didn't have to wrestle with decimalisaton a few years later - come to that, you probably still think in proper money. Bet you a tanner you're still worth a few bob, eh?

Dear old Blighty's changed a bit since your time, though sometimes you wouldn't think it to judge by the telly programmes. You might even recognise some familiar faces if you're allowed to go to the pictures.

But so much is different now, Ronnie. We've had six prime ministers since you legged it, you lucky devil.

We have a free market economy now, and privatised trains run for profit. Anyone can get a bit of the action... Ronnie? Ronnie? Where are you going, Ronnie?

fields.headline: The Tractor factor
fields.standfirst: Philip Ham on the nickname driving fans and players crazy
fields.trailText: Philip Ham on the nickname driving fans and players crazy.
fields.body:
I've recently purchased the new Massey Ferguson MF6200 and am finding it a real boon on the farm. I've been fair nipping between the clamps of sugarbeet in this little beastie and I can now get the cows housed and hosed down by 11.30! Marvellous!

Actually, that's not true at all, but the way the media have latched on to our self-given Tractor Boys sobriquet you wonder whether they really do think we all spend our lives up to our necks in silage or scooting about in Massey Ferguson's finest.

I don't want to drive a Jaguar 950 through any preconceptions, but we're not all farmers in this part of the world. Obviously some of us are, but by no means all of us.

The Tractor Boys (or Boyz to trendier mags) thing is a joke, a bit of a dig at the perceived superiority of certain clubs, some massive, some not, we've endured on the terraces over the years.

The whole thing appears to have started at Birmingham a couple of years back. Early on the Brummies were chanting something implying interference with sheep on our part (NB: Do people really think that Birmingham is an urban utopia?) and thinking this was the best thing since sliced bread. fields.headline: League ratify Chesterfield's nine-point penalty
fields.trailText: The Football League have ratified the nine-point penalty imposed on Chesterfield for financial irregularities.
fields.body:
The Football League have ratified the nine-point penalty imposed on Chesterfield for financial irregularities.

The decision means Chesterfield drop from second to third place in the Third Division. However, they are still almost certain to gain automatic promotion: they are currently on 77 points, three points clear of Hartlepool, and have a vastly superior goal difference.

Finally agreeing to the sanction, Football League chief executive David Burns insisted: "The board continues to believe that a nine-point deduction does not reflect the damage that Chesterfield Football Club have done to the integrity of the competition."

Burns said the League now plans a wide-ranging review of the "regulation" of their clubs, prompted by irregularities in striker Luke Beckett's transfer from Chester, which was one of two charges on which Chesterfield were found guilty.

Burns added: "From the outset, this has been an unhappy affair for all the involved parties. It is now time for us to draw a line under the matter, and after a short period of reflection, review the procedures that exist for the internal regulation of our clubs.

"It is our belief that we need to set in place a system that is impartial, independent and outwardly-transparent - and supporters and clubs can be confident that those who break the rules are dealt with in a just and appropriate manner.

"For example, without wanting to pre-empt our own review, I strongly believe that steps must be taken to prevent clubs fielding players for which they owe money to other clubs."

fields.headline: Poems from the longlist
fields.trailText: Here are more poems from the hot hundred that didn't make the cut. This competition had no rules. Poets could do anything within the160 character maximum of a text message. This meant that terse versers had to risk whether the judges would understand their shorthand.
fields.body:
Here are more poems from the hot hundred that didn't make the cut. This competition had no rules. Poets could do anything within the160 character maximum of a text message. This meant that terse versers had to risk whether the judges would understand their shorthand.

Ying
uncovered
I can still smell
my wet hair
even in the dark.

Eadstand
I look
at the clear
green
sky above.
Stars,
like daisies,
glinting all around.

Just like in Rome
where yi walk down streets
where the colessium
blinks at yi
in slow shutter speed,
here in Gorgie,
the fitba' stadium
does much the same.

Pleasuresunday
and the feel
of new jeans pulled up, crisp,
shop smelling new,
your waking smile,
with difficult to open eyes. All innocent.

Today
Your eyes are the blue
of the deep end of the pool
the world
has been put through the rinse cycle
and dries in the sun
and i am happy

Miaouw!
I've a habit
of making the end
of my poems
more important
than the start.
My inability
is always obvious.
It fills me
with a sadness blacker than death.

Two rivers
On London bridge
my phone rang.
You'd just got in,
going for a coffee
over the clyde.
Five hours ago
you'd said thanks love
when i brought you tea.

This is my Haiku
If you don't like it, fuck you!
It obeys the rules.
They phone you up your mum & dad.

Dad is Caribbean,
mam is a tyke,
do I sit on the fence?
Do I take sides?
Sing for Lara,
cheer for Gough,
chew on jerk chicken,
take scollops and
chips, I am me.

Burglary
I noticed/
mud on the stairs/
then/
a space/
where the plastic bags/
of christmas presents/
were./
Now i feel/
dirty/
and trodden on.

First light
dawn has never broken -
it melts the night
and pours the morning open.

Chips,99's&7ups,snoggingxthe c.
That was luv 1963.
Romancexemail,sexxtext,
luv aint much fun in 2001.

Haiku #1
she's not what she seems; she's summer 3 years ago and tuesday night dreams.

Come quickly
The bath is over-flowing.
The candles are burning down.
I have cut a peach in half.
Don't make me eat it alone

To my MP*
I put my cross*
in your box*
and I was right*
all along*
you were the wrong*
answer

Choosing
1 love me
2 hate me
3 miss me
4 need me
5 adore me
6 like me
7 feel me
8 wana hug me
9 wana kiss me
10 wana kill me
send ur best 3 answers

Sorry i stole & burned-out your car & found your phone & am texting myself on it

fields.headline: The message is the medium
fields.standfirst: Two of Britain's foremost poets, Peter Sansom and UA Fanthorpe, assess the creative output from your mobile phones in a competition that has inspired first-time and seasoned bards alike. Here are the poets' judgments and the winning entries
fields.trailText:
The Guardian's pioneering text poetry competition attracted nearly 7,500 entries from 4,700 mobile phones. A key part of the exercise, done with Consult Hyperion, was the interactive element. The entries were winnowed down to 100 and given to our judges, Justine Jordan, books editor of Guardian Unlimited, U A Fanthorpe and Peter Sansom. They chose a short list of seven, below, each of which was texted to all participating phones over seven days. Most winners, and entrants, had never written a poem before. This met the main aim - to turn text messaging into a creative force. Sorry for the glitches and thanks to everyone who joined in the fun.
Victor Keegan, editor, Online

The winners

Sheffield
Sun on maisonette windows

startling drivers

I drive on
Steve Kilgallon

no, i am not linda,
I hv not slept w/yr sis,

Gd luk w/viag.
Luv, yr wrong no. xxx

my face flashes

Carole Bromley

FIFTH

Watch dog
Watch me,

round your house of a body:

RUNNERS UP

Move
bed, u have seen some action,

Landlord, u may remove
every chip, scuff, stain: who knows
what reflections
old mirrors project in the dark
Melissa Terras

i w8 fr yr mesg the beep yr wrds of rude luv.
U mke me blush w

14: a txt msg pom.
his is r bunsn brnr bl%,

W/ac/dc going thru.
