Translation:
14: a text message poem
his eyes are bunsen burner blue,
his hair like iron filings
with ac/dc going through.
I sit by him in chemistry,
it splits my atoms
when he smiles at me

Peter Sansom's comments
It was a pleasure, not work at all, doing this, and easily the most enjoyable competition I've judged. It's partly because poems are an effort, usually, through sheer length and density, and in competitions - as in magazine editing, actually, the effort is rarely repaid. But you have to put the work in, because, as the saying is, a poem is only as good as its reader. The beauty of this job was that you could get the measure of the whole piece in one go, even if as with a surprising number of them you were far from exhausting the poem in one or two reads. This was true of even the shortest of the long shortlist: "They phone you up, your mum and dad." It didn't reach the final seven, but it's already a catchphrase in our house. What's more, it is postmodern (though admittedly it isn't bollocks), because of its self-referentiality, recasting (and therefore commenting on) a famous line of poetry while at the same time talking about mobiles, or at any rate about a generation independent but always because of the phone in shouting distance. Also, this poem made us laugh out loud.

Still, "They phone you up" didn't make the cut because it depends too much on the Larkin line it parodies. Others though not as short were just as concise and presented stories or traded insights or humour often with texture of language and rhythmical purpose (as we say in the trade). "Ying", for instance, another spoof we were sorry to let go, has the oriental or rather new age whiff of a manx haiku: 'uncovered, I can/ still smell my wet hair/even in the dark.'

As you might expect, a number of the entries were haikus. In Chinese, haikus are real poems because, so I'm told, neighbouring words alter each other's meanings, allowing the texts to open in the mind like paper flowers in a tumbler of water. Whereas in English, they tend to be short, up-their-own-arse poems made by grown men in brown cords walking up and down counting. I said as much once, the inspiration as it turned out for this: 'Peter Sansom says/Not to bother with haiku./Well, he can fuck off.'

Which is to say one of the joys of the competition was how much grainy real-life could be got into 160 characters, though there was room for delicate watercolour too. The most interesting aspect, and which may actually be quite radical, is how having to scroll down the screen makes the reading experience entirely linear, giving real suspense to each line break, making us attend to every word and to guess ahead before the new line comes up. You can't help glancing down the page in ordinary poems for clues, for orientation; but with a text poem you stay focussed as it were in the now of each arriving line.

This gives extra force, for instance, to punch lines, and indeed makes it seem an urgent business, reading a text poem, like the pools score teleprinter used to be, or how it was when Ezra Pound said poetry was news that stays news.

UA Fanthorpe's comments
There is a quality of jokiness about English poetry, and the Guardian's terse verse contest encouraged that. So did its text message format, which has affinities with the resourceful stratagems of the old telegram. I like a poem that starts "Pls, stop sendg msgs2ths". The reader is being tested, as with a crossword puzzle or a Shakespeare play.

Poetry has always enjoyed fiddling around with the shapes of words and numbers of words or number of syllables: haiku, cinquain, englyn, and so on, and I have to admit to writing a poem about a road sign, in road sign language, which consists partly of words with their vowels extracted and partly of shorthand versions of place names. So in a way, the newest thing about the Guardian's competition was not the text message style, but the precise number of characters available.

It was interesting to see how inventive the competitors were. Some wrote fairly normal poems (as far as style is concerned); some wrote with as much technical resourcefulness as possible. The results were disappointing in some ways, in that the subjects tended to be rather predictable - the usual subjects, in fact: love/sex predominated, along with "special moments".

I've recently been judging another (more familiar) poetry competition, where the range of subjects was infinitely more surprising. But it is, of course, difficult to get far with such a small word count; you have, on the whole, to be sure that the reader understands what you're writing about from the start. And limitation of form means that it's difficult to achieve very much complexity of feeling.

I was looking for wit and technical inventiveness in the more technologically adventurous poems, and for imagination, density and the magical quality of take-off in the others. On the whole, the less technical did better - partly because the more technical had struggles with layout, and characteristically became unstuck with the last line, which is always where a poem either works or doesn't.

There were some poems which I shall remember with delight, but which didn't achieve the Final Seven because there wasn't enough substance to them: I treasure particularly two.

"They phone you up, your mum and dad."

"Basildon: imagine a carpark."

It was surprising how many competitors used rhyme, I suspect as a substitute for imagery. The form allowed only exceptionally gifted writers to develop an image to any extent, whereas the inevitable brevity made it quite easy to make something of a rhyme, if not exactly a rhyme-scheme. I was moved and amazed at how much feeling could be introduced in so small a space: there was great tenderness, spirit, imagination in the best entries.

On the other hand, it was sad to see how some, faced with such a small canvas, squandered words when they could have used the possibilities more fruitfully.

fields.standfirst: Editor Philip Ham on why the fanzine has recently changed its name
fields.trailText: Those Were The Days began as a paper-based fanzine back in 1990. Town fans had seen the side collapse during the 80s from a side which won the Uefa Cup and regularly challenged at the top of the old First Division. We had been relegated and had suffered under John Duncan's management.
fields.body:
Those Were The Days began as a paper-based fanzine back in 1990. Town fans had seen the side collapse during the 80s from a side which won the Uefa Cup and regularly challenged at the top of the old First Division. We had been relegated and had suffered under John Duncan's management.

The current editors (myself, Gavin Wilding - web stuff and Dan Thomas - graphics) are the third incumbents. Since 1995 we have charted on paper and on the web the highs and lows of George Burley's reign at the top. Recently we switched to These Are The Days in tribute to the return of European football to Portman Road. And partly as the players had begun to complain about the name on national television.

The website can be found here: http://www.thesearethedays.co.uk and details of how to buy the fanzine can be found here: http://www.thesearethedays.co.uk/stall

fields.trailText: May 2: Underwear website Splendour.com is to sell its lingerie through Debenhams and Allders.
fields.body:
The underwear site, Splendour.com, is to sell its lingerie through Debenhams and Allders.

Globalfulfillment.com has scrapped its fulfilment operation - and axed 90 jobs - to concentrate solely on software services.

The defunct digital agency, Blueberry.net, has plunged MagicButton into liquidation.

A founder of Carlton's new media operations, Dominic Graveson, has joined the agency, Head New Media.

BT Openworld has linked up with Money Supermarket.

Richard Lord, the departing editor of Revolution, writes in his final column: "So long, farewell, auf wiedersehen, adieu" and thanks everyone - even his mum, who has been a regular feature of his column over the years. "It's been emotional," he concludes.

Virgin Group has overhauled Virgin.com, its gateway to the group's separate websites.

fields.headline: Anti-poverty organisations to receive £130m
fields.trailText: Voluntary organisations working on a range of community anti-poverty initiatives will receive £130m in funding to help them take control of their own affairs, the government announced today.
fields.body:
Voluntary organisations working on a range of community anti-poverty initiatives will receive £130m in funding to help them take control of their own affairs, the government announced today.

Ministers billed the announcement as "the next steps in the government's drive to boost the voluntary sector and transform the relationship between the state and voluntary action".

Seventeen areas in England will share in a £70m Children's Fund Local Network, designed to tackle poverty and disadvantaged children and young people by providing funding to local community-based projects (see table).

The network is part of the government's new children and young people's unit set up last year, a cross-departmental body accountable to the department of education and employment.

The community foundation network, a grant-making body with local branches has been charged with administering grants to local voluntary groups.

The money comes from the previously announced £450m children's fund.

A total of 88 of the most deprived areas of Britain will receive grants of at least £200,000 each over three years from a separate £50m "community chest" fund to support voluntary and community groups.

Other measures announced today also include the establishment of a £7.7m mentoring fund in which older members of the community are matched to young people and adults who are in need of support.

Chancellor Gordon Brown said it was not about providing a "cut-price alternative" to state funding. He said: "We are putting down funds to help voluntary organisations help themselves."

Home office minister Paul Boateng announced plans to shake up the way money is allocated to local voluntary groups.

He said this would make it easier for them to get funding by "cutting out unnecessary bureaucracy, simplifying the administration process, providing more training and support and increasing groups' independence and autonomy".

The plans are published in a consultation document Funding Community Groups.

The government measures also include £1.2m to transform the recruitment, retention and support of charity trustees with extra training, and to enable voluntary groups to work with the local media and raise awareness of volunteering.

A total of £1.7m has been set aside for a new database drawing together information and advice for community organisations which are accessible via the internet.

The measures also include a "one day off a year" scheme, in which employers allow their staff to carry out voluntary work in their local communities for one day.

fields.headline: Cordiant snaps up Bulletin
fields.trailText: 5pm: Global marketing group Cordiant Communications has acquired broadcast PR company Bulletin International, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The UK-based global marketing group, Cordiant Communications, has acquired broadcast PR company Bulletin International.

Cordiant has made an initial payment £2.9m for Bulletin, but may pay up to £8.5m depending on Bulletin's financial performance to December 2003.

Bulletin has headquarters in London and offices in Hong Kong, New York and Singapore and its clients include Rolls-Royce, BMW, Michelin, Motorola and Philips.

The agency promotes its clients through television and online media.

Bulletin will become part of Cordiant's Business Communications International (BCI) network and establishes a presence for the network in Hong Kong and Singapore.

The acquisition is part of Cordiant's plan to build its business in high growth marketing sectors, particularly business communications.

"The acquisition of Bulletin is an important strategic move to help BCI broaden its range of services," said Michael Bungey, the chief executive of Cordiant chief executive.

"Bulletin also represents an opportunity to strengthen BCI's existing operations in London and New York while adding a presence in Asia, one of the key development regions for the network."

webTitle: Unhappy medium: the life and trial of 'hellish Nell' (I)

fields.headline: Unhappy medium (I)
fields.standfirst: Hilary Mantel delves into the pitiful story of spiritualist Helen Duncan, the last woman to be tried under the 1735 Witchcraft Act,  in this exclusive online essay from the London Review of Books
fields.trailText: Hilary Mantel delves into the pitiful story of spiritualist Helen Duncan
fields.body:
Hellish Nell: Last of Britain's Witches by Malcolm Gaskill. Fourth Estate, 402 pp., £15.99, 5 April, 1 84115 109 2
Buy it at a discount from BOL

April 1944. Winston Churchill sent a memo to Herbert Morrison at the Home Office: Let me have a report on why the Witchcraft Act, 1735, was used in a modern Court of Justice. What was the cost of this trial to the State, observing that witnesses were brought from Portsmouth and maintained here in this crowded London, for a fortnight, and the Recorder kept busy with all this obsolete tomfoolery, to the detriment of necessary work in the Courts? The person tried and convicted at the war-damaged Old Bailey was a stout and ailing Scotswoman called Helen Duncan, whom few people loved and many exploited. She was not a witch in any popular sense of the word; she did not fly, wear a pointed hat or have congress with the devil, and neither she nor her followers imagined that she did. She was a witch only in the sense that she was convicted under an old statute, as a convenience to the court. If the attention-grabbing title can be excused, it is because the author has a strange and pitiful tale to tell.

Rumours of Churchill's indignation, and of his own spiritualist leanings, have been enough to make the case bob back into public consciousness every few years. As Malcolm Gaskill says, "we inherit ancestral tales reworked by each generation to make their truth powerful rather than precise, moral rather than empirical." Among the majority today, reverence for Churchill survives surprisingly intact; it is a folk-tale Churchill who intervenes in the case, incisive and on the side of the underdog. In fact, as Gaskill shows, Churchill took no further part in either vilifying or vindicating Helen Duncan. If he was superstitious, that made him like many soldiers and ex-soldiers. If, as a young man, he had consulted an astrologer, then he was a natural leader for a nation that employed state stargazers to track the forecasts of their Nazi counterparts.

Helen's trial lasted eight days, and ended with a jail sentence of ten months, which (less remission) she served in Holloway. Prosecuted psychics often elicited public sympathy, especially when the police were suspected of entrapment. Helen's tabloid image henceforth was as the 'St Joan of Spiritualism'. The charges against her arose from a police raid on a séance in Portsmouth, where informers were planted in the audience. Though Helen was a well-known medium who commanded a troop of followers, her deceptions on this occasion were no more florid, distasteful or ludicrous than the tricks she had been getting away with for years. Fortune-tellers were usually dealt with summarily under the Vagrancy Act of 1824: not hauled before judge and jury, flattered by the attentions of King's Counsel and the national press. So why was the silencing of Mrs Duncan considered so vital by the state?

Her partisans, and conspiracy theorists in general, looked back to 1941, when at an earlier séance in Portsmouth Helen had raised the spirit of a young sailor. In life, he had served in HMS Barham. News of his materialisation soon spread among the families in the port. This was a source of dismay to the Admiralty, who had not yet admitted that the warship had gone down. Malcolm Gaskill explores this legend, which is central to the strange life of Helen Duncan. There is a question-mark over how specific Helen's identification was, and whether its precision increased in the retelling. Did Helen actually name the ship, or did she extract the name from an anxious audience member, and produce an apparition to suit? Had there been some security leak which had brought her the knowledge by ordinary means? However it may be, it does seem that MI5 was involved in building the case against her, and it is clear that she was seen as a security risk - damaging to morale, at least. However she got her peculiar knowledge, it was best to lock her up and teach her a lesson.

Malcolm Gaskill has undertaken to tell the life-story of Helen Duncan, placing her in the context of her time and class. The book is also in a wider sense an enquiry into "how we know the things we know" and how what we can know or choose to know is circumscribed by our culture. As far as Helen and her trade is concerned, he will try for a position of observant neutrality: "I do not seek to exonerate her, any more than I am committed to a rationalist crusade against superstition." A Cambridge historian, he is generally a prosaic and stable guide through what Freud called "the black tide of mud of occultism". Sometimes his material tempts him into a tweedy sarcasm, and sometimes he strays into twopenny-coloured mode; the people who queued to see Helen's trial were "curious citizens, successors to the Londoners of Hogarth's day who had gathered there to follow the condemned to Tyburn, jeering and sharing the latest from the Grub Street presses". Anyone who explores the issue of the paranormal is vulnerable, both to accusations of crankiness and to a sort of self-disgust about the sensationalism involved; and it is hard to sift out an acceptable truth, given the human tendency to confabulate, the fallibility of memory, the wide scope for interpretation, and the prejudice which invests the whole subject. As a good historian should, he insists, he is going to try to vanish in the presence of his subject. He would not like to think that, like some spirit guide made of papier-mâché, he is now Helen's announcer, her mouthpiece, and that his dematerialisation amounts to crouching in the half-light behind a torn curtain on a rickety rail.

He writes very well about Helen's background and her upbringing in the small Scottish town of Callander. Like much else about her, the date of her birth is uncertain. She was the fourth of eight children in the family of a skilled man, a slate-worker and builder. The family were not very poor, but their circumstances were modest and their outlook austere. At the age of seven or so Helen began to report clairvoyant experiences, which her mother warned her not to speak about outside the family. It was a part of the country where folk belief in second sight, omens and ghosts had simply slid underground, and her mother's warning was perhaps designed to protect her less against scepticism than unhealthy interest. The name of Hellish Nell, however, had nothing to do with preternatural abilities: she got it because she was a noisy, boisterous tomboy.

But as she grew up, she developed what Gaskill describes as a "crippling diffidence, timidity and passivity, punctuated by sudden outbursts of hysterical rage". It was a passivity which allowed her to be strip-searched before her séances, tied to her chair, enveloped in sacks, sewn into shroud-like cocoons intended to prevent fraudulent limbs from emerging; which made her agree to swallow dye for test-séances, and allow her body cavities to be probed by doctors appointed by those who had an interest in proving that she was a cheat. One could argue, too, that it was this passivity which made her choose her trade in the first place, made her earn her living as the mouthpiece of dead people: travelling the roads of Britain, sustained by tea and endless cigarettes, her parasitic husband in tow, her paying public always fresh and expectant, the thought of her needy children ever in mind, and her heavy body always sicker, and apt to take on the sicknesses of other people. It is no wonder that the rage burst out from time to time, causing her to curse out loud, and lunge at sitters who upset her, and try to knock sceptics down with chairs. In the early 1930s, one witness described her as "by no means a magnetic personality . . . rather a repellent one that aroused one's critical faculties". There was nothing other-worldly about her coarse features and plain speech, and yet perhaps she was not so unattractive as the self-righteous and brutal busybodies who tried persistently to expose her. If there was money to be made from raising the dead, there was also a profit to be shown from proving the dead to be made of old newsprint and cheesecloth. With credulity on the one hand, bigotry on the other, and greed everywhere, the history of spiritualism shows humanity in an unedifying light.

The town where Helen grew up was a poor community, with low wages and high unemployment. The average age at which women married was 26, which attests to the difficulty of setting up a separate household; the choice for many men was between migration and emigration. When the Great War broke out, the boys queued down the street to join up. But Hellish Nell, 16-years-old, pregnant and disgraced, had already been banished to Dundee, and would seldom return to Callander. In Dundee she lived in a working-woman's hostel and worked in a jute mill. She applied for munitions work, but was found to have TB, and sent to a sanatorium. Discharged, she took a post as an auxiliary at Dundee Royal Infirmary, where the sights and sounds of the psychiatric wing worked on what was already, no doubt, a morbid imagination. Her baby was a girl, and would be the first of eight children. Helen's pregnancies were perilous, and some of her children had birth defects. She suffered from a complex of conditions which exacerbated each other: she was hypertensive and diabetic, had kidney damage, and suffered from pleurisy and abdominal pains, which cannot have been helped by her self-punishing habit of ingesting carpet tacks and cigarette ends; it was not just her audience who swallowed rubbish.

Her husband, Henry Duncan, was a Dundee boy who enlisted at 16. His very poor family had a history of hauntings, and Henry seems to have been superstitious, sensitive and intelligent. Later, he would become the theroretician, while Helen attended to the practical business of raising spooks. Most mediums were women, and the men - with revered exceptions like the great Victorian DD Home - were seedy after-thoughts with inferior talents. There was perhaps something degradingly feminine in the pursuit, in the helplessness, the physical indignity of being the plaything of the deceased; gifted men preferred to be impresarios, and manage their talented wives. Henry Duncan emerges from Gaskill's account as a manipulator and a liar, but his early life was sad beyond bearing. Invalided out of the Army with rheumatic fever, he would never regain good health. He met Helen through his sister, who was a workmate of hers, and they had no doubt that they were soul mates. They married in 1916, and their early years together were wretched, with one or other of them too sick to work, though Henry took on casual labouring where it was offered and Nell would turn her hand to anything. Henry started a furniture business which failed, seemingly not through his own fault; he had a heart attack, and Helen engaged herself to crippling work in the bleach-fields to feed them, at the same time taking in washing and mending, and organising the sale of stock to pay the creditors. In the end Henry became too ill to work, and spent his time reading spiritualist books; though Helen was widely known to be psychic, she had not yet embraced - if she ever did - the corpus of cult belief.

Spiritualism thrived on disaster, and on poverty. The comfort of 'proved survival' was superior to the airy assurances, given over the years by the orthodox churches, that the deficits of this life would be repaired in the next. For the working classes it had this advantage: it did not operate de haut en bas. A practising and proficient medium was likely to arise in any stratum of society, and if you lived in one of Britain's cities you were likely to find one a few streets away. Spiritualism was a neighbourly, engrossing business, offering a particular and home-grown comfort. It thrived in the Mechanics Institutes and the philanthropic and self-improvement societies of the industrial towns. The great war gave it impetus: all kinds of occult belief flourished, among the fighting forces and among civilians. In the trenches, among men facing death minute by minute, chance incidents were blown up and acquired a magical dimension. When death is dealt out so randomly, the notion of cause and effect is lost. Phenomena like the 'Angel of Mons', invented by a popular writer, were subsequently 'seen' by thousands of soldiers.

Peace brought little respite to the bereaved imagination. It was as if there was a widespread feeling that somewhere, just out of reach, the young men were still alive. Returning spirits were always in favour of world peace and brotherhood; they were never bellicose or revengeful. Trite though their messages were, one can hear in them the voices of the living, battered by disaster, pitchforked into quarrels of their masters' making. Where did the revolutionary impulse go, in British society? In the 18th century it went to sing hymns at Methodist meetings; in 1917, to bawl spiritualist anthems and sit tight, once again, in the hope of a fair deal in the hereafter. A great strength of Gaskill's book is that it provides, by the way, a piece of working-class history: he makes spiritualism comprehensible in the context of the utter bleakness of the lives he describes. The night Henry Duncan's mother died - a diabetic, worn out, an old woman at 40 - Henry and Nell saw her disembodied hand tapping at their window; they recognised it by the marks of her trade, the scars across her palm made by her herring-gutter's knife. The bitterness of imagination that could give rise to such an image, the poverty that bred it, the pity it inspires: all these are part of Helen Duncan's story, and part of a common story which suggests a hunger for consolation which only a new religion could assuage.

If the context is tragic, however, the daily practice of spiritualism was a theatrical spectacle that, as Gaskill says, drew on 'farce, burlesque and vaudeville'. Spiritualism, in its modern form, began in 1848 in upstate New York, where the teenage Fox sisters heard rapping noises in their farmhouse, found human bones in their cellar, and soon afterwards struck a deal with the showman Phineas T Barnum. Gaskill has a whole catalogue of comic and grotesque manifestations which could only have fooled the most suggestible of sitters, or those determined to get value for money. Performing mediums were hated by magicians and illusionists who, having laboriously copied their feats, would expose them as frauds; some of these illusionists, like Houdini, were disaffected believers for whom the spirits had declined to perform. It would be natural to assume that the spiritualist movement was a branch of the music-hall, a low-class amusement, reactive even: washed in on a tide of irrationality, lapping against the stony convictions of Victorian science. But, as Gaskill describes, the opposite case is true: the rise of spiritualism coincided with the high point of scientific materialism, and the assumptions of one creed fed the other.

Henry Duncan emerges from Gaskill's account as a manipulator and a liar, but his early life was sad beyond bearing. Invalided out of the Army with rheumatic fever, he would never regain good health. He met Helen through his sister, who was a workmate of hers, and they had no doubt that they were soul mates. They married in 1916, and their early years together were wretched, with one or other of them too sick to work, though Henry took on casual labouring where it was offered and Nell would turn her hand to anything. Henry started a furniture business which failed, seemingly not through his own fault; he had a heart attack, and Helen engaged herself to crippling work in the bleach-fields to feed them, at the same time taking in washing and mending, and organising the sale of stock to pay the creditors. In the end Henry became too ill to work, and spent his time reading spiritualist books; though Helen was widely known to be psychic, she had not yet embraced - if she ever did - the corpus of cult belief. Spiritualism thrived on disaster, and on poverty. The comfort of 'proved survival' was superior to the airy assurances, given over the years by the orthodox churches, that the deficits of this life would be repaired in the next. For the working classes it had this advantage: it did not operate de haut en bas. A practising and proficient medium was likely to arise in any stratum of society, and if you lived in one of Britain's cities you were likely to find one a few streets away. Spiritualism was a neighbourly, engrossing business, offering a particular and home-grown comfort. It thrived in the Mechanics Institutes and the philanthropic and self-improvement societies of the industrial towns. The great war gave it impetus: all kinds of occult belief flourished, among the fighting forces and among civilians. In the trenches, among men facing death minute by minute, chance incidents were blown up and acquired a magical dimension. When death is dealt out so randomly, the notion of cause and effect is lost. Phenomena like the 'Angel of Mons', invented by a popular writer, were subsequently 'seen' by thousands of soldiers. Peace brought little respite to the bereaved imagination. It was as if there was a widespread feeling that somewhere, just out of reach, the young men were still alive. Returning spirits were always in favour of world peace and brotherhood; they were never bellicose or revengeful. Trite though their messages were, one can hear in them the voices of the living, battered by disaster, pitchforked into quarrels of their masters' making. Where did the revolutionary impulse go, in British society? In the 18th century it went to sing hymns at Methodist meetings; in 1917, to bawl spiritualist anthems and sit tight, once again, in the hope of a fair deal in the hereafter. A great strength of Gaskill's book is that it provides, by the way, a piece of working-class history: he makes spiritualism comprehensible in the context of the utter bleakness of the lives he describes. The night Henry Duncan's mother died - a diabetic, worn out, an old woman at 40 - Henry and Nell saw her disembodied hand tapping at their window; they recognised it by the marks of her trade, the scars across her palm made by her herring-gutter's knife. The bitterness of imagination that could give rise to such an image, the poverty that bred it, the pity it inspires: all these are part of Helen Duncan's story, and part of a common story which suggests a hunger for consolation which only a new religion could assuage. If the context is tragic, however, the daily practice of spiritualism was a theatrical spectacle that, as Gaskill says, drew on 'farce, burlesque and vaudeville'. Spiritualism, in its modern form, began in 1848 in upstate New York, where the teenage Fox sisters heard rapping noises in their farmhouse, found human bones in their cellar, and soon afterwards struck a deal with the showman Phineas T Barnum. Gaskill has a whole catalogue of comic and grotesque manifestations which could only have fooled the most suggestible of sitters, or those determined to get value for money. Performing mediums were hated by magicians and illusionists who, having laboriously copied their feats, would expose them as frauds; some of these illusionists, like Houdini, were disaffected believers for whom the spirits had declined to perform. It would be natural to assume that the spiritualist movement was a branch of the music-hall, a low-class amusement, reactive even: washed in on a tide of irrationality, lapping against the stony convictions of Victorian science. But, as Gaskill describes, the opposite case is true: the rise of spiritualism coincided with the high point of scientific materialism, and the assumptions of one creed fed the other. Continue

webTitle: John Townend denies he will speak out

fields.headline: Race row MP denies he will speak out
fields.standfirst:
Tory leadership hauls in rightwinger for second dressing down

Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Whitehall
fields.trailText: John Townend, the rightwing Tory MP who sparked the row over race, was given a second dressing down by the Conservative leadership yesterday after he allegedly pledged to break his silence when he stands down at the general election.
fields.body:
John Townend, the rightwing Tory MP who sparked the row over race, was given a second dressing down by the Conservative leadership yesterday after he allegedly pledged to break his silence when he stands down at the general election.

Amid reports that he regretted apologising and withdrawing his remarks about a "mongrel race" in Britain, Mr Townend was summoned by the Tory whips yesterday to explain his behaviour.

The outspoken MP for Yorkshire East denied that he was planning to speak out after the election. His explanation was accepted by the Tory whip, James Cran, prompting central office to claim that the matter was now closed. "These stories are fiction - Townend will remain shut up," one Tory source said.

The source's remarks came after Mr Townend emphatically denied telling yesterday's Yorkshire Post that he regret ted apologising for his controversial remarks about race. The newspaper's political editor, Brendan Carlin, quoted Mr Townend as telling friends: "I have probably made a mistake but I was only given 10 minutes."

Mr Townend's denial was undermined last night when it emerged that he - rather than his "friends" - told a second newspaper yesterday that he was planning to speak out after the election. Asked by the Hull Daily Mail about whether he regretted his apology, Mr Townend said: "I will tell you all after the election."

It is understood that Mr Townend is angry over the way he has been treated by the Tory leadership. William Hague, who has refused to remove the Tory whip from the MP, told him on Monday to withdraw his remarks or face expulsion from the party. Mr Townend initially put up a fight, but caved in within half an hour.

The confusion over Mr Townend's views came as Mr Hague faced pressure to de-select a Conservative general election candidate who warned of "the dangers posed by large scale immigration". Simon Pearce, who is standing in St Helens North, made his remarks in a letter to the Daily Telegraph in which he defended Mr Townend.

Dave Watts, the Labour MP for St Helens North, said: "William Hague must stand up to the extremists in the party and de-select Simon Pearce."

The revival of the race row will anger the Tory leadership which faced pressure last night from Laurence Robertson, the second Tory MP who was forced to apologise after he endorsed Mr Townend's remarks.

The MP for Tewkesbury has been telling colleagues that he has received a lot of support and was even told by his constituency chairman he should not have backed down. Lord Tebbit has also been flooded with supportive mail since joining the row.

The unease within the party over the leadership's handling of the issue, which appears likely to boil over after the election in spite of Mr Townend's denials, will alarm Mr Hague who will be fearful of a new row at a delicate moment in his career. Mr Hague, whose opinion poll ratings have sunk, will face severe pressure to stand down if he suffers a heavy election defeat.

MPs on the right will use his handling of the row to criticise him for caving into what Mr Townend called the "race relations gestapo".

More enlightened members on the left will criticise him for appearing weak after he took four days to act against Mr Townend.

A challenge to Mr Hague appeared more likely after a series of bleak opinion polls for the Tories.

An NOP poll, commissioned for Channel 4's Powerhouse political chat show yesterday, gave Labour 51%, the Tories 29%, Liberal Democrats 13% and others 7%.

Such a result would produce a Labour majority of 250 - a significant increase on the 1997 majority of 179.

webTitle: Soldiers murdered man at nightclub, court told

fields.headline: Soldiers murdered man at nightclub, court told
fields.standfirst:
Prosecutor tells how defendant boasted after 'vicious' attack

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: One of four soldiers accused of murdering a black man outside a nightclub said: "We will give the black bastard a good kicking," a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
One of four soldiers accused of murdering a black man outside a nightclub said: "We will give the black bastard a good kicking," a court heard yesterday.

Bristol crown court was told that Private Thomas Myers's comment was overheard by a doorman at Reflections nightclub in Westbury, Wiltshire, not long before railway worker Glyne Agard, 34, was found dead in the nearby club car park. Mr Agard had multiple head injuries.

His brother Stephen, 33, and friend Gary Belgrave, were also seriously injured in the attack, which occurred just after 2am on June 18 last year.

Myers, 20, and Privates Wayne King, 20, and Marc Hunter, 18, and Lance Corporal David White, 23, of the Green Howards Regiment based at Battlesbury Barracks, Warminster, are all charged with murder.

John Royce QC, prosecuting, told the jury how the three friends, all from Reading, had gone to the nightclub after watching an England v Germany football match on television.

"They left the nightclub but they never got home," Mr Royce said. "Glyne Agard met his death in the nightclub car park. Stephen Agard was attacked so that he was close to coma, and Gary Belgrave was also attacked so that he sustained a number of serious injuries."

He told the court the "action" had taken place "rapidly" as people were leaving the club.

It was alleged that the incident was triggered by a young woman complaining to King, Myers and Hunter of a minor assault by a black man that she said had taken place inside the club. King was then alleged to have said: "It's not on. You can't hit a woman. We are going to sort it out".

Minutes later, the court was told, Glyne Agard came out of the club followed by his brother and friend. A discussion ensued between the two groups about who was responsible for the alleged assault, during which Glyne Agard denied any part in the incident.

It was as he walked away with the other two men that a doorman at the club heard Myers say: "We will give that black bastard a good kicking," Mr Royce said.

The nightclub doorman said the soldiers then went towards the car park. He said two of them looked back, giving an intimidating stare to the black men as they left.

Mr Royce told the jury they would hear conflicting versions of what happened next over the course of the trial because the events took place so quickly, and because the action moved from place to place

However he told the court: "There is no doubt that Glyne Agard was viciously attacked. Mr King appears to have been at the forefront of that to start with. And indeed he later told police: 'I lost my temper. I ran over and hit the man. I head butted him and punched him twice'."

King is also alleged to have told police he saw someone kick Mr Agard as he tried to get up from the ground.

The jury were shown CCTV footage of the incident, frame by frame, but Mr Royce warned that the time lapse on the film and the rotation of the camera meant the footage would not give a full picture of what took place. He went on: "The attack on Glyne Agard rapidly led to both Stephen and Gary coming across to where he was and the fighting moved down to the lower car park.

"The three black men were in effect left on the ground with injuries," he said. "Gary Belgrave suffered serious facial injuries and Stephen Agard was left close to coma after the attack."

He said Glyne Agard had died as a result of a number of blows to the head which, in combination with the alcohol he had consumed, led to his death.

He then told the court how, after the attack, King had allegedly boasted of his actions, saying: "I have done all three of them." King was then prevented from leaving the scene in a taxi with Hunter and Myers by a doorman, he said.

"Far from expressing concern or regret about the black men, one of whom was dead, here was Mr King trumpeting what he had done".

Myers had not made any comments to police and Hunter had told officers he had tried to get Myers to leave but had failed, and then watched events unfold from a waiting taxi, Mr Royce said.

The court then heard that White had told police his recollection of events had not been good because he had been drunk, but that he remembered trying to split two people up.

All four soldiers are also charged with violent disorder. King, Myers and Hunter are charged with causing both Stephen Agard and Gary Belgrave grievous bodily harm with intent.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Comment: Blair and the end of foot and mouth

fields.headline: Blair dazzled by false dawn
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister is willing foot and mouth to end, but we've got some way to go yet, writes Martin Wainwright
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The prime minister is willing foot and mouth to end, but we've got some way to go yet, writes Martin Wainwright.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's speechwriters were ransacking their dictionaries of popular music this morning, as realisation gradually dawned that Roy Orbison's It's Over wasn't precisely the right theme tune for foot and mouth.

Widely flagged as announcing that the disease has been mastered at last, the prime minister's speech was never going to be that reckless. But the need to avoid even a hint of jollity and "let's get on with life again" clearly had not fully sunk in among the spin doctors.

In purely epidemiological terms, the worst may indeed be over, with the rate of new outbreaks on an apparently steady decline. But even the most experienced vets are now inured to surprises. Foot and mouth broke out again yesterday on Exmoor, in an area declared disease-free by Maff just last week.

It would be a brave visitor, too, who announced the end of the crisis to farmers in Cumbria, where the pyres blaze on and the fells stay shut. Or in Northumbria, where blood trails from the leaking carcass disposal lorries have villagers in understandable and unappeased uproar.

But the real mountain still to climb is the repair of collateral damage to commerce a world away from farming - not merely tourism, which has at least had sympathetic headlines and supportive away-days by Cabinet Ministers - but in almost every sector.

A national survey today reveals that 56% of businesses in the north of England have suffered a drop in orders directly attributable to the disease; if you don't need to repair a barn, you don't need the joiner, who doesn't need the screws, which don't need the forge time. Thus a foundry miles from any unfortunate calf or lamb becomes a victim of the plague.

Others damaged, but accorded few fanfares, include hundreds of thousands of school students whose geography field study projects have been ruined by foot and mouth travel restrictions.

With the new AS levels, that means three whole years of the country's young people are justifiably jumpy. Some of them are voters, as are all their parents. And they know that the problems are far from over for them.

It wasn't a rock singer who best described the real, current situation, but one of Mr Blair's predecessors at number ten. Faced with premature glee-mongers after Field Marshal Montgomery's victory at El Alamein, the great man rumbled (with absolute accuracy): "This is not the end. It is not even the beginning of the end. But it is perhaps the end of the beginning."

fields.headline: Avalon wins comedy contracts
fields.trailText:
5pm: Avalon PR to promote Al Murray and Steve Coogan comedy shows, reports Julia Day.
03.05.2001: Pub Landlord extends drinking hours
22.03.2001: Avalon waiting as Playboy king comes to town
fields.body:
Avalon PR, the agency that launched Big Brother, Popstars and the Frank Skinner Show, has been appointed to handle the public relations for two new TV series.

The agency has signed a deal to promote the new series of Al Murray's Sky One sitcom, Time Gentleman Please.

Avalon will also handle PR for a Steve Coogan comedy for ITV called the Sketch Show.

The series, which comprises seven 30-minute shows, will be screened later this year.

It is being produced by Charlie Hanson, whose credits include Harry Hill, Chef and Birds of a Feather.

Ed Thompson of Avalon PR, said: "We are delighted to be working with Sky and ITV on the PR for these series. Both shows will benefit from our expertise in TV and entertainment PR."

fields.headline: Eff off, FA, and Effusive (not)
fields.trailText: KICK UP A STINK AND THEY CAN'T MAKE THE LINK
fields.body:
KICK UP A STINK AND THEY CAN'T MAKE THE LINK

Fat footpad Robert Maxwell may not have done much good in the time he waddled this earth, but the pug-ugly pickpocketer did at least do one beneficial thing before his unctuous frame oozed off the side of his boat and slicked into the sea. His 1983 attempt to amalgamate Reading and Oxford and create the Thames Valley Royals sparked mass public protests which proved fans can stop businessmen in their tracks if they need to. Maxwell's scheme was foiled, and the die was cast: similar merger-mad oafs who've tried it on since have been told to sling their hooks. So thanks Bob, you fat bastard, because plans are afoot to merge QPR with Wimbledon - and we've got an idea!

Earlier today, Rangers confirmed that they are in "very early stage discussions" with the Dons about a possible link-up, which would see Dons boss Terry Burton coach a team playing in front of crowds of 00,000 at Loftus Road. "Our initial view is that, in the current financial environment for football outside the Premier League, the idea could have merit and may be worth exploring further," the spokesperson explained. "But we must emphasise that it is still very early days. The talks with Wimbledon will only continue if there is general approval from our supporter base." Also making a promise we can hold him to, is Wimbledon chairman Charles Koppel. "If the fans felt that this was not the best thing," he said today, "we would re-evaluate and move along a different route."

Which should mean that nothing will happen, because it's already kicking off nicely on the frontline. "Any move to merge QPR with Wimbledon this year, or at any stage in the future, will be opposed by every possible means," promised Libby Magrill, spokeswoman for the QPR Supporters Trust. OUR KNEES HAVE GONE ALL TREMBLY

Bad news for Brummies. Yep, the new Bull Ring is going to be as horrible as the old one, just with a few more coffee shops. Sorry about that. Oh, and you're not going to get to house the new national stadium either, despite what you were told yesterday. "We just can't afford these sums of money," he said. So with no money to build, and no intention of moving, we're looking forward to attending the new Wembley in the not-too distant future. If we bring our own torches, we might even be able to light up the pitch.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I am a human and not a robot and I have been on antibiotics for two months and need an operation on my sinuses. People should say: 'Thank you Di Canio' because other players at this club have had injuries no worse than mine but have taken weeks off" - Paolo Di Canio does a lot of work for West Ham, but he doesn't like to talk about it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

Birds do it. Bees do it. Even educated Fiver writers do it (well, occasionally). And earlier this season, Real Madrid and Mark Viduka seemed to be saying: "Let's do it. Let's fall in love." It was Real who made the first move, sweeping the 16-stone striker off his feet - which isn't easy at the best of times - and lavishing praise on his Big Cup performances. And like a love-struck teen, Viduka responded with doggy-in-the window eyes and Jo Guest legs. So pity poor Mark, as Madrid coach Vincente Del Bosque - the man who could make a decent living as a Danny DeVito impersonator if only he'd shave off his ridiculous moustache and grin inanely once in a while - poured a bucket of ice-cold water on the whole deal.

THE RUMOUR MILL

He Is He Was (He Will Be Again) Emmanuel Petit has turned down a £4m move to Chelsea, leaving Spurs as favourites to land the 30-year-old.

Juventus are the latest club to be linked with a move for Arsene Wenger when his Arsenal contract expires at the end of next season.

Juan Sebastian Veron's lawyer, Giuseppe Petrelli, has confirmed that Real Madrid have made a £30m bid for his client. "The Spanish club have offered £30 million for him," he said.

Ipswich could sign Norwich keeper Andy Marshall on a free transfer this summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

The Football League's board of directors have ratified the nine-point penalty imposed on Chesterfield for financial irregularities. However after finally agreeing to the sanction, Football League chief executive David Burns said: "The board continues to believe that a nine-point deduction does not reflect the damage that Chesterfield have done to the integrity of the competition." The decision means that Chesterfield, who are three points ahead of fourth-placed Hartlepool with a vastly superior goal difference, are almost certain to be promoted.

Gianfranco Zola has signed a new two-year deal Chelsea and will end his playing career at the club. "One of the reasons I decided to stay is that I have not won the premier league title and I am looking forward to doing so in the two years I have left," he said at a press conference today. Zola has also been given the option of a further two years at Stamford Bridge in a coaching capacity when the new deal runs out.

Spanish sports daily Marca today continued its assault on Leeds by claiming the players were "awkward and primitive like Englishmen 15 centuries ago". Sportswriter Julian Ruiz wrote: "Leeds, who seemed like a storm against Deportivo, reminded me of those poor Englishmen who invented football 15 centuries ago when they cut off a Viking's head, put it in a bag and started to kick it around, as awkward and primitive as that."

Hearts goalkeeper Antti Niemi has been named as Bank of Scotland Scottish Premier League Player of the Month for April.

Paul di Giacomo has become the latest Kilmarnock player to pledge his future to the Rugby Park club. The 18-year-old has signed a new three-year deal after a string of first-team appearances this season.

Dutch Football (12.35am) They should have won Euro 2000, some say.

Argentine Football (2.10am) They should have been given Las Malvinas back, some say.

webTitle: Report confirms foot and mouth's virulence

fields.headline: Report confirms foot and mouth's virulence
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The current foot and mouth epidemic has been a more "national" disease than the 1967 outbreak, a government report said today.
fields.body:
The current foot and mouth epidemic has been a more "national" disease than the 1967 outbreak, a government report said today.

In 1967 94% of infected farms were in the north-west Midlands and north Wales. The major clusters this year have been located over a wider area, stretching from just north of the Scottish border to Devon.

The report says that the geographical dispersal of the disease before the first case was diagnosed was much more widespread than in 1967. It also points to changes in the livestock industry, which have meant a much greater movement of animals than 30 years ago.

The lack of control over sheep movements has meant that "the same animal can be moved several times in a few days".

However, the report insists that the slaughter policy and the speed with which resources were mobilised compares favourably to 1967.

Then, the armed forces were called in after 12 days. This time, according to the report, contacts were established between the ministries of agriculture and defence on the day the outbreak was detected.

"The more careful preparation for military deployments ensured that many of the difficulties experienced in 1967, in integrating the military and civil response, were not repeated this time round," it says.

In 11 weeks, 2,382,000 animals have been slaughtered at a peak rate of more than 500,000 a week.

In addition, 15,000 vehicles have been used to combat the outbreak. The tonnage of carcasses moved each week is now greater than that of all the ammunition transported by the British forces during the Gulf War.

Burial sites for carcasses equal to 200 Olympic-size swimming pools have been excavated, with the mass burial site in Thropmorton in Worcestershire alone having the capacity to hold more than 430,000 sheep.

Nevertheless, the report concludes that its short comparison of the two epidemics is "cursory and incomplete".

It says that the 1967 outbreak was probably caused by imports of infected meat, legally introduced into the animal food chain. "It is not yet established whether the cause of the current outbreak was due to illegal actions," it adds.

In 1967, 434,000 animals were culled in 32 weeks. "The logistic operation to tackle the current outbreak is of a different scale of magnitude than the 1967-8 operation," it says.

webTitle: Rising star in the Land of the Rising Sun

fields.headline: Rising star in the Land of the Rising Sun
fields.standfirst: Japan's new prime minister is basking in popular adulation, but can it last, asks Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: Japan's new prime minister is riding high on a tide of popular adulation, but can it last, asks Jonathan Watts.
fields.body:
Elation. Fear. Irrationality. Ecstatic highs. Despairing lows. Periods of wild hope punctuated by bouts of agonizing doubt. The tell-tale signs are unmistakable: Japan is madly, desperately, head over heels in love.

The nation has been in a swoon since last Thursday, when its dashing new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, swept into power on a masterful pledge to restore financial and fiscal discipline, whatever the cost.

His opinion poll ratings have hit an astonishing 86%, which means that in the space of a week Japan has gone from having its most derided prime minister of all time to its most adored.

The passion has even spread to the markets. Having lost almost a third of its value under Yoshiro Mori, the Nikkei index of the Tokyo stock exchange rose almost 4% on Monday on hopes for Koizumi's new administration.

If the figures are remarkable, then the reasons for them are amazing. A large part of Koizumi's appeal is that he promises pain: clearing up the financial sector even if it means two years of recession, bankruptcy and unemployment.

This has clearly touched a previously undiscovered masochistic streak in the electorate. For most of the postwar period, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party has taken a grandfatherly approach to administration: preferring to spoil rather than to spank.

But the electorate appears to have been secretly longing for the smack of firm government, a desire that Mr Koizumi - like Margaret Thatcher in Britain - seems just as keen to satisfy.

His uncompromising stance has been apparent in foreign policy and security issues. Koizumi has pushed an unusually assertive agenda by stating his keenness to reform the country's pacifist constitution to recognize the nation's self-defence forces as an army. He has also infuriated China by insisting on his right to visit a shrine honouring veterans and war criminals.

But Japan's infatuation for its new premier is not just because he plays the role of tough guy. It is also related to something else that has been missing in Japanese politics for a long time: style.

Media descriptions of Koizumi have focused on his smart suits and permed hair, which has led to the nicknames "Beethoven" and the "Lion Kong."

At first, such monikers seem a little over the top for a 59-year-old, who does not immediately strike the eye as a colourful character. But compared to his four predecessors - the bushy-browed septagenarian Tomiichi Murayama, the grim martial arts expert Ryutaro Hashimoto, the bumbling uncle-figure Keizo Obuchi and the portly buffoon Mori, he appears relatively modern, individualistic and sexy.

The fact that he is single - a divorcee with two children - has not hurt this image nor have his efforts to promote women and young politicians to his administration.

These factors have allowed him to win the crucial support of Makiko Tanaka, Japan's most popular politician and now its first female foreign minister. Three years ago during Mr Koizumi's failed leadership bid, Ms Tanaka labelled him "a weirdo". This time, she has declared herself his "political wife", creating an odd couple that has as much celebrity appeal as political clout.

He has also picked the closest Japan has ever come to a sexy cabinet line-up. Instead of the usual old duffers, he has chosen five women (two was the previous record), three private-sector appointees and one of the leaders of the rebellious young LDP turks who have been making a lot of noise in recent years.

Koizumi's charm, however, had its limits. Toyota refused to allow its president Hiroshi Okuda to take the post of finance minister. And Sadako Ogata, former United Nations high commissioner for refugees, turned down an offer of the foreign minister's post, saying she was unclear about the new prime minister's policies.

That remains the biggest doubt about Mr Koizumi. While he has struck a popular tone, he has yet to provide much substance or to inflict much pain. The truth may be that neither he nor the electorate are in a hurry to rush into a relationship that is going to have to hurt if it is to last. But Mr Koizumi, at least, is under few illusions. After hearing of his record high ratings, he observed wryly: "The only way from here is down."

Koizumi has pushed an unusually assertive agenda by stating his keenness to reform the country's pacifist constitution to recognize the nation's self-defence forces as an army. He has also infuriated China by insisting on his right to visit a shrine honouring veterans and war criminals. But Japan's infatuation for its new premier is not just because he plays the role of tough guy. It is also related to something else that has been missing in Japanese politics for a long time: style. Media descriptions of Koizumi have focused on his smart suits and permed hair, which has led to the nicknames "Beethoven" and the "Lion Kong." At first, such monikers seem a little over the top for a 59-year-old, who does not immediately strike the eye as a colourful character. But compared to his four predecessors - the bushy-browed septagenarian Tomiichi Murayama, the grim martial arts expert Ryutaro Hashimoto, the bumbling uncle-figure Keizo Obuchi and the portly buffoon Mori, he appears relatively modern, individualistic and sexy. The fact that he is single - a divorcee with two children - has not hurt this image nor have his efforts to promote women and young politicians to his administration. These factors have allowed him to win the crucial support of Makiko Tanaka, Japan's most popular politician and now its first female foreign minister. Three years ago during Mr Koizumi's failed leadership bid, Ms Tanaka labelled him "a weirdo". This time, she has declared herself his "political wife", creating an odd couple that has as much celebrity appeal as political clout. He has also picked the closest Japan has ever come to a sexy cabinet line-up. Instead of the usual old duffers, he has chosen five women (two was the previous record), three private-sector appointees and one of the leaders of the rebellious young LDP turks who have been making a lot of noise in recent years. Koizumi's charm, however, had its limits. Toyota refused to allow its president Hiroshi Okuda to take the post of finance minister. And Sadako Ogata, former United Nations high commissioner for refugees, turned down an offer of the foreign minister's post, saying she was unclear about the new prime minister's policies. That remains the biggest doubt about Mr Koizumi. While he has struck a popular tone, he has yet to provide much substance or to inflict much pain. The truth may be that neither he nor the electorate are in a hurry to rush into a relationship that is going to have to hurt if it is to last. But Mr Koizumi, at least, is under few illusions. After hearing of his record high ratings, he observed wryly: "The only way from here is down." fields.headline: Ikea
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the world's best-loved, worst-hated furniture retailer on the net
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the world's best-loved, worst-hated furniture retailer on the net
fields.body:
1. The world's biggest furniture firm is to create 1,450 new jobs in two new stores and a distribution centre in Britain. It already operates 140 stores in 29 countries worldwide.

2. The store openings in Southampton and Sheffield are part of a previously announced plan to invest £700m and create 10,000 new jobs over 10 years.

3. Ikea has expanded relentlessly since it was founded in Sweden 1947 by Ingvar Kamprad.

4. It remains a private company, with no published accounts. It likes to boast of its environmental-friendliness, but does not believe in giving too much away.

5. Ikea customers, on the other hand, love to talk about the firm. There used to be a website called ihateikea.co.uk, featuring horror stories about the company's products.

6. But the one about the legless chair now links to an error page on the company's Swedish website - perhaps because Ikea do not like to have their name misused.

7. In the USA, Ikea goods are held by some to represent a cool alternative culture - Mr Kamprad even considers himself something of a philosopher.

8. The subject of flatpack furniture arouses strong passions. But is it art?

9. You can, if you wish, buy flatpack coffins (not at Ikea), though the concept of self-assembly is surely a little flawed.

10. Another flatpack item as yet unavailable from the Swedish giant, is the, ahem, bondage cage.

fields.headline: Addiction prevention through audience participation
fields.standfirst: Actors usually don't like having their performance interrupted by the audience. But for a theatre company made up of recovering alcoholics and drug addicts, that's the whole point. Martin McNamara reports
fields.trailText: Actors usually don't like having their performance interrupted by the audience. But for a theatre company made up of recovering alcoholics and drug addicts, that's the whole point. Martin McNamara reports.
fields.body:
A select audience crammed into the small impromptu theatre watches as the lead character in the play battles against her addiction to drink and drugs, tries to help her new boyfriend fight his own war against alcoholism and has to cope with the threats of her dealing ex-lover.

Suddenly, a voice from the audience is contradicting the actor bringing some of his own life experience to the fictional dilemmas on stage. Eventually, he gets up on stage and takes over one of the main roles himself.

This would be considered a disaster for most theatre companies. But for Outside Edge it is a normal night's work, using theatre to help recovering addicts and alcoholics confront their problems.

The company is the brainchild of Philip Fox, an actor who 16 years ago found his life was being destroyed by his addiction to heroin, cocaine and alcohol. "I saw that theatre was something that kept me alive," he said.

After overcoming his addictions and spending years working in community theatre, he started devising plans for a theatre group to help other recovering addicts and alcoholics come to terms with their problems.

Outside Edge has now been touring rehabilitation centres and prisons since 1999. The actors are all recovering alcoholics or ex-drug addicts. Their specially-devised plays deal specifically with the problems recovering addicts face every day.

The troupe performs a one-hour play, then runs through it again. The second time around the audience is encouraged to stop the actors and provide their own input into what is happening on stage - even to the point of getting up and taking over the roles themselves.

"It is stunning how well that can work," said Mr Fox. "Our audiences can be full of rage and they have to get up to have their say."

Dave Mulvaney, manager of the Self Help Recovery Project (Sharp) in London, which has put on Outside Edge productions for its clients, said: "It is very useful, because it's a very creative medium to deliver relapse prevention therapy. It is alive and powerful and impacts on all the dynamics - family, work, the violence of growing up - all major issues in these people's lives."

John Gordon Smith, head of the drug and alcohol team at Hammersmith and Fulham council, was an early champion of the company and is now on its board of trustees. He says: "It's great to have these plays that people can come along to and see aspects of their own lives. It's a play, but on the other hand it is also an active dialogue on what people have gone through. It actively takes them to a different level."

Barry Maher was a recovering alcoholic and a drama school student when he went along to see an early production. "I was only six months out of treatment, so it was all still fresh for me," he said. "It was the first time I'd seen anything like my own experiences on stage like that."

He went on to audition for the company and is now a regular member of Outside Edge. "The second part of the show is quite improvised and you don't know what you're going to come up against. The audience can be pretty vulnerable and pretty volatile."

The plays, dealing with issues such as relationships, incest and crime associated with addiction, often hit a strong nerve in the lives of the audiences, many of whom are seeing live theatre for the first time in their lives.

In a previous production, Family Life, Mr Maher played a social worker who takes a woman's child into care. "Some of the women who got up in the audience during that play had gone through that and they were laying into you as a character," he said. "You can get shocking responses from people to what they have seen."

Adam Langer was one recovering drug addict who saw Family Life while he was going through treatment with a self-help group. "I was in floods of tears," he said. "You go and see a play that has no pretensions, no preaching, but just shows you what your home and your life was like. That is incredibly powerful."

For Mr Langer, now clean for two years, the company has a valuable role to play in any rehabilitation programme.

"In places like prisons and treatment centres, the hardest thing for people is to be vulnerable, to get in touch with what is inside you. But this work is so overwhelmingly in your face, it just breaks through that denial and it is an incredibly useful tool."

"What is important is that people with addictions are not used to playing with different roles," said Mr Fox. "They're stuck in the role of the addict. The plays get them to rehearse other roles, to see things from a different perspective."

 Outside Edge take their latest production, Harry and Susie Get Married? on tour around England in May, telephone: 020 7371 8020 for details.

webTitle: New Yorkers fear summer power struggle

fields.headline: New Yorkers fear summer power struggle
fields.standfirst: The heat is rising in the city, reports Jane Martinson, and some say New York is next for power blackouts
fields.trailText: The heat is rising in the city, reports Jane Martinson, and some say New York is next for power blackouts
fields.body:
It's summer in the city of New York. After months of miserable weather, temperatures have been in the 80s all week and the latest reports suggests that this summer could be a scorcher.

Everybody's happy, apart for those miserable souls who fear power blackouts as the humidity heads for 100%.

Energy analysts believe that America's largest city is the most likely to follow the example of California into a power crisis this summer. On paper at least, New York's antiquated, deregulated supply is going to find it tough to meet the increased demand of a rising population and high temperatures.

State authorities are rushing to complete 7 power stations before June 1, while Consolidated Edison, the local supplier, has requested approval for 11 new mini-generators in case of a power shortage. Environmentalists and local neighbourhood groups have already filed lawsuits to stop them from doing so.

Such battles echo those being played out on a national scale. Dick Cheney, the vice-president, gave a huge boost to the energy industry this week when he said that more power plants should be built. In doing so, he reopened a door on the nuclear power industry shut since a radioactive leak on Three-Mile Island more than 20 years ago.

Environmentalists are horrified by this supply-side mentality. They argue that if Americans curtailed some of their gas use - they are the world's greatest consumers by a wide margin - then the need for more polluting or dangerous sources of power would be avoided.

Cheney, a former oil industry executive, dismissed the idea of conservation as 1970s-era thinking on Monday. "Without a clear, coherent energy strategy, all Americans could one day go through what Californians are experiencing now, or worse," he said.

Such words strike at the heart of New Yorkers, some of whom are already shunning the public transit system for fear of an air conditioning failure.

The excessive demand that plagues the rest of America holds true in New York, where some people spend the summer months hardly ever venturing out of air conditioned spaces. However, Manhattan's problems are exacerbated by an elderly transmission system which transports energy from outside the island.

Consumer advocates and ConEd itself also argue that the speedy deregulation of the industry, which took effect in November 1999, is also leading to price fixing and an inadequate response to a potential crisis.

As the political temperature rose this week, the Northest Power Co-ordinating Council, a non-profit industry group, said that new power plants should help keep the lights on this summer in all but the most unusual circumstances. These circumstances include a week-long heatwave or a major transmission line failure. The council put the chances of such an event happening - a thunderstorm hitting a transmission line, for example - as "1 in 5,000".

Local watchdogs disagree. Gerald Norlander, executive director of PULP, said such rose-tinted assessments depended on statistical testing rather than reality. "Most assurances that we won't have a problem this summer are being given on the basis of arithmetic," he said.

"A combination of bad luck and a mistake or two could put us back in 1978 [the last time of major shortages in the city]."

While the debate about blackouts rages, few argue that New York will see more price increases this year in spite of the fact that its prices are already the highest in the US. After increasing 40% in the last two years, prices could rise 50% more if this summer turns out to be as hot as expected. The main culprit is the state's dependance on gas-fired plants as gas prices have doubled in the past year.

During an unprecedented economic boom, high prices failed to deter increased use. US government figures suggest that electricity demand will grow 2.3% nationally this year, with New York City no exception.

Such is the average consumer's failure to connect increased supply with a lack of conservation that the government's bid to return to nuclear power is winning votes. In a poll commissioned by The Associated Press, half of those questioned said they support using nuclear power to generate electricity while 30% said they opposed it. The rest said they didn't know.

Some even said they would not mind a new nuclear plant being built less than 10 miles from their homes. Three Mile Island, America's worst commercial nuclear accident, leaked radioactive steam into the atmosphere in Pennsylvania, less than an hour by train from New York.

The last summer in New York proved to be the coldest since 1914. As the political battles and the temperature heats up, New York could find itself a national battleground.

webTitle: Departmental welfare officers to prevent drop-outs

fields.headline: Departmental welfare officers to prevent drop-outs
fields.trailText: Sussex University has created a new administrative post for student welfare in every department, in an attempt to prevent students dropping out.
fields.body:
All universities consider ways of preventing students dropping out, but Sussex University has gone further than many by creating a new administrative post for student welfare in every department. But there is disagreement over whether this is the new way forward in student retention or a step too far.

Although welfare officers have been around for decades at an institutional level, students have seen a drop in the support they receive from their professors.

That has been almost inevitable, according to administrators at universities around the country. As class sizes increase and budgets decline, personal tutors have been able to devote less time to each individual student.

So to try to make up for the shortfall, almost every school of study at Sussex University has created a new welfare officer, usually trained in counselling, who can offer advice and support to students about mental health or financial issues.

"Though we have tried to maintain personal tutors, the staff-student ratio is such that we had to do something. These advisors can provide support across a range of problems and have been meeting together to work out how best to help students in a particular department," said one senior administrator.

The National Union of Students' (NUS) new vice president for welfare, Claire Kober, welcomes any new help for students, if the system works.

She argues that students are working more hours, with less money and from a greater diversity of backgrounds than before, all of which create new pressures that universities have to help alleviate if they want undergraduates to stay in their courses.

However, not everyone is welcoming the birth of a new administrative post. While Professor Maggie Woodrow, executive director of the European Access Network at Westminster University, welcomes anything that increases access, she is not convinced about this particular idea.

"In my experience, people do not like to go even to their personal tutor. Students like to see their teachers, with whom they already have a relationship. I am not sure a new post would be any better," she said.

Anne Heyno, head of counselling and advisory services at the University of Westminster, was equally unconvinced about the creation of a new job, and stressed that she would rather see more support for the role of personal tutor.

webTitle: Rugby league: Halifax lose their helmsman

fields.headline: Halifax lose their helmsman
fields.trailText: Halifax, who have lost their last six Super League games, gained a wing but lost a chief executive yesterday.
fields.body:
Halifax, who have lost their last six Super League games, gained a wing but lost a chief executive yesterday.

The Blue Sox have snapped up Jason Lee, a 30-year-old from Pontypridd who has been a consistent tryscorer in the Northern Ford Premiership for Keighley, and was available because of the Cougars' fresh financial problems.

But Nigel Wood, who has been Halifax's chief executive since before the Super League revolution of 1995, supervising their move from Thrum Hall to the Shay and last year's escape from serious financial problems, has stepped down.

Wood's position as company director of Super League Europe will be discussed at a board meeting this week.

Wigan's prop Neil Cowie was cleared by a disciplinary hearing yesterday after being put on report in last Sunday's 20-12 defeat at London Broncos for a possible spear tackle. He will now be able to play in tomorrow night's home game against Wakefield Trinity.

The Leeds wing Karl Pratt has been summoned to appear at next Wednesday's disciplinary hearing after an incident in the Rhinos' 38-26 win at Halifax on Monday night.

Andy Gregory, who will coach Lancashire in the Origin match against Yorkshire at Headingley on June 5, has suffered a blow with the Great Britain forward Adrian Morley being denied permission by the Sydney Roosters to return from Australia for the game.

Salford, who have lost one second-row in Warren Jowitt for at least six weeks with a dislocated shoulder sustained at his old club Wakefield on Monday, are to offer a contract extension to another, Andy Coley. The 22-year-old has been outstanding since making the short move from Swinton during the winter, forcing his way into contention for a place in the Lancashire team, and the City Reds have moved quickly after rumours of interest from St Helens.

Bobbie Goulding will return from a thigh injury as Salford aim to end a run of three consecutive defeats at Halifax on Sunday evening.

Australia's National Rugby League has demanded an explanation from one of its member clubs, the Parramatta Eels, after persistent speculation that they have applied for a franchise for the Super 12 rugby union competition.

On the other hand the Cronulla wing Mat Rogers, a member of Australia's World Cup-winning squad last autumn, is expected to follow Penrith's Ryan Girdler by rejecting an approach from the Australian Rugby Union and signing a new deal with his current club.
