fields.headline: O'Sullivan 'does a Mozart'
fields.trailText: Ronnie O'Sullivan, never a finalist at the Crucible, cruised into the last four of the Embassy World Championship here on the day that Stephen Hendry, seven times the title winner, confessed to being "just outplayed" as Matthew Stevens eliminated him 13-5.
fields.body:
Ronnie O'Sullivan, never a finalist at the Crucible, cruised into the last four of the Embassy World Championship here on the day that Stephen Hendry, seven times the title winner, confessed to being "just outplayed" as Matthew Stevens eliminated him 13-5.

O'Sullivan's 13-6 quarter-final victory over Peter Ebdon left even his opponent impressed. "He's the game's equivalent to Mozart - the snooker he produced was nothing short of sensational," said Ebdon.

"One of the highlights of the match came when I was 4-3 up and Ronnie made the 108 break to go 4-4 - it was just magical, nothing short of genius. I looked up to the commentary box and I was smiling because I thought, 'Well, you can't better this'."

O'Sullivan agreed that this was a key frame: "Peter started off really well and coming off 4-4 set me up for the evening session." As that evening saw O'Sullivan run through his virtuoso repertoire to take the session 8-0, yesterday's action verged on the academic.

Joe Swail, the No16 seed, looked O'Sullivan's likely semi-final opponent when he turned his 6-2 overnight arrears into a 9-7 lead at lunch over his fellow Ulsterman Patrick Wallace.

The world No59 has done well on his Crucible debut, beating Alan McManus and Mark King to reach the quarters, but seemed to need a couple of frame-winning chances in going to 6-2 and it was no surprise when the experienced Swail came back strongly to win seven of the morning frames.

The ultra-professional Hendry, 11-5 down overnight to Stevens, had made sure he had four clean shirts available but in truth there was never much prospect that he would need them. The axe fell quickly at 13-5 and Hendry had "no complaints, no excuses" later.

"I was just outplayed," he admitted. "Matthew was outstanding. If his cue action isn't the best in snooker, it's very close. If you don't have him tight on the balk cushion he's going to knock in a long ball every time."

Then the 32-year-old Scot, who has not won a world-ranking event this season, added: "I've got a problem with my game that I've had for three or four years now. If I do sort that out I can win again".

John Higgins earned a semi-final against Stevens last night when, after century breaks of 110, 139 and 113 had taken him from 5-3 to a 10-6 interval lead over Ken Doherty, he came out decisively to edge the first two frames of the evening. He went on to finish Doherty off in style with a fourth century break of 105.

webTitle: Racing: Go-Racing deal flawed says Board

fields.headline: Go-Racing deal flawed says Board
fields.trailText: One step forward and two steps back seems to be the best way to sum up the media rights negotiations between the racecourses and the Go-Racing syndicate. By Chris Hawkins.
fields.body:
One step forward and two steps back seems to be the best way to sum up the current media-rights negotiations between the racecourses and the Go-Racing syndicate.

After the Racecourse Association came out on Tuesday advising its members to accept the Go-Racing deal, the British Horseracing Board yesterday announced its dissatisfaction with such a recommendation.

Chris Reynolds, managing director of the BHB, issued a statement which read: "We are surprised that the RCA is prepared to 'enthusiastically recommend' the Go-Racing contract in its present form.

"The RCA have assured us throughout that they have made it clear to Go-Racing that they insist on racing receiving a direct levy replacement payment and we have been led to believe that Go-Racing accept this in principle.

"We trust the courses will join with the RCA in ensuring that the wording of the contract properly protects racing's direct income streams before signing."

The "direct income streams" referred to is the mechanism to ensure that racing gets a percentage guarantee from the betting turnover generated by interactive and internet wagering worldwide.

With the levy system due to be scrapped in 2003, racing must have a replacement source of income over and above the media-rights deal which will bring income to the courses.

As yet there appears to be no specific mention of this in the Go-Racing contract and the BHB's concern is perfectly understandable. The courses have a responsibility to the whole of the industry.

Entries numbering 36 for the Ascot Gold Cup, the highlight of the Royal meeting next month, were published yesterday and Dalampour and Royal Rebel were installed the 7-1 joint favourites by the Tote.

Looking farther ahead to August, Vinnie Jones, the ex-footballer, and Frankie Dettori will be the team captains in the Blue Square Shergar Cup at Ascot in which Jones's home team of jockeys will be taken on by the Rest of the World.

 Racing has won the first round in the battle for compensation from the government over losses sustained during the foot and mouth crisis, as the Prime Minister yesterday promised to examine the matter following a question by David Rendel MP.

Rendel urged Tony Blair to acknowledge that racing had lost a large number of meetings and pointed out that self-employed jockeys have been particularly hard hit. "This complements contacts we have already had with the Rural Task Force," said BHB secretary-general Tristram Ricketts.

fields.headline: Godolphinset fair for Guineas
fields.standfirst: Dettori expects Dubai team to have edge after wintering in sun
fields.trailText: Godolphin's 2,000 Guineas colts, Tobougg and Rumpold, were out on Newmarket Heath yesterday and after wintering in the warmth of Dubai both looked to be in fantastic condition.
fields.body:
Godolphin's 2,000 Guineas colts, Tobougg and Rumpold, were out on Newmarket Heath yesterday and after wintering in the warmth of Dubai both looked to be in fantastic condition.

Logic and past early-season results - two 2,000 Guineas victories and one 1,000 win in the last five years for Godolphin - suggest their sojourn in the sun must confer an advantage particularly this year when the English spring has been so harsh.

Frankie Dettori, who partners Tobougg on Saturday, believes this to be so and commented: "We have had a smooth preparation and I think there's a little bit more of an advantage this year. Of course all horses in the Guineas are with fantastic trainers and I'm sure that one day they will be 100% good horses but maybe not just yet."

Dettori went on to explain why he had chosen Tobougg rather than Rumpold, who won the Dubai Guineas trial.

"There's nothing between the two and I've opted for Tobougg because he's won two Group One races whereas Rumpold has won the trial and a maiden race at Ascot as a two-year-old. I've gone for the one with the experience.

"Tobougg has done all his work in Dubai. It is now a case of getting there on Saturday in one piece."

With conditions drying out remarkably at Newmarket - one work-rider yesterday described the ground as on the fast side of good - conditions should suit Rumpold.

Simon Crisford, racing manager to Godolphin, has always maintained this colt with his low action needs fast ground and, although Dettori talks about him having won only a maiden at Ascot, he did slam the subsequent top-rated two-year-old Minardi by five lengths.

Aidan O'Brien, trainer of Minardi, walked the course at Newmarket yesterday and will decide overnight which of his five entries will run. Besides Minardi he has Mozart, King's County, Black Minnaloushe and Darwin in the race.

Minardi has never run beyond six furlongs and there has to be an element of doubt whether he will stay a mile.

One horse Dettori will not have to worry about in the 2,000 is the Free Handicap winner Clearing who has been confirmed by Teddy Beckett, racing manager to the colt's owner Khalid Abdullah, as a runner in the French Guineas on Sunday May 13.

"We feel he has his best chance in France and only if there were significant defec tors would we consider running him at Newmarket," said Beckett.

This decision releases Abdullah's retained jockey Richard Hughes to ride Tamburlaine for Richard Hannon whose other runner King's Ironbridge will be partnered by Dane O'Neill.

Tobougg is now 5-2 favourite with Hill's, who then bet 7-1 Golan and Nayef, 8-1 Munir, 9-1 Rumpold, 10-1 Minardi, Frenchmans Bay and Tamburlaine.

Talking about Muwakleh, his mount in the 1,000 Guineas, Dettori said: "I rode her work in Dubai before she ran. She's the best filly we've got but who is to say she is better than the others?

"She's got to be more of a dark shot than the colts as we haven't got any form to compare her with the others. She's only beaten our fillies."

Muwakleh is second best with Hill's at 3-1 behind the 11-4 favourite Karasta, Sir Michael Stoute's filly who is the mount of Kieren Fallon. Stoute has not won the 1,000 Guineas since Musical Bliss in 1989.

fields.headline: PR Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: May 4
fields.trailText: May 4: The London Borough of Tower Hamlets has finally appointed a communications chief.
fields.body:
The London borough of Tower Hamlets has finally appointed a communications chief after 18 months of turmoil. London borough of Haringey head of communications Siobhan Crozier will take up the job.

Henry's House has acquired the main programme PR brief for this summer's Big Brother TV series.

Tetley is holding a consumer PR pitch with a number of high-profile agencies believed to be in the running.

Global telecoms giant Marconi's decision to hire its first global PR agency stands to benefit Hill & Knowlton to the tune of at least £5m.

BT Cellnet's Andrew Hawkins head of communications has quit after eight weeks in the job. He has left to become the director general of the Investor Relations Society.

Simon Young, the former assistant editor of the Sunday Express, ventured into the world of PR consulting this week with the launch of his own agency, SJY Media.

Joy Johnson, the former Labour party director of communications, has left her post as strategic communications director at GPC to become head of media relations for the greater London authority.

fields.headline: Penney pay-off for smart Betts
fields.standfirst: Somerset 174 Warwickshire 178-6 Warwickshire won by four wickets
fields.trailText: Trevor Penney organised Warwickshire's pursuit of a modest total to beat Somerset yesterday, finishing a pugnacious, well-paced and undefeated innings of 73 by pulling the first ball of the final over backward of square to the boundary.
fields.body:
Trevor Penney organised Warwickshire's pursuit of a modest total to beat Somerset yesterday, finishing a pugnacious, well-paced and undefeated innings of 73 by pulling the first ball of the final over backward of square to the boundary.

It was bowled by Marcus Trescothick, captaining Somerset while Jamie Cox nurses a groin strain. The win erased the memory of the previous day, when Warwickshire had been mugged by Gloucestershire off the last ball of the match and Somerset had crushed Glamorgan.

On a pitch offering some early life, and with the ever-present but unfulfilled threat of rain, the visitors chose to bowl first. Although Trescothick shone briefly, any Somerset hopes of setting a demanding target were stifled when Vasbert Drakes and, above all, Melvyn Betts reduced the hosts to 44 for five. Betts, newly recruited from Durham, bowled unchanged with fire and imagination to return his best one-day figures of four for 22, which won him the gold award.

In support, Mohammed Sheikh showed once again that he has a promising ability as a one-day bowler. Of no more than medium pace, and with no great lift off the pitch, he spears the ball into the batsman and allows no liberties.

The fact that Somerset could recover enough from the Betts assault to make Warwickshire work for victory was almost entirely due to Keith Parsons. Although as substantially built as a Somerset farmer, the Taunton-born Parsons does not bully the ball in the style of west country smiters such as Arthur Wellard or Ian Botham. He prefers the nudge, the deflection, the placement. With Richard Johnson he coaxed 47 for the ninth wicket.

But the game is a cruel one. With Warwickshire running away with it, Trescothick gave himself an over. His first ball was a wide long hop, but Mike Powell obligingly smashed it high and straight to Parsons at backward gully, where it was juggled and spilled. Parsons made some amends first by catching Powell and then by taking Neil Smith in a carbon copy of the missed opportunity, but by then Warwickshire were almost home.

Earlier in the visitors' reply Steffan Jones, forming a useful opening attack with Johnson in the absence of Andy Caddick, had given Somerset some hope with three cheap wickets, and when Powell joined Penney Warwickshire were four down for 71. But Powell, the newly appointed captain, played with fitting responsibility in a stand that put on 70 match-winning runs.

 It rained on the Rose Bowl parade. The opening game at Hampshire's £17m stadium, the Benson & Hedges Cup match against Essex, was cancelled 90 minutes before the start and the ground is so sodden that tomorrow's fixture with Surrey is already in doubt.

fields.headline: Pakistan fly in minus Shoaib
fields.trailText: Pakistan arrived in England yesterday afternoon without Shoaib Akhtar, the world's fastest bowler, immediately sparking rumours that the injury-troubled Rawalpindi Express had broken down again and created more problems for a side already burdened by controversy.
fields.body:
Pakistan arrived in England yesterday afternoon without Shoaib Akhtar, the world's fastest bowler, immediately sparking rumours that the injury-troubled Rawalpindi Express had broken down again and created more problems for a side already burdened by controversy.

According to tour officials, however, Shoaib's absence is caused by nothing more sinister than a stomach ailment that precluded him travelling.

Speaking at Heathrow yesterday, the tour manager Saeed Yawar said the fast bowler had been suffering from a stomach problem and fever for a few days. "There is nothing seriously amiss," he said.

"But his condition meant that he was not able to complete his fitness tests. As a result he has had a blood screening and we are awaiting the results of this. It is a rule of the Pakistan Cricket Board that a player cannot go on tour until he has been given the all clear. In any case there is no point in taking along a player whose fitness is in doubt."

The new captain Waqar Younis said he expected Shoaib to be well enough to join them over the next few days.

Wasim Akram, the former captain who is also in the party, criticised the restricting of Pakistan to a two-Test series. He believes they are being used merely as a warm-up act for the five-Test Ashes series later in the summer.

"I don't know why we agreed to it or why the England and Wales Cricket Board offered it to us," he said. "Although England won in Pakistan, we won the last three series here and we have more supporters here than anybody else, so it would have been a full house for a five-Test series.

"It is not an insult, but it won't be any fun. The first game you are just getting into it, the second Test you are just picking up and then there is no third match, we will be on our way home.

Matthew Hoggard has been given the all clear by the ECB to play again for Yorkshire after a scan on an injured rib revealed no serious damage.

Hoggard, centrally contracted to the England squad, damaged his rib in a fielding mishap in Canterbury last week, casting doubt on his international availability this summer. But he is now poised to vie with Dominic Cork for the last seam-bowling place for the first Test against Pakistan at Lord's.

Ted Dexter, who captained England in 30 Tests and was chairman of selectors from 1961-64, will be the new MCC president, succeeding Lord Alexander of Weedon on October 1.

fields.headline: Glamorgan fall to hammer of Bichel
fields.standfirst: Glamorgan 228-9 Worcestershire 229-5 Worcestershire won by five wickets
fields.trailText: Replacing Glenn McGrath is one of the game's less enviable tasks but on this evidence Worcestershire have made an astute choice in Andy Bichel.
fields.body:
Replacing Glenn McGrath is one of the game's less enviable tasks but on this evidence Worcestershire have made an astute choice. Andy Bichel, signed largely for his ability to take wickets, demonstrated again that Australians can usually be relied on to give value for money by scoring the first limited-overs century of his career.

His punishing innings helped Worcestershire to their second victory in the Benson & Hedges Cup inside three days and they are now well placed to qualify for the quarter-finals for the first time since 1995. Not bad for a side that failed to win a single one-day match after June 24 last season.

Bichel's batting record suggests he is nothing more than a useful tailender but, promoted to No3 when Anurag Singh was dismissed in the first over, he avoided the recklessness normally associated with a pinch-hitter. He got off the mark with a thumping cover drive off Steve Watkin and then settled down, his first fifty occupying 82 balls.

After that he changed tactics - and the course of the game. His next fifty came in 34 balls and his century came out of 150 for three. The increase in tempo was too much for those keeping score. For an embarrassingly large part of the Worcestershire innings the scoreboard gave only a general impression of what was happening and it was not altogether clear whether the applause for Bichel's century was one run premature. "It was just as well he got another single," one of the scorers was overheard to say later, but no one could quite remember how or where it had been gathered.

When he was run out for exactly 100, 77 were still needed from 15 overs. Further significant slip-ups were avoided by Vikram Solanki, David Leatherdale and Nick Boulton, who took Worcestershire to victory with some ease, although Robert Croft, bowling with a chipped bone in his left thumb, did persuade Solanki to self-destruct.

In the morning, Glamorgan's batting promised more than it delivered. Their new overseas signing Jimmy Maher looked purposeful enough before playing across a ball from Bichel, a Queensland team-mate. Maher look unimpressed with the lbw decision and the time it took umpire Vanburn Holder to give it.

If his dismissal was questionable, Steve James's was downright unlucky. Michael Powell's firm straight drive was deflected on to the stumps by Stuart Lampitt with James out of his ground. It was a significant bonus for Worcestershire because the Glamorgan captain was in the mood. Three of the seven boundaries in his innings of 49 were struck back over the head of the bowler.

Matthew Maynard and Keith Newell ensured Glamorgan had something to defend. Both scored at nearly a run a ball before Graeme Hick decided to have a go. He bowled Newell with his first ball and was instrumental in restricting Glamorgan, crucially, to 57 runs from their last 10 overs.
fields.bodyText: Replacing Glenn McGrath is one of the game's less enviable tasks but on this evidence Worcestershire have made an astute choice. Andy Bichel, signed largely for his ability to take wickets, demonstrated again that Australians can usually be relied on to give value for money by scoring the first limited-overs century of his career. His punishing innings helped Worcestershire to their second victory in the Benson & Hedges Cup inside three days and they are now well placed to qualify for the quarter-finals for the first time since 1995. Not bad for a side that failed to win a single one-day match after June 24 last season. Bichel's batting record suggests he is nothing more than a useful tailender but, promoted to No3 when Anurag Singh was dismissed in the first over, he avoided the recklessness normally associated with a pinch-hitter. He got off the mark with a thumping cover drive off Steve Watkin and then settled down, his first fifty occupying 82 balls. After that he changed tactics - and the course of the game. His next fifty came in 34 balls and his century came out of 150 for three. The increase in tempo was too much for those keeping score. For an embarrassingly large part of the Worcestershire innings the scoreboard gave only a general impression of what was happening and it was not altogether clear whether the applause for Bichel's century was one run premature. "It was just as well he got another single," one of the scorers was overheard to say later, but no one could quite remember how or where it had been gathered. When he was run out for exactly 100, 77 were still needed from 15 overs. Further significant slip-ups were avoided by Vikram Solanki, David Leatherdale and Nick Boulton, who took Worcestershire to victory with some ease, although Robert Croft, bowling with a chipped bone in his left thumb, did persuade Solanki to self-destruct. In the morning, Glamorgan's batting promised more than it delivered. Their new overseas signing Jimmy Maher looked purposeful enough before playing across a ball from Bichel, a Queensland team-mate. webTitle: The truth about life after birth

fields.headline: The truth about life after birth
fields.standfirst: Women tend to be unprepared for the gruesome reality of the days and weeks following childbirth, new research suggests.  Katharine Shaw offers an eye-opener
fields.trailText: Women tend to be unprepared for the gruesome reality of the days and weeks following childbirth, new research suggests. Katharine Shaw offers an eye-opener.
fields.body:
Zero hour

A flood of utter relief and a ripped perineum, helped by a rush of endorphins. If you do not know what a perineum is, then I pray you never find out.

20 minutes after birth

Euphoria and all that. I am distracted by sight, feel, smell of a beautiful salty, messy baby until my legs are hoisted skywards and bright lights are shone on my private parts. Unable to cope with the carnage single-handedly, the midwife calls for the obstetrician who, she claims, is a "devil with a needle". Having endured childbirth you'd think the small matter of being injected in the perineum would be a piece of cake ... ah, but no. Despite the local anaesthetic, Doctor Needlepoint tugs and jabs as if stitching up a mainsail. It would seem silly under the circumstances to make a fuss.

45 minutes

The midwife wants to tell me all about my "tear" and is slightly taken aback that I don't want the details. She takes my husband outside to explain quite how bad it is down there. When she comes back (husband with a "bright smile") she says she should put a catheter in as it might be a "bit sore" to pee. I consume handfuls of painkillers in anticipation of the anaesthetic wearing off.

One hour

Warm, flooding feeling in the bed. I ring the bell in terror assuming I'm haemorrhaging but it's just the catheter bag "malfunctioning". My stomach is still vast, as if another baby is lurking in there. The midwife explains that it takes six weeks for my womb to shrink back to normal size. She prods it regularly over the next few days to see that it is doing this and that I have not retained any of the placenta, and presumably, to rule out any lingering foetuses.

Six hours

Still haven't dared get up. It feels like someone has snuck in and battered my parts with a baseball bat. Fortunately, my baby is a great distraction.

Seven hours

Catheter is removed and I am guided to the bathroom to "get cleaned up". The bed looks like a scene from The Godfather and I look and move like Frankenstein's monster. My legs shake and ache. My head is light. I have the distinct impression that my intestines and colon are going to fall out of my vagina. But, fortunately, I am still euphoric at having produced an actual baby. I daren't sit down in the bath and I watch in dismay as a lot of blood goes everywhere. The nurse rubs me down like I'm a horse, and gives me a pad that would be adequate for one. She also gives me a pair of paper knickers. They have small pink sprigs on them, a nice touch.

Day one

I have to recline, since sitting feels life-threateningly painful. I refuse to look down there and also refuse to let my husband look as I don't want him to retain this image. He thinks I'm mad, as he saw the baby come out. My stomach is still inflated. My shoulders, oddly, ache as if I've carried a piano around for several days. My breasts are producing weird pale liquid called colostrum, that my baby laps up round the clock but other than this they don't feel any different. I have been given "stool softener" pills but apparently may not be able to "go" for quite some time.

Day two

I am still having painful "contractions". This is my womb shrinking and shouldn't persist. Walking out of the hospital is a challenge. I have to stick my bum out and take tiny steps like an ancient tribal dancer. I am dismayed that I look heavily pregnant. I am unable to sit down in the car and have to perch, one cheek on the side of the seat, swearing.

Day three

I now see the need for stool softener and can confirm that it has failed. I am genuinely alarmed by my piles. Can still barely move, let alone sit down. My boobs have inflated to the size and texture of medicine balls; my nipples are bright red and sore. Exhaustion. I keep crying. The pregnancy book explains that this is a normal hormonal day-three thing - my oestrogen and progesterone levels have "dropped precipitously". I cannot see an evolutionary need for this. The authors suggests my husband gets us a nice takeaway. Lots of blood. Oh, and I'm incontinent and fat. Apart from that, motherhood is a breeze.

Day four

My husband finally insists on taking a look at my parts. I am sure he'll never want me again, but right now couldn't care less. He claims - to my astonishment - that they look almost normal. I know he is lying because when I move I can feel the wind whistling up there and things flapping. Also, the midwife told me she put in purple stitches. Love is a wonderful thing.

Week two

Still incontinent. Still fat. Breastfeeding is hell. My baby eats at least once an hour (what happened to "four-hourly schedules"?) My nipples are cracked. I am variously engorged and completely milk-free. And I now have a suspicious red, painful lump on one breast. The midwife says it's a "blocked duct" and I should massage it and steam it. A day later, the whole side of the boob is red and enflamed and feels like someone is sticking hot knives into it. I have a fever. Midwife diagnoses mastitis - an infection of the milk ducts - and prescribes rest (ha), steaming them over a pan of hot water, massage and antibiotics.

Week three

The mastitis takes three days of agony and gradually dissipating fever and four more of low-grade pain to disperse. And I have to keep breastfeeding through the pain. I can now walk, but after any time on my feet I feel, again, that someone has battered my perineum with a hard object.

Week six

My book talks about "easing back into sex". One of the tips is "don't be discouraged by pain". Hello? My hair is falling out and I am two stone overweight. My stretch marks are angry red and my belly looks like a crumpled, partially deflated balloon. I tried to do some pelvic floor exercises but was unable to locate a single responsive muscle. I have also just noticed another red lump on the same breast. Sexy?

Week seven

Another week, another bout of mastitis, course of antibiotics. Fretful baby. I have been told that his elephantine wind problem could be a result of dairy produce in my diet and so have cut it out. He is still farting and writhing. I have had no sleep and am depressed. My health visitor gives me a questionnaire to check whether I have post-natal depression. Apparently not. My depression is, she says, "normal".

Week eight

Life is, at last, looking up. The piles have almost gone. I can now walk for half an hour without pain but my bladder control is dodgy. However, I slept for three consecutive hours two nights in a row and I managed to faintly twitch my pelvic floor yesterday. Still exhausted. Still fat. But my baby smiles now as well as farts. Which somehow makes it all worthwhile. Sort of.

fields.headline: Take my breath away
fields.standfirst: It can destroy your personal life and your confidence - and it's all in your mind, not your mouth.  Sarah Ebner  reports on halitophobia - the irrational fear of having bad breath
fields.trailText: It can destroy your personal life and your confidence - and it's all in your mind, not your mouth. Sarah Ebner reports on halitophobia - the irrational fear of having bad breath.
fields.body:
Alix Taylor seemed to be spending rather a large part of her working day in the bathroom. But there was nothing wrong with her bladder. Taylor, 27, was simply brushing her teeth. "It sounds ridiculous, but I used to bring a toothbrush and toothpaste into work with me," she says, looking a little shamefaced. "I simply couldn't be without them. I used to brush my teeth about 10 times a day. I also chewed gum the whole time because I was sure I had bad breath. I hated being in lifts with people and worried about travelling on the tube. I just didn't want to be in close proximity to anyone. I was really paranoid."

But Taylor did not have bad breath. She was suffering from the latest in a seemingly endless assortment of modern terrors - "halitophobia", or the fear of having bad breath.

Help is now available for Taylor and others like her, with the somewhat improbable launch of a self-help group called Halitophobics Anonymous. It aims to help those deluded souls who are convinced, wrongly, that they have bad breath.

Dr Philip Stemmer, clinical director of the Fresh Breath Centre, a specialist oral hygiene practice in London, and the driving force behind Halitophobics Anonymous, claims that an astonishing 1% of the British population (650,000 of us) have halitophobia in "one form or another". He says that he set up the group because he noticed that many people who sought his help did not need it, at least for their breath.

"Halitophobia is a condition whereby people think they have halitosis when they haven't, or imagine they have enormous problems when they only have very minor ones," says Stemmer. "It is not a new problem, but it has only recently been recognised."

It is almost impossible to detect your own bad breath and this fuels the anxiety, which can lead to a pre-occupation with tooth-brushing, gum-chewing or mint-sucking. In a society in which we are under constant pressure to look and smell good, halitosis is about as desirable as foot and mouth disease. This is despite the fact that research suggests 98% of us have bad breath - usually caused by bacteria which coat the teeth and gums - at some point in our lives.

"Phobias are very common," says Cosmo Hallstrom, a consultant psychiatrist and medical director of the Florence Nightingale clinic in Chelsea, London. "They are mostly minor but can get out of control. The problem occurs when you start trying to avoid your phobia. You need to confront it or it will get worse.

"I think there is a propensity in all of us to develop particular phobias at certain times in life. Halitophobia could develop quite innocently, through a minor breath problem. They try to avoid it and take a mint. Then they want something stronger and start brushing their teeth a lot, but it is never quite enough. The phobia builds up and takes over. For example, they may be rejected by a partner and blame that on the bad breath they think they have. Life gets miserable and they blame their breath."

Blaming misfortune on bad breath is exactly what Joe Wallace did. He had never been unduly concerned about his breath until an argument with his daughter. "I can't even remember what the argument was about now," says Wallace, 45. "But I do remember that she told me not to shout at her because I stank. I was devastated and couldn't understand why no one had ever told me before."

His wife said their daughter was just "winding him up" but it was too late. "I started chewing gum a lot, which drove my wife mad," he says. "I also noticed people watching me on the tube. Perhaps it was because my constant chewing was annoying, but I was convinced that it was because the gum wasn't properly masking my breath."

Two dentists told Wallace his breath was fine. "It didn't help," he says. "I was really sensitive. I was having a bad time at work and began thinking it was because I was making other people's lives a misery by breathing on them. I started to cover my mouth when I talked."

The crunch came when Wallace lost his job. He sank into a depression and convinced himself that his problems were all due to his (non-existent) halitosis.

"Eventually my doctor sent me to a psychiatrist for my depression," he says. "Luckily she realised I needed to see someone for the phobia and I went to a psychologist. I now feel much more confident."

There are many different kinds of phobia, - whether irrational fear of objects, situations, or creatures. Most common are social phobias such as fear of public speaking or heights, and fear of animals or insects (often snakes and spiders).

Some people also have a fear of their own body odour, or suffer from dysmorphia, also known as "imagined ugliness syndrome", which makes them obsessed with a perceived defect in their appearance. Halitophobia simply hasn't been discussed seriously before.

Taylor had never had any sort of phobia until a friend asked her if she had brushed her teeth one day. "It hit a nerve. I probably did have bad breath, but that comment gave me a problem that was psychological rather than medical," she says. It took years before another friend told Taylor she couldn't spend her life brushing her teeth. That prompted her to visit the Fresh Breath Centre. "They told me I had a little gum disease but after I had been about four times, they said I was better," she says. "I didn't believe them. It was still making my life a misery."

The problem remained until Taylor was introduced to some fellow sufferers. "It was brilliant to find out that I wasn't the only one and made me see my situation in a different light. I still use mouthwash and brush my teeth, but it doesn't play such a large role in my life. I'm so much happier and more confident. I can even see now how ridiculous I was being before."

The only obvious downside to all this is that the help offered by this new group is not free: far from it. The introductory meeting costs £10, then after that a course of six sessions costs £95. Whether or not you think it is worth it will depend on how desperate you are - and how much you spend in an average month on mints and mouthwashes.

fields.headline: Monitoring new drugs
fields.standfirst: New drugs may have side effects which - at worst - kill. So why not change how they are monitored?
fields.trailText: New drugs may have side effects which - at worst - kill. So why not change how they are monitored?
fields.body:
What is a black triangle? Some tricky little sign that we have all forgotten from the Highway Code? No? Well, let's try an easier one - what is the yellow card (but not the one the referee waves after a dodgy tackle)?

A minority of people are likely to know the significance of these colour codes in relation to prescription medicines prescribed by GPs and yet they are important to us all. The yellow card is the form a doctor fills in and sends off to the medicines control agency if he is concerned that a patient has had a serious side-effect from a particular drug. The black triangle on the information sheet sent to doctors by the manufacturer tells them that the drug is less than two years old. Doctors are supposed to report all side-effects of black triangle drugs - not just the serious ones.

These are the nuts and bolts of what is known as pharmaco-vigilance in the UK, a system set up to prevent what happened with Thalidomide occurring again. Clinical trials do not show spot problems that may occur in a tiny minority of people, or what may happen to long-term users. Yellow cards and black triangles form a safety net which has alerted the authorities to unexpected harmful effects of licensed medicines and averted disasters.

A new drug should be under intense scrutiny. Look at Zyban, the new, black-triangle, anti-smoking drug. There have been 35 deaths among users so far. Each one is reported and investigated. The MCA and the manufacturers say that in each case, so far, there has been a separate underlying cause, such as lung disease caused by cigarettes or, in the case of the air stewardess who died, the combination of Zyban and anti-malarial drugs. Deaths are pretty well always reported, but not so some of the other side-effects of medicines. The Consumers Association points out that a staggering 6% of all hospital admissions are caused by adverse effects of drugs. Surely the detection system should have been prevented some of them?

In fact, there are major problems with the safety net. The Drug and Therapeutics Bulletin, a respected journal sent to all doctors, recently did a survey which found that a quarter of information sheets on new drugs sent to doctors by manufacturers did not carry the black triangle symbol. It also found that the information about the sort of side-effects on the liver that certain powerful drugs could cause was inadequate.

Doctors are busy. If Mrs Robinson arrives with a headache, they aren't going to fill in a yellow card if they don't see a black triangle, unless they happen to know the drug she is on is only 18 months old. The Bulletin thinks that patients could be put at risk and wants the MCA to act. But there are other, longstanding weaknesses. Doctors don't have to fill in a yellow form. It is voluntary. Some doctors fill in stacks, some hardly any - the average is less than one a year per doctor.

Then there is the patient. Things may be changing, but historically the British patient doesn't want to trouble the doctor, particularly with something minor and mildly embarrassing like diarrhoea. But it could be a warning sign of something serious. In an age of increasingly powerful new drugs, there are those who think the yellow card system just isn't good enough. The Consumers Association wants patients themselves to fill in yellow cards and post them off to the MCA. The idea was immediately slapped down by the Department of Health on behalf of the MCA. Health professionals are better placed to make appropriate judgments on potential side-effects was the response.

It is an answer that smacks of the patriarchal attitudes that modernisation of the NHS is supposed to be trying to oust and ill at odds with all we have been told by the politicians about a health service led by consumers. If the MCA has a better answer, perhaps it should tell us.
fields.bodyText: What is a black triangle? Some tricky little sign that we have all forgotten from the Highway Code? No? Well, let's try an easier one - what is the yellow card (but not the one the referee waves after a dodgy tackle)? A minority of people are likely to know the significance of these colour codes in relation to prescription medicines prescribed by GPs and yet they are important to us all. The yellow card is the form a doctor fills in and sends off to the medicines control agency if he is concerned that a patient has had a serious side-effect from a particular drug. The black triangle on the information sheet sent to doctors by the manufacturer tells them that the drug is less than two years old. Doctors are supposed to report all side-effects of black triangle drugs - not just the serious ones. These are the nuts and bolts of what is known as pharmaco-vigilance in the UK, a system set up to prevent what happened with Thalidomide occurring again. Clinical trials do not show spot problems that may occur in a tiny minority of people, or what may happen to long-term users. Yellow cards and black triangles form a safety net which has alerted the authorities to unexpected harmful effects of licensed medicines and averted disasters. A new drug should be under intense scrutiny. Look at Zyban, the new, black-triangle, anti-smoking drug. There have been 35 deaths among users so far. Each one is reported and investigated. The MCA and the manufacturers say that in each case, so far, there has been a separate underlying cause, such as lung disease caused by cigarettes or, in the case of the air stewardess who died, the combination of Zyban and anti-malarial drugs. Deaths are pretty well always reported, but not so some of the other side-effects of medicines. The Consumers Association points out that a staggering 6% of all hospital admissions are caused by adverse effects of drugs. Surely the detection system should have been prevented some of them? In fact, there are major problems with the safety net. The Drug and Therapeutics Bulletin, a respected journal sent to all doctors, recently did a survey which found that a quarter of information sheets on new drugs sent to doctors by manufacturers did not carry the black triangle symbol. It also found that the information about the sort of side-effects on the liver that certain powerful drugs could cause was inadequate. Doctors are busy. If Mrs Robinson arrives with a headache, they aren't going to fill in a yellow card if they don't see a black triangle, unless they happen to know the drug she is on is only 18 months old. The Bulletin thinks that patients could be put at risk and wants the MCA to act. But there are other, longstanding weaknesses. Doctors don't have to fill in a yellow form. It is voluntary. Some doctors fill in stacks, some hardly any - the average is less than one a year per doctor. Then there is the patient. Things may be changing, but historically the British patient doesn't want to trouble the doctor, particularly with something minor and mildly embarrassing like diarrhoea. But it could be a warning sign of something serious. In an age of increasingly powerful new drugs, there are those who think the yellow card system just isn't good enough. If the MCA has a better answer, perhaps it should tell us.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson  on morning sickness, stomach cancer, a complication caused by glandular fever and traces of blood in urine
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson on morning sickness, stomach cancer, a complication caused by glandular fever and traces of blood in urine.
fields.body:
Morning sickness

Q I am six weeks pregnant and being very sick. I have tried homeopathy, acupuncture, yoga, eating all the time, not eating all the time, hot water - nothing works. My GP said I can take an antihistamine that is safe in pregnancy and will help the nausea but I really don't want to take any drugs. What can I do?

A Ginger. Gingerbread or biscuits, ginger beer - anything with ginger in it. Seventy pregnant Thai women were divided into two groups. One group took a gram of ginger a day for four days, the others swallowed a placebo. The ginger group said they felt less sick and vomited less, the placebo group reported no change.

Blood group query

Q I read a review of a book that purported to link blood groups with diet. The reviewer dismissed these claims but did say that there was a higher risk of developing stomach cancer if your blood group is A. Is this true?

A It is not really clear why we have different blood groups - it is assumed that in evolutionary terms having a particular blood group in a particular time and place conferred some advantage in fighting infections and surviving. The commonest blood group in the UK is O, and A is the second commonest. Any evolutionary advantage has almost certainly disappeared and we are all much of muchness from a blood-group point of view. The association between blood group A and stomach cancer is weak and dates from a time when blood group was one of the few variables that could be tested for. It is possibly still true that if you take everyone with stomach cancer, you find a slightly higher than average number of people with blood group A. But if you take the huge numbers of healthy people who happen to be blood group A, it is unlikely that they have a statistically higher than average chance of developing stomach, or any other, cancer.

A nasty rash

Q I am a 19-year-old law student. I have had lots of antibiotics courses for sore throats and have never had a bad reaction. Two weeks ago, I had a particularly awful throat and could hardly swallow. I felt completely wretched and had a high temperature and swollen glands in my neck. My GP gave me amoxycillin. I then developed an itchy red rash from head to toe. I phoned NHS Direct and was told it was probably an allergic reaction and to see my GP. Why I should develop an allergy to amoxycillin?

A If your sore throat was due to glandular fever, the antibiotic may have triggered the rash because there can be a cross-reaction between the antibodies produced when you have the infection and the antibiotic itself. You could ask for a blood test called Paul-Bunnell which will tell you whether you have glandular fever. It is useful to know because if so, you can expect to feel off colour for a variable length of time - anything from one to several weeks, which may be important if you have exams looming. The virus responsible is Epstein-Barr, a member of the herpes family. It is usually a mild, though unpleasant disease from which you should make a complete recovery with no specific treatment (there is none). You can spread the virus by kissing or exchanging saliva.

Blood and water

Q I had to have a medical for an insurance policy. When the doctor tested my urine, she said it showed some blood present. I have since heard that the test showed no infection. My GP rechecked the urine and also found a small amount of blood. I was advised to ignore it but the insurance company insists I see a specialist before it issues the policy. Should I worry?

A You are probably going to have to see a urologist (waterworks specialist) or nephrologist (kidney specialist) if you want the policy. There is a big debate in medical circles among people interested in these things as to whether or not you can safely ignore painless bleeding into the urine which only shows up on testing and is not visible to the naked eye. It appears that around 10% of adults over 25 have this sort of problem, if indeed it is a problem at all. Blood tests can show that your kidneys are functioning normally and really that is all that the insurer should need to issue your policy.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: Former Sunday Express man sets up PR firm

fields.headline: Former Sunday Express man sets up PR firm
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Simon Young, former assistant editor of the Sunday Express, has set up his own PR consultancy, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The former assistant editor of the Sunday Express, Simon Young, has set up his own PR consultancy after taking voluntary redundancy from the newspaper.

Mr Young is this week launching his own agency, SJY Media.

The agency aims to offer clients PR support, including general publicity, media relations and crisis management.

It also hopes to provide larger agencies with expert media and crisis communications advice.

Mr Young has wasted no time in striking out on his own. He left the Sunday Express last month in the tide of redundancies following Richard Desmond's arrival at Express Newspapers.

Mr Young joined the newspaper in 1995 as a reporter and moved through the ranks to become assistant editor.

He previously worked on the Daily Star, Sunday Times and the Sun.

fields.headline: Ramblers on rampage with Express
fields.trailText: 10am: The Ramblers Association has complained to press watchdogs about an article in the Sunday Express which blamed ramblers for the spread of foot and mouth, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Ramblers Association has written a furious letter to the Press Complaints Commission following the publication of a spoof article in the Sunday Express which blamed ramblers for the spread of foot and mouth.

But the PCC is believed to have rejected the claim on the grounds that the article was a joke.

A letter to the PCC from the chief executive of the association, Nick Barrett,sent in March, condemns the "odious" article as "inaccurate" and warns that it could "incite violence".

And it asks the PCC to help secure a 600-word article in the Sunday Express's news pages "devoted to an accurate examination of the true causes of the disease and of the voluntary restrictions imposed by many groups as an act of sympathy".

The letter was prompted by a joke article, written under the byline of a fictitious "Colonel Pinstripe", entitled "Filthy ramblers are to blame".

"Are we right to burn poor animals with foot and mouth?" asked the column, published in March.

"What about turning our attention instead to the real perpetrators of the foul disease?" the piece continues.

"These are the so-called 'ramblers', who constantly wander across our land, depositing their mess and litter everywhere, leaving gates open and generally going where they are not wanted.

"They wallow in their own filth and are far more disgusting and dirty in their personal habits than the pigs I keep in my own backyard."

Later on, "Colonel Pinstripe" says that "it" - that is, a cull of ramblers - "could all be done quite humanely".

"They would probably squeal a bit at first, but a club-hammer to the back of the head would soon stop that."

The Ramblers Association does not appear to have accepted that the article was a joke.

In the letter, Mr Barrett says he is "particularly concerned by the author's suggestion that ramblers should be rounded up and disposed of."

And the letter continues: "Not one in over 200 confirmed cases of foot and mouth disease has been attributed to the actions of a recreational walker."

A spokeswoman for the Ramblers Association was not prepared to comment on the contents of the complaint made to the PCC.

The PCC also confirmed that the complaint had been dropped, but was not prepared to go any further.

The closure of Nova magazine will see the loss of 20 journalists jobs at IPC.

"Persistence pays off" for Tristan Davies, who has taken over as editor of the Independent on Sunday.

The former Mirror editor David Leigh has left the paper after 12 years to join the Daily Express as assistant editor, news.

A news agency reporter told he would be on call 24-hours a day has become the UK's first employee to win an unfair dismissal case involving the new Working Time regulations.

fields.headline: Millbank attacks tactical vote 'myth'
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Labour's campaign high command has ordered election candidates not to promote tactical voting after high-profile party supporters called on voters to back the Liberal Democrats to keep out Conservatives.
fields.body:
Labour's campaign high command has ordered election candidates not to promote tactical voting after high-profile party supporters called on voters to back the Liberal Democrats to keep out Conservatives.

A leaked memo from Labour's Millbank headquarters instructs candidates on a "line to take" against tactical voting, and describes as a "mythology" the widespread view that tactical votes contributed to the party's landslide victory at the last election.

The order follows calls by the leftwing singer Billy Bragg for tactical agreements between Liberal Democrat and Labour supporters to oust Tory MPs in marginal seats at the coming general election, and the creation of a website linking anti-Tory tactical voters.

An article in the leftwing newspaper Tribune by its former editor Paul Anderson also urged tactical votes for the Liberal Democrats, though the paper later made clear that it opposed the strategy after protests from readers.

Millbank's attempt to stamp on talk of tactical voting in advance of the election will be seen as an attempt to soothe disquiet among activists concerned that a clear election message of support for Labour could be obscured.

It also reflects a sense among traditional party members that Labour's significant poll lead means it no longer needs to contemplate cooperation with the Lib Dems, nor the electoral reform, leading to a system of proportional representation, sought by supporters of the Lib-Lab project.

But prospective parliamentary candidates in some seats where Labour is in third place claim that many supporters are preparing again to vote Liberal Democrat to oust or keep out a Conservative.

One candidate suggested early canvassing returns reflected a "seismic shift" to the Liberal Democrats from Labour in the south-west, reflecting last year's byelection in Romsey, Hampshire. The Lib Dems snatched the Tory seat on a 12% swing, while the Labour candidate lost his deposit.

The Millbank memo of April 27, which refers to the Tribune article, tells candidates: "Line to take: We do not endorse a campaign of tactical voting. We have Labour candidates in every seat and urge all voters to vote Labour."

It adds: "There is a mythology about tactical voting which would have us believe that we only won in 1997 because a lot of people voted for us who are really Liberal Democrats.

"In fact there are very few committed Liberal Democrats, their support has a huge turnover from one election to the next. Probably less tactical voting took place in 1997 than it ever had before and to our gain."

The voting analyst John Curtice, deputy director of the Economic and Social Research Council's centre for research into elections and social trends, last night ridiculed as "absolute rubbish" Millbank's suggestion that tactical voting played no part in Labour's 1997 victory.

Tactical voting in 1997 gained Labour an estimated 15-21 seats from the Tories and the Liberal Democrats a further 10-14, he added. But local elections since 1997 indicated tactical voting was now "unravelling" as the Tory "ogre" diminished.

fields.headline: City Slicker lambasts Morgan
fields.trailText: Ex-Mirror reporter James Hipwell has launched a stinging attack on the paper's editor, Piers Morgan, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
James Hipwell, one of the two former City Slickers on the Mirror who were sacked amid allegations of insider dealing, has launched a stinging attack on the paper's editor, Piers Morgan.

Mr Hipwell defended himself and his former colleague, Anil Bhoyrul, against Mr Morgan's claim in an interview in MediaGuardian last week they had "got off lightly" from the Press Complaints Commission and the paper during the scandal.

"In reality, Piers is the one who got off lightly," wrote Mr Hipwell.

"There is no difference between what we did and what he did, save the volume of trading. We might have bought into a few more companies but, in the main, his investments were larger, as you would expect from someone on £300k a year."

He continued: "And whereas we got fired for gross misconduct, Piers got editorial control of another newspaper."

In the interview in trade magazine Press Gazette, Hipwell also claimed that when he and Mr Bhoyrul were working on the City Slickers desk, they were instructed "to shake things up a bit".

In his article he criticised the PCC's rules on share dealing and said he and Mr Bhoyrul - with the approval of Mr Morgan - effectively ignored the regulations.

"Our response was to dip our toes into the waters of the stock market - with the implicit agreement of our editor," he wrote.

Mr Hipwell also claimed: "If journalists were given the incentive to write proper share tips (by risking their own cash) you can bet your bottom dollar more research would be carried out to find good companies."

Later on in the piece, he extended his criticism of Mr Morgan to other Trinity Mirror executives, saying they "bailed out" of the popular column as soon as conditions became "choppy".

And he claimed the company manipulated the image of the Slickers to make them look like "a couple of barrow boys", an image which was "totally alien" to them.

Mr Hipwell, who is now working as a PR consultant with Max Clifford, is still under investigation by the department of trade and industry along with Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Morgan.

fields.headline: Labouring the point
fields.standfirst:
New bid to bring Blair down to earth with a bump

Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Undaunted by his record as the first prime minister to father a child while in office, the Tories have decided to bless Tony Blair with even greater powers.
fields.body:
Undaunted by his record as the first prime minister to father a child while in office, the Tories have decided to bless Tony Blair with even greater powers.

With a week to go until the general election is expected to be called, the Tories yesterday unveiled a poster which depicted the prime minister as heavily pregnant.

Next to the slogan "four years of Labour and he still hasn't delivered", a smiling prime minister is pictured in a v-necked sweater proudly patting his bump.

The poster, a spoof of the famous 1970s Saatchi and Saatchi family planning advertisement, right, is designed to ram home the message that the government has failed to deliver despite its grand promises in 1997.

Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet office minister who unveiled the poster, said: "The British public has been waiting for a delivery that hasn't happened - it is the longest gestation period in history." Labour had broken its promises on more police officers, NHS waiting lists and taxes since taking power in 1997, he added.

He dismissed a series of opinion polls which indicated that the Tories could be heading for a worse result than their crushing defeat of 1997. "These things are not as important as the policies and the issues during the campaign," he said.

Margaret Beckett, the Commons leader, said the Tories had "nothing to offer but cynicism and cuts". The Tory poster, which was dreamed up by the party's Yellow M advertising agency, was inspired by the 1970s Saatchi and Saatchi family planning poster. A pregnant man in a jumper was pictured over the slogan: "Would you be more careful if it was you that was pregant?"

The Maternity Alliance laughed off the poster, although Christine Gowdridge, its spokeswoman, admitted: "The Saatchi poster was fantastically successful. Maybe the Tories are onto something."

webTitle: Hague may be on way out

fields.headline: Hague may be on way out, grassroots Tories reassure waverers
fields.standfirst:
Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: With his opinion poll ratings at an all-time low, William Hague might have expected some support from one of the Conservatives' safest seats in Britain.
fields.body:
With his opinion poll ratings at an all-time low, William Hague might have expected some support from one of the Conservatives' safest seats in Britain.

But activists in the Tory stronghold of Bridgwater in Somerset are planning to take out newspaper advertisements to reassure wavering voters that Mr Hague could still be replaced if they vote for the party.

Alarmed by the hostile views of Mr Hague on Bridgwater's doorsteps, Tories are planning to spend nearly £3,000 to run a series of half page advertisements in local newspapers during the four-week election campaign.

A leaked memo from the constituency of the retiring former defence secretary, Tom King, who won a 15,248 ma jority in 1997, says that the advertisments would "explain to Conservatives who do not like William Hague that the only way to find a new leader is to get the Conservatives in power under William Hague so that a new leader can emerge from the more unknown Conservative members of parliament".

Tories in Bridgwater denied that the memo was an attack on Mr Hague. David Stickland, a local Tory member, said: "It was not meant to be anti-William Hague. It just means that there were quite a number of people who are anti-William Hague and I just want to say to them in this area let's get him in and give him a chance."

But Tony Blair mocked the memo in the Commons yesterday, saying that there was a "very broad field" of hopeful Tory leaders. Tory MPs reacted furiously and rounded on the Commons Speaker, Michael Martin, for allowing the prime minister to read the memo. Mr Martin angrily intervened, telling the Tories: "Don't tell me how to do my job."

A red-faced Mr Martin turned on the rightwing Tory MP Gerald Howarth, who led the protests, saying: "I hope you weren't referring to me. I know how to conduct my affairs. I hope you are not attacking the chair."

webTitle: Train robber Biggs to return to UK

fields.headline: Train robber Biggs to return to UK
fields.standfirst:
Talk: should Ronnie Biggs serve his time?

From the archive: Train robbery trial report
fields.trailText: Great train robber Ronnie Biggs has told police he plans to return to Britain after 35 years on the run, Scotland Yard revealed today.
fields.body:
Great train robber Ronnie Biggs has told police he plans to return to Britain after 35 years on the run, Scotland Yard revealed today.

Mr Biggs is prepared to face arrest when he flies into the country from his home in Rio de Janeiro. The 71-year old claimed he is in failing health after recently suffering his third stroke.

Explaining his reasons for giving himself up, Mr Biggs said: "I am a sick man. My last wish is to walk into a Margate pub as an Englishman and buy a pint of bitter.

"I hope I live long enough to do that."

Mike Gray, who has been a pen pal of Mr Biggs for 12 years and runs RonnieBiggs.com, a website dedicated to the villain, said: "It is something we have been talking about for the last 12 months".

Asked when Mr Biggs planned to return, he said: "Within the week is the rumour from Brazil." He said that it depended on how quickly he could get a passport from the British government.

Mr Biggs's one-page email, addressed to Detective Chief Superintendent John Coles, head of Scotland Yard's serious and organised crime group, read: "To Mr John Coles, Scotland Yard, London.

"I would like to give myself up to you. What I need is passport documentation to travel back to Britain.

"I'm prepared to be arrested at the gate when I arrive at Heathrow airport to submit myself to the due process of the law."

He also included a thumbprint, which can be linked to his police records to prove the email is genuine.

The fugitive is now debt-ridden and the latest of a series of strokes has left him partially paralysed and unable to speak.

"I think it is because his health is deteriorating all the time. For the past 12 months... it has been getting worse," Mr Gray said.

"He has this love for England... he does not want to die in Brazil."

He said that Biggs's son would accompany him on the flight back to Britain if the necessary documentation was obtained.

Mr Biggs was part of a gang that escaped with a then record £2.6m after holding up a Glasgow to London night train in 1963.

The train's driver, Jack Mills, was coshed as the gang boarded the train near Cheddington, Buckinghamshire, in a robbery immortalised in the film Buster.

Ronnie Biggs was sentenced to 30 years but, after only 15 months, he escaped from Wandsworth prison in south London by scaling a 25ft wall on a rope ladder and jumping into an open-top furniture van with a mattress inside.

He fled abroad and settled in Brazil in 1970. His son Michael was born there, making him ineligible for extradition.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, has said that if Mr Biggs entered the UK he should be returned to prison. She said that the home secretary had the power to release prisoners on compassionate grounds, but that this should be used only when they are "in imminent danger of death ... not just with an illness that will eventually result in death".

webTitle: How the great train robber has eluded justice

fields.headline: How the great train robber has eluded justice
fields.standfirst:
Ronnie Biggs could finally be coming home after 35 years on the run. Find out here how he evaded the law for so long

Talk: should Ronnie Biggs serve his time?

From the archive: Train robbery trial report
fields.trailText: Ronnie Biggs could finally be coming home after 35 years on the run. Find out here how he evaded the law for so long.
fields.body:
Ronnie Biggs could finally be coming home after 35 years on the run. The ailing 71-year-old has emailed Scotland Yard declaring he is prepared to face jail for a pint in a Margate pub.

Biggs was part of a gang which stole £2.6m from a mail train in the early hours of August 8, 1963.

Train driver Jack Mills, 57, was coshed with iron bars during the robbery. He never returned to work and never made a full recovery. He died in 1970.

Biggs's personal share of the haul was £147,000 - worth about £1.6m in today's terms. Biggs faces nearly 29 years behind bars should he return to Britain, although the actual sentence is likely to be reduced because of his age and the time which has elapsed since he escaped.

He was jailed for 30 years, but escaped from London's Wandsworth prison in 1965 after serving just 15 months.

After he escaped - in a furniture van - Biggs took his wife Charmaine and sons, Farley and Chris, now in their thirties, to Spain. He spent two months there convalescing after having plastic surgery to change his appearance. After being tracked down by Scotland Yard to Australia, Biggs fled to Brazil, where he has lived since. He arrived in Brazil in 1970 when the country had no extradition treaty with the UK.

Scotland Yard detective Jack Slipper, who spent his career trying to get Biggs returned to Britain, arrested him in Rio in 1974.

But the train robber successfully argued against extradition because he had a Brazilian dependent, a young son, Michael, by his girlfriend Raimunda. Michael is no longer legally reliant on his father.

Biggs's luck continued when, in April 1977, he met some ratings from the British frigate Danae, in Rio for a courtesy visit. He went aboard for a few drinks but was not arrested.

In 1978 Biggs recorded No One is Innocent, for the Sex Pistols. During the lean times in Rio, he also raised money by selling T-shirts of himself and entertaining Japanese tourists.

In March 1981 he was kidnapped in Rio by a gang of adventurers and smuggled to Barbados by boat. Their aim was to bring him back to Britain.

But the Barbados high court decided the rules governing extradition to Britain had not been properly put before the island's parliament, and Biggs, being allowed to return to Rio, escaped again.

In January 1994 Biggs published his autobiography, Odd Man Out. After reading the book Jack Slipper wrote: "I don't know if I'd go so far as to say I liked him after reading the book. But I admit he's a likeable character - the sort of person whose company I'd enjoy if we met, say, on holiday."

In 1997 the Brazilian supreme court rejected a new request by the British government to extradite him. In March 1998 he suffered a stroke which temporarily left him unable to speak.

webTitle: David McKie: Poll the other one

fields.headline: Poll the other one
fields.trailText: According to a senior adviser to the Queen, support for republicanism is no higher now than it was in the days of William IV and Victoria.
fields.body:
According to a senior adviser to the Queen, talking to the Observer's columnist Pendennis, support for republicanism is no higher now than it was in the days of William IV and Victoria. "It's such a shame," he mused, "that polling doesn't have a longer history." Well, exactly. "Who do you think would make the best leader for the children of Israel: Moses? Aaron? Joshua, son of Nun? Caleb, son of Jephunneh? None of these?"

It is pretty clear that this question was being assiduously asked in the wilderness (see Numbers, chapter 14), though not of course with the rigid sampling techniques favoured by Professor Robert M Worcester. And even where there is a history, it is often hard to get at. Few of the many thousands of questions with which people with clipboards have pestered unfortunate citizens over the years can be disinterred without a disproportionate struggle. So it's welcome to find a new book called British Political Opinion 1937-2000, compiled by Robert J Wybrow and edited by Professor Anthony King, which plots what, according to Gallup, we thought at the time on a wealth of issues from the advisability of restoring Churchill to office to the case for moving straight to Prince William on the death of our present Queen.

In some ways the book is frustrating: such a wealth of figures, with so little attempt to put them in context, despite the fact that the professor is an acknowledged whizz at psephological whys and wherefores. But prepare, even without such guidance, to be surprised. Life is not always, perhaps not often, quite as we remember it. Dissatisfaction with the government's conduct of the second world war peaked not in 1940, when Chamberlain was replaced, but in March 1942. In April 1979, a month before Thatcher's triumph, the Tories led Labour as the party best equipped to deliver a fair society. In 1988, when respondents were asked which of the party leaders would make the best prime minister, one of the leaders went unmentioned by anyone.(You will have to wait to the end for the answer to that one.*)

But my favourite finding of all comes when Gallup asks voters where they would place various party leaders on a left-right scale. That 4% in the decade 1980-90 assigned Margaret Thatcher to the far left is almost beyond belief. There are few richer delights in the study of polls than the discovery of contrarians. Sometimes responses like these have the smack of mischief-making about them. An ICM poll for the Mirror in September last year found that 1% of respondents thought the battle of Britain 60 years earlier had been fought with the Romans, while 4% said the Normans. Asked who had been leading Britain in those fateful days, 2% (6%18-24s) said King Alfred, and 1% (2% of 18-24s) Margaret Thatcher. Were all of these people serious?

As you browse through ICM's polls for the Guardian through last year, other findings, less spectacularly shocking but still decidedly curious, leap out and thwack you. Here are 1% of avowed Labour supporters, asking which party they'd least like to see winning the next election, replying: Labour. Here are 1% classing nurses and teachers in the category more often reserved for journalists and estate agents: devoid of public respect. Here are 22% of Conservatives - in March, well before the autumn of discontent - saying that if Gordon Brown needs more money he should shove up the tax on petrol. Elsewhere we find 20% of Conservative respondents agreeing that the monarchy is no longer necessary.

Who are these people? Some are having a bit of fun at the clipboard's expense. Some are the kind of curmudgeons who tell the annual British Social Attitudes survey that the government is spending too much on assistance to carers. Some may be simply perverse, like the 0.4% who boast - the last BSA survey again - that if the government tried to deter use of the motor car by doubling the price of petrol they would use their cars even more. Or confused, like the people who told ICM early this year that although they did not think mobile phones a health hazard, they would not themselves, on those grounds, use a mobile phone.

But let us not disparage dissent. Some of the pollsters' contrarians are motivated by nothing worse than determination to think for themselves and not to succumb to mere fashion. What a shame, though, that not one of these people could have been found to put up a hand for the party leader who in 1988 went unmentioned by anyone. *Who was, by the way, Robert Maclennan, briefly leader of the doomed SDP. Go on, admit it: you'd forgotten him too.

 British Political Opinion 1937-2000: the Gallup Polls, published by Politico's, £30

fields.headline: Checks on locums 'insufficient'
fields.trailText: Patient safety may be at risk because hospitals have inadequate systems for rooting out incompetent doctors, according to the commission for health improvement (CHI), the health service inspectorate.
fields.body:
Patient safety may be at risk because hospitals have inadequate systems for rooting out incompetent doctors, according to the commission for health improvement (CHI), the health service inspectorate.

CHI today published a damning report into the case of an elderly pathologist who misdiagnosed more than 200 cancer patients.

It severely criticises four NHS trusts and the Department of Health (DoH) over the scandal and warns that hospitals up and down the country are still failing to make adequate checks when employing temporary locum doctors.

Dr Peter Homa, chief executive of CHI, said: "The continuing failure by hospitals across the country to follow basic procedures in appointing locum consultants must, inevitably, raise concerns about patient safety. They need to be addressed with urgency and determination."

The CHI report was ordered after it emerged that 79-year-old Dr James Elwood, a consultant pathologist, had wrongly diagnosed more than 200 cancer patients at the Princess Margaret Hospital in Swindon.

Dr Elwood had worked as a locum pathologist in three other trusts - the Royal United Hospital Bath trust, the Mid-Sussex trust and Frimley Park Hospitals trust - between 1995 and 1999.

Despite concerns being raised about his performance as early as 1995, investigations did not start until 1999.

In the biggest ever review of tests ever conducted, more than 10,000 diagnoses by Dr Elwood had to be rechecked.

More than 200 people were found to have been wrongly diagnosed, seven of whom suffered serious consequences as a result.

One woman had a breast removed unnecessarily and another patient was left in a "life-threatening" condition. The commission's report found that all four trusts had failed to carry out even basic checks on Dr Elwood's background and career when he came to work for them.

It said: "The four trusts failed to use adequate safeguards when employing Dr Elwood in terms of obtaining references, checking career history, in interviewing, in carrying out health checks and in his induction."

The report was not an investigation into Dr Elwood himself, who escaped professional punishment by voluntarily erasing himself from the medical register.

A code for employing locums was introduced in 1997 by DoH. But the report said many trusts were failing to comply with the code's rules on checking the background of temporary doctors.

The commission was strongly critical of the DoH's systems on employing elderly and locum doctors. It said there was "too much reliance" on locums because of chronic shortages of pathologists and "poor workforce planning".

Trusts must seek a special order to employ doctors aged over 70, proving there is a pressing need to employ them and that they are fit to practice.

But CHI said the procedure was simply a "rubber stamp and provides no safeguard for the employing trust or patients".

Monitoring of locum consultants was "poor" and DoH's code on employing locums needed to be strengthened.

Trusts were also unclear about how cases of alleged incompetence should be investigated and a "clear national protocol" needed to be developed by the government, the commission said.
