They need to be addressed with urgency and determination." The CHI report was ordered after it emerged that 79-year-old Dr James Elwood, a consultant pathologist, had wrongly diagnosed more than 200 cancer patients at the Princess Margaret Hospital in Swindon. Dr Elwood had worked as a locum pathologist in three other trusts - the Royal United Hospital Bath trust, the Mid-Sussex trust and Frimley Park Hospitals trust - between 1995 and 1999. Despite concerns being raised about his performance as early as 1995, investigations did not start until 1999. In the biggest ever review of tests ever conducted, more than 10,000 diagnoses by Dr Elwood had to be rechecked. More than 200 people were found to have been wrongly diagnosed, seven of whom suffered serious consequences as a result. One woman had a breast removed unnecessarily and another patient was left in a "life-threatening" condition. The commission's report found that all four trusts had failed to carry out even basic checks on Dr Elwood's background and career when he came to work for them. It said: "The four trusts failed to use adequate safeguards when employing Dr Elwood in terms of obtaining references, checking career history, in interviewing, in carrying out health checks and in his induction." The report was not an investigation into Dr Elwood himself, who escaped professional punishment by voluntarily erasing himself from the medical register. A code for employing locums was introduced in 1997 by DoH. But the report said many trusts were failing to comply with the code's rules on checking the background of temporary doctors. The commission was strongly critical of the DoH's systems on employing elderly and locum doctors. It said there was "too much reliance" on locums because of chronic shortages of pathologists and "poor workforce planning". Trusts must seek a special order to employ doctors aged over 70, proving there is a pressing need to employ them and that they are fit to practice. But CHI said the procedure was simply a "rubber stamp and provides no safeguard for the employing trust or patients". Monitoring of locum consultants was "poor" and DoH's code on employing locums needed to be strengthened. Trusts were also unclear about how cases of alleged incompetence should be investigated and a "clear national protocol" needed to be developed by the government, the commission said.

webTitle: Equity raise spectre of British actors' strike

fields.headline: Equity raise spectre of British actors' strike
fields.trailText: A British actors strike could be in the offing within six months, if the performers' union Equity doesn't reach an agreement with the Producers Alliance for Cinema & Television (PACT). The conflict, like the potential action by the Screen Actors Guild in America, is over continuing residual payments to actors.
fields.body:
A British actors strike could be in the offing within six months, if the performers' union Equity doesn't reach an agreement with the Producers Alliance for Cinema & Television (PACT). The conflict, like the potential action by the Screen Actors Guild in America, is over continuing residual payments to actors.

The current agreement means that a performer who works for the minimum rate on a British production receives just £22 per day for the rights to their work for all time, no matter how much profit the finished work rakes in. Equity's assistant general secretary, Andy Prodger told Guardian Unlimited Film that the union wanted to introduce ongoing payments to its members based on the success of productions, but that PACT has declined.

"At present, it doesn't even matter if you're in a James Bond film, you still won't receive any more money," he explained. And, under the current agreement, American actors working in the UK on predominately British productions receive residual payments, while British actors don't. Prodger refers to Mission Impossible, saying: "it was made in the UK, and $1.8m (£1.3m) has been paid to the small number of American actors who appeared in the film, but not a penny has gone to any of the British artists."

Rectifying this situation is Equity's priority, and the union has given PACT six months notice of termination of the current agreement. Prodger says: "We're hoping to get a positive response before the end of the six months, but if it doesn't happen we would have to advise our members not to accept contracts. We don't want to strike, but we are very serious about getting a fair share of the profits."

webTitle: Cancer smear test errors killed 14 women

fields.headline: Cancer smear test errors killed 14 women
fields.trailText: Fourteen women have died of cervical cancer despite being given the all-clear after smear tests, an audit into cervical screening services in Leicestershire revealed today.
fields.body:
Fourteen women have died of cervical cancer despite being given the all-clear after smear tests, an audit into cervical screening services in Leicestershire revealed today.

The study of 403 women diagnosed with cervical cancer in a seven-year period showed that smear tests produced inaccurate results in nearly a third of cases.

Sixty-four more women eventually had to undergo radical treatment, including hysterectomies, after wrongly being given the all-clear at a time when their condition could have been treated with a simple operation, the Department of Health said.

The audit of women diagnosed with the disease between January 1993 and August 2000 found 122 discrepancies, of which 84 patients had a "false negative" smear. Of those, 14 died and 64 underwent more radical treatment than they might otherwise have needed. The remaining women were not believed to have suffered any adverse consequences.

Speaking at a press conference at the Department of Health in central London, the government's cancer "tsar", Mike Richards, said it was tragic that women had died and offered his condolences to bereaved relatives but stressed that Leicestershire was not failing.

He admitted the NHS had made mistakes but denied it had been negligent.

He said: "No screening test can ever be 100% accurate, it is not an exact science. That is why the audit was undertaken in the first place, to learn and then improve the service.

Mr Richards said that the relatives of the 14 women who died would be told about the exact circumstances by Leicestershire health officials later today. He admitted that some could take legal action.

Women who have been diagnosed with cervical cancer in Leicestershire will be offered an appointment with their gynaecologist and counselling.

Mr Richards stressed that the cervical cancer screening programme in Leicestershire had to be understood in context.

"Leicester is not failing, it performs well on all qualitative assurance measures and death rates from cervical cancer are falling in line with national trends," he said.

"We recognise this may and will cause distress to some of the patients. The NHS say sorry when they get things wrong. We want to put the audit into the public domain so that learning is not just in Leicestershire but all around the country.

Government health figures show that the NHS Cervical Screening Programme saves around 1,300 lives a year. It is directly responsible for a 42% drop in incidents of cervical cancer between 1988 and 1997. It is estimated that the programme has saved more than 8,000 lives in that time.

Mr Richards said it was unlikely that the problem of wrongly interpreted smears was restricted to Leicestershire. "We can assume that around the rest of the country there will be other cases where diagnosis of cervical cancer or abnormality on the smear were not picked up.

Philip Sturman, chief officer of Leicestershire Community Health Council, which represents patients, urged the public not to panic.

"It is important not to scare people with these results - screening saves lives," he said.

The NHS cervical screening programme was set up in 1988 and is based in Sheffield. It has screened almost four million women in England each year with around 3,450 new cases of cervical cancer - the most common form of cancer in women aged under 35 - diagnosed.

Figures show that 83.7% of women of screening age have had a smear in the last five years with 3.3m women aged 25 to 64 screened.

The smear test spots abnormal cells, but does not test for cancer itself.

webTitle: Winn to head PR at Compaq

fields.headline: Winn to head PR at Compaq
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Compaq has appointed Kate Winn as its PR chief for the UK and Ireland, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Compaq has appointed Kate Winn as its new public relations chief for the UK and Ireland.

Ms Winn joins the IT company as public relations manager from her position as head of communications at GoodCorporation.com, a dot.com start-up involved in setting up a global network for corporate social responsibility.

She previously spent five years at Marketforce Communications, culminating as an account director for the KPMG Consulting account.

At Compaq Ms Winn will report to Nicola Adamson, the head of corporate communications for Compaq UK and Ireland.

She will work closely with Compaq's PR agency, Firefly, and will be responsible for raising awareness of Compaq's growing role as a provider of solutions to business, as well as the IT hardware on which the company built its reputation.

"Kate is bringing a wealth of communications experience with her to Compaq, further strengthening our public relations team," said Robert Fedder, the director of strategy and marketing at Compaq.

fields.headline: Airey trumpets Lygo defection
fields.trailText:
12.45pm update: Channel 5 boss Dawn Airey has hailed as a coup the defection of Kevin Lygo from Channel 4, reports Julia Day.
03.05.2001: Lygo jumps ship for Channel 5

26.01.2001: Kevin's horoscope

15.01.2001: Countdown to E4 - Kevin's secret diary
fields.body:
Dawn Airey has hailed the defection of Kevin Lygo from Channel 4 as a coup for Channel 5.

The chief executive of Channel 5 described him as "an exceptional talent" and the "perfect" man to attract new viewers to the station, which recently celebrated its fourth birthday.

"Kevin Lygo is an exceptional talent who has been at the forefront of commissioning some of the most innovative and widely viewed entertainment formats of the last few years," said Ms Airey.

"Combine this with his start-up experience from E4 and he makes the perfect candidate to take Channel 5 into the next phase of our growth," she added.

The Channel 4 chief executive, Michael Jackson, said he was sorry to see Mr Lygo go and praised his talent-spotting abilities.

"Kevin has completely revitalised Channel 4 entertainment and unearthed a phenomenal array of new comic talent." he said.

"Ali G, Trigger Happy TV, Smack the Pony, Spaced, Black Books and So Graham Norton are the best testament to the scale of his contribution at Channel 4."

Mr Lygo launched his career in TV as a comedy scriptwriter at the BBC.

He has worked on the Two Ronnies, Rowan Atkinson's satirical show Not the Nine O'Clock News and Tracey Ullman's Three of a Kind. He helped launch Terry Wogan's chat show for BBC1 a decade ago.

Mr Lygo went on to become head of development for BBC entertainment and before defecting to Channel 4 headed up the department's independent producution unit responsible for Men Behaving Badly, Game on and the Frank Skinner Show.

He said: "This is a marvellous opportunity for me. I am leaving Channel 4 at a high point and I am very excited by this chance to be a part of the growing success story that is Channel 5."

An RTL Group spokesman said: "To get a mainstream entertainment executive like Kevin is a sign of Dawn's pulling power and the channel's ambitions."

webTitle: Unhappy medium: the life and trial of 'hellish Nell' (II)

fields.headline: Unhappy medium (II)
fields.trailText: Hilary Mantel delves into the pitiful story of spiritualist Helen Duncan
fields.body:
If you attended a séance, you were not asked to open the eye of faith, but to trust your direct experience; all the senses were to be gratified and convinced. You did not have to accept the truth of the Bible or swallow sermons about the existence of a spirit world: all you had to do was turn up and pay your money, and you would see and hear for yourself. Immortality was sold as a fact, not a pious hope; it was not just the soul that went on after death, but the body and the hands and the feet. Dead fingers stretched out to touch and pat the cheeks of the living, or chalked their messages on slates, or plucked at spirit harps. Discarnate lungs puffed at wind instruments. Bouquets of roses - thornless - were 'apported' into the séance room, and dogs, cats, rabbits and parrots attested to the fact that the inhabitants of Victorian pet cemeteries would rise too. Sequestered behind a curtain, protected by the half-dark, the medium would pass into a trance state and soon the voices of the dead would come through, wanting to be recognised. Masks, wigs, wires, beards and rubber gloves were the props the mediums employed, and for the voices they used their native histrionic ability; a daughter of Nell's once remarked bitterly that if all her mother's manifestations were self-engendered, she was a loss to the acting profession. It was, and is, extremely difficult to reconcile the evidence of witnesses of psychic phenomena. Many séances were becalmed, with long stretches of non-event, so that when a sudden dramatic event did occur the sitters were not sufficiently focused to report on its nature. The same 'manifestations' could leave an audience divided, half of them sneering and half of them moved to tears.

Helen Duncan was a classic 'materialisation medium', and central to her act was the production of ectoplasm, a substance for which there is no recipe, and which now has vanished from the world. Ectoplasm was a milky emission which gave life to spirit forms. It emanated from the medium's nose and mouth and from the area of darkness within her clothes, and took on semi-solid form, with features that the willing onlooker could recognise. One witness to a performance by Hellish Nell described it as "a liquid spurting from the nipples of her breasts". In giving birth to the dead, the medium is both male and female; ectoplasm is both semen and breast-milk. From time to time sitters attempted to snip or wrench or tug pieces of it away, in order to submit it to laboratory analysis. Tests were often inconclusive: it was cloth, or paper fibres bound with egg-white - or it was a substance unknown. In its most detectable form it consisted of yards of fine muslin packed within the medium's capacious undergarments, or possibly within the medium's capacious body cavities. It was often suggested that the muslin was regurgitated, and it was seriously maintained that some mediums had two stomachs. Ectoplasm smelled like old cloth; or, some said, like death. Another feature of a medium's performance was a 'spirit guide', in whose voice the medium would often speak. Nell's guide was called Albert. He was tall, and rather superior, and his favourite song was South of the Border. He spoke in a strangulated drawl, his accent veering between RP and Strine. When photographed, he looked like a rolled-up newspaper. He often ridiculed Henry Duncan and showed a degree of contempt for the audience. Helen had a second guide, Peggy, who was a mischievous child-spirit made out of a stockinette vest. Her party-piece was Baa-Baa Black Sheep, though she could also produce a verse of Loch Lomond.

This was the practice of mediumship, as carried out by Helen Duncan in a career which spanned some twenty years, and engrossed thousands; it was a joke, a fiction that a child could see through. But the body of theory that Henry assimilated during his long sickly days was created by some of the finest minds of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Society for Psychical Research was founded in 1882 by a selection of eminent Victorians. It seems strange to us now that some of the best scientific brains of an era could have been employed on ghost hunts. But these men were not fools. They were asking reasonable questions about the natural world, and trying to establish an investigative framework for a new branch of science. They tried to maintain a healthy scepticism while not rejecting evidence because it came in unorthodox ways, and to formulate an experimental protocol which would be equal in rigour to that employed by practitioners in the more established branches of scientific knowledge. Their intellectual efforts were constantly sabotaged by the antics of some of the mediums themselves: so that spiritualism began to seem shoddy, trivial and childish. And if the showmen made problems for the scientists, so did the scientists make problems for the toiling medium, tied perspiring to her chair, tussling with the outrageous demands of her own unconscious. The events with which parapsychology concerns itself are irregular, spontaneous and ambivalent, but in order to prove that parapsychology was a science, researchers needed to analyse and quantify events which were repeatable, regular and unequivocal. The business of cheating is therefore not hard to understand. Once a medium had achieved results among her family and friends, the pressure was on to perform in public, and then obtain credentials by performing before investigative bodies. Mediums resorted to magicians' tricks, often as much out of a desire to please as a desire to make money; their suggestible personalities and sometimes low status made them vulnerable to flattery and afraid of losing their reputations if they did not get consistent results. Exposure might be shaming, but was not necessarily, or even usually, the end of a career. True believers hit back hard at anyone who challenged them; and there was always a small percentage of phenomena that no one could explain away without resorting to mental contortions that were greater than those required to accept, simply, that the dead were walking nightly through the land.

When Duncan began to practise as a medium, some of her early 'manifestations' were terrifying in their violence and hostility. Her first séances brought her no profit, but around 1930 she began to glimpse commercial possibilities. Soon afterwards she agreed to her first London season, making a contract for sittings with the London Spiritualist Alliance, and decamping to a rented house in Thornton Heath. These sittings attracted genteel society, but they were also test séances, and proved a challenge for Henry Duncan when he had to explain why his wife extruded surgical gauze and fragments of a sanitary towel. Henry, more in sorrow than in anger, admitted that an hour or two before her sittings Helen would pass into a dissociated state in which she would secrete various articles about her person, not knowing what she did. Helen was, then, out of his control: and out of her own. If she cheated, she couldn't help it. Accused of theatrical feats of regurgitation, Helen said ingenuously: "they give me credit for more than I can do."

Her great mistake was her involvement with Harry Price, a ghost hunter, professional journalist and professional sceptic. Price liked to present himself as in pursuit of knowledge but was really, like so many in the spirit game, in pursuit of profit. In 1923 he had split off from the Society for Psychical Research - ghost-hunters are sectarian and quarrel a lot - and founded the National Laboratory of Psychical Research. The first time Helen saw him, at the headquarters of the LSA, she sensed 'malevolent vibrations'. Nevertheless she agreed to give sittings for him. It was easy to get her into his power, because she always wanted money; her trade was anything but secure. Gaskill does not try to work out how much money Duncan made, but is certain that the various bodies and societies who exhibited her took a much greater share of the proceeds of her work. By the evidence he gives of changes in her family's circumstances, she made enough to lift them out of poverty; this was achieved by a tough schedule and constant travelling, and by submitting herself to physical indignities at which a prostitute might baulk.

Harry Price set about Duncan's humiliation with sadistic relish. He drafted in two doctors to examine her. "They brought a bag of tools with them," he wrote, "took off their coats to the job and really got down to it. But they found nothing. Every orifice and crack where an instrument or hand would go was thoroughly explored; every nook and cranny was examined; but at each fresh place they drew a blank." This blankness did not exonerate Helen. At her next séance the doctors pounced on her 'ectoplasm' with surgical scissors, and roused her from a trance by shouting into her face. She was in such bad physical shape that she was admitted to St Thomas's, where she swigged a bottle of disinfectant and had her stomach pumped. When she recovered, the LSA packed her off home. In 1933, at a séance in Scotland, she was surprised by a sitter who made a grab at her, turned on the lights and found her rapidly concealing 'Peggy' under her clothes. "I'll brain you, you bloody bugger,'"Helen shouted; she was prosecuted for fraud and fined ten pounds. But this setback, and Price's debunking report, hardly affected the esteem in which she was held in the world of spiritualist churches and societies. She flourished, especially when the second world war brought new separations and griefs to which she could cater. Once again, belief was not confined to the uneducated, but was widespread among dons, clergymen and officers in the Armed Forces; bereavement affected all classes. Gaskill estimates that the creed had a million adherents by 1944; there were a thousand churches and some fifty thousand home circles. In 1941 the Royal Navy recognised spiritualism as a religion and sailors were allowed to hold spiritualist services at sea. Helen pulled in huge audiences - until she attracted the attention of the authorities, and her antics at the Master Temple Psychic Centre in Portsmouth brought her to court under the Witchcraft Act.

Gaskill leaves it till rather late in the book to ask what might have been going on in Duncan's head through her many years as empress and chief freak of the psychic world. As a historian of popular beliefs, he is more interested in her audiences than in Duncan herself, and his description of the heartless tricks practised by her colleagues and forbears is thorough to the point of tedium. This is not his fault; most books about spiritualism are more or less dull, because once the gross, unsophisticated nature of the frauds has been laid bare, there is no entertainment value in multiplying examples. The 'inner' history of mediumship is far more interesting, but it would necessarily comprehend a history of 'hysteria', in its various incarnations through the centuries: for since the end of the 19th century mediumship has been viewed as a ritualised form of hysteria, which converts weakness to strength and empowers the powerless. (To say this is to adopt the term, neutrally, for the purpose of discussion, and to leave aside the question of whether hysteria exists, or ever did exist, as a definable disease entity; the term may change, but the complex of behaviour once described as 'hysterical' can still be observed.) Gaskill recognises that, when shares in Helen's body are allocated, feminist and also psychoanalytical theories have a claim, but it is beyond the scope of his book to map their territory and patrol the borders. As he observes, it is not difficult to see how mediumship liberated its more genteel female practitioners. They could flirt with their audience and mock them; in deep trance, they could behave aggressively and with an overt sexuality.

With Hellish Nell, the case is rather different. One senses a powerful personality trapped in a sick and disabled body which others despised for its ugliness. Swoons and faints were not the least of it for Nell; her flesh was marked with circular burns from "returning ectoplasm" (or her own cigarettes) and she often ended sessions as if she had been in a fight, "dazed in the corner, blood and slime dripping from her chin". In the world in which she grew up, there was a vast and perhaps damaging disjunction between middle-class ideals of femininity and the reality of working women's lives. Hysteria is empowering but it is also a punishable offence. For Helen, such fame and prosperity as she attained came at a high cost in physical and mental degradation: she was a performer in the pornography of her age. One of Harry Price's allies, a woman who examined Helen, told him she possessed "enormous depths of pelvis", and assured him that "pelvic concealment of articles is one of the commonest acts of insane females, especially if there is any taint of immorality in them. One, two and three large bath towels, secreted in the pelvis, is of common occurrence in any Female Lunatic Asylum."

This is the late-night gossip of ward orderlies, redolent of cocoa and gaslight; it is the chatter of the freak-show, from that Hogarthian London which Gaskill evokes early in the book; it is at the frontier of what one can say of a human being, without confiscating their humanity entirely. It would have been good to find Gaskill a little keener to nail it as myth-making and stigmatisation. But of course, it is not his job to defend Nell or pity her, slumped and bleeding in her corner, the corpses of the western front packed into her knickers, the drowned mariners of the Barham leaking from her ears. Sympathy is left to Nell herself, who like an infant can only speak of herself in the third person, and speak through the disdainful Albert: 'Thank goodness I love her, she is a poor beggar.'

Gaskill gives a detailed account of the trial of Hellish Nell, but her subsequent history, and the history of her profession, can be summarised briefly. Emerging from Holloway, she was soon back at work, but she had to dodge the spiritualist authorities, and never quite recovered her former glory. In 1956 a séance in Nottingham was raided by the police; subsequently she was taken ill, and died five weeks later, aged 59. By then, the statute which had trapped her at the Old Bailey had been superseded. The Fraudulent Mediums Act of 1951 stated that no prosecutions were to be undertaken without the involvement of the DPP; where money had changed hands, spiritualists could be fined or imprisoned for fraud, but there was an exemption for "anything done solely for the purposes of entertainment". This Act, friendly to the trade, drew its teeth. The occult was degraded to an amusement; and television soon offered a better one. During the 1950s, interest in spiritualism fell away; communities fractured; credulity invested itself in flying saucers, and later in crop circles, reincarnation, alien pregnancies, millennial cults. Simple death - except to the rawly bereaved - was no longer interesting enough.

Helen Duncan has successors, though she might despise them. Every weekend - in the South-East of England, at least - the newspapers advertise a selection of 'Psychic Fayres', as an alternative to the usual pursuits of DIY and out-of-town shopping. They are held in the banqueting annexes of steak-houses and the hospitality suites of non-league football clubs, and the mediums - who often themselves practise a variety of psychic arts - are mixed promiscuously with the tarot card readers and the palmists. Here they sit on fringed cushions behind trestle tables draped in sleazy silks and nylon velvets, stacked with an array of crystals and charms: carefully conforming to stereotype, just as if they were in a film about themselves. fields.bodyText: If you attended a séance, you were not asked to open the eye of faith, but to trust your direct experience; all the senses were to be gratified and convinced. You did not have to accept the truth of the Bible or swallow sermons about the existence of a spirit world: all you had to do was turn up and pay your money, and you would see and hear for yourself. Immortality was sold as a fact, not a pious hope; it was not just the soul that went on after death, but the body and the hands and the feet. Dead fingers stretched out to touch and pat the cheeks of the living, or chalked their messages on slates, or plucked at spirit harps. Discarnate lungs puffed at wind instruments. Bouquets of roses - thornless - were 'apported' into the séance room, and dogs, cats, rabbits and parrots attested to the fact that the inhabitants of Victorian pet cemeteries would rise too. Sequestered behind a curtain, protected by the half-dark, the medium would pass into a trance state and soon the voices of the dead would come through, wanting to be recognised. Masks, wigs, wires, beards and rubber gloves were the props the mediums employed, and for the voices they used their native histrionic ability; a daughter of Nell's once remarked bitterly that if all her mother's manifestations were self-engendered, she was a loss to the acting profession. It was, and is, extremely difficult to reconcile the evidence of witnesses of psychic phenomena. Many séances were becalmed, with long stretches of non-event, so that when a sudden dramatic event did occur the sitters were not sufficiently focused to report on its nature. The same 'manifestations' could leave an audience divided, half of them sneering and half of them moved to tears. Helen Duncan was a classic 'materialisation medium', and central to her act was the production of ectoplasm, a substance for which there is no recipe, and which now has vanished from the world. Ectoplasm was a milky emission which gave life to spirit forms. It emanated from the medium's nose and mouth and from the area of darkness within her clothes, and took on semi-solid form, with features that the willing onlooker could recognise. One witness to a performance by Hellish Nell described it as "a liquid spurting from the nipples of her breasts". In giving birth to the dead, the medium is both male and female; ectoplasm is both semen and breast-milk. From time to time sitters attempted to snip or wrench or tug pieces of it away, in order to submit it to laboratory analysis. Tests were often inconclusive: it was cloth, or paper fibres bound with egg-white - or it was a substance unknown. In its most detectable form it consisted of yards of fine muslin packed within the medium's capacious undergarments, or possibly within the medium's capacious body cavities. It was often suggested that the muslin was regurgitated, and it was seriously maintained that some mediums had two stomachs. Ectoplasm smelled like old cloth; or, some said, like death. Another feature of a medium's performance was a 'spirit guide', in whose voice the medium would often speak. Nell's guide was called Albert. He was tall, and rather superior, and his favourite song was South of the Border. He spoke in a strangulated drawl, his accent veering between RP and Strine. When photographed, he looked like a rolled-up newspaper. He often ridiculed Henry Duncan and showed a degree of contempt for the audience. Helen had a second guide, Peggy, who was a mischievous child-spirit made out of a stockinette vest. Her party-piece was Baa-Baa Black Sheep, though she could also produce a verse of Loch Lomond. This was the practice of mediumship, as carried out by Helen Duncan in a career which spanned some twenty years, and engrossed thousands; it was a joke, a fiction that a child could see through. But the body of theory that Henry assimilated during his long sickly days was created by some of the finest minds of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Society for Psychical Research was founded in 1882 by a selection of eminent Victorians. It seems strange to us now that some of the best scientific brains of an era could have been employed on ghost hunts. But these men were not fools. They were asking reasonable questions about the natural world, and trying to establish an investigative framework for a new branch of science. They tried to maintain a healthy scepticism while not rejecting evidence because it came in unorthodox ways, and to formulate an experimental protocol which would be equal in rigour to that employed by practitioners in the more established branches of scientific knowledge. Their intellectual efforts were constantly sabotaged by the antics of some of the mediums themselves: so that spiritualism began to seem shoddy, trivial and childish. And if the showmen made problems for the scientists, so did the scientists make problems for the toiling medium, tied perspiring to her chair, tussling with the outrageous demands of her own unconscious. The events with which parapsychology concerns itself are irregular, spontaneous and ambivalent, but in order to prove that parapsychology was a science, researchers needed to analyse and quantify events which were repeatable, regular and unequivocal. The business of cheating is therefore not hard to understand. Once a medium had achieved results among her family and friends, the pressure was on to perform in public, and then obtain credentials by performing before investigative bodies. Mediums resorted to magicians' tricks, often as much out of a desire to please as a desire to make money; their suggestible personalities and sometimes low status made them vulnerable to flattery and afraid of losing their reputations if they did not get consistent results. Exposure might be shaming, but was not necessarily, or even usually, the end of a career. True believers hit back hard at anyone who challenged them; and there was always a small percentage of phenomena that no one could explain away without resorting to mental contortions that were greater than those required to accept, simply, that the dead were walking nightly through the land. When Duncan began to practise as a medium, some of her early 'manifestations' were terrifying in their violence and hostility. Her first séances brought her no profit, but around 1930 she began to glimpse commercial possibilities. Soon afterwards she agreed to her first London season, making a contract for sittings with the London Spiritualist Alliance, and decamping to a rented house in Thornton Heath. These sittings attracted genteel society, but they were also test séances, and proved a challenge for Henry Duncan when he had to explain why his wife extruded surgical gauze and fragments of a sanitary towel. Henry, more in sorrow than in anger, admitted that an hour or two before her sittings Helen would pass into a dissociated state in which she would secrete various articles about her person, not knowing what she did. Helen was, then, out of his control: and out of her own. If she cheated, she couldn't help it. Accused of theatrical feats of regurgitation, Helen said ingenuously: "they give me credit for more than I can do." Her great mistake was her involvement with Harry Price, a ghost hunter, professional journalist and professional sceptic. Price liked to present himself as in pursuit of knowledge but was really, like so many in the spirit game, in pursuit of profit. In 1923 he had split off from the Society for Psychical Research - ghost-hunters are sectarian and quarrel a lot - and founded the National Laboratory of Psychical Research. The first time Helen saw him, at the headquarters of the LSA, she sensed 'malevolent vibrations'. Nevertheless she agreed to give sittings for him. It was easy to get her into his power, because she always wanted money; her trade was anything but secure. Gaskill does not try to work out how much money Duncan made, but is certain that the various bodies and societies who exhibited her took a much greater share of the proceeds of her work. By the evidence he gives of changes in her family's circumstances, she made enough to lift them out of poverty; this was achieved by a tough schedule and constant travelling, and by submitting herself to physical indignities at which a prostitute might baulk. Harry Price set about Duncan's humiliation with sadistic relish. He drafted in two doctors to examine her. "They brought a bag of tools with them," he wrote, "took off their coats to the job and really got down to it. But they found nothing. Every orifice and crack where an instrument or hand would go was thoroughly explored; every nook and cranny was examined; but at each fresh place they drew a blank." This blankness did not exonerate Helen. At her next séance the doctors pounced on her 'ectoplasm' with surgical scissors, and roused her from a trance by shouting into her face. She was in such bad physical shape that she was admitted to St Thomas's, where she swigged a bottle of disinfectant and had her stomach pumped. When she recovered, the LSA packed her off home. In 1933, at a séance in Scotland, she was surprised by a sitter who made a grab at her, turned on the lights and found her rapidly concealing 'Peggy' under her clothes. "I'll brain you, you bloody bugger,'"Helen shouted; she was prosecuted for fraud and fined ten pounds. But this setback, and Price's debunking report, hardly affected the esteem in which she was held in the world of spiritualist churches and societies. She flourished, especially when the second world war brought new separations and griefs to which she could cater. Once again, belief was not confined to the uneducated, but was widespread among dons, clergymen and officers in the Armed Forces; bereavement affected all classes. Gaskill estimates that the creed had a million adherents by 1944; there were a thousand churches and some fifty thousand home circles. In 1941 the Royal Navy recognised spiritualism as a religion and sailors were allowed to hold spiritualist services at sea. Helen pulled in huge audiences - until she attracted the attention of the authorities, and her antics at the Master Temple Psychic Centre in Portsmouth brought her to court under the Witchcraft Act. Gaskill leaves it till rather late in the book to ask what might have been going on in Duncan's head through her many years as empress and chief freak of the psychic world. As a historian of popular beliefs, he is more interested in her audiences than in Duncan herself, and his description of the heartless tricks practised by her colleagues and forbears is thorough to the point of tedium. This is not his fault; most books about spiritualism are more or less dull, because once the gross, unsophisticated nature of the frauds has been laid bare, there is no entertainment value in multiplying examples. The 'inner' history of mediumship is far more interesting, but it would necessarily comprehend a history of 'hysteria', in its various incarnations through the centuries: for since the end of the 19th century mediumship has been viewed as a ritualised form of hysteria, which converts weakness to strength and empowers the powerless. (To say this is to adopt the term, neutrally, for the purpose of discussion, and to leave aside the question of whether hysteria exists, or ever did exist, as a definable disease entity; the term may change, but the complex of behaviour once described as 'hysterical' can still be observed.) Gaskill recognises that, when shares in Helen's body are allocated, feminist and also psychoanalytical theories have a claim, but it is beyond the scope of his book to map their territory and patrol the borders. As he observes, it is not difficult to see how mediumship liberated its more genteel female practitioners. They could flirt with their audience and mock them; in deep trance, they could behave aggressively and with an overt sexuality. With Hellish Nell, the case is rather different. One senses a powerful personality trapped in a sick and disabled body which others despised for its ugliness. Swoons and faints were not the least of it for Nell; her flesh was marked with circular burns from "returning ectoplasm" (or her own cigarettes) and she often ended sessions as if she had been in a fight, "dazed in the corner, blood and slime dripping from her chin". In the world in which she grew up, there was a vast and perhaps damaging disjunction between middle-class ideals of femininity and the reality of working women's lives. Hysteria is empowering but it is also a punishable offence. For Helen, such fame and prosperity as she attained came at a high cost in physical and mental degradation: she was a performer in the pornography of her age. One of Harry Price's allies, a woman who examined Helen, told him she possessed "enormous depths of pelvis", and assured him that "pelvic concealment of articles is one of the commonest acts of insane females, especially if there is any taint of immorality in them. One, two and three large bath towels, secreted in the pelvis, is of common occurrence in any Female Lunatic Asylum." This is the late-night gossip of ward orderlies, redolent of cocoa and gaslight; it is the chatter of the freak-show, from that Hogarthian London which Gaskill evokes early in the book; it is at the frontier of what one can say of a human being, without confiscating their humanity entirely. It would have been good to find Gaskill a little keener to nail it as myth-making and stigmatisation. But of course, it is not his job to defend Nell or pity her, slumped and bleeding in her corner, the corpses of the western front packed into her knickers, the drowned mariners of the Barham leaking from her ears. Sympathy is left to Nell herself, who like an infant can only speak of herself in the third person, and speak through the disdainful Albert: 'Thank goodness I love her, she is a poor beggar.' Gaskill gives a detailed account of the trial of Hellish Nell, but her subsequent history, and the history of her profession, can be summarised briefly. Emerging from Holloway, she was soon back at work, but she had to dodge the spiritualist authorities, and never quite recovered her former glory. In 1956 a séance in Nottingham was raided by the police; subsequently she was taken ill, and died five weeks later, aged 59. By then, the statute which had trapped her at the Old Bailey had been superseded. The Fraudulent Mediums Act of 1951 stated that no prosecutions were to be undertaken without the involvement of the DPP; where money had changed hands, spiritualists could be fined or imprisoned for fraud, but there was an exemption for "anything done solely for the purposes of entertainment". This Act, friendly to the trade, drew its teeth. The occult was degraded to an amusement; and television soon offered a better one. fields.headline: Red and Olay in Superdrug promotion
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Superdrug customers who buy Olay products will receive a free mini edition of Red this month, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Emap's Red magazine has joined forces with Superdrug and Procter & Gamble's beauty line, Olay.

The three partners will launch a four-week sampling campaign on May 9.

Under the deal, Superdrug customers who buy any Olay skincare product will receive a free mini edition of Red.

The promotion will be trailed on olay.com and reddirect.co.uk and supported with a direct mail campaign to customers of Red Direct, Red's home shopping service.

The mini magazines will be displayed in Superdrug stores in co-branded units and promoted with adverts on Superdrug in-store radio.

"We are delighted to be working with Olay this summer, particularly as we share obvious brand synergies," said Trish Halpin, the editor of Red.

"The special mini-edition of Red is designed to be a treat for Olay purchasers.

"It provides the perfect opportunity to deliver the magazine - and communicate its core values - to women who may have heard of Red but not yet tried it," she added.

webTitle: QPR and Wimbledon in merger talks

fields.headline: QPR and Wimbledon in merger talks
fields.trailText: Queens Park Rangers have confirmed they are in "very early stage discussions" with Wimbledon about a possible merger of the two clubs.
fields.body:
Queens Park Rangers have confirmed they are in "very early stage discussions" with Wimbledon about a possible merger of the two clubs.

The talks began after QPR were put into administration with debts of around £8m, while Wimbledon have been searching for a permanent home for several years.

The announcement came after a report in this morning's Sun. The article claimed that the proposed new team will be coached by Dons boss Terry Burton and will play its home games at Loftus Road.

However, a spokesperson for Loftus Road plc, the owners of QPR, was at pains to state that a final decision has yet to be made.

"Our initial view is that, in the current financial environment for football outside the Premier League, the idea could have merit and may be worth exploring further," he explained.

"But we must emphasise that it is still very early days and no firm agreement whatsoever has been reached. The talks with Wimbledon will only continue if there is general approval from our supporter base."

Wimbledon chairman Charles Koppel also played down the reports.

"No agreement to merge Wimbledon with QPR has been reached," he insisted. "While discussions regarding the idea of a possible merger have taken place, we realise that no agreement could ever be reached without consulting our supporters first.

"If the fans felt that this was not the best thing, we would re-evaluate and move along a different route."

Unsurprisingly, supporters have already opposed the mooted merger.

Libby Magrill, spokeswoman for QPR 1st, the Queens Park Rangers Supporters Trust, said: "Historically, QPR fans will not support a merger with any other Football League club.

"Proposed mergers with Brentford in 1967 and Fulham in 1987 were successfully opposed by the fans, and any move to merge QPR with Wimbledon this year, or at any stage in the future, will be opposed by every possible means.

"QPR fans will fight to retain the identity of our club. We know that Wimbledon fans will do the same."

Wimbledon fans also expressed their opposition to the proposal, promising to protest at a meeting between the club and supporters' organisations later this week.

The Wimbledon Independent Supporters' Association declared that they "unequivocally oppose the merger of two separate identities, families, supporters and histories" and added: "At our forthcoming meeting on Sunday with chairman Charles Koppel prior to the final game of the season, we shall be discussing and exploring the way to go forward.

"In addition, we shall be making clear to the owners of Wimbledon Football Club our desire for our own stadium and retained identity.

"We urge the vigilance of Wimbledon and QPR supporters during this time and ask that you make your voices heard far and wide."

Meanwhile, speculation that a third London club, Brentford, could also become involved was dismissed by chairman Ron Noades, who had been linked with a rival bid.

Noades told the Evening Standard: "We are not interested in any merger with or takeover of QPR.

"We were in talks with QPR about a possible ground share at Loftus Road but those cannot proceed until the club is out of administration.

"In the meantime, our own talks about a new ground for Brentford in the borough of Hounslow are progressing well.

"If QPR and Wimbledon merge we would be interested to talk to them about a possible ground share if we do manage to move to a new home ourselves."

It has also been reported that an unidentified City-based consortium are preparing a £12m bid to buy QPR outright and keep the club's identity.

Their bid is for the rugby and football wings of Loftus Road plc and would involve QPR and Wasps sharing Rangers' Acton training ground.

webTitle: Cancer smear test errors killed 14 women

fields.headline: Cancer smear test errors killed 14 women
fields.trailText:
Fourteen women have died of cervical cancer despite being given the all-clear after smear tests, an audit into cervical screening
services in Leicestershire revealed today.
fields.body:
Fourteen women have died of cervical cancer despite being given the all-clear after smear tests, an audit into cervical screening services in Leicestershire revealed today.

The study of 403 women diagnosed with cervical cancer in a seven-year period showed that smear tests produced inaccurate results in nearly a third of cases.

Sixty-four more women eventually had to undergo radical treatment, including hysterectomies, after wrongly being given the all-clear at a time when their condition could have been treated with a simple operation, the Department of Health said.

The audit of women diagnosed with the disease between January 1993 and August 2000 found 122 discrepancies, of which 84 patients had a "false negative" smear. Of those, 14 died and 64 underwent more radical treatment than they might otherwise have needed. The remaining women were not believed to have suffered any adverse consequences.

Speaking at a press conference at the Department of Health in central London, the government's cancer "tsar", Mike Richards, said it was tragic that women had died and offered his condolences to bereaved relatives but stressed that Leicestershire was not failing.

He admitted the NHS had made mistakes but denied it had been negligent.

He said: "No screening test can ever be 100% accurate, it is not an exact science. That is why the audit was undertaken in the first place, to learn and then improve the service.

Mr Richards said that the relatives of the 14 women who died would be told about the exact circumstances by Leicestershire health officials later today. He admitted that some could take legal action.

Women who have been diagnosed with cervical cancer in Leicestershire will be offered an appointment with their gynaecologist and counselling.

Mr Richards stressed that the cervical cancer screening programme in Leicestershire had to be understood in context.

"Leicester is not failing, it performs well on all qualitative assurance measures and death rates from cervical cancer are falling in line with national trends," he said.

"We recognise this may and will cause distress to some of the patients. The NHS say sorry when they get things wrong. We want to put the audit into the public domain so that learning is not just in Leicestershire but all around the country.

Government health figures show that the NHS Cervical Screening Programme saves around 1,300 lives a year. It is directly responsible for a 42% drop in incidents of cervical cancer between 1988 and 1997. It is estimated that the programme has saved more than 8,000 lives in that time.

Mr Richards said it was unlikely that the problem of wrongly interpreted smears was restricted to Leicestershire. "We can assume that around the rest of the country there will be other cases where diagnosis of cervical cancer or abnormality on the smear were not picked up.

Philip Sturman, chief officer of Leicestershire Community Health Council, which represents patients, urged the public not to panic.

"It is important not to scare people with these results - screening saves lives," he said.

The NHS cervical screening programme was set up in 1988 and is based in Sheffield. It has screened almost four million women in England each year with around 3,450 new cases of cervical cancer - the most common form of cancer in women aged under 35 - diagnosed.

Figures show that 83.7% of women of screening age have had a smear in the last five years with 3.3m women aged 25 to 64 screened.

The smear test spots abnormal cells, but does not test for cancer itself.

fields.headline: The national stadium
fields.standfirst:
The national stadium fiasco rolls on, after the government refused to bankroll the rebuilding of Wembley. Sean Ingle explains

Special report: The future of Wembley
fields.trailText: The national stadium fiasco rolls on, after the government refused to bankroll the rebuilding of Wembley. Sean Ingle explains.
fields.body:
What's happening now?
Uncertainty, uncertainty and yet more uncertainty. On Tuesday the future of Wembley was thrown in doubt when the Football Association announced they were unable to find the £660m needed to fund the rebuilding of the stadium and begged the government to intervene. A Downing Street spokesman responded by warning the FA the government would not act as a "lender of the last resort". Cue endless newspaper speculation about the project's funding, viability and future.

So what's going to happen next?
It's still up in the air. Some commentators reckon that Wembley could be bulldozered and a new stadium built in Birmingham. It's more likely, however, that a freshly designed, cheaper stadium will be built on the graveyard of the old Wembley

Why all this talk of a move to Birmingham?
There's a valid argument that a national stadium should be in easy reach of the majority of the country. That means Birmingham, not London. A move to the midlands would also allow a government that talks the decentralisation talk to actually walk the decentralisation walk. Against this view comes a two-fisted assault of realpolitik: for a future England Olympic or World Cup bid to succeed, it would have to be in London - as would the national stadium.

Why all need to rebuild Wembley at all?
Did you ever go to a match at the old Wembley? The ground was a dump, the seating was uncomfortable and the return tube journey (once you actually got on a tube) hellish.

So that's why the decision was made to rebuild Wembley?
Not totally. The story actually goes back to 1996, when Wembley won a competition to be the site of a new, multi-sports national stadium (beating sites in Birmingham and Manchester in the process). Three years later, Wembley National Stadium Limited [WNSL] and the FA announced plans for a magnificent-looking 90,000-capacity football and athletics stadium designed by Sir Norman Foster, costing £475m and scheduled to open in 2003.

When did things start going wrong?
In December 1999, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, stunned parliament by announcing that the new stadium would not be able to stage athletics events, such as the Olympic Games, as originally planned. By August 2000, the cost of rebuilding Wembley had gone up from £475m to £600m, and doubts were beginning to be expressed about the viability of the project.

And then?
Things went from bad to worse. By December 2000, every City institution approached by WNSL and its bankers Chase Manhattan were refusing to lend the money to build the stadium. The same month, the FA took control of the Wembley project from WNSL and Ken Bates (who was forced to step down) and announced the £660m scheme would be drastically scaled down to cut costs.

Will there be any more developments over the next few weeks?
Don't expect anything major to happen until after the election. After that, a new design team will be appointed, with the possible brief of designing a new 80,000-capacity national stadium capable of hosting athletics and other sports - which will almost certainly be built on the site of the old Wembley.

And in the meantime?
Wembley is losing a cool £2m a week. These consultants cost a lot of money, you know

webTitle: 'End in sight' for foot and mouth

fields.headline: 'End in sight' for foot and mouth
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The prime minister said today that the government was getting foot and mouth disease under control, but everyone should remain "vigilant".
fields.body:
The prime minister said today that the government was getting foot and mouth disease under control, but everyone should remain "vigilant".

The last pyre has now been lit in Devon, a county that suffered a large backlog of slaughtered animals awaiting disposal. It is expected to burn for a week but, when it stops, no more will be built.

"The battle is not over yet but I believe that we are on the home straight," he said.

Mr Blair thanked the people who worked to bring foot and mouth disease under control, the logistics of which operation he said had exceeded the scale of the Gulf war.

Vets, the army, scientists and farmers were among those applauded for their efforts and endurance. But Mr Blair insisted that the disease was not at an end.

"We will remain on watch. It is essential that we do so. We will not slacken our guard against foot and mouth."

The prime minister added that there is a lot of work to be done cleaning up affected farms and rebuilding the tourist industry. He said the bank holiday weekend provided an opportunity to remind the public that the best way to help the countryside was to visit it.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, will work with the livestock industry on a regeneration package once the outbreak is over.

The government's chief scientist, David King, said that the current outbreak was more severe than the last, in 1967, because it was transmitted through sheep, not cattle.

That made the contiguous cull policy, where animals on neighbouring farms were slaughtered, entirely necessary, he said. Professor King added that the policy was recently sharpened, not relaxed, to spare animals, such as Phoenix the calf, who were on farms at no risk from the disease.

He said that foot and mouth had declined according to predictions that confirmed cases would halve every two weeks. There is currently an average of eight new cases a day, Professor King explained, which is down from 16 a fortnight ago and 32 two weeks before that.

webTitle: Winning the referendum is the beginning, not the end

fields.headline: Winning the referendum is the beginning, not the end
fields.standfirst:
Blair must sell a vision of Europe, as well as the euro, to the voters

Special report: economic and monetary union
Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: Blair must sell a vision of Europe, as well as the euro, to the voters.
fields.body:
When the euro-referendum happens, which as I reported on Tuesday is likely to be next year, it will be a great existential contest. Though the question will be a technicality about the currency, the struggle will be about the future of Britain. The outcome will settle matters for at least a decade if the answer is no, indefinitely if it is yes. The stakes will be the highest imaginable. This is the kind of political gamble seldom seen anywhere. To win it, Tony Blair will have to achieve the great irony of making Britain, several years after everyone else joined up, the first country in Europe to secure a direct popular mandate for membership of the single currency.

At the moment, he's not equipped to do this. Nowhere near. He has barely started. The build-up of public rejection, folded into mounting hostility to "Europe" in general, has been nurtured by a decade's worth of propaganda in major newspapers, for which Europe is the key exhibit in the degradation of their reporting - and their front-page merger of comment with news, masquerading as fact, that supports it. The government has not addressed this with any collective urgency. It will take time after June 8 to map the path, re-steer the media, manage opinion, galvanise the party and cement a coalition, all elementary preliminaries to a referendum.

There's a further challenge. The UK's entry would be the first whose timing makes it likely that the process will straddle another election. A yes result would come only towards the start of what's being reckoned a three-year period before euro notes and coins displace the beloved pound. There are Tories already preparing to fight in the last ditch, and promise sterling's salvation even after the currencies have locked. So in the Treasury especially, the referendum is seen as a start not an end. Its verdict must endure. Though Gordon Brown no longer says he needs evidence of a 70-30 majority before a referendum is contemplated, there's anxiety that a narrow result might not be accepted as legitimate, with consequent damage in financial and political markets alike. In the view of both Blair and Brown, the campaign must produce a deep, not a momentary, change in opinion.

The fundamental reason why Blair thinks he can achieve this is that nobody has attempted it before. Opinion against the euro has built without a single wholehearted speech by any leading figure, in either major party, making the case the other way. Not one. Only Paddy Ashdown and Charles Kennedy have been unambiguous. Apart from them, the case has gone by default, every favourable utterance drained by disclaimers. The arresting consequence of this is not that nearly 70 per cent of people, if asked today, would vote no, but that more than 30 per cent would vote yes. This is the ground Blair believes he can cultivate and extend. In the polls, most people concede that the euro, though they dislike the prospect of it, is likely to happen anyway. To ministers this too is promising material. It suggests that long-term thinking has a decent chance of eclipsing short-term terror and distaste.

Getting that far, however, entails winning some battles with the other EU members. In Brown's mind, by far the most important concerns tax harmonisation. He is finding common ground with other finance ministers on the behaviour of the European Central Bank, its absurdly deflationary targeting, and its lack of what they call a political face. Most agree, Brown included, that while the ECB must remain independent, its lack of a political dimension and its incompetence at explaining itself have become serious liabilities.

Tax, on the other hand, will not go away. Euro-members believe that some bits of harmonisation will soon be essential. Britain has been successful, at both Nice and Malmo, in keeping it off the agenda. Brown knows this cannot last for ever. He insistently interrogates every EU finance minister he meets, on this subject more than any other. But one of the toughest issues facing him will be, I think, not how to perpetuate the veto, but how to find words that admit minimal areas of harmonisation are unavoidable. The word needs de-demonising. There's a limit to how long Euro-members will wait.

For Blair, as prime minister, the bigger picture is what bothers him. He knows that, when he seeks voters' approval for the euro, he will need a story to tell about the future of Europe. What kind of EU are we being asked to bind ourselves definitively into? He won't be able to answer that question precisely before 2004. But the direction is important. Will it be the EU of the German SPD, whose policy paper this week voiced intense impatience with gridlock in Brussels and proposed empowering the commission to break it, alongside more "democratisation" via both the council, of national leaders, and the European parliament?

Though part of this appeals to Blair, because it has a strong parallel thrust taking some powers back to the nation states, it is integrationist. It shapes the silhouette of a partly political Europe. As such, and irrespective of its limits, it is wide open to the fear-mongering we saw in the press this week, feeding on simplistic images which, after decades of exaggeration on one side and false denial the other, have become the standard fare of Britain's EU discussion. Even though some of the German plan will be rejected by many EU members, it is a benchmark for the debate that will now unfold. Germany is becoming, for the first time since 1958, the unrivalled leader of Europe.

Blair rejects the German vision. He may want a more efficient "Europe", and therefore a better commission. But he's a modern Gaullist. He talks more than ever about nations not being submerged. He knows that the future-of-Europe debate will play directly into his referendum, and is pleading with other leaders to be sensitive to that. Their self-restraint may be imperfectly achieved. Strongly though he will resist the more lurid forms of federalisation, therefore, it is imperative for any successful campaign here that he finds the language in which to describe, and indeed exalt, as no British leader has done before, the necessarily political dimension of this body we've belonged to for almost 30 years.

On both economic and political fronts, in other words, Brown and Blair must take risks with the picture they paint. Holding the referendum may be a huge political gamble, but the precondition for winning it is to gamble on something else - a bit of honest clarity. Blair seems to accept that. He has exceptional belief in his powers of persuasion. He also knows that if he can't deliver a result after this election, he never will, and maybe no one else will either. He needs to make a start in the election itself: if Hague is smashed, let Europhobia not fail to be included explicitly among the ruins. But it's what comes next that matters. Forward in the 21st century, or back to the 20th?

As such, and irrespective of its limits, it is wide open to the fear-mongering we saw in the press this week, feeding on simplistic images which, after decades of exaggeration on one side and false denial the other, have become the standard fare of Britain's EU discussion. Even though some of the German plan will be rejected by many EU members, it is a benchmark for the debate that will now unfold. Germany is becoming, for the first time since 1958, the unrivalled leader of Europe. Blair rejects the German vision. He may want a more efficient "Europe", and therefore a better commission. But he's a modern Gaullist. He talks more than ever about nations not being submerged. He knows that the future-of-Europe debate will play directly into his referendum, and is pleading with other leaders to be sensitive to that. Their self-restraint may be imperfectly achieved. Strongly though he will resist the more lurid forms of federalisation, therefore, it is imperative for any successful campaign here that he finds the language in which to describe, and indeed exalt, as no British leader has done before, the necessarily political dimension of this body we've belonged to for almost 30 years. On both economic and political fronts, in other words, Brown and Blair must take risks with the picture they paint. Holding the referendum may be a huge political gamble, but the precondition for winning it is to gamble on something else - a bit of honest clarity. Blair seems to accept that. He has exceptional belief in his powers of persuasion. He also knows that if he can't deliver a result after this election, he never will, and maybe no one else will either. He needs to make a start in the election itself: if Hague is smashed, let Europhobia not fail to be included explicitly among the ruins. But it's what comes next that matters. Forward in the 21st century, or back to the 20th? hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Belgium's push to unify EU rattles UK and Sweden

fields.headline: Belgium's push to unify EU rattles UK and Sweden
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian prime minister, praised  as "very good" the proposals for greater political  integration made this week by the German chancellor,  Gerhard Schröder.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian prime minister, praised as "very good" the proposals for greater political integration made this week by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. The proposals for discussion irritated a British government hoping to avoid EU controversy on the eve of an election.

Mr Schröder proposed abolishing the council of ministers and turning the European commission into an executive body headed by a prime minister. The council would be replaced by a second chamber whose members, appointed by member states, would review parliamentary legislation.

The Belgians also managed to outrage normally unflappable Sweden, holder of the EU's rotating presidency, by launching their own detailed programme two months before their term begins on July 1. Mr Verhofstadt also implied that the Swedes would fail to achieve their own goals.

The Belgian Liberal leader said he would be looking at prospects for the "harmonisation" of workers' consultation rules across the EU, a subject on which Tony Blair is isolated; on the continent there is outrage about recent mass redundancies.

British diplomats have been worried for months about the contents of the declaration due to be made at the EU summit in Laeken, Belgium, in December. It follows on from last year's agreement at Nice for a "deeper, wider debate" by 2004.

"There is support for an ambitious Laeken declaration," Mr Verhofstadt said. "We don't want to be aloof and neutral."

Mr Blair, worried about a future euro referendum, has already asked the Belgian leader to tone down discussion of tax harmonisation. But Mr Verhofstadt's priorities explicitly mention "a common economic policy".

Last night the Conservatives pounced on his comments.

"The Belgian presidency reads like a leftwing wish-list for an EU superstate," said the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude.

"Most European governments are now unveiling ideas for the future of the EU. Labour are shamefully silent because they know their own beliefs contradict those of the mainstream majority of the British people. Tony Blair is scared of debate."

Nations holding the rotating EU presidency do not automatically get their way: they must try to find the middle ground of any debate. But they can be highly influential in setting priorities and tone.

Preparations for the change to euro notes and coins - due on January 1 - and negotiations on enlargement would be big preoccupations, Mr Verhofstadt said.

France, meanwhile, rejected Mr Schröder's vision of a future Europe, but said that the EU should still be heading "much further down the road to integration".

In the first official French reaction to the Schröder plan, France's European affairs minister, Pierre Moscovici, described it as "lacking in balance".

"States cannot simply be the second chamber of the European parliament," Mr Moscovici said, adding that the chancellor's ideas "go a long way down a German - that is to say federalist - road".

"I don't think it is at the centre of EU thinking," he said.

fields.headline: Pub Landlord extends drinking hours
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: The sitcom based on Al Murray's Pub Landlord stand-up act is to get a second Sky One run, reports Jason Deans.
.13.09.00: Enfield gives BSkyB biggest audience share for two years
08.09.99: Sky agrees £3m deal for pub landlord
fields.body:
Time Gentlemen Please, the sitcom based on Al Murray's Pub Landlord stand-up act, has been recommissioned for a second Sky One run.

Sky One has ordered a further 15 episodes of the sitcom, which will again be co-written by Murray and fellow comedian Richard Herring.

The Avalon Television show will return with regular first series cast members Julia Sawalha, Phil Daniels, Rebecca Front and Jason Freeman on board.

Murray signed a £3m deal with Sky One in September 1999 to develop his Pub Landlord live routine into a sitcom.

The first 22-part run of Time Gentlemen Please had a mixed critical reaction, but achieved good ratings for Sky One, with a peak audience share of 9% in multi-channel homes.

The show has also gone out on the Seven Network in Australia.

"This deal further underlines Sky's commitment to invest in the very best British talent," said Mark Freeland, Sky One controller of original programmes.

Murray is currently performing his new Pub Landlord stand-up show My Gaff, My Rules in London.

Related stories

fields.headline: A-level playing field
fields.standfirst:
Changes to the curriculum mean that sixth formers are being encouraged to broaden their choice of subject

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Changes to the curriculum mean that sixth formers are being encouraged to broaden their choice of subject.
fields.body:
Advanced or A-levels have proved a resilient qualification but they were designed for an era when far fewer people went on to university. New students bent their choices to their strengths. The proportion of A-level students taking the "mixed" option, sciences and arts/ social science subjects together, rose from less than a tenth in 1962 to more than a third in 1995.

But such mixtures did not entail breadth and there were difficulties. Some of those who did not mix and match found themselves narrowed into an all-science or all-arts curriculum.

These trends, charted by Alan Smithers at Liverpool University, help explain the thinking behind Curriculum 2000, the new post-16 system of qualifications for England, Wales and Northern Ireland. David Blunkett the education secretary wants more students to take a science or a language alongside their principal subjects. He has also introduced "vocational A-levels", another can of worms. In some of the first such exams nine out of ten students failed.

The new attempt to broaden the 16-18 curriculum, which got going last September, is about to face its first serious test as this summer thousands of lower sixth formers start taking the new AS-level.

The old A-level calendar of five terms of thinking deep thoughts before a student's future was decided in a short, brutal summer at the end of the upper sixth had been undermined in recent years by modular A-level courses and the introduction of AS levels. Now it has been demolished. Students do not have to complete two years now to have something to show for their work. But they are expected to take four or five AS levels in their first year of study.

Most students take the exams in June. In the second year of sixth form, they take A2s. The AS and the A2 together constitutes a new A-level. The AS is a qualification in its own right, but the A2 is not. The AS level is meant to be easier than A-level, though perhaps not "GCSE plus 10%" as it has been characterised. The A2 is supposed to be harder than A-level but some teachers reckon it will do well to retain the same standard.

The government also wants students to acquire "key skills" within their course. These are listed as numerical skills, communications and information technology. Next year, new "advanced extension awards" will be available for the brightest students.

So far, the fullest description of the first year of Curriculum 2000 comes from the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service, which surveyed 1,300 schools. It reports that 66.1% of students following an academic curriculum were doing four AS levels, 3.6% were doing five and 17.8% were doing three. Some in government hoped that five would become the norm in the first year, but it has not yet. Some 8.4% of students had dropped one or more AS subject already. Some 75.4% of students were expected to concentrate on three A2s in the second year and 14.4% to take four.

It is not clear whether students are taking a new mix ture of subjects. Asked if they were encouraging students to take subjects from contrasting disciplines, 8.2% replied "yes, definitely" and 44.4% "yes, generally". But 42.4% said they were "neutral".

This report and a survey by the Secondary Heads Association (SHA) suggest an emerging divide between private and state schools. The SHA says 95% of maintained but only 56% of independent schools will test for all three of the key skills mentioned above. It also looks as though class sizes in state schools are growing. Fewer state schools and colleges (14% compared with 35% in the private sector) plan to offer the advanced extension awards.

The Institute of Education in London finds what it calls "quantitative gains and qualitative questions". The gains include much more time being spent on teaching. The 1988 Dearing report on sixth form education, the source of these curriculum reforms, criticised the fact that British students generally got only 15-18 hours of taught time a week, compared with around 30 hours in France or Germany.

But schools are also finding AS is more of a grind than an intellectual challenge. Students were choosing to do a fourth AS not because they thought it demonstrated breadth but because it was not too difficult or merely because it was new. Inevitably, there are worries about workload. A survey by the Association of Colleges suggests more pupils are sticking with courses than last year. But the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' conference heard that some students are buckling under the pressure and the letters page of Guardian Education shows many students are finding working weeks of around 50-60 hours an immense strain.

Next month UCAS publishes a list of the new "tariffs" required by universities for entry in autumn 2002. Curriculum 2000 will have a huge impact on the admissions process as colleges will already have the results of students' first year A-level study. Most universities have been slow to respond to the new qualifications, prefer to ignore key skills and are reluctant to give guidance on whether they would prefer the "extra" AS-level to be a different discipline. The result is yet more anxiety for students who are losing the pleasure of a rare exam-free summer between GCSE and the rest of their lives.

 Will Woodward is the Guardian's education editor. will.woodward@theguardian.comco.uk
