webTitle: Charities urged to shake off 'big business' image

fields.headline: Charities urged to shake off 'big business' image
fields.trailText: The head of the charity commission has warned major charities that they must adopt a more collaborative approach if they are to convince the public they are not "wasting resources".
fields.body:
The head of the charity commission has warned major charities that they must adopt a more collaborative approach if they are to convince the public they are not "wasting resources".

Chief charity commissioner John Stoker also said the big charities must work harder to dispel a growing public perception that they are turning into impersonal "big businesses".

Speaking at the Charity Finance Directors' Group (CFDG) annual conference, Mr Stoker said: "Our postbag suggests that people's experiences of fundraising can add to the impression of a crowded - even overcrowded - charity field.

"Part of this is just a feeling that there is an awful lot of it about. But part is also a reaction against the way in which fundraising is sometimes done."

Mr Stoker also said the sheer number of charities caused public concern. "If you're told that there are 188,000 registered charities - or 4,000 charities just in Devon, or 600 cancer charities, or 200 homelessness charities in London - you immediately struggle to imagine what each can possibly be doing that is distinctive."

Public confidence and support could be boosted if charities engaged in more joint working, Mr Stoker claimed. This was in addition to the concrete benefits he said could be realised in terms of reduced costs, enhanced income or improved services.

Mr Stoker recommended shared helplines, the joint production of training material, purchasing consortia, joint flag days, combined grant administration and marketing initiatives, through to partial or full mergers.

For its part, the charity commission was collaborating with voluntary sector umbrella bodies - the CFDG; the National Council for Voluntary Organisations; the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations, and the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers - to study the need for a central repository of knowledge and information, and a source of advice for charities on collaborative working.

But Mr Stoker also said charities needed to dispel the myth that there were too many charities. He said of the 190,000 registered charities, 30,000 were subsidiaries of others and a further 130,000 were volunteer-run local charities.

"This still sounds a lot, until you start adding up the various types: 2,300 recreation ground and playing field charities; 2,400 parent and teacher associations and home school associations; 5,300 village halls, and so on, across the spectrum of community endeavour.

"By and large there is no overlap, no duplication and little scope for cost-cutting."

These calculations leave about 30,000 charities that employ staff and can be seen as professional charities.

Mr Stoker said there are clear advantages to be had from a healthy plurality of charities and added: "We need to hammer home these advantages with the public, not expect them to be taken as read."

Continuing the theme of greater openness, Mr Stoker said charities needed to be willing to disclose, explain and justify their actions and expenditure.

"When people say things like 'charities are big businesses nowadays,' they are articulating a specific sense of regret. This is the regret that some charities have grown impersonal as they have grown large and that they have been unable to maintain a charitable way of doing things that distinguishes them from the hard ways of business, and, indeed, from the public sector."

fields.headline: The news just keeps coming
fields.trailText: We've loads on the site today and more to come later. Here's what's making headlines this lunchtime:
fields.body:
We've loads on the site today and more to come later. Here's what's making headlines this lunchtime:

News: £100m for maternity services

Health secretary Alan Milburn has unveiled a £100m cash injection for maternity services to ensure every woman has one-to-one, continuous care with a midwife during labour.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/NHSstaff/story/0,7991,481965,00.html

Mental health: Exorcism: abuse or cure?

While the use of exorcism in treating mental health problems may seem far-fetched, Anglican and Catholic priests are still performing the controversial ritual. David Batty reports.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare/0,7886,374545,00.html

Local government: Councillors urged to take oath

A thinktank says councillors should take a 'Hippocratic oath', pledging to do their best to serve the community.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/modlocalgov/0,7989,392390,00.html

Voluntary sector: Charity staff face redundancy

NCVO, the charities' representative body, is to make nearly 10% of its staff redundant in a restructure.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/charitymanagement/0,8145,423472,00.html

Charities urged to shake off 'big business' image

The head of the charity commission has warned major charities that they must adopt a more collaborative approach if they are to convince the public they are not 'wasting resources'.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/voluntary/

Housing: Government to target number of B&B homeless

Housing minister Nick Raynsford has announced an initiative to get families out of bed and breakfast hotels.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/housing/

Voluntary sector: Samaritans target farmers with TV adverts

The Samaritans are rushing out a TV campaign urging farmers to seek help following a series of suicides related to the foot and mouth crisis.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/campaigning/0,8145,390105,00.html

More health: NHS faces £3.9bn negligence claims

The NHS is facing claims totalling £3.9bn in England for negligence by hospital doctors and other staff, according to a report today from the national audit office, the official watchdog on public spending.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health/

Health: Legal threat to morning-after pill sales

Britain's longest established anti-abortion group has won permission for a high court action to try to stop sales of the morning-after pill to women over 16 from pharmacists, without a prescription.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health/story/0,7890,481964,00.html

Social care: Scots social workers 'sensitive and reliable'

Social workers' reputations as bureaucratic, interfering busy-bodies is unfounded, according to a survey of public attitudes to the profession by the Scottish executive.

More social care: Minister defends smack and smoke rules for childminders

Controversial new rules allowing childminders to smack their charges and smoke in front of them will be included in the first national childcare standards due to be published next week, education minister Margaret Hodge has revealed.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare/

Log on to the site later as we will be constantly updating the news and features throughout the day.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/

fields.headline: BBC1 is no match for ITV's Big Match
fields.trailText: 2pm TV overnights: The Leeds v Valencia Champions League game drew an audience of 7.5m, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Manchester United's departure from the Champions League took its toll on ITV's rating last night, when only 7.5m watched Leeds United's semi-final clash with Valencia.

Two weeks ago, 9.3m viewers witnessed Bayern Munich push Man United out of the Champions League.

The Big Match - Live, which featured coverage of Leeds' 0-0 draw with Valencia, went out between 7.30pm and 9.45pm last night.

The football show had 7.5m viewers and a 34% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

The Big Match was still too strong for the BBC1 competition.

This is Your Life was the strongest opposition and went out between 8pm and 8.30pm.

The Michael Aspel-fronted show had 6.9m viewers and a 31% audience share.

BBC1's latest documentary offering, Hollywood Knives - the Secret History of Tinseltown Under the Scalpel, went out last night between 9pm and 10pm.

It pulled in 5.2m viewers and had a 22% audience share.

ITV's documentary about Delia Smith's ownership of Norwich City Football Club went out between 10.35pm and 11.20pm and beat BBC1's movie, Breast Men.

Ooh Ahh Delia had 3.6m viewers and a 28% audience share; while Breast Men, which starred Friends' David Schwimmer as one of the doctors who invented breast implants, had just 2.6m.

fields.headline: Merger memories
fields.trailText: Today's announcement that QPR and Wimbledon are in talks over a possible merger has stirred some unwelcome old memories. Not so long ago, it seemed as if there was a new club about to be formed on a daily basis.
fields.body:
Today's announcement that QPR and Wimbledon are in talks over a possible merger has stirred some unwelcome old memories. Not so long ago, it seemed as if there was a new club about to be formed on a daily basis.

Although the two clubs in question have never tried it on with each other before, it's hardly the first time either of them have entertained the idea of shedding their identity and jumping into bed with another club.

Almost exactly two years ago to the day, Wimbledon were in discussions with their Selhurst Park landlords Crystal Palace over a merger. The idea only fell by the wayside because of strong fan opposition and the fact that Wimbledon were not prepared to give up the Premiership place they then held to join Palace in the First.

Wimbledon's efforts pale into insignificance however when compared with the Rangers. QPR nearly linked up with Brentford in 1967, before supporters got their act together and told the men in suits where to stick their superclub.

But the same west London club were also major players in one of the most high-profile merger controversies of the 80s. In 1987, David Bulstrode, chairman of Fulham and commercial developers Marler, bought Loftus Road. Bulstrode had earmarked Craven Cottage for lucrative housing and needed somewhere to dump the then-struggling residents, so he mooted the idea of Fulham Park Rangers. "Bulldozer" Bulstrode's plan was only derailed by the frenzied efforts of fans, local councillors and, eventually, the Football League.

There was one other big merger story that decade, and it can be summed up in two fat words: Robert Maxwell. The sweaty swindler took control of Oxford in the early 80s and soon announced plans to merge the club with Reading. Neither set of fans thought much of the rotund idiot's scheme, and successfully took to the streets to put a stop to it.

Much the same thing happened a few years later in Edinburgh, when Hearts chairman Wallace "Merger" Mercer tried to swallow up Hibs to form Edinburgh United. Sense again prevailed, although only because Kwik-Fit chairman Tom Farmer saved the Hibees at the last minute by saving the struggling Easter Road club from receivership.

Dundee and Sheffield are just two other cities whose residents have given the big two fingers to merger plans: Dundee, Dundee United and the Sheffields Wednesday and United all live to fight another day and other half-baked schemes. So the message is: if you don't want a super club, then take to the streets. Just as long as it's not Oxford St.

There has, however, been one successful merger, of sorts. Highland League clubs Inverness Caledonian and Inverness Thistle merged in the early 90s to become Inverness Caledonian Thistle, joined the Scottish League, and are now one of the strongest teams in the Scottish First Division.

Even then, there were serious downsides. Although overall crowds are up, many stalwart supporters have left in disillusionment, never to return to the clubs they've followed for years. And you've got to feel for fans of Inverness's third club, Clachnacuddin, who declined to join the merged club and remain three divisions below their rivals, peering up.

fields.headline: Kremlin's influence waning
fields.standfirst: A Russian rethink on Bush's missile defence programme betrays growing anxiety about the country's international clout, writes Ian Traynor
fields.trailText: A Russian rethink on Bush's missile defence programme betrays growing anxiety about the country's international clout, writes Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
After months of fierce hostility from the Kremlin towards the Bush administration's missile defence plans, the Russians are pragmatically calculating that there is no stopping the New Right ascendancy in America and that their best hope is to negotiate to try to influence the Pentagon scheme.

President Vladimir Putin, Russian defence officials, parliamentary bigwigs and the foreign policy elite in Moscow have been warning all this year that the US "Son of Star Wars" scheme will trigger a new arms race and destabilise the world.

Suddenly the Kremlin has changed its tune. A mood of realpolitik appears to be taking hold. We can neither beat nor stop the Americans, so we might as well try to influence them by being positive, open to talks, runs the Kremlin calculation.

Many analysts in Moscow see this as a tactical and strategic error, encouraging the Bush team to ride roughshod over Russian sensibilities and priorities. In this view, the first Russian mistake came earlier this year when Mr Putin proposed to the Nato secretary-general, George Robertson, that missile defences could be put on the international agenda and that Russia had its own ideas for a European missile defence plan that would be less ambitious than the American and leave existing international arms control agreements intact.

The Russian plan was flimsy. Not taken seriously. Perhaps it was not even intended seriously, but rather as a political gambit aimed at detaching Nato's European allies from its transatlantic leader. If so, the gambit failed.

Instead Nato and the US seized on Mr Putin's "concession" and his implicit recognition that the threat of modern missiles proliferation was indeed a problem not addressed by the cold war instruments of the 1972 ABM treaty and the entire body of arms control pacts which flowed from that.

Mr Bush's keynote speech on missile defence included the most conciliatory words yet from his administration on relations with Russia. Seen from Moscow, Mr Bush's first 100 days have been notable for the gratuitous snubs directed at Moscow by Donald Rumsfeld, the Pentagon chief, and Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser.

''Russia and the United States should work together to develop a new foundation for world peace and security in the 21st century. We should leave behind the constraints of an ABM treaty that perpetuates a relationship based on distrust and mutual vulnerability,'' Mr Bush declared.

''We should work together to replace this treaty with a new framework that reflects a clear and clean break from the past, and especially from the adversarial legacy of the cold war. This new cooperative relationship should look to the future, not to the past. It should be reassuring, rather than threatening. It should be premised on openness, mutual confidence and real opportunities for cooperation, including the area of missile defense.

''We may have areas of difference with Russia, but we are not and must not be strategic adversaries. Russia and America both face new threats to security. Together, we can address today's threats and pursue today's opportunities.''

Such inclusive remarks flatter the Russians, who have been virtually pleading for an early Bush-Putin summit, so far unsuccessfully. Mr Bush called British, French, German, and Japanese leaders to brief them on his speech and then, a full day later, he also spent 12 minutes on the phone to Mr Putin.

The Kremlin is increasingly on the defensive, keen to maintain parity at the negotiating table with the Americans. But the Russians are punching above their weight and they know it. If Mr Bush's central message on missile defence and arms control is that the cold war is history, it follows that the US victor will be less than accommodating towards the vanquished enemy. Magnanimity appears in short supply.

The Kremlin's eagerness to engage with the Americans reflects the fear of US unilateralism. If Mr Bush this week signalled he wanted to slash the US nuclear arsenal to sweeten the bitter Star Wars pill, there was little sign that he wanted to pursue the arms cuts in tandem with the Russians.

Mr Putin, too, is keen to enact large cuts in Russia's nuclear warheads to around one-quarter of current stockpiles, not least for reasons of economics and badly needed military reform. But he wants that to happen in concert with the Americans to show that Russia is still a great power commanding international prestige, his central leadership pledge to the Russian public.

Besides, the nuclear arsenal is perhaps Russia's sole remaining source of leverage with the Americans. Washington appears to be suggesting that it wants to slash its warheads anyway, regardless of the Russian arsenal which it does not view as threatening and also to avoid being bound by international agreements.

Mr Putin came to power by playing on Russian frustration with national decline and promising to make Russia great again. But despite Mr Bush's conciliatory language, his administration demonstrates weekly that Russia is sinking as a US foreign policy priority.

fields.headline: Ken you credit it?
fields.standfirst: Ken Bates, sacked as chairman of the new Wembley, has waded into the row again by telling the world that Kate Hoey should be "shot" for undermining the project. Funnily enough, this isn't the first time big Ken has opened his even bigger mouth
fields.trailText: "Since Kate Hoey was appointed sports minister there was nothing but criticism. We were supposed to be pulling together but all she did was undermine everything, and she's not qualified to do so" - On being removed as chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited, Ken has a public pop at Kate Hoey.
fields.body:
"Since Kate Hoey was appointed sports minister there was nothing but criticism. We were supposed to be pulling together but all she did was undermine everything, and she's not qualified to do so" - On being removed as chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited, Ken has a public pop at Kate Hoey.

"Even Jesus only had one Pontius Pilate. I had a whole team of them" - From the same bilious resignation letter, Ken on the rest of his WNSL colleagues.

"There was only one Matthew Harding and, if I might say so, thank God for that. I don't think I could have coped with two of them" - Ken on his former colleague, only one year after Harding's death in a helicopter crash.

"You would not expect Ruud to go to Peterborough on a wet Tuesday night in November to watch a player we fancy" - Ken on Ruud Gullit, after he'd sacked him in 1998.

"John is a very well-balanced individual, he has a chip on both shoulders" - Ken on John Gregory.

"I don't know whether pay-per-view could be operated across national borders. There may be a billion United supporters in the Far East, but getting a tenner out of them is another matter" - Ken offers his considered opinion on pay-per-view TV.

"There is no escaping the fact Sutton was a disaster. His attitude wasn't right towards the end. He wasn't good for Chelsea" - Ken, who saw fit to spend £10m on Chris Sutton, lambasts the player only 12 months later.

"Someone came up to me recently and said they actually preferred the old atmosphere [at Stamford Bridge]. I said to him: 'Not only do you look like a prat, but you are a prat. If you really think the atmosphere was better then, come and see me after the game and I'll get two security guards to rough you up and piss in your pocket.'" - Ken heads boldly into the future.

AND FINALLY

"I'm not starstruck around players. How could I be? I'm the biggest star here!"

fields.headline: Indy cuts online operations
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: The Independent has become the latest newspaper to scale back its internet operation, writes Amy Vickers.

Special report: dot.coms and dotgones
fields.body:
The Independent has become the latest newspaper to scale back its internet operation.

The cuts - believed to affect seven contract staff and all casuals - were made last week as part of a longer-term plan to achieve profitability.

Overheads have been cut and Independent Digital has been reduced to a core of around 18 staff.

Richard Withey, the managing director of Independent Digital, said it was now track to break even by the first quarter of 2002.

"We've always run a small, tight but effective ship. Yes, we have lost a couple of contractors, and some casual shifts, but we still have enough of both, plus our very effective permanent team led on the editorial side by David Felton," he said.

"Our recent and well-received redesign led to much greater automation, and allows us to do this without pain."

Independent.co.uk was launched as the paper's most significant online offensive to date in July 1999, but soon after began to scale back its investment in original content and remained a modestly sized operation when competitors began to rapidly expand.

However, to show it meant business, the Independent brought in two former News International internet experts, Mr Withey and Paul Simon, and seconded David Felton, assistant editor on the paper, to be online editor.

Mr Simon left last month to set up his own consultancy, called Isaiah Consulting.

The recent belt-tightening reflects an industry-wide trend to button down and survive the downturn in internet advertising revenues.

Last month the Financial Times said it was cutting 40 staff, Trinity Mirror laid off 85 staff and closed a number of websites, while Emap slashed 100 staff from Emap Digital and axed some websites.

fields.headline: Handbag.com mulls masthead TV move
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Women's website Handbag.com is considering a move into masthead TV-type programming, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Handbag.com is considering a move into masthead TV-type programming.

The women's website, jointly owned by the Telegraph Group and Boots, has recommissioned internet TV company Kamera to produce broadcasts for its website, which it said could be a precursor to Handbag.com-branded TV shows.

Kamera, which counts the boss of BBC Worldwide's internet and interactive division, Drew Kaza, among its non-executive board members, has already developed 'how to' shows for Handbag.com.

The new commissions mean Kamera will produce three new original internet shows and a further series of 'how to' shows featuring Handbag.com personalities.

"Handbag has been doing internet broadcasting for a few months now and it's been going very well," said a spokeswoman for Handbag.com.

"There is a possibility further down the line of extending this to TV - it's an obvious extension."

fields.headline: Missing schoolgirl 'met man through internet'
fields.trailText: Police were today continuing their search for a schoolgirl who is believed to have disappeared with a man she met through an internet chatroom.
fields.body:
Police were today continuing their search for a schoolgirl who is believed to have disappeared with a man she met through an internet chatroom.

Kelly Marie Reid, 16, left her home in Merthyr Tydfil, south Wales, last Thursday.

The teenager, due to take her GCSE examinations this summer, is believed to be with 20-year-old Robert Percy, a supermarket worker from Exeter, who she met online last October.

Detective Inspector Keith Bowman of south Wales police said yesterday that they could not state yet whether or not there were any suspicious circumstances behind her disappearance.

However, he added that he was particularly worried because the pair had met over the internet.

He said: "It looks like she has gone with him willingly but it doesn't mean she wants to stay. Meeting over the internet means you don't really know who they are dealing with."

Mr Percy had visited Ms Reid, who left home with a rucksack of clothes and around £100 in cash, only twice since they began communicating online.

Mr Percy has not been seen at his work or by his family since the time of Ms Reid's disappearance. They are believed to be in the south east of England travelling in a blue-black Rover car.

webTitle: IPPR tells councillors to take community oath

fields.headline: IPPR tells councillors to take community oath
fields.trailText: A leading thinktank has come up with a novel way to enhance the profile of local politicians - it suggests that they take a "Hippocratic oath", pledging to do their best to serve the community.
fields.body:
A leading thinktank has come up with a novel way to enhance the profile of local politicians - it suggests that they take a "Hippocratic oath", pledging to do their best to serve the community.

Local councillors are so disenchanted with their jobs that they are taking on the "No one likes us, we don't care" mantra of Millwall football club, according to report published today by the Institute for Public Policy Research.

To add to their woe, latest opinion polls suggest that turnout for local elections, postponed to June 7 because of the foot and mouth crisis, will fall to a postwar low. Matthew Taylor, the director of the IPPR, said: "The depressingly low status of councillors, both on the street and in the corridors of power, should be taken more seriously by anyone interested in revitalising our flagging economy."

The oath, which would potentially give councillors a legal redress against edicts from national government they disagree with, has the backing of several local politicians.

Councillor Ian Bottrill, of Warwickshire county council, said: "I have no doubt that this oath will help local government gain the confidence of both people and the government that we can really deliver."

The report also argues against local referendums, such as the one held recently by Bristol city council on whether to raise council tax. In that case, local voters vetoed an increase, but the IPPR insists that "complex decisions councils have to make can't be made adequately by a whole community in a one-off ballot".

Milton Keynes and Croydon have tried similar, one-off experiments.

fields.headline: Scottish business gets new glossy
fields.trailText:
8.30am: A week after Business 2.0 folded, a new glossy magazine is being launched to Scotland's business community, reports Jessica Hodgson.
30.04.2001: Bleak future for Business 2.0 staff
fields.body:
Just one week after Business 2.0 announced its closure, a new glossy magazine is being launched to Scotland's business community.

Up Magazine, launched by MHP Associates, is pitching itself as glossy and upmarket, stressing its similarities with Vanity Fair and the Sunday supplements.

The magazine is being launched with backing from businesses like Bank of Scotland, Ernst & Young and Scottish Power, and will have staff based in London, New York, Sydney and Beijing as well as a further eight at its Glasgow base.

The first issue carries an interview with Sun Microsystems chief Scott McNealy, and "globally minded Scots" Willie Haughey and John Rowley.

Editor John Hatfield, a former Scotsman and FT journalist, said: "We've got a very experienced team, and being Scots, we're used to running it on a tight cost base."

Up Magazine's publisher John Main said: "Ideas are global these days and our aim is to seek out the cutting-edge thinkers and leading players globally and mix that with the best that Scotland and the UK has too offer. We offer inspiration and thought leadership."

Editor John Hatfield claimed also that the magazine's coherent offline strategy would be an important ingredient in its success.

fields.headline: Scotland to adopt best value
fields.trailText: Scottish local government could be working under a new statutory "best value" service-delivery regime in less than two years' time, the Holyrood parliament has announced.
fields.body:
Scottish local government could be working under a new statutory "best value" service-delivery regime in less than two years' time, the Holyrood parliament has announced.

The principles behind the new system will be broadly the same as those already implemented for local government in England and Wales, which place a legal duty on councils to secure "continuous improvement" of their performance.

Scotland's deputy finance and local government minister Peter Peacock said the executive would bring forward legislative proposals in the autumn, and a spokeswoman confirmed that the system could be in place by late 2002.

Scottish councils already operate under a non-statutory best-value framework with the previous and widely disliked compulsory competitive tendering regime suspended.

The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) said that the legal groundwork of Scottish best value would be more a product of partnership working between local and central government than the English system had been.

Cosla claims the bill will draw close connections between best value and community planning, a process that sees councils drawing up a vision for their area in close consultation with local people.

The convention also expects the new bill to be less prescriptive than its English counterpart, allowing local councils more freedom on how they consult their communities, and how they present information about their performance.

Audit Scotland may take the role of policing the new system, although the details of the inspection regime are still under discussion. A Cosla spokesman said one of the options being debated was a cross-sector inspectorate.

Cosla president Norman Murray welcomed Mr Peacock's announcement, saying that the executive would work closely with local government on the bill: "The executive has given its commitment to working in partnership with us, and we in Cosla are equally committed to playing a full part and working closely with the executive during the bill's progress."

Mr Peacock's move comes after a period of heavy discussion with local authorities north of the border. A consultation paper published last year received nearly 70 responses.

The executive is also looking at ways to expand the best value system across the Scottish public sector.

fields.headline: Today's Tories speak up
fields.trailText:
1pm: Today editor Rod Liddle has refuted Michael Ancram's claim that the BBC is a Tory no-go area. By Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The editor of BBC Radio's Today programme has refuted Tory chairman Michael Ancram's claim that the BBC is "empty of people who hold Conservative views".

In this week's Spectator magazine, Rod Liddle presents a straw poll of views held by producers and reporters on the programme which he says show a "fair amount of sympathy for the ideological touchstones identified by the Conservative chairman as anathema to BBC people".

The poll, which Mr Liddle admits was "vulnerable to editorial gerrymandering" reveals that 66% of staff on the programme support reduced government, while 60% want to keep the pound.

The claim contradicts Mr Ancram's assertion that "the politically correct environment [of the programme] dictates that belief in lower taxes, smaller government and saving the pound are the wrong beliefs to hold".

Mr Liddle does, however, concede that Labour was the most popular party, garnering 35.7% of the vote, with the Conservatives coming in second.

Earlier this year Mr Liddle was tipped as a potential replacement for the Spectator's editor, Boris Johnson, who is expected to leave the magazine to stand as a Tory MP.

fields.headline: Blair embroiled in fresh advertising row
fields.trailText: 1pm: The government is at the centre of a fresh row over advertising after admitting the DSS underestimated its spending by £7m. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The government is at the centre of a fresh row over advertising spend after it emerged that the Department of Social Security had underestimated its spending by £7m.

The Conservative party accused Labour of misleading Parliament after the DSS admitted it had wrongly published an advertising budget of £11.3m for the year to the end of March.

In fact, the department spent £18.4m.

Jeff Rooker, the social security minister, blamed the error on a lack of coordination between separate DSS offices.

He said he was taking urgent action to ensure a new system was put in place.

But the fiasco will prove a serious embarrassment to the government, which has been accused o spending taxpayers' money to highlight its policies ahead of a general election.

It emerged last month that Labour was the highest-spending UK advertiser during February outspending multinational companies such as Unilever and Procter & Gamble, with £16.4m going on advertising in just one month.

webTitle: Political soup, as only Alastair can create

fields.headline: Political soup, as only Alastair can create
fields.standfirst: Matthew Tempest attends one of the last lobby briefings by the prime minister's official spokesman and muses on the unique ingredients of a Campbell special
fields.trailText: May 3: Matthew Tempest attends one of the last lobby briefings by the prime minister's official spokesman and muses on the unique ingredients of a Campbell special.
fields.body:
At 3pm yesterday the prime minister told the Commons and the country that no decision on a US missile defence programme would be made until a firm proposal had been received.

At 3.35pm in the Commons press gallery, the prime minister's official spokesman Alastair Campbell told a throng of political journalists that the so-called Son of Star Wars was "broadly a good idea."

Even journalists not versed in reading between the lines of the highly erudite Mr Campbell could detect that this was a significant policy slippage from the repeated flat bat the prime minister had played to the same question from William Hague in the Commons.

And again it raises the question - not to be answered here - of who is setting government policy, the prime minister or his spokesman?

Cynics argue that the policy line is agreed between the two men, who are best friends as well as political soul mates. Their theory is that while Mr Blair gives the TV cameras (and thus posterity) the straight line, off-camera and behind the scenes, Mr Campbell pushes controversial policy forward in the shadowy recesses of the "lobby briefing."

It's a system that could only operate in the UK. In the States, where this particular issue originates, President Bush's press secretary gives televised on the record briefings so no doubt can arise.

Here, despite years of diplomatic ping pong between broadcasters and Downing Street, briefings have never been televised. Indeed until 1986, parliament did not allow cameras in.

With the prime minister's office recently vetoing the idea of televised head to head contests between the party leaders during the election campaign, the likelihood of Mr Campbell appearing on screen is not even on the agenda.

It is television's loss that the medium was never graced by the star performer in Mr Campbell, who will step back from briefing journalists one to one after the election. As even his fiercest critics will agree, he has the charisma and stage presence that could have seen him pursue a career as a standup comedian.

And his Cambridge-educated wit and quick thinking is more than capable of dealing with the largely public school, macho and male world of the lobby: those political journalists working in Westminster granted access to the twice-daily audience with the prime minister's official spokesman.

Not only are Mr Campbell's exchanges with journalists not televised, but the edited version of the sessions are vetted and approved by the spokesman himself before being posted on the No 10 website.

Bizarrely, considering the money Downing Street has already invested in expanding the prime minister's press office, setting up a media monitoring unit and a strategic communications section, the highlights of Mr Campbell's exchanges are presented with this disclaimer: "For reasons of time and costs, these briefings are not transcribed. Instead, a record of the main points made in the briefing is circulated within Whitehall. The extracts in this section are taken from that record."

Thus the truly combative and barbed questioning is tidied up to present the world with a calm and reasoned outline of what the prime minister's thinking on any particular issue is - or edited if so desired.

And of course, Mr Campbell's favourite tricks are invisible on the web. On a blazing hot June day last summer, he was briefing British and foreign journalists on the prime minister's position ahead of a European conference.

More than 70 hacks were crammed into the windowless basement under No 10 where the morning briefings are held, and the heat was stifling. On entering the lion's den, Mr Campbell immediately signalled a minion to switch the air conditioning off.

Thus, by the end of his 20-minute briefing, as the time came for questions from the floor, sweat-soaked journalists were simply desperate for fresh air and daylight.

Mission accomplished.

webTitle: Son of North Korean leader 'enters Japan illegally'

fields.headline: Son of North Korean leader 'enters Japan illegally'
fields.standfirst:
A man authorities believe to be the eldest son of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il has been detained at a Japanese airport for attempting to enter the country illegally

Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: A man authorities believe to be the eldest son of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il has been detained at a Japanese airport  for attempting to enter the country illegally.
fields.body:
A man authorities believe to be the eldest son of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il was detained at Narita airport outside Tokyo for attempting to enter Japan illegally, Kyodo News agency reported today.

Government officials said they were trying still to identify the man, and planned to expel him to China within a couple of days.

National broadcaster NHK reported that the man told authorities he was South Korean.

A South Korean government source said: "There is a possibility that he may indeed be Kim Jong Nam, the son of Kim Jong Il. But we are still collecting intelligence and we cannot say it for sure."

Kyodo said immigration officers detained the man when he arrived from Singapore on Tuesday aboard a Japan Airlines flight with three other people. He carried a forged passport from the Dominican Republic, Kyodo said.

The national police agency, the immigration office, the prime minister's spokesman, Narita police, the Foreign Ministry and the airline all said that they could not immediately confirm the reports.

Japanese government sources said that the people with the man were thought to be relatives.

The general association of Korean residents in Japan said it had no information on the report and that no visit by the reclusive North Korean leader's eldest son was scheduled.

Meanwhile, Kim Jong Il today told a European delegation that his moratorium on missile tests would last at least until 2003, officials said.

During five hours of talks with the first western European leaders to visit North Korea, Kim also said that he wants to hold a second summit with South Korean leader Kim Dae Jung, but not while the Bush administration is reviewing its policies with the North, EU officials said.

They added that North Korea has agreed to send officials to Europe this summer to discuss opening talks about its human rights record.

Little is known about Kim Jong Il's family, but according to South Korean officials, he is believed to have three children, including Kim Jong Nam, who was born in 1971. All were born to different mothers.

Kim Jong Nam was born to 64-year-old Sung Hae Rim. Sung made international headlines in 1996 when she was reported to have defected to the West after disappearing from her Swiss villa. The news followed rumours that Kim Jong Il had jilted her. But South Korea's main government spy agency later denied the reports.

Kim Jong Nam has lived most of his life abroad, in countries such as Switzerland and Russia. His mother, Sung, is believed to be in Moscow for medical treatment for depression.

fields.headline: Lygo jumps ship for Channel 5
fields.trailText:
10am: The man in charge of the Big Breakfast and hit entertainment series So Graham Norton is quitting Channel 4 for Channel 5, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
26.01.2001 Kevin's horoscope

Countdown to E4: Kevin's secret diary
fields.body:
The man who has just clinched a £3m deal to keep Graham Norton at Channel 4 has quit the station.

Kevin Lygo, the station's head of entertainment and controller of E4, is leaving after three-and-a-half years to take up a £250,000-plus job as Channel 5's director of programming.

His move will be a blow to Channel 4, coming less than four months after it launched the new digital TV service, E4.

It also represents an admission by the Channel 5 chief executive, Dawn Airey, that she could no longer do both jobs.

Mr Lygo said: "Yes, it is true I'm leaving. I am delighted but I am not going for some time so it is too early to talk about it in detail."

Ms Airey, who was the station's founding director of programmes, took over as Channel 5's chief executive in October when David Elstein stepped down.

At the time she claimed she would be able to hold down both jobs.

However, one insider said: "It has become apparent over the last few months that she just can't do both. The chief executive's job is concerned with the bigger picture. You simply can't deal with politicians, regulators and the business of a channel and be in charge of details in the schedule as well."

Mr Lygo, who previously worked at the BBC, has had one of the most fraught jobs in entertainment.

He oversaw Chris Evans's TFI Friday through some of its most controversial moments and was brave enough to put the series out of its misery by axing it last year.

He is also preparing to axe the beleaguered Big Breakfast, another show that once starred Chris Evans.

The station is expected to serve a six-month notice on the programme in June.

Mr Lygo can also take credit for discovering Ali G and Graham Norton - he commissioned the Eleven O'Clock show which spawned the spoof gangsta interviewer. And he last week clinched a £3m deal with Norton for his Friday night chat show series.

Mr Lygo was not at the station when Evans was first hired and he missed out on the programme's first clashes with watchdogs including the day when Happy Mondays star Shaun Ryder swore live on air 13 times.

But the show and its presenter, Chris Evans, continued to cause trouble.

Last year TFI Friday was condemned by watchdogs after a seven-year-old boy was reduced to tears after losing a staring competition.

webTitle: McGuinness' IRA role on Bloody Sunday

fields.headline: McGuinness admits leading IRA role on Bloody Sunday
fields.standfirst:
Bloody Sunday
Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness confirmed publicly for the first time yesterday that he was a leading member of the IRA on Bloody Sunday.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness confirmed publicly for the first time yesterday that he was a leading member of the IRA on Bloody Sunday.

He replied "yes" when journalists in Belfast asked if he had given a written statement to the Saville inquiry, saying he was the Provisionals' second in command in Derry when paratroopers shot dead 14 unarmed men at a civil rights march on January 30, 1972. "I will also tell them there were no IRA units on the march, no IRA weapons in the area and no IRA shots fired at the army," said the Northern Ireland education minister.

The tribunal has already seen a military intelligence document, where an anonymous agent accused Mr McGuinness of starting the mayhem by firing a shot.

Mr McGuinness, who has accused the army of murder on Bloody Sunday, dismissed suggestions that republican paramilitaries had been shot dead that day and buried in secret.

Relatives of the dead have welcomed his decision to give evidence, hoping it will absolve their loved ones from any blame for Bloody Sunday.

Next Tuesday, the Stormont assembly will debate a motion of no confidence in Mr McGuinness as a member of the power sharing executive.

fields.trailText: May 4: Ford, General Motors and Daimler-Chrysler are looking for agencies to promote a consumer website.
fields.body:
Car giants Ford, General Motors and Daimler-Chrysler are joining forces to launch a consumer website and are looking for agencies to promote the venture.

The Online Travel Portal has reopened talks with advertising agencies despite appointing BMP DDB to the business last December.

A new row over the government's soaring advertising spend erupted this week after the Department for Social Security admitted it had underestimated its figures.

Ananova has picked Lowe Lintas and the Media Planning Group to its creative and media accounts.

Asda is talking to media agencies about its £23m business.

TBWA/London has promoted Trevor Beattie to chairman.

The Economist's advertising campaign is to return to TV for the first time in four years.

A decision by the Ellesse sportswear company to handle its advertising in-house after seeing agency pitches has angered advertising agencies.

webTitle: £66m aid package for axed steel workers

fields.headline: £66m aid package for axed steel workers
fields.trailText: A £66m aid package to help workers axed by steel giant Corus was today announced by the Welsh assembly first minister, Rhodri Morgan.
fields.body:
A £66m aid package to help workers axed by steel giant Corus was today announced by the Welsh assembly first minister, Rhodri Morgan.

The Welsh assembly is to put £50m into the package, with the other £16m provided by the government.

In a statement to the assembly, Mr Morgan said the government would introduce a scheme to provide aid to those workers affected by the latest round of job cuts announced by Corus and those in previous rounds back to January 2000.

A total of 2,800 Welsh steelworkers will lose their jobs. Some 6,000 workers across the UK face the axe. The government scheme will see individual workers given lump sums of £2,500.

The likely cost for this part of the scheme that applies to Wales is £16m. It is subject to approval from Europe, which would include refunding almost half the gross cost.

Mr Morgan said the unions and Corus would be jointly applying for European social fund money to support a training package for workers facing redundancy.

The package is likely to cost £5.7m in Wales. Corus has agreed to make a significant contribution to that.

Some £7m of the £66m package is for employment and training measures funded by the assembly. That will pay for extra employment and training for workers made redundant by Corus and its contractors as well as their families and those in the supply chain.

Mr Morgan said: "Many of those who will lose their jobs have considerable skills and talents which will allow them to find good, new jobs without too much difficulty.

"Others will need top quality advice and guidance and first class training if they are to move on successfully to new employers."

The employment service is also to increase its job information work in Wales and offer a wide range of services tailored to the needs of Corus staff.

fields.headline: Thursday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are sporting jumpers with Nazis on them
fields.trailText: Real Madrid have abandoned their interest in Mark Viduka. The Spanish giants, who were quoted a price of £18.5m when they inquired after the Australian earlier this season, were unimpressed by his performance against Valencia last night. "Mark Viduka disappointed me in this match," coach Vicente del Bosque told onefootball.com. "I remembered when he played against us in the Santiago Bernabeu, he was almost a perfect striker. But since then, I think he has become worse and worse as the season has gone on. For this match he did not seem very focussed and nor did Alan Smith."
fields.body:
Real Madrid have abandoned their interest in Mark Viduka. The Spanish giants, who were quoted a price of £18.5m when they inquired after the Australian earlier this season, were unimpressed by his performance against Valencia last night. "Mark Viduka disappointed me in this match," coach Vicente del Bosque told onefootball.com. "I remembered when he played against us in the Santiago Bernabeu, he was almost a perfect striker. But since then, I think he has become worse and worse as the season has gone on. For this match he did not seem very focussed and nor did Alan Smith."

Juventus are the latest club to be linked with a move for Arsene Wenger when his Arsenal contract expires at the end of next season. The Daily Star reckons that current coach Carlo Ancelotti will be sacked in the summer and replaced by former hero Marcello Lippi, but only for the one season before Wenger takes over.

Gerard Houllier is ready to further strengthen his Liverpool squad this summer, telling the Mirror: "We need two or three new players." The paper speculates that those three are Bixente Lizarazu, Frank Lampard, and Damien Duff.

Planet Football reports that Real Madrid have made an offer for Lazio's Juan Sebastian Veron. They quote the player's lawyer, Guiseppe Petrelli, as saying: "Lazio have received an offer from Real Madrid for my client which is practically double what Cragnotti paid Parma for Veron two years ago."

Ipswich manager George Burley will be given £15m to spend on new players this summer, according to the Mirror.

Derby's on-loan Icelandic international Thordur Gudjonsson has claimed Spurs are interested in signing him this summer. "Teams from Germany, Hansa Rostock and Werder Bremen, and Tottenham from England are chasing me," Gudjonsson told Planet Football. Whether this has anything to do with the fact that Derby have failed to take up the option of signing him themselves remains to be seen.

fields.headline: Festival spirit
fields.standfirst: Dogged by delays and a hostile press, the Festival of Britain looked like being a Dome-sized disaster when it opened 50 years ago today. Instead it was an extraordinary success. In this 1963 essay,  Michael Frayn explained how it marked the end of an era
fields.trailText: Dogged by delays and a hostile press, the Festival of Britain looked like being a Dome-sized disaster when it opened 50 years ago today. Instead it was an extraordinary success. In this 1963 essay, Michael Frayn explained how it marked the end of an era.
fields.body:
"In 1951," wrote Evelyn Waugh, in the epilogue to his novel Unconditional Surrender, "to celebrate the opening of a happier decade, the Government decreed a Festival. Monstrous constructions appeared on the south bank of the Thames, the foundation stone was solemnly laid for a National Theatre, but there was little popular exuberance among the straitened people, and dollar-bearing tourists curtailed their visits and sped to the countries of the Continent where, however precarious their condition, they ordered things better."

Poor Evelyn Waugh. It was certainly not the Festival of his Britain. For those sections of the upper- and middle-classes of whose subconscious anxieties he is the curator the Festival marked the climax of a decade in which almost every single act of government had been inimical to their immediate interests. Festival Britain was the Britain of the radical middle-classes, the do-gooders; the readers of the News Chronicle, the Guardian, and the Observer; the signers of petitions; the backbone of the B.B.C. In short, the Herbivores, or gentle ruminants, who look out from the lush pastures which are their natural station in life with eyes full of sorrow for less fortunate creatures, guiltily conscious of their advantages, though not usually ceasing to eat the grass. And in making the Festival they earned the contempt of the Carnivores - the readers of the Daily Express; the Evelyn Waughs; the cast of the Directory of Directors - the members of the upper- and middle-classes who believe that if God had not wished them to prey on all smaller and weaker creatures without scruple he would not have made them as they are.

For a decade, sanctioned by the exigencies of war and its aftermath, the Herbivores had dominated the scene. By 1951 the regime which supported them was exhausted, and the Carnivores were ready to take over. The Festival was the last, and virtually the posthumous, work of the Herbivore Britain of the BBC News, the Crown Film Unit, the sweet ration, the Ealing comedies, Uncle Mac, Sylvia Peters ... all the great fixed stars by which my childhood was navigated.

The King declared the Festival open on May 3rd 1951. There was a sense of holiday in the air, and, after careful observation of the crowds lining the streets to see the Royal Family, The Times gave its verdict - "People in Joyous Mood." At the South Bank they worked all that day - and all that night - and as the guests began to come through the front gates for the private view on the morning of May 4th. The South Bank, or at any rate, 95% of it, was ready on schedule. By the time the official visitors had left and the first handful of the general public had been let in, it was pouring with rain. The visitors splashed dismally round, offering no visible evidence of enjoyment. It was a gloomy baptism.

But the sense of anti-climax did not last. It quickly became clear that the South Bank, conceived in austerity and shaped by expediency, was a knockout. For two or three evenings the police had to close the streets round the Embankment to traffic, as the crowds poured down to gaze at the floodlit dream-world breathing music on the other side of the river. "People making for the South Bank," reported the Manchester Guardian, "begin to smile as they come close to it." The Guardian suggested that "on bright sunny days it seems likely that a trip across the Thames to the South Bank will be as invigorating as a trip across the Channel." It certainly was. The crowds came in, and wandered round in a state of somnambulism, forming queues with such abstracted readiness that the attendants found difficulty in preventing the accumulation of queues that led nowhere at all.

No one had ever seen anything like it before. Apart from the New Towns, it was one of the first concerted attempts at modern architecture in Britain in this century, a brilliant microcosm in which every single object had been designed for its job. For a few hours people stepped out of the squalid compromises of the everyday urban scene into a world where everything was made to please. There was music on the loudspeakers to walk round to. There were plenty of cafes to sit down at. There were the two distinctive shapes by which cartoons and souvenirs of the Festival were instantly identifiable - the great closed scallop shell of Ralph Tubb's Dome of Discovery and the Skylon, the luminous exclamation mark with which the young engineers Powell and Moya had won the competition for vertical feature. Round every corner there was a new delight - a catwalk to look down from, or the superb water mobile by Richard Huws, which imitated the regular sequence of small and great waves on the shore. There was the river to look at. And, on the other side of the river, the magnificent sombre building line of the north bank, revealed for the first time as a back curtain to the colourful and extravagant outlines of the Festival architecture.

Later in the season balloonists took off from the South Bank and drifted with the wind in the leisurely way of Edwardian high summer, to the open country outside the city. Charles Elleano crossed the river on a tight-rope. And twice a week, when darkness fell, there was open-air dancing among the twinkling lights that studded the Fairway.

Someone, unfairly described the South Bank exhibition as "all Heal let loose". Afterwards, the fashions it set in architecture and design were quickly copied, became cliches, and eventually looked vulgar against the growing affluence of the fifties. But now that the whole painful process of outgrowing an out-of-date fashion has been completed, we can look back and appreciate just what a box of delights the South Bank really was. Though, as with any box of delights, the most delightful thing was the packaging, and the air of surprise and excitement it gave to the contents. The contents themselves were a little more mundane. The exhibition was supposed to show Britain's contribution to civilisation. This, of course, is the sort of thing that museums are about anyway and the Festival could only do it in the same way that a museum would, with samples of fossils and steam-engines, and pictures of more fossils and more steam-engines. But what else can you have a national exhibition about? Still, the splendour of their housing carried the exhibits; and the radar screens, the craftsmen making cricket-bats, and the three dimensional representations of the integral calculus gave point and a sense of importance to their surroundings. The best thing of all about the South Bank was just being there.

Over eight million people went to the Pleasure Gardens at Battersea, and nearly eight and a half million visited the South Bank. But there can have been few people in Britain whose lives remained completely untouched by the Festival. The Festival symbol devised by Abram Games was ubiquitous. So was the word "Festival". The great programme of poetry readings, serenade concerts, firework displays, and children's sports rolled across Britain relentlessly, and, though the local Festival Rose Show may have been remote in spirit from the pre-stressed concrete elan of the South Bank, it brought with it some suggestion of national identity and consciousness. The BBC - the most thoroughbred Herbivores of all - hammered the Festival into the national cortex with 2,700 programmes on the subject.

At the end of September the Festival closed. The King should have been present, but he was ill - dying, as it turned out. The curious summer was over; a way of life was ending, too.

What is one to think of the Festival? It was not quite the roaring success of the Great Exhibition, which was seen by six million people - a third of the population at that time. Nor did it generate the intense national enthusiasm of a piece of routine royal pageantry like the Coronation. Rainald Wells, who at the beginning of the year had suggested abandoning it, gave in the Daily Telegraph a grudging but not crushing verdict on behalf of the Carnivores: "It may perhaps be likened to a moderately successful party, but one held on he wrong day and at far too great a cost. We are none the sadder for it, but we might have been wiser to have kept the money in our pockets." Far too great a cost? The total net expenditure, apart from the loans for the Festival Gardens, was just over eight million pounds comfortably within the estimate. Not quite so satisfactory as the 1851 Exhibition, which made profits big enough to finance the building of the Victoria and Albert Museum but cheap by modern standards of Government expenditure. By a not overwhelming majority the country liked the Festival. But the South Bank and Battersea were also paid a more striking compliment. The acid democratic test of housing estates and similar undertakings is whether or not they are smashed up by that section of the community which has no other redress for being treated with contempt or condescension; and at the end of the season the police were struck by the absence of hooliganism and other crime in both places. It was quite a tribute.

The Festival was a rainbow - a brilliant sign riding the tail of the storm and promising fairer weather. It marked the ending of the hungry forties, and the beginning of an altogether easier decade. But it was not, as its critics had feared, to mark the consolidation of the Herbivorious forces which had made it. To adapt Rainald Wells's verdict, it may perhaps be likened to a gay and enjoyable birthday party, but one at which the host presided from his death-bed.

fields.trailText:
9.15am: Big Brother PR supremo James Herring is fighting a court battle following his sudden departure from Avalon, writes Claire Cozens .
18.04.2001: Cath Taylor scoops Big Brother PR account

Special report: Big Brother
fields.body:
The Big Brother PR supremo, James Herring, is at the centre of a court battle following his sudden departure from Avalon.

The company took out a high court injunction against Mr Herring after it emerged that a company run by his wife, Cath Taylor, had won a contract to handle some of the PR for the new series of Big Brother.

Mr Herring masterminded the PR for the last series for Avalon.

The injunction means that Mr Herring, who resigned from Avalon at the end of last year, will not be able to work for any of the company's competitors, including Cath Taylor Associates, during his one-year notice period.

Mr Herring gave the court an undertaking to agree to the terms of the injunction.

"The directors of Avalon wish to make it clear that legal action against an employee has never been necessary in 12 years of running the Avalon group," the company said in a statement.

"This unprecedented step by Avalon was taken with regret (following consultation with Avalon's senior staff, directors and legal team) in light of the exceptional circumstances surrounding Mr Herring's sudden departure from the company and the suspicions generated by the movement of the Big Brother PR business."

The statement said Mr Herring had failed to turn up for work on April 2, despite previous assurances he would remain at the company until a handover to his successor had been completed.

The company will also seek legal damages from Mr Herring over the affair.

He handed in his notice at the company last October to join media company iBalls.

webTitle: Missile defence casts cloud over Korean sunshine

fields.headline: Missile defence casts cloud over Korean sunshine
fields.standfirst:
George Bush's ostensibly peace-keeping quest for global missile defence could destroy a fragile detente in one of the most dangerous places on earth, fears Simon Tisdall

Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: George Bush's ostensibly peace-keeping quest for global missile defence could destroy a fragile detente in one of the most dangerous places on earth, fears Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
Before George Bush announced his ambitious plans for global missile defence this week, he made a point of telephoning interested parties to tell them what he proposed.

This courtesy was extended to other leaders such as Britain's Tony Blair and Russia's president, Vladimir Putin.

But South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, had to wait a day to get his call from the White House - after Bush had already delivered his speech. If Kim were feeling sensitive, he might be inclined to resent what that seems to say about Seoul's place in Washington's international pecking order.

The US president's delay in calling was doubly odd, given that what he had to say about the necessity of missile defence has special relevance to South Korea and to Kim's own political position.

In his announcement, Bush pointed the finger of blame at North Korea as one of the world's "least responsible" states - states that were bent on acquiring weapons of mass destruction (WMD) and advanced missile technology that flouted anti-proliferation efforts.

Although the US president did not mention the Pyongyang regime by name, there could be no doubt who he was talking about.

Earlier in the week, the US state department also singled out North Korea for opprobrium. In common with Iraq, Iran, Libya, Sudan and Cuba, it was once again labelled a state sponsor of international terrorism.

This toughening American line is based on part on a Pentagon report, published in January, that accused North Korea of having secretly developed one or perhaps two nuclear weapons - despite a 1994 agreement with the US on peaceful uses of nuclear technology.

The Pentagon said North Korea was developing a two and three-stage intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) that could carry a small nuclear warhead, or a chemical or biological weapon, to US territory; and that it was actively stockpiling medium and short-range ballistic missiles that threatened South Korea and Japan.

For good measure, the Americans described North Korea as a "major proliferator" of WMD-related technology, particularly in respect of exports to Iran and Pakistan.

When Bush met Kim in Washington in February, he surprised the South Korean leader by insisting not only that North Korea was a big threat but also that it could not be trusted to keep its word. He announced that the US was freezing contacts with Pyongyang, despite the openings made by the Clinton administration, and launched an overall policy review.

Given the seriousness of the North Korean problem, as the Americans see it, and given that North Korea's supposed activities underpin the rationale for missile defence, it is perhaps all the more surprising that Bush did not contact Kim earlier.

For the fact of the matter, which Bush advisers if not Bush himself surely appreciate, is that it is South Korea - not the US - that is most directly threatened by a deterioration in relations with North Korea and by North Korean weapons.

It is South Korea that is still technically at war with the North, 50 years after the Korean conflict divided the peninsula. And it is South Korea - and specifically Kim - that has launched a sunshine policy of detente aimed at bridging the divide and ultimately bringing the nation together.

This sunshine policy, which came to a climax of sorts last June with the first ever meeting between Kim and North Korea's "great general", Kim Jong Il, is now in serious danger of clouding over, if not of being engulfed in a thunderstorm.

Much of that is due to Washington's new hard line which has antagonised and alarmed the North and dismayed Kim Dae Jung.

Earlier this year, North Korea threatened to end the voluntary freeze of missile testing that it had undertaken in talks with the US. Last week, it demanded the withdrawal of the 37,000 US troops that are based in South Korea. After Bush's missile defence speech, it angrily denounced the US leader.

Various confidence-building measures agreed at last year's summit between the two Korean leaders, including the opening of a railway link, have been delayed or stymied by this growing atmosphere of distrust.

Even though North Korea is said to be once again facing a food crisis, and is importing emergency supplies of fertiliser from international aid donors, its leadership seems to be digging in politically too, as faith in Kim's peace process fades on both sides of the border.

Kim had hoped above all that Kim Jong Il could be induced to attend a follow-up summit in Seoul next month. That now looks increasingly unlikely.

If Kim did not apportion considerable blame for this deterioration on the change of administration in Washington, he would be less than human. In his conversation with Bush, he implored the US to complete its policy review and get the dialogue going again as a matter of urgency. All he got by way of reply was a complacent assurance that the new US policy would be enunciated "in timely fashion".

Unfortunately, it already seems pretty clear what sort of line the Bush administration is going to adopt. Its top defence and security priority is missile defence. North Korea, as depicted by Washington, provides a key justification of the need for missile defence. So its status as a missile-toting 'rogue state' cut off from US assistance and international lending looks set to continue.

If the US opts for ostracism instead of openness, Kim knows it could spell the end for his sunshine policy and the political kudos (including the Nobel peace prize) it has brought him.

He also knows that although the EU sent a delegation to Pyongyang this week determined to revive the peace process, it is Washington that largely calls the shots, militarily, financially and diplomatically, on the Korean peninsula.

If the detente between the Koreas does indeed collapse, it may come to be seen as the first victim of Bush's doctrine of missile defence. Far from making the world a safer place, it will have delivered an enormous setback to peace in one of the most dangerous places on earth.

fields.headline: Nova magazine to close for second time
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The increasingly competitive women's magazine market claimed another victim yesterday with the closure, for the second time in its history, of the style magazine Nova. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The increasingly competitive women's magazine market claimed another victim yesterday with the closure, for the second time in its history, of the style magazine Nova.

IPC pulled the plug on its recently revived title, saying it wanted to concentrate on the bigger selling Marie Claire. Staff on Nova, whose groundbreaking 1960s incarnation launched the career of the writer Molly Parkin, were said to be devastated.

It is thought that IPC is attempting to trim its stable of loss-making titles in advance of a possible stock market flotation next year. Its troubled Woman's Realm, aimed at more mature readers, was merged with Woman's Weekly last month.

Tim Brooks, the managing director of IPC South Bank, one of the publisher's London magazines divisions, said that Nova had not been performing well enough.

"Nova was ground-breaking in its style and delivery, but commercially has not reached its targets. IPC has an aggressive launch strategy, and an important part of this strategy is the strength to take decisive action and close unviable titles."

After being absent from the newsstands for 25 years, it was revived in May last year under the editorship of Deborah Bee and was positioned as an edgy, fashion based lifestyle magazine.

Sales were not outstanding, and a new team was brought in under the editorship of Jeremy Langmead, a former editor of the Sunday Times's Style magazine, and his deputy Rachel Cook.

But staff on the magazine believe that IPC did not have the faith required to turn the magazine round under the new regime. The June issue, which goes on sale soon, will be the last, even though Mr Langmead and Ms Cook have already finalised the July edition.

IPC said staff would be given jobs elsewhere in the group, but it is thought that some are already negotiating their pay-offs.

While Mr Brooks said that IPC was still committed to launching new magazines, IPC staff said he was simply an "axeman" who would cut the group back to the bone for a lucrative floatation, from which executives would benefit financially.

Caroline Baker, a journalist on the original magazine and now fashion director at You magazine, said she was not surprised by the closure. "It was exactly like all the other magazines and failed to capture the British public's imagination. They should have left the old one alone, not tried to bring it back."

It was launched in its original guise in 1965 by what was then the Mirror Group's magazines division under editor Dennis Hackett. It had a huge impact on the fashion of the era.

It tackled serious issues as well as fashion, carrying a feature about homosexual law reform when the issue was politically controversial. It fell victim to sluggish sales, and closed in 1975.

It was revived last year at a time when the women's magazine sector is becoming increasingly crowded. A number of other newly launched magazines were fighting for readers, including the pocket-sized glossy Glamour magazine.

All have been attempting to tap into the sales of of long-running titles like Cosmopolitan, Elle and Marie Claire, which continue to dominate the market.

Dedicated followers of fashion

Eve

Launched in August 2000 by BBC Worldwide UK. Aimed at 30-40 year olds who have outgrown the younger glossies. Claims to be a "contemporary, thought-provoking" read. Circulation: 129,711

Red

Launched in 1998 by EMAP Elan. Intended as a hipper, younger version of Good Housekeeping. More feature based than fashion orientated. Circulation: 155,083

Glamour

Launched in April by Conde Nast. Handbag sized with emphasis on glamour. Aimed at single, young women, enjoying their age and freedom. Estimated that the first edition sold 500,000 copies

Marie Claire

Launched in 1988 by IPC Magazines. Award winning and ground breaking. A mixture of a fashion glossy with serious reportage. Aimed at 20-34 year olds, read by those nearer 30 and 40. Circulation: 400,543

webTitle: Henry's House bags Big Brother PR account

fields.headline: Henry's House bags Big Brother PR account
fields.trailText:
11.45am Henry's House has scooped the main PR brief for the next series of Big Brother, writes Julia Day.

03.05.2001: Injunction against PR man Herring

Special report: Big Brother
fields.body:
Henry's House has scooped the main PR brief for the next series of Big Brother.

The account was previously handled by Avalon PR, which is at the centre of a row over the programme's former PR chief, James Herring.

Big Brother's promotion and media handling will be headed up by Henry's House founder, Julian Henry, and director Charlotte Hickson as part of a five-strong team.

But the programme's commercial and online PR account, won last month by Cath Taylor Associates, is at the centre of controversy.

Cath Taylor's husband, James Herring, masterminded PR for Big Brother's last series while working at Avalon, from which he resigned at the end of last year.

Avalon has now taken out an court injunction against Mr Herring after "suspicions generated by the movement of the Big Brother PR business".

Ms Taylor is believed to be in talks with her lawyers.

Henry's House has carried out previous campaigns for Channel 4, handling PR on the Big Breakfast and the Zoe Ball vehicle, the Priory.

The agency will provide a round-the-clock press office by setting up a combined office and flat close to the Big Brother house in east London's Bromley-by-Bow.

A 24-hour media hotline and website for the press will operate.
