fields.headline: The media empire that could not strike back
fields.standfirst: The collapse of Vladimir GusinskyÕs Media-Most empire could signal the destruction of free speech in Russia, or at least the beginning of the end for that freedom, writes Russian journalist Leonid Radzikhovsky
fields.trailText: May 3: The destruction of Media-Most has been MoscowÕs most inflammatory political upheaval, writes Leonid Radzikhovsky.
fields.body:
The swift three-day destruction of Vladimir GusinskyÕs media holding has been MoscowÕs biggest, most inflammatory political upheaval.

Indeed, it was a blitzkrieg: at 3am on the night before Easter, the management of the NTV television company Ð Mr GusinskyÕs major operation and the heart of his Media-Most holding Ð was replaced.

Two weeks ago, two more Gusinsky-owned publications were targeted Ð the newspaper Sevodnya was closed and the editor-in-chief of the magazine, Itogi, was replaced.

It was a truly crushing defeat. Of Mr GusinskyÕs former media empire, only the popular Ekho Moskvy radio station remains. But it is quite clear the radio station will not be overlooked and its hour will come.

I am, or rather was, a staff writer for the (now defunct) newspaper Sevodnya. On Monday 16 April, I wrote an article for the next issue of the newspaper and faxed it to the office at about 7pm.

At 10pm I switched on my TV set and heard the newspaper had been shut down.

Mr GusinskyÕs Media-Most holding incorporated NTV, Ekho Moskvy, the television company TNT, the publishing house Sem Dnei (including Sevodnya, Itogi and the magazines Sem Dnei and Karavan Istorii), the satellite television company NTV plus the film company Kino-Most and several other organisations.

In its best times (before the 1998 crisis) Media-Most was valued at over $1bn (a huge amount for Russia).

However, the financial crisis that hit Russia in 1998 and the dramatic dwindling of the advertising market had put Most in a precarious position and caused serious financial problems.

Mr Gusinsky found a simple way out. He took loans from RussiaÕs gigantic gas firm Gazprom. In exchange, Gazprom became a co-owner of Media-Most and its various structures (Gazprom owns 46% of NTV shares).

Mr Gusinsky tried to keep a controlling stake in his companies but, gradually, he became more entangled.

This is the financial side of the story Ð the side that has been dwelled on at length by Gazprom managers, who insist everything is very simple: Mr Gusinsky is bankrupt.

His property will be taken over by the creditor as the payment of debt. And thatÕs it. There is nothing more to discuss.

But there is. The reasons for Mr GusinskyÕs rise and fall lie not in business but in politics.

Mr Gusinsky saw the mass media not as "pure business" but as an instrument of political influence.

He built NTV not in order to get profits from advertising (although, of course, he tried) but because he was hoping to squeeze financial gains from the political game.

Mr Gusinsky quarrelled with most of Boris YeltsinÕs inner circle, but his position became even shakier when Vladimir Putin came to power.

During the parliamentary elections in 1999, Mr Gusinsky supported Mr PutinÕs opponents.

When they lost, Mr Gusinsky added a short name Ð Mr Putin Ð to the long list of his enemies. And then the time came to repay Gazprom.

Gazprom, under pressure from the Kremlin, demanded the repayment of credits not in the form of lobbying services (as in the past) but in cash.

The trap in which Mr Gusinsky had put himself slammed shut, from both sides, financial and political.

Mr Gusinsky was arrested in Moscow but was then released in exchange for a promise to sell his holding.

He left for Spain, where he looks set to remain now the Spanish authorities have refused to cooperate in extraditing him to Russia.

Finally, Gazprom removed the NTV management on absolutely legal grounds, having established a majority control over the station.

The NTV staff challenged the takeover, triggering street protests in Moscow.

But in the early morning of April 14, Gazprom officials came to the NTV offices and seized control of the company.

Of the 350 NTV journalists who left, many are now working for the TV-6 channel owned by another disgraced and exiled oligarch, Boris Berezovsky.

With our newspaper Sevodnya, things were even simpler.

The director of the publishing house, Sem Dnei Biryukov, was only too happy to see the back of of Mr Gusinsky.

Biryukov and Gazprom have a controlling interest in the publishing house. In a meeting with Mr GusinskyÕs lawyers, they decided to liquidate our newspaper, which is a political irritant to the Kremlin.

A fundamental question remains. Does all this mean the destruction of the freedom of speech in Russia, or at least the "beginning of the end" for this freedom?

I have no definite answer. There is no doubt Mr GusinskyÕs financial weakness was only a pretext for his destruction. But it is still unclear whether the destruction of Mr GusinskyÕs business was a strike against freedom of speech or personal revenge against Mr Gusinsky by Mr Putin's and Mr YeltsinÕs circle.

If this is just a personal revenge against Mr Gusinsky, the campaign against the mass media will end once he is out and elements of freedom of speech will remain.

If this is a campaign against freedom of speech, then it is just the beginning.

NTV journalists will not be allowed to work on the TV-6 channel and opposition newspapers will start to be closed one by one.

Because Mr Putin holds his cards so close to his chest, either option seems at present to be equally plausible. But we will not have to wait long before it becomes clear.

 Leonid Radzikhovsky is a former senior columnist for the liberal daily newspaper, Sevodnya

His property will be taken over by the creditor as the payment of debt. And thatÕs it. There is nothing more to discuss. But there is. The reasons for Mr GusinskyÕs rise and fall lie not in business but in politics. Mr Gusinsky saw the mass media not as "pure business" but as an instrument of political influence. He built NTV not in order to get profits from advertising (although, of course, he tried) but because he was hoping to squeeze financial gains from the political game. Mr Gusinsky quarrelled with most of Boris YeltsinÕs inner circle, but his position became even shakier when Vladimir Putin came to power. During the parliamentary elections in 1999, Mr Gusinsky supported Mr PutinÕs opponents. When they lost, Mr Gusinsky added a short name Ð Mr Putin Ð to the long list of his enemies. And then the time came to repay Gazprom. Gazprom, under pressure from the Kremlin, demanded the repayment of credits not in the form of lobbying services (as in the past) but in cash. The trap in which Mr Gusinsky had put himself slammed shut, from both sides, financial and political. Mr Gusinsky was arrested in Moscow but was then released in exchange for a promise to sell his holding. He left for Spain, where he looks set to remain now the Spanish authorities have refused to cooperate in extraditing him to Russia. Finally, Gazprom removed the NTV management on absolutely legal grounds, having established a majority control over the station. The NTV staff challenged the takeover, triggering street protests in Moscow. But in the early morning of April 14, Gazprom officials came to the NTV offices and seized control of the company. Of the 350 NTV journalists who left, many are now working for the TV-6 channel owned by another disgraced and exiled oligarch, Boris Berezovsky. With our newspaper Sevodnya, things were even simpler. The director of the publishing house, Sem Dnei Biryukov, was only too happy to see the back of of Mr Gusinsky. Biryukov and Gazprom have a controlling interest in the publishing house. In a meeting with Mr GusinskyÕs lawyers, they decided to liquidate our newspaper, which is a political irritant to the Kremlin. A fundamental question remains. Does all this mean the destruction of the freedom of speech in Russia, or at least the "beginning of the end" for this freedom? I have no definite answer. There is no doubt Mr GusinskyÕs financial weakness was only a pretext for his destruction. But it is still unclear whether the destruction of Mr GusinskyÕs business was a strike against freedom of speech or personal revenge against Mr Gusinsky by Mr Putin's and Mr YeltsinÕs circle. If this is just a personal revenge against Mr Gusinsky, the campaign against the mass media will end once he is out and elements of freedom of speech will remain. If this is a campaign against freedom of speech, then it is just the beginning. NTV journalists will not be allowed to work on the TV-6 channel and opposition newspapers will start to be closed one by one. Because Mr Putin holds his cards so close to his chest, either option seems at present to be equally plausible. But we will not have to wait long before it becomes clear.  Leonid Radzikhovsky is a former senior columnist for the liberal daily newspaper, Sevodnya MediaGuardian.co.uk special report World press freedom day

webTitle: British woman dies in Athens explosion

fields.headline: British woman dies in Athens explosion
fields.trailText: A British woman died in Athens today in an explosion believed to have been caused when a bomb she was carrying in her car went off by mistake.
fields.body:
A British woman died in Athens today in an explosion believed to have been caused when a bomb she was carrying in her car went off by mistake.

The woman - named locally as Susan Mary Arris, 49 - was found in a car with British registration plates in the southern Athens suburb of Voula. The bomb had been placed underneath the handbrake and a remote control device was found in a bag in the car.

The woman was wearing black gloves and had cotton wool in her ears, Athens police said. A dog was also found dead inside the car.

Their investigation was understood to be focusing on the woman's possible links with organised crime rather than terrorism or suicide. One theory was that the bomb went off accidentally as she travelled to an unknown destination to plant it in the early hours of this morning.

The explosion, in a white BMW owned by Ms Arris, happened at around 3am local time (1am BST). Ms Arris reportedly had Greek citizenship and had been living in Greece for many years.

A spokeswoman for the British embassy in Athens said the embassy was in contact with the police to try to confirm the identity of the woman and her nationality.

webTitle: IPPR tells councillors to take community oath

fields.headline: IPPR tells councillors to take community oath
fields.trailText: A leading thinktank has come up with a novel way to enhance the profile of local politicians - it suggests that they take a "Hippocratic oath", pledging to do their best to serve the community.
fields.body:
A leading thinktank has come up with a novel way to enhance the profile of local politicians - it suggests that they take a "Hippocratic oath", pledging to do their best to serve the community.

Local councillors are so disenchanted with their jobs that they are taking on the "No one likes us, we don't care" mantra of Millwall football club, according to report published today by the Institute for Public Policy Research.

To add to their woe, latest opinion polls suggest that turnout for local elections, postponed to June 7 because of the foot and mouth crisis, will fall to a postwar low. The national average turnout for local elections is now below 30% and surveys reveal less than 5% of people can name their local councillor.

Matthew Taylor, the director of the IPPR, said: "The depressingly low status of councillors, both on the street and in the corridors of power, should be taken more seriously by anyone interested in revitalising our flagging economy."

The oath, which would potentially give councillors a legal redress against edicts from national government they disagree with, has the backing of several local politicians.

Councillor Ian Bottrill, of Warwickshire county council, said: "I have no doubt that this oath will help local government gain the confidence of both people and the government that we can really deliver."

In the report, the thinktank attacks the image of national politicians, whose posturing in Westminster it says "undermines the reputation of many councillors as inclusive community representatives."

The report also argues against local referendums, such as the one held recently by Bristol city council on whether to raise council tax. In that case, local voters vetoed an increase, but the IPPR insists that "complex decisions councils have to make can't be made adequately by a whole community in a one-off ballot."

Milton Keynes and Croydon have tried similar, one-off experiments.

More controversially, the pamphlet argues that Britain's 25,000 councillors should receive more on the job training for their posts, claiming that the current £177 spent per member is an under investment.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Nokia junior | Tiny view
fields.byline: Ashley Norris, Greg Whitaker and Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Nokia junior
Nokia is once again aiming for the youth market with a budget mobile phone that goes on sale this week.

The dual band Nokia 3300 has interchangeable covers, a Wap browser and games. The 3300 also sees the debut of a new game - Bumper. Other game packs and animated screen savers can be downloaded via the Club Nokia web and Wap sites.

Other facilities include voice dialing and a ring first then vibrate option. Talk time is rated at 4.5 hours, standby at 260 hours. www.nokia.com

Tiny view
It might connect to a TV and look like a large silver VCR, but there is far more to Tiny Computer's Takami than just video recording. It is a stripped down version of a PC that turns a TV into a digital home entertainment centre. Among its many features are music and movie playback, video recording, game playing via CD-Rom, and internet and email access.

Its headline feature is its hard disk video recorder that enables time-shifters to store programmes on its 40gigabyte hard disk. The unit will also pause live TV. The hard disk can be used to store music as MP3 files. These can either be ripped from its CD player or downloaded from the net.

The unit's home cinema facilities include a Dolby digital surround sound decoder and a DVD player.

The basic Takami, which is accompanied by a remote control, wireless keyboard and stereo speakers, is on sale now for £999. Tiny is also offering the unit with a 15inch LCD screen for £1,500. See www.tiny.com

Smile and click
Kodak has unveiled a system that it claims takes the hassle out of connecting a digital camera to a PC.

EasyShare, which debuts on the company's just launched DX3500 model, pictured below, is based around an innovative docking station which not only connects the camera to the PC, but also automatically recharges its batteries.

Once the software has been installed, users open up the software and transfer the image from the camera to the computer at a press of a button.

With a couple of further button and mouse clicks, the user can email the images, print or edit them.

Images are stored on an internal 8MB of memory. Further memory can be added with the addition of a CompactFlash card.

The DX3500 has an image resolution of 2.2 megapixels and features a 3x digital zoom. It goes on sale later this month. In July it will be joined by the DDX3600 which adds a 2x optical zoom and digital video to the specification of its sibling model. Both models are also Mac compatible. www.kodak.co.uk

Cut-price Intel Intel has slashed the price of 1.5GHz and 1.4GHz Pentium 4 processors following the introduction of the 1.7GHz version. The faster version has been launched at an unexpectedly low price: $352 compared with $519 for the 1.5GHz chip. On Monday Intel halved the price of the slower chips, with the 1.5GHz falling from $519 to $256, and the 1.4GHz falling from $375 to $193. However, Intel did not cut the price of Pentium III processors, and at $225, a 1GHz PIII now costs more than a faster P4. The 1.5GHz P4 has had its price cut three times in the past two months: earlier this year, it cost more than $800. Intel wants to move the PC market as rapidly as possible from the PIII to the P4, and is also under competitive pressure from AMD's Athlon and Duron processors, which can use cheaper memory chips.

fields.headline: Threatened by a herb
fields.standfirst: Researchers are trying to discredit St John's wort. They are funded by a pharmaceutical company
fields.trailText: Researchers are trying to discredit St John's wort. They are funded by a pharmaceutical company.
fields.body:
What a gullible lot depressed people are. In America they spend $400m a year on the anti-depressant herb St John's wort that has as much effect as a sugar pill. So says a study published in the prestigious Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) last month. A trial, involving 200 people who'd suffered from a "major depression" for at least four weeks, found the herb was no better than a placebo. Time magazine's follow up last week devoted two pages to the news, including an interview with a self-appointed "quack-buster" who declared that he wasn't surprised.

Several other things about the trial are not surprising. The researchers received "unrestricted funding" from the drug company Pfizer, who also manufacture the pre scription anti-depressant Zoloft, along with a "me-too" herbal product containing St John's wort. It is also the latest in a series of drug company sponsored drug trials that have raised doubts about efficacy or safety of St John's wort. The researcher advises people currently taking the herbal extract to consider one of the "two dozen prescription medications whose effectiveness has been proved".

Protecting the public from harmful or useless medicines is of course a laudable aim. But, quite apart from the fact that more than 20 other studies have found St John's wort to be beneficial for "mild to moderate" depression, the drug companies credentials in this field are not exactly impressive. For a start, as the recent South African court battles over patents and generic drugs for Aids illustrated, the companies are prepared to go to great lengths to protect their profits. The rising spending on St John's wort and other herbal remedies is certainly a threat. Even more pertinent is the growing concern, by both academic institutions and top medical journals, about the way drug companies are prepared to conceal or manipulate results that put their own products in an unfavourable light.

Last autumn JAMA announced that the results of a trial into the effectiveness of an immune boosting drug were incomplete, because the unnamed drug company involved were withholding them. The trial had showed the drug to be ineffective and the company wanted the results suppressed.

It was far from an isolated incident. Only last month the Lancet published a letter from a doctor claiming that the drug company Bayer, when asked for supplies of a certain drug so that he could run a trial on it, demanded he sign a letter promising not to reveal any results without their permission. The journal made this damning comment: "The efforts by the drug companies to suppress, spin and obfuscate findings that do not support their commercial purposes was first revealed to their full lethal extent during the thalidomide tragedy. [Since then]... the insidious tactics of the big pharma have changed very little."

What has changed is that many more researchers have drug company links. A study published last December found that only one of the top 10 medical schools in the US has clear regulations forbidding researchers from having a financial involvement in the companies they are supposedly impartially testing. Dr Ian Chalmers, director of the Cochrane Collaboration, an organisation dedicated to promoting evidence-based medicine, believes that secrecy has led to tens of thousands of unnecessary deaths because doctors were not alerted to the dangers.

The impartiality of drug-company funded research into herbal medicine must be called in to question. The problems created by herbal medicines are minuscule by comparison, even allowing for some under-reporting. The worst recent case of damage from a herbal product involved 30 people who developed cancer as a result of being prescribed a Chinese herb, in error, in Belgium.

Even if herbs can occasionally prove harmful, abuse of medicinal herbs (with the exception of marijuana) is unheard of. The same is not true of prescription drugs. A report out in April, but not covered at length in Time magazine, revealed that an estimated 4m Americans were abusing them - compare that with the official figure of 5m hard-core street addicts.

The pharmaceutical approach to medicine, for all its undoubted scientific brilliance and health benefits, is far from the final word in treatment. A study published last month found that 40% of Aids patients who are receiving the best pharmaceutical companies can offer - protease inhibitors - are also using a range of complementary medicines.

Instead of occasional bits of research aimed at damaging a competitor, what is needed is a serious and properly funded programme to discover how the obvious benefits of herbal and other complementary treatments can best be put to work. Only 40% of news stories about drug breakthroughs reveal the financial links between drug companies and the researchers involved. Perhaps the really gullible are those who don't take drug company claims with a big pinch of salt.

 Jerome Burne is editor of the newsletter Medicine Today.

fields.headline: Telegraph launches sports dailies
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The Daily Telegraph is launching daily sports supplements from May 15 to regain ground lost to the Observer, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Daily Telegraph is launching daily sports supplements for every new day of the week from May 15.

In a bid to regain its pre-eminence as the number one paper for sport, the Telegraph will launch an eight-page supplement every day from Tuesday to Friday, pushing business news to the back of the paper.

The new sections will showcase the work of the Telegraph sports reporters and columnists, Paul Hayward, Henry Winter, Michael Henderson, Mihir Bose, Tony McCoy, Colin Montgomerie and Michael Parkinson.

The Daily Telegraph's editor, Charles Moore, said the new sections were "the most exciting development in the Daily Telegraph's sports coverage" since he took over as editor.

The Telegraph has a good reputation for its sports coverage, with some of the best-respected columnists in the industry.

The move is a bid to regain some ground lost to the Observer, whose Sport Monthly, launched last year, has been a huge success with readers and advertisers.

fields.headline: NHS faces £3.9bn negligence claims
fields.trailText: The NHS is facing claims totalling £3.9bn in England for negligence by hospital doctors and other staff, according to a report today from the national audit office, the official watchdog on public spending.
fields.body:
The NHS is facing claims totalling £3.9bn in England for negligence by hospital doctors and other staff, according to a report today from the national audit office, the official watchdog on public spending.

The 23,000 claims outstanding total £2.6bn, with another £1.3bn estimated as the likely cost of claims not yet received for mishaps which have already occurred.

Sums paid in damages and costs to settle negligence claims have spiralled from £50m in 1997-98, through £107m in 1998-99, to £386m in 1999-00.

The study, which excludes claims against GPs, is the first survey to look at all negligence claims in every NHS trust in England. It paints a picture of a slow, expensive and inefficient system in which claims settled in 1999-00 had taken an average of 5 years and costs often exceeded the damages received.

Eight per cent of cases took 10 years or more. The report highlights a huge backlog of old cases, with claims which are still open averaging more than eight years on the books and 22% of open claims dating back more than 10 years.

For nearly half the claims settled in 1999-00, legal and other costs were higher than the damages. For settlements up to £50,000, the costs were higher than the damages in two out of three cases.

The rising bills are partly down to increased numbers of patients suing: the rate of clinical negligence claims went up by 72% from 1990 to 1998. The size of settlements has also risen following a court ruling covering a number of test cases which changed the way awards are calculated.

The report recommends new ways of dealing with claims, for instance by mediation rather than litigation, or by claims managers who can offer a range of remedies tailored to patients' wants.

A "package" approach recommended by the report could include a reasonable settlement offer at an early stage, an explanation, meetings with medical staff to explore what went wrong, an apology, and action to prevent a recurrence.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "The NAO is absolutely right to highlight the issue of rising claims, but the fact is that the total £3.9bn is an estimated figure for potential costs spread over future years."

In 1999-00 the NHS in England paid out under £400m in clinical negligence costs, while the total NHS budget in England was just over £40bn.

"There are two ways to reduce clinical negligence costs. We are working on reducing clinical errors in the first place by introducing an independent patients safety agency to record errors, mistakes and near misses, and to speed up the process of sorting them out", said the spokesman. "But we also need to ensure that money spent on claims is going to patients who deserve it - not on spiralling legal costs."

A "package" approach recommended by the report could include a reasonable settlement offer at an early stage, an explanation, meetings with medical staff to explore what went wrong, an apology, and action to prevent a recurrence. A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "The NAO is absolutely right to highlight the issue of rising claims, but the fact is that the total £3.9bn is an estimated figure for potential costs spread over future years." In 1999-00 the NHS in England paid out under £400m in clinical negligence costs, while the total NHS budget in England was just over £40bn. "There are two ways to reduce clinical negligence costs. We are working on reducing clinical errors in the first place by introducing an independent patients safety agency to record errors, mistakes and near misses, and to speed up the process of sorting them out", said the spokesman. "But we also need to ensure that money spent on claims is going to patients who deserve it - not on spiralling legal costs."

fields.headline: T-Online fails to impress
fields.trailText: 11am: T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, has failed to win over the doubters with its latest set of results, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, has failed to dispel doubts about its business model in its latest set of results.

The Deutsche Telekom-owned company has promised to reduce its dependence on access fees, but its first quarter results showed a rise in turnover from charging customers to dial up to the internet.

In a further blow to T-Online, it reported a steep fall in advertising and e-commerce turnover, which had been highlighted as one of the main alternatives to access revenue.

Most of the company's 8.7m subscribers come from Germany, which provides 7.1m of its customers, with the rest in France, Spain and Portugal.

T-Online said its operating loss for the first three months of the year was virtually unchanged from the previous quarter at £41.6m.

Advertising and e-commerce revenue shrank 36% to £19.4m and access revenues climbed 22% to £150.3m.

The company has lost its position as the darling of European ISP stocks and has been overtaken by Sardinian rival Tiscali.

Analysts are plumping for Tiscali because it will be the first to turn profitable at the end of 2001 and has taken a leading role in consolidating an overcrowded sector.

Mounting concern over the business models of ISPs, and doubts about whether the companies can survive on their own, has redirected the focus of investors towards profitability.

T-Online's popularity has also been blighted by a series of high-level management disputes with its parent company, Deutsche Telekom, which resulted in the departure of several key executives last year.

Ron Sommer, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, has parachuted in his own men to run the company, which has lessened T-Online's reputation as an independent company.

It has also effectively ruled out the ISP's chances of offering voice services over the net, which would 'cannibalise' Deutsche Telekom's core fixed-line business.

This blocks a potentially large revenue stream for T-Online, and underlines the difficulty it will have in diversifying sources of turnover.

fields.headline: Beattie named TBWA chairman
fields.trailText: 11am: Trevor Beattie has been promoted to chairman of TBWA/London, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Trevor Beattie has been promoted to chairman of TBWA/London following the departure of the agency's chief executive and joint managing director.

The appointment makes TBWA one of only two top 20 London agencies to have a creative as its chairman.

Mr Beattie will run TBWA/ London along with Garry Lace, who has been promoted from joint managing director.

The promotions will see Paul Bainsfair, who was recently promoted to president of TBWA in northern Europe, take a back seat in the day-to-day management of the agency.

The changes follow last week's news that Simon Clemmow, chief executive of TBWA/London, had quit to set up a new agency with the agency's joint managing director, Johnny Hornby.

Mr Beattie said his promotion sent a signal that creativity was now the agency's number one priority.

webTitle: Time for a rethink on monitoring new drugs

fields.headline: Time for a rethink on monitoring new drugs
fields.standfirst: New drugs may have side effects which - at worst - kill. So why not change how they are monitored?
fields.trailText: New drugs may have side effects which - at worst - kill. So why not change how they are monitored?
fields.body:
What is a black triangle? Some tricky little sign that we have all forgotten from the Highway Code? No? Well, let's try an easier one - what is the yellow card (but not the one the referee waves after a dodgy tackle)?

A minority of people are likely to know the significance of these colour codes in relation to prescription medicines prescribed by GPs and yet they are important to us all. The yellow card is the form a doctor fills in and sends off to the medicines control agency if he is concerned that a patient has had a serious side-effect from a particular drug. The black triangle on the information sheet sent to doctors by the manufacturer tells them that the drug is less than two years old. Doctors are supposed to report all side-effects of black triangle drugs - not just the serious ones.

These are the nuts and bolts of what is known as pharmaco-vigilance in the UK, a system set up to prevent what happened with Thalidomide occurring again. Clinical trials do not show spot problems that may occur in a tiny minority of people, or what may happen to long-term users. Yellow cards and black triangles form a safety net which has alerted the authorities to unexpected harmful effects of licensed medicines and averted disasters.

A new drug should be under intense scrutiny. Look at Zyban, the new, black-triangle, anti-smoking drug. There have been 35 deaths among users so far. Each one is reported and investigated. The MCA and the manufacturers say that in each case, so far, there has been a separate underlying cause, such as lung disease caused by cigarettes or, in the case of the air stewardess who died, the combination of Zyban and anti-malarial drugs. Deaths are pretty well always reported, but not so some of the other side-effects of medicines. The Consumers Association points out that a staggering 6% of all hospital admissions are caused by adverse effects of drugs. Surely the detection system should have been prevented some of them?

In fact, there are major problems with the safety net. The Drug and Therapeutics Bulletin, a respected journal sent to all doctors, recently did a survey which found that a quarter of information sheets on new drugs sent to doctors by manufacturers did not carry the black triangle symbol. It also found that the information about the sort of side-effects on the liver that certain powerful drugs could cause was inadequate.

Doctors are busy. If Mrs Robinson arrives with a headache, they aren't going to fill in a yellow card if they don't see a black triangle, unless they happen to know the drug she is on is only 18 months old. The Bulletin thinks that patients could be put at risk and wants the MCA to act. But there are other, longstanding weaknesses. Doctors don't have to fill in a yellow form. It is voluntary. Some doctors fill in stacks, some hardly any - the average is less than one a year per doctor.

Then there is the patient. Things may be changing, but historically the British patient doesn't want to trouble the doctor, particularly with something minor and mildly embarrassing like diarrhoea. But it could be a warning sign of something serious. In an age of increasingly powerful new drugs, there are those who think the yellow card system just isn't good enough. The Consumers Association wants patients themselves to fill in yellow cards and post them off to the MCA. The idea was immediately slapped down by the Department of Health on behalf of the MCA. Health professionals are better placed to make appropriate judgments on potential side-effects was the response.

It is an answer that smacks of the patriarchal attitudes that modernisation of the NHS is supposed to be trying to oust and ill at odds with all we have been told by the politicians about a health service led by consumers. If the MCA has a better answer, perhaps it should tell us.

webTitle: Cruise sues over gay affair allegations

fields.headline: Cruise sues over gay affair allegations
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise has filed a $100m (£66m) lawsuit against a homosexual porn star who has alleged that they had an affair
fields.body:
Tom Cruise has filed a $100m (£66m) lawsuit against a homosexual porn star who has alleged that they had an affair, Reuters reports. Not content with the possibility of a lengthy legal battle over his divorce from Nicole Kidman, Cruise has also begun proceedings against Kyle Bradford (also known as Chad Slater), for a story which the "adult" actor sold to a magazine called Actustar.

The story, which was also translated in Spanish publication TVyNovelas, claimed that Bradford and Cruise were involved in an homosexual affair which, when discovered by Kidman, led to the couple's divorce. Cruise's lawyers assert that "the defamatory story was fraudulent and malicious in that Bradford concocted the entire story and issued it to the international media at a time when he knew Cruise was going through a highly publicized marital separation".

The Cruise/Kidman divorce has generated a huge amount of publicity, and the lawsuit claims that Bradford made his allegations "for the purpose of publicizing himself at Cruise's expense". Cruise is suing Bradford for defamation and is demanding damages for what the lawsuit calls his "vicious, self-promoting story".

The actor has long had to contend with rumours about his (and his wife's) sexuality, and the legal documents state that, "While Cruise thoroughly respects others' right to follow their own sexual preference, he is not a homosexual and had no relationship of any kind with Kyle Bradford".

fields.headline: Scots social workers 'sensitive and reliable'
fields.trailText: Social workers' reputations as bureaucratic, interfering busy-bodies is unfounded, according to a survey of public attitudes to the profession by the Scottish executive.
fields.body:
Social workers' reputations as bureaucratic, interfering busy-bodies is unfounded, according to a survey of public attitudes to the profession by the Scottish executive.

The Scotland-wide poll, carried out as part of the first annual report of the social work services inspectorate (SWSI), found that 72% of people felt services were sensitive to individual need and 77% thought services were reliable and did what they said they would do.

The survey also found a good awareness of services, with three-quarters of those surveyed knowing how to contact them should they need to, and 68% believing that social work services were quick to respond.

But despite the apparently high public opinion of both services and professionals, local authorities were facing increasing problems in recruiting and holding onto staff.

"Unless the serious problems faced in recruiting and retaining staff are firmly and urgently addressed, locally and nationally, then services will deteriorate. For the many thousands who depend on them, and for their families, that would be tragic," the report says.

Earlier this year a poll by the Local Government Association and Community Care magazine found social work's image at an all-time low with many people seeing them as interfering, ineffective and excessively bureaucratic.

The SWSI's annual report includes a snapshot of services in each council to gain a comprehensive picture of social work services across Scotland.

It found that social work had responded well to changes since local government reorganisation in 1996 by setting up new services, developing new partnerships and breaking down departmental boundaries.

The report highlights the need to promote more "enlightened entrepreneurship" in social work, with new ideas too rarely taken on board and included in mainstream practice.

"Too often, schemes or projects are limited to pilots or single teams within authorities. People are sometimes reluctant to learn from professional colleagues outside the authority and too often other authorities' successful ways of working are dismissed for not having been developed locally."

Chief social work inspector Angus Skinner said the survey's findings were encouraging because they showed what the public really thought of social work.

"There has been an image problem and it is very important that people working in the service understand that they are valued by the society in which they work. Because bad news is more readily reported than good news, that balanced picture doesn't always come across," he said.

"There are a number of ways in which we should be tackling the recruitment problem - by providing better education and training, better support for frontline staff, better strategic planning by authorities and by finding new ways of attracting people into the profession."

Ruth Stark, professional officer for the British Association of Social Workers in Scotland, welcomed the report but claimed it failed to recognise the true extent of the recruitment crisis in social work.

"It is encouraging that the public does have some knowledge about what is being done, although there is still a lot of room for improvement. But notwithstanding public opinion, some of the problem has to do with the poor press and poor political backing for social work services," she said.

webTitle: New broom Vialli aims to sweep Watford to Premiership

fields.headline: New broom Vialli aims to sweep Watford to Premiership
fields.trailText:
Gianluca Vialli has signed a three-year deal with the First Division club and will take over at the end of the season when Graham Taylor retires.
Factfile on Watford's new boss

Watford the town awaits Vialli
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli was yesterday unveiled as the man chosen to succeed Graham Taylor at Watford, resurrecting a managerial career seemingly derailed when Chelsea sacked him last September amid allegations of dressing-room unrest.

But it is never easy to displace a local legend and, just as Dave Bassett did at the end of Taylor's first spell at Vicarage Road in 1987, Vialli has chosen to wash his hands of the old regime. In will come several friends from his Chelsea days, likely to include Ray Wilkins and Ray Lewington; out go Luther Blissett, Tom Walley and Kenny Jackett, ending 25-year associations with the club.

Their departure came as a shock to Watford fans on an otherwise uplifting day, but Vialli is determined that, unlike during his ill-fated spell at Stamford Bridge, he will be surrounded by allies.

"At Chelsea I felt I couldn't express myself, but here I think I can get what I need," he said. "That doesn't mean to buy the best players but to be free to have ideas and to see them implemented.

"After I left Chelsea I thought next time that has got to be a priority for me and I can see that at Watford I will have the opportunity to express myself in the best possible way. I'm here to improve my skills as a manager but most of all to have fun."

The talk yesterday was of a "marriage" between a manager and a board who share a footballing vision. And that vision goes beyond the First Division.

"You must have a target," Vialli said. "The challenge is to take this club to the Premiership, and not just for a year but for as long as possible. Our benchmark is to be like Ipswich and Charlton. They are small clubs but very well run financially and they also play good football."

Even in their most successful periods good football was rare at Watford. "I think the potential is there, but something can be done to improve the quality," Vialli said of his squad. "I like quality players, players with the right mentality, but you've got to be realistic." He insisted he was "very happy" with a transfer budget of around £4m. "People think managers all want big money, but we just want to do our job and here I think I can. I've had a look around; I've been to the training ground. Everything is fantastic and I can't wait to start." Compared with Chelsea's, of course, most training grounds are fantastic.

Vialli shrugged off criticism - led by Taylor - of his changes to the coaching staff. "That's the way things go," he said. "You have to work with people you know and trust. I'm not doing it because I'm ruthless but because that's the only way I can feel comfortable and do my job."

Taylor said: "If the club is my baby, I'm confident I'm handing it over to someone who understands it. But I'm disappointed that people like Kenny and Luther haven't even been given an opportunity. My view is that continuity is important, and the backroom staff are often the innocent victims."

Elton John, Watford's chairman and now the only link to their past success, had no such qualms. "I just want to say how incredibly excited I am that we've appointed Luca and his amazing managerial team," he said from his Los Angeles home.

Watford will hope Vialli sees out his three-year contract. On Sunday, as Juventus stuttered to a 1-1 home draw with Lecce, their fans were calling for the man who as captain lifted their last European Cup in 1996 to take over at the Stadio delle Alpi. One day, perhaps, he will.

fields.headline: Press freedom websites worldwide
fields.trailText: May 3: Click here to access the international websites of 12 organisations campaigning for press freedom.
fields.body:
Freedom Forum
The home page for the Freedom Forum, an organisation set up to promote and defend international press freedom. www.freedomforum.org
Index on Censorship
The body monitors press restrictions worldwide. The site includes useful links to today's events worldwide. www.indexoncensorship.org
Unesco
The UN organisation is backing Press Freedom Day. It says May 3 serves as an occasion to inform the public of violations of the right to freedom of expression and as a reminder that many journalists brave death or jail to bring people the news. www.unesco.org
The International Freedom of Express Exchange
The organisation links freedom of expression groups around the world and its site provides the latest news of violations across the globe. www.ifex.org
The Electronic Frontier Foundation
A similar organisation, based in the US, but for internet publications. www.eff.org
The Unlimited Free Speech Society
A page of links and resources for anyone interested in free speech or issues relating to the protection of journalists. www.freespeech.org
Committee to Protect Journalists
A global non-profit organisation that monitors the safety and protection of journalists worldwide. www.cpj.org
The Institute for War and Peace Reporting
An organisation set up to monitor safety and provide support and resources for journalists in conflict zones. www.iwpr.net
MediaChannel
A US-based internet portal with news and features about the industry with a press freedom focus. www.mediachannel.org
Reporters Sans Frontieres
A Paris-based international monitoring organisation that investigates allegations of brutality against journalists. www.rsf.fr
The International Press Institute
A global free speech promotion portal with good news coverage of the world's trouble spots. www.freemedia.at
The Campaign for Freedom of Information
A UK-based organisation campaigning against restrictions on press coverage. www.cfoi.org.uk

webTitle: Minister defends smack and smoke rules for childminders

fields.headline: Minister defends smack and smoke rules for childminders
fields.trailText: Controversial new rules allowing childminders to smack their charges and smoke in front of them will be included in the first national childcare standards due to be published next week, education minister Margaret Hodge revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Controversial new rules allowing childminders to smack their charges and smoke in front of them will be included in the first national childcare standards due to be published next week, education minister Margaret Hodge revealed yesterday.

She defended her decision to allow childminders to do so - with parents' agreement - and said she had been infuriated by professional representatives who insisted they were better placed than families to judge such issues.

Smacking and smoking by workers in all other childcare settings will be outlawed.

Giving evidence to the all-party select committee for its inquiry into early years education, Mrs Hodge insisted the government had been right to resist pressure, after a poll showed 83 % of parents felt it was a decision they should make themselves. "This is an issue for parents. The idea that we, as politicians, have a better understanding of the welfare of their children is insulting to parents."

Hailing a revolution in childcare since Labour came to power, Mrs Hodge said it was now the second fastest-growing sector in the labour market. Record numbers of men had expressed an interest in a career in the sector, she said.

The new childcare standards will be published next week and will come into force in July under a new inspection regime overseen by the office for standards in education. Mrs Hodge said the first national standards for under-eights daycare and childminding will cover all private and public sector day nurseries, playgroups, creches and after-school clubs.

Mrs Hodge came under fire from the Conservative MP, Nick St Aubyn, who said the issue of smacking and smoking was so important that it should have been debated in parliament.

The Labour committee chairman, Barry Sheerman, added: "There is a unanimous view on this committee that you are wrong."

fields.headline: Telecoms boost with Orange up 33%
fields.trailText: 10am: Orange boosted the telecoms sector this morning with a strong set of first quarter results, writes Dan Milmo
fields.body:
Orange boosted the telecoms sector this morning with a strong set of first quarter results.

The UK's third largest mobile phone operator was on the receiving end of negative market sentiment towards telecoms in February, when it was forced to slash its flotation price by 18%.

However, the France Telecom-owned company today bolstered its reputation as a fast-growing company, adding 2.7m customers worldwide since the beginning of the year, taking its total customer base to 33.2m.

Orange worldwide turnover for the first three months of the year rose 33% to £2.1bn, with UK revenues soaring 42% to £778m.

France remains Orange's strongest market, with turnover climbing 19% to £930m.

The far-from detailed statement was in line with analysts' expectations, although some said the company's parent may cause problems in the future.

"The problem that faces Orange is that it is no longer its own master, and that the new master may have a very different agenda. France Telecom has been talking a lot about integrating fixed line and mobile operations," said John Tysoe, telecoms analyst at West LB Panmure.

However, Orange is well positioned for the introduction of 3G phones over the next 18 months, with content and network deals already in the pipeline.

In the meantime, Orange will launch its intermediate-stage GPRS services over the summer, and it is seen as an important taster for customers' appetites for next-generation services.

The group's shares fell over 1% to 703p in early trading, but well above its recent low of 515p and a clear distance from its much-debated float price of 638p.

France Telecom today reported a 36% rise in revenue to £6.47bn, while its Wanadoo internet service provider said turnover fell from £218m to £195m.
