webTitle: Full text of John Stoker's speech

fields.headline: Full text of John Stoker's speech
fields.standfirst: In a speech at the Charity Finance Directors' Group annual conference, John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, warns that charities must try to convince the public that they are not "wasting resources" and dispel perceptions that they are turning into impersonal "big businesses"
fields.trailText: In a speech at the Charity Finance Directors' Group annual conference, John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, warns that charities must try to convince the public that they are not "wasting resources" and dispel perceptions that they are turning into impersonal "big businesses"
fields.body:
I'd like to cover three topical issues that affect support for charities - the debate about "too many charities", the need for openness and accountability in the way in which charities operate, and the central importance of safeguarding charities' independence. Then I want to mention the enhanced work programme the Commission will be pursuing from the beginning of the next financial year with money from our successful bid in last year's Comprehensive Spending Review. Finally I'll announce two important developments in the area of investments.

The first of my issues that affect support for charities is the view - one we hear quite a lot nowadays - that there are too many charities. This sounds straightforward -and worrying. But what does it mean? What concerns about charities does it express? And what should the response to these concerns be?

There are a number of factors driving the perception.

· Firstly, the numbers, pure and simple. If you're told that there are 188,000 registered charities - or 4000 charities just in Devon, or 600 cancer charities, or 200 homelessness charities in London - you immediately struggle to imagine what each can possibly be doing that is distinctive. And if a charity's not doing anything distinctive, why does it need to exist separately from others doing much the same thing?
· Secondly, many of the people who ask these questions - including donors - think the principle that "two can live as cheaply as one" holds good in some general sense for charities. The more separate charities there are, the more money they see as wasted. Wasted, that is, on the costs that each has to incur creating the administrative apparatus to sustain it in existence, and on promoting itself as a separate entity.
· Thirdly, our postbag suggests that people's experiences of fundraising can add to the impression of a crowded - even overcrowded - charity field. Part of this is just a feeling that there is an awful lot of it about. But part of it is also a reaction against the way in which fundraising is sometimes done. The methods most often objected to are the ones seen by recipients as costly or wasteful, or as the product of an over-competitive or aggressive attitude. One of the conclusions that people draw, rightly or wrongly, from seeing aggressive competition between fundraising charities is that there are too many charities competing for too few funds.
· Fourthly, some people think that it's too easy to set up a charity. The only legal requirement is for a constitution that contains exclusively charitable objects. You don't, for instance, need to provide any particular evidence of unmet need in the area in which the new charity is going to operate. There is a perception that some people set up their own charities, or continue the ones they are involved with, at least partly out of self-interest - they want their own organisation so that they can make sure things are done in the way they want.

How should we react to these potentially damaging perceptions?

Let's first have a look at some of the numbers and try to dispel a few myths. In round figures there are about 190,000 charities on the commission's register. Of these, about 30,000 are subsidiaries or constituents of a larger charity. They are registered in their own right because they typically have their own constitutions and funds. But they're not administratively separate - they have the same trustees as their parent charity and are run with it.

That leaves about 160,000 main charities. I've seen estimates that 80% of voluntary organisations are volunteer-run as opposed to professionally run. That is, they have no paid staff and rely entirely on their trustees and other volunteers. This seems to match quite well with our own figures, which show that 67% of registered charities have an annual income under £10,000 with 90% under £100,000. The income level of the typical charity just starting to take on paid staff thus looks to be of the order of £30-40,000 - as one might have guessed.

As well as the low costs that come from being volunteer-run, most charities below this size have something else that evidence suggests strongly appeals to contributors - a local character. Funds are spent where they are raised. Those who contribute to the charity can see what their contribution achieves.

A figure of 125-130,000 volunteer-run local charities still sounds a lot, until you start adding up the various types: 2,300 recreation ground and playing field charities; 2,400 PTAs and Home School Associations; 5,300 village halls; and so on across the spectrum of community endeavour.

All these charities are doing the same things as all the others of the same type, but are serving different communities. By and large there is no overlap, no duplication and little scope for cost-cutting. There might well be scope for finding ways to use resources more effectively, but that's not a "numbers" matter.

That still leaves around 30,000 charities, including every charity represented here today I imagine, that are to a greater or lesser extent professionally run. It's the professionally run charities that are usually obliged to respond to the charges of duplication and waste, and over-aggressive fundraising. And, as I shall come to in a moment, it's the commission that has to reply to accusations that it's too easy to start up a charity (or, from other quarters, that it's too difficult to register a charity).

One final point on numbers. The register doesn't inevitably increase every year. In our last reported financial year, 1999/2000, the register decreased by about 3,000 as we identified and removed a large number of inactive charities.

There are three things that need to form the basis of a response to the concerns I've outlined.

First, there are clear advantages to be had from a healthy plurality of charities. We need to hammer home these advantages with the public, not expect them to be taken as read. The service-user or beneficiary gains from the breadth of choice on offer. Charities can develop the capacity to specialise and to provide a personal service on a human scale. The precise interests of people who want to donate to, volunteer for, join, or support charities are also more likely to be satisfied when there are charities of all shades. And although I mentioned the unseemly side of over-competitiveness, one mustn't forget the benefits of competition in encouraging efficiency and attentiveness to users' needs.

Secondly, we must acknowledge public concern about duplication and inefficiency, and show that we don't intend to tolerate them. Those of us running charities must be clearly seen to explore the scope for benefit from collaboration with other charities and organisations. There are big benefits of public confidence and support to be had from showing collaborative as opposed to over-competitive instincts. These are in addition to the concrete benefits can be realised in terms of reduced costs, enhanced income or improved services.

What I am not saying is that everyone must rush out and try to merge with everyone else. What I am saying is that there is a very wide variety of possibilities for working better by working together. These range from modest ventures like shared helplines or the joint production of training material for professional staff through joint service-delivery units, purchasing consortia, joint flag days, appeals or advocacy campaigns on appropriate issues, combined grant administration, joint marketing initiatives, to partial or full mergers.

Many of you are of course already very much alive to the possibilities and are benefiting from various types of collaborative ventures - but then you are a sophisticated and well-informed group. There are some examples of good quality information and guidance - NCVO's study on marketing collaborations; the Baring Foundation's guide to good practice in mergers; the Liverpool University guidance on legal aspects of merger. What doesn't exist at the moment, though, is a central repository of knowledge and information, and source of advice for charities, on collaborative working. To fill this gap CFDG, NCVO, ACEVO and ICFM, at the commission's suggestion, are putting together a study into the demand for, and feasibility of, such a service. The third part of our response is really to ask a question in return. If you are concerned that there are too many charities, how do you want to control and ration things? Who will decide which charities deserve to be allowed to start up or continue and which do not?

Our national tradition is that any person can, without needing any permission from the state, lawfully join with others to form an association for purposes of public benefit. The role of the state, through the commission, is to confirm that the organisation meets the legal criteria that define charitable status, and to register the organisation so that it is monitored and has access to advice, and so that information about it comes into the public domain. We can't deny registration on any grounds other than failure to meet those legal criteria, and wouldn't want to have the power to do so.

But there is an expectation, and not an unreasonable one, that we should intervene in some way if an organisation presents itself for registration and is evidently set up to fail. It's not rare for an intending charity to come to us with an impeccable constitution meeting all the legal criteria, but with over-ambitious goals, unrealistic ideas about the prospects for income generation, and inadequate governance arrangements. We could wave it through, watch it struggle along for a couple of years, then remove it from the register when it folds up. Or we could do what we already do - encourage the trustees to develop, before registration, sensible plans which are likely to give them a much better chance of achieving their aims. These might include considering whether in fact starting a new organisation is the best way of achieving aims - what about joining up with an existing organisation?

I repeat that we can't and won't refuse registration on the grounds of poor planning. But we're equally convinced that it would be irresponsible of us, and wasteful of resources in the long run, not to do what we properly can to make sure that a charity starts off on a sound footing. One that's set up, to fail could waste donors', funders' and taxpayers' money, leave creditors unpaid, and tie up our resources.

Finally, on the numbers game, there is one way in which charities can combat suggestions of waste and excessive numbers which is potentially as powerful as all the others put together. This is to tell the story, clearly, persuasively and professionally, of what they achieve for beneficiaries. The more the debate can focus on achievements - on outcomes, in the jargon, rather than on costs and other inputs - the better for public confidence in charity.

Now, still on the theme of good communications, I want to make some points about openness and transparency.

One of the differences between the old Statement of Recommended Practice on Accounting by Charities and the new SORP is the extra emphasis put on reporting. I mean reporting in the sense of painting a picture, in words as well as figures and in a way that people who are not financial experts can understand, of what the charity has used its resources for during the year, and what it has achieved.

We especially hope that the trustees' report will become a key document. We have seen in the past too many so-called trustees' reports written in dusty and outdated audit-prose. Indeed the trustees might not have seen their report before the board meeting in which it was thrust in front of the chair with instructions to sign. Only in a limited sense can this be called the "trustees'" report. This is a plea for real trustees' reports.

We see a variety of reactions from charities to public and media interest in administration and fundraising costs.

Some charities react in a defensive way and seek to disclose little, usually for one of two reasons. Either the charity thinks that any unsolicited interest in its affairs is impertinent and unjustified - a reaction that we do still see from time to time from charities that are in the habit of calling themselves "private" charities. Or, far more commonly, the charity is worried that what it says will be misunderstood, taken out of context, or used to compare it unfavourably with other charities.

These worries are understandable. But I'm sure that charities' interests are best served in the long run by adopting a culture of openness - a willingness to disclose, explain and justify - and worst served by a culture of defensiveness and "keeping the head down".

In this connection there is one point that we need to be much less coy about. It is that good management and administration cost money. It's unrealistic to expect a large charity to run to the highest standards of efficiency and stewardship without recognising that it has to pay salaries that will attract and motivate the right staff, and has to pay open market rates for bought-in goods and services.

Where a presumption seems to exist that people who work for charities ought to be prepared to work for next to nothing, or that charities should somehow be able to trade on their status to get goods and services at no cost, that needs to be challenged.

In challenging it, however, we need to accept that the professionalisation of charity can give the impression of organisations that are moving away from their charitable roots. The same impression sometimes results from charities pursuing methods of fundraising that echo commercial sales practices. When people say things like "charities are big businesses nowadays," they are articulating a specific sense of regret. This is the regret that some charities have grown impersonal as they have grown large, and that they have been unable to maintain a charitable way of doing things that distinguishes them from the hard ways of business - and, indeed, from the public sector.

The third "confidence" issue that I want to address is independence. There is a widely held perception that part of the value of charity lies in it being independent of the state, on the one hand, and of business interests on the other. Charity is seen as being about altruism and the voluntary principle, not about carrying out governmental imperatives or serving the profit motive. And yet, increasingly, charity and the state and (to a lesser extent) charity and business interact at all sorts of levels, and in all sorts of ways.

Most obviously, the contract culture involves charities co-operating with local authorities, and providing services under contract on behalf of local authorities.

· More and more local authorities, keen to obtain the fiscal and other benefits of charitable status, are setting up charities to manage their leisure centres or their museums or their housing stock.

· Business sponsors charity on an ever increasing scale. Cause-related marketing arrangements proliferate.

· Building societies have set up charities and insist that new savers and borrowers agree to donate to them any windfalls that may result from demutualisation.

· The governing bodies of charities increasingly include representatives of the funding bodies that support them.

These developments are seen in some quarters as undermining the independence of charity. And it is certainly true that developments of this sort can pose a challenge to charities' independence. But it is a challenge that charities - and the legal framework that supports them - are able to meet.

Of course, it is crucially important that charities - and those who have dealings with charities - should understand the framework within which charities operate and the ways in which charities are legally required to be independent. It is equally important that the public should be aware that independence continues to be an essential characteristic of charity, and should be able to see that independence when they look at charities in action.

The guidance that we published in March on Charities and Independence emphasises the importance of independence as regards

· the purposes for which charities are established

· the way that charities are governed

· and the way that charities operate.

The essential point is that charities must exist for charitable purposes only - not to carry out the wishes or policies of the state, or of business - not to carry out some hidden agenda of the charity's promoters - just to carry out charitable purposes.

And it is for the trustees to decide how those charitable purposes are to be carried out, not some outside body. In making those decisions, the trustees must act solely in the interests of the charity, not in anyone else's interests. That means that, even if a trustee is appointed by a funding body, he or she isn't there to represent the funder's interests. It doesn't matter how an individual becomes a trustee. Once someone accepts trusteeship, as a trustee his or her loyalty must be to the charity.

An important principle is that charity money can't be spent on things that should be paid for by government. At most, trustees can use charitable funds only to supplement the services that government must pay for. In our periodic MORI surveys of public attitudes there is some concern that charities are being required to pay for things that government should be paying for.

Secondly, trustees can't just surrender their discretion. They have to decide who the charity is going to benefit and how. That means that joint projects can only get off the ground where what the funder wants coincides with what the trustees think will best achieve the charitiy's charitable purposes.

It also means that trustees can't accept funding conditions that restrict their activities outside the funding agreement. They can't accept conditions, for example, that prevent them speaking out on behalf of their beneficiaries. In this context, the only constraints upon them are the restrictions - set out in the guidelines we publish - that limit the sort of political and campaigning activity that charities can engage in. One of these restrictions is the prohibition on engagement in any aspects of party politics, including - perhaps especially - at election time. Our evidence suggests that the public are generally happy with the way charities manage to stay out of politics in that sense. But it is equally clear the credibility of any charity getting improperly involved in party politics is likely to suffer at least in the short term and perhaps permanently.

I want to turn now to the Commission's future work programme.

Under the Chancellor's Comprehensive Spending Review the Commission has been given more funding to pursue some new initiatives, and to develop some of our existing functions. The funding amounts to an extra £4m plus a year from April 2002.

The first area I want to mention is a new kind of Commission report on charity practice. We already produce a comprehensive range of booklets and other guidance for trustees - our "CC" range alone runs to 58 titles. Our intention now is to publish broadly based studies of themes and issues to show how practice is matching up to the precept in our best practice guidance - what works well; where the pitfalls are; what lessons can be learnt.

This will enable us, as the regulator, to put the spotlight, not just on the best practice that we want to encourage and celebrate, but also what needs to change and improve. The reports will continue to focus on core commission concerns in the areas of governance, finance, organisation and administration. They will not seek to get into best practice in particular areas of service provision. CDFG is among the bodies that we have already consulted in drawing up our proposals both for possible themes and for ways of approaching the production of these reports, and I am very grateful for their help and support.

While the funding for these reports will not be available until April 2002 we intend to run two pilot studies this year. One of the pilots will look from the commission's regulatory viewpoint at trustee induction, including the selection and recruitment of trustees.

The second pilot study will look at charities and commercial partnerships. This is a topic which is increasingly relevant as charities seek to secure additional funds, or further their aims, by working with a commercial partner.

A significant part of the new money will be used to fund an enhanced programme of visits to charities by commission staff. From last month, we have started to phase in new-style "review visits" with the aim of increasing their impact as a regulatory tool, as well as improving our relationships with charities and our ability to monitor developing trends and issues. 150 of the new-style visits will be conducted before April 2002, when the full launch takes place. Thereafter, we plan to conduct 600 visits per year. The new programme will complement, not replace, our current outreach activities involving seminars, roadshows, surgeries and so on.

Review visits will use a modular structure based on the best practice framework in the commission's booklet 'Hallmarks of a Well Run Charity'. As well as reviewing the charity's published accounts, reports and other documentation, our staff will talk to trustees and others about the charity's activities, trusts, governance, and internal controls.

For most of you, a detailed risk assessment for your organisation will underpin your internal control framework. Many of you, in your annual report, are already referring - in line with Turnbull recommendations and the new SORP - to that assessment, confirming that systems have been established to mitigate major risks. Some of you will have access to an internal audit facility. All of you here today are likely to have external auditors.

In framing our finance modules for the enhanced visits programme, we are looking at the steps the charity has taken to control risk, how it has responded to the findings of internal and external auditors, and the quality of financial controls in general. We don't want to duplicate work already carried out and won't be appearing on the scene to carry out an audit by another name. We will, however, want to see evidence of appropriate controls and sound financial management. When appropriate, a commission accountant will take part in the review visit.

We want to make the visits valuable for individual charities, giving them reassurance that they are following good practice. To ensure mutual benefit, we will agree in advance with the charity an agenda that includes issues nominated by the charity and ones nominated by the commission.

The detailed report that we will provide to the charity will be structured to indicate areas where the charity must take some action because the law specifically requires it; things to be considered because the law generally requires it; and recommendations for good practice. Some cross-cutting issues highlighted by visits will feed into the thematic reports I've just been describing.

The extra funding also includes an extra £1m a year which will enable us to increase our capacity to carry out statutory investigations. There will also be a project to enable clients to carry out all of their business with us electronically, if that is what they choose.

I want to turn now to investments. Many of you will know that the commission has been looking at the treatment of investment returns. Specifically we have been considering whether endowed charities should be allowed to be more flexible in their treatment of investment returns. We've wanted to assess whether flexibility would lead to the better use of resources for the benefit of present and future beneficiaries. Charities and their financial advisers had been telling us for some time that the rules on the treatment of investment returns on capital funds were now so out of date that they often worked against the interests of beneficiaries.

Last summer we sought views on this issue and received a large number of detailed submissions. These were helpful to us in thinking about the issues and we're grateful to everyone who put time and effort into giving us their views and ideas. The general thrust of these showed a high degree of support for our proposals.

Since then we've been developing our approach to the question of how trustees could be given power to allocate investment returns in a flexible way. The introduction of such a power would enable charities more effectively to balance the needs of present and of future beneficiaries.

I can confirm today that we are now willing to offer the trustees of endowed charities a power to allocate the total return received from investments at their discretion rather than in the way dictated by the standard rules.

This power will enable charities to invest their funds in the way that they judge will produce the best returns for the charity, regardless of the form - capital or income - in which returns are received. It will also enable them to allocate the return between present and future beneficiaries in the way they consider best enables them to fulfil their duty to be fair to all beneficiaries. As with the use of any such powers, trustees must act prudently and reasonably and must use the power in the interests of the charity. The power will have to be given to charities one by one at their request - we can't introduce it in a blanket way.

Trustees have an obligation to treat all their beneficiaries - present and future - fairly. The power will not remove or diminish that obligation.

To ensure that the obligation is honoured, the power given to trustees will be subject to a number of directions. These are designed specifically to protect the interests of present and future beneficiaries, and to ensure that the wish of any donor wanting to establish an enduring charity can be upheld. The directions are key to the use of the power and take the form of duties that must be carried out before the power can be used.

The directions require a duty of even-handedness and a duty of care similar to the duty of care in the new Trustee Act.

Charities will also be under a duty to disclose publicly their use of the power. This was a point that was thought important by respondents to our consultation. The consensus was that disclosure of the use of the power would be an important feature in guarding against misuse. We agree.

Obtaining professional investment advice will also be essential. It will give the trustees confidence that their overall pattern of investment and expenditure is sustainable.

Under the new power, charities will have a wide discretion to allocate investment returns as they see fit, constrained only by the obligation to be even-handed. We will expect them to use the power in a way that doesn't prejudice the charity's ability to meet both present and future needs.

The power doesn't, I stress, undermine the legal concept of permanent endowment - an endowment which can't be expended and must remain perpetually intact. Nor will the new power remove the ability of someone founding a charity to set it up in a permanently endowed form if he or she so wishes.

We recognise the need for trustees to take a long-term view on the generation and the allocation of investment returns. The guidance we produce will therefore draw attention to the fact that investment returns and inflation fluctuate from year to year - if anyone needs to be reminded after the last few weeks, markets can go up and down in a volatile way. We will also in our guidance emphasise the duty to make fair decisions about the resources to be spent on current and future beneficiaries.

We will be putting our guidance on the total return approach onto our website in the next week or so.

One thing we are putting onto our website today is some guidance about charities' use of their funds for programme-related investment. A programme-related investment, a term that I want to make clear we didn't invent, is a form of social investment. It's a way of using funds to achieve charitable aims rather than to secure an investment return.

Many charities, not just pure grant-makers, have the capacity to use their funds to make grants. But there's been some uncertainty about the extent to which charities can use their funds to make soft loans to, or equity investments in, businesses run for community benefit by social entrepreneurs.

Our guidance has examples of the use of both income and capital funds for programme-related investment. Essentially we're saying that charities probably have more latitude to make programme-related investments than they might have thought - if indeed they'd thought about it at all. We hadn't thought about it ourselves before the chancellor's appointment last year of the Social Investment Task Force. It reported in October on ways of enabling under-invested communities to access investment funds. David Carrington, from whom we'll hear later, was a member of this Task Force.
fields.bodyText: I'd like to cover three topical issues that affect support for charities - the debate about "too many charities", the need for openness and accountability in the way in which charities operate, and the central importance of safeguarding charities' independence. Then I want to mention the enhanced work programme the Commission will be pursuing from the beginning of the next financial year with money from our successful bid in last year's Comprehensive Spending Review. Finally I'll announce two important developments in the area of investments. The first of my issues that affect support for charities is the view - one we hear quite a lot nowadays - that there are too many charities. This sounds straightforward -and worrying. But what does it mean? What concerns about charities does it express? And what should the response to these concerns be? There are a number of factors driving the perception. · Firstly, the numbers, pure and simple. If you're told that there are 188,000 registered charities - or 4000 charities just in Devon, or 600 cancer charities, or 200 homelessness charities in London - you immediately struggle to imagine what each can possibly be doing that is distinctive. And if a charity's not doing anything distinctive, why does it need to exist separately from others doing much the same thing? · Secondly, many of the people who ask these questions - including donors - think the principle that "two can live as cheaply as one" holds good in some general sense for charities. The more separate charities there are, the more money they see as wasted. Wasted, that is, on the costs that each has to incur creating the administrative apparatus to sustain it in existence, and on promoting itself as a separate entity. · Thirdly, our postbag suggests that people's experiences of fundraising can add to the impression of a crowded - even overcrowded - charity field. Part of this is just a feeling that there is an awful lot of it about. But part of it is also a reaction against the way in which fundraising is sometimes done. The methods most often objected to are the ones seen by recipients as costly or wasteful, or as the product of an over-competitive or aggressive attitude. One of the conclusions that people draw, rightly or wrongly, from seeing aggressive competition between fundraising charities is that there are too many charities competing for too few funds. · Fourthly, some people think that it's too easy to set up a charity. The only legal requirement is for a constitution that contains exclusively charitable objects. You don't, for instance, need to provide any particular evidence of unmet need in the area in which the new charity is going to operate. There is a perception that some people set up their own charities, or continue the ones they are involved with, at least partly out of self-interest - they want their own organisation so that they can make sure things are done in the way they want. How should we react to these potentially damaging perceptions? Let's first have a look at some of the numbers and try to dispel a few myths. In round figures there are about 190,000 charities on the commission's register. Of these, about 30,000 are subsidiaries or constituents of a larger charity. They are registered in their own right because they typically have their own constitutions and funds. But they're not administratively separate - they have the same trustees as their parent charity and are run with it. That leaves about 160,000 main charities. I've seen estimates that 80% of voluntary organisations are volunteer-run as opposed to professionally run. That is, they have no paid staff and rely entirely on their trustees and other volunteers. This seems to match quite well with our own figures, which show that 67% of registered charities have an annual income under £10,000 with 90% under £100,000. The income level of the typical charity just starting to take on paid staff thus looks to be of the order of £30-40,000 - as one might have guessed. As well as the low costs that come from being volunteer-run, most charities below this size have something else that evidence suggests strongly appeals to contributors - a local character. Funds are spent where they are raised. Those who contribute to the charity can see what their contribution achieves. A figure of 125-130,000 volunteer-run local charities still sounds a lot, until you start adding up the various types: 2,300 recreation ground and playing field charities; 2,400 PTAs and Home School Associations; 5,300 village halls; and so on across the spectrum of community endeavour. All these charities are doing the same things as all the others of the same type, but are serving different communities. By and large there is no overlap, no duplication and little scope for cost-cutting. There might well be scope for finding ways to use resources more effectively, but that's not a "numbers" matter. That still leaves around 30,000 charities, including every charity represented here today I imagine, that are to a greater or lesser extent professionally run. It's the professionally run charities that are usually obliged to respond to the charges of duplication and waste, and over-aggressive fundraising. And, as I shall come to in a moment, it's the commission that has to reply to accusations that it's too easy to start up a charity (or, from other quarters, that it's too difficult to register a charity). One final point on numbers. The register doesn't inevitably increase every year. In our last reported financial year, 1999/2000, the register decreased by about 3,000 as we identified and removed a large number of inactive charities. There are three things that need to form the basis of a response to the concerns I've outlined. First, there are clear advantages to be had from a healthy plurality of charities. We need to hammer home these advantages with the public, not expect them to be taken as read. The service-user or beneficiary gains from the breadth of choice on offer. Charities can develop the capacity to specialise and to provide a personal service on a human scale. The precise interests of people who want to donate to, volunteer for, join, or support charities are also more likely to be satisfied when there are charities of all shades. And although I mentioned the unseemly side of over-competitiveness, one mustn't forget the benefits of competition in encouraging efficiency and attentiveness to users' needs. Secondly, we must acknowledge public concern about duplication and inefficiency, and show that we don't intend to tolerate them. Those of us running charities must be clearly seen to explore the scope for benefit from collaboration with other charities and organisations. There are big benefits of public confidence and support to be had from showing collaborative as opposed to over-competitive instincts. These are in addition to the concrete benefits can be realised in terms of reduced costs, enhanced income or improved services. What I am not saying is that everyone must rush out and try to merge with everyone else. What I am saying is that there is a very wide variety of possibilities for working better by working together. These range from modest ventures like shared helplines or the joint production of training material for professional staff through joint service-delivery units, purchasing consortia, joint flag days, appeals or advocacy campaigns on appropriate issues, combined grant administration, joint marketing initiatives, to partial or full mergers. Many of you are of course already very much alive to the possibilities and are benefiting from various types of collaborative ventures - but then you are a sophisticated and well-informed group. There are some examples of good quality information and guidance - NCVO's study on marketing collaborations; the Baring Foundation's guide to good practice in mergers; the Liverpool University guidance on legal aspects of merger. What doesn't exist at the moment, though, is a central repository of knowledge and information, and source of advice for charities, on collaborative working. To fill this gap CFDG, NCVO, ACEVO and ICFM, at the commission's suggestion, are putting together a study into the demand for, and feasibility of, such a service. The third part of our response is really to ask a question in return. If you are concerned that there are too many charities, how do you want to control and ration things? Who will decide which charities deserve to be allowed to start up or continue and which do not? Our national tradition is that any person can, without needing any permission from the state, lawfully join with others to form an association for purposes of public benefit. The role of the state, through the commission, is to confirm that the organisation meets the legal criteria that define charitable status, and to register the organisation so that it is monitored and has access to advice, and so that information about it comes into the public domain. We can't deny registration on any grounds other than failure to meet those legal criteria, and wouldn't want to have the power to do so. But there is an expectation, and not an unreasonable one, that we should intervene in some way if an organisation presents itself for registration and is evidently set up to fail. It's not rare for an intending charity to come to us with an impeccable constitution meeting all the legal criteria, but with over-ambitious goals, unrealistic ideas about the prospects for income generation, and inadequate governance arrangements. We could wave it through, watch it struggle along for a couple of years, then remove it from the register when it folds up. Or we could do what we already do - encourage the trustees to develop, before registration, sensible plans which are likely to give them a much better chance of achieving their aims. These might include considering whether in fact starting a new organisation is the best way of achieving aims - what about joining up with an existing organisation? I repeat that we can't and won't refuse registration on the grounds of poor planning. But we're equally convinced that it would be irresponsible of us, and wasteful of resources in the long run, not to do what we properly can to make sure that a charity starts off on a sound footing. One that's set up, to fail could waste donors', funders' and taxpayers' money, leave creditors unpaid, and tie up our resources. Finally, on the numbers game, there is one way in which charities can combat suggestions of waste and excessive numbers which is potentially as powerful as all the others put together. This is to tell the story, clearly, persuasively and professionally, of what they achieve for beneficiaries. The more the debate can focus on achievements - on outcomes, in the jargon, rather than on costs and other inputs - the better for public confidence in charity. Now, still on the theme of good communications, I want to make some points about openness and transparency. One of the differences between the old Statement of Recommended Practice on Accounting by Charities and the new SORP is the extra emphasis put on reporting. I mean reporting in the sense of painting a picture, in words as well as figures and in a way that people who are not financial experts can understand, of what the charity has used its resources for during the year, and what it has achieved. We especially hope that the trustees' report will become a key document. We have seen in the past too many so-called trustees' reports written in dusty and outdated audit-prose. Indeed the trustees might not have seen their report before the board meeting in which it was thrust in front of the chair with instructions to sign. Only in a limited sense can this be called the "trustees'" report. This is a plea for real trustees' reports. We see a variety of reactions from charities to public and media interest in administration and fundraising costs. Some charities react in a defensive way and seek to disclose little, usually for one of two reasons. Either the charity thinks that any unsolicited interest in its affairs is impertinent and unjustified - a reaction that we do still see from time to time from charities that are in the habit of calling themselves "private" charities. Or, far more commonly, the charity is worried that what it says will be misunderstood, taken out of context, or used to compare it unfavourably with other charities. These worries are understandable. But I'm sure that charities' interests are best served in the long run by adopting a culture of openness - a willingness to disclose, explain and justify - and worst served by a culture of defensiveness and "keeping the head down". In this connection there is one point that we need to be much less coy about. It is that good management and administration cost money. It's unrealistic to expect a large charity to run to the highest standards of efficiency and stewardship without recognising that it has to pay salaries that will attract and motivate the right staff, and has to pay open market rates for bought-in goods and services. Where a presumption seems to exist that people who work for charities ought to be prepared to work for next to nothing, or that charities should somehow be able to trade on their status to get goods and services at no cost, that needs to be challenged. In challenging it, however, we need to accept that the professionalisation of charity can give the impression of organisations that are moving away from their charitable roots. The same impression sometimes results from charities pursuing methods of fundraising that echo commercial sales practices. When people say things like "charities are big businesses nowadays," they are articulating a specific sense of regret. This is the regret that some charities have grown impersonal as they have grown large, and that they have been unable to maintain a charitable way of doing things that distinguishes them from the hard ways of business - and, indeed, from the public sector. The third "confidence" issue that I want to address is independence. There is a widely held perception that part of the value of charity lies in it being independent of the state, on the one hand, and of business interests on the other. Charity is seen as being about altruism and the voluntary principle, not about carrying out governmental imperatives or serving the profit motive. And yet, increasingly, charity and the state and (to a lesser extent) charity and business interact at all sorts of levels, and in all sorts of ways. Most obviously, the contract culture involves charities co-operating with local authorities, and providing services under contract on behalf of local authorities. · More and more local authorities, keen to obtain the fiscal and other benefits of charitable status, are setting up charities to manage their leisure centres or their museums or their housing stock. · Business sponsors charity on an ever increasing scale. Cause-related marketing arrangements proliferate. · Building societies have set up charities and insist that new savers and borrowers agree to donate to them any windfalls that may result from demutualisation. · The governing bodies of charities increasingly include representatives of the funding bodies that support them. These developments are seen in some quarters as undermining the independence of charity. And it is certainly true that developments of this sort can pose a challenge to charities' independence. But it is a challenge that charities - and the legal framework that supports them - are able to meet. Of course, it is crucially important that charities - and those who have dealings with charities - should understand the framework within which charities operate and the ways in which charities are legally required to be independent. It is equally important that the public should be aware that independence continues to be an essential characteristic of charity, and should be able to see that independence when they look at charities in action. The guidance that we published in March on Charities and Independence emphasises the importance of independence as regards · the purposes for which charities are established · the way that charities are governed · and the way that charities operate. The essential point is that charities must exist for charitable purposes only - not to carry out the wishes or policies of the state, or of business - not to carry out some hidden agenda of the charity's promoters - just to carry out charitable purposes. And it is for the trustees to decide how those charitable purposes are to be carried out, not some outside body. In making those decisions, the trustees must act solely in the interests of the charity, not in anyone else's interests. That means that, even if a trustee is appointed by a funding body, he or she isn't there to represent the funder's interests. It doesn't matter how an individual becomes a trustee. Once someone accepts trusteeship, as a trustee his or her loyalty must be to the charity. An important principle is that charity money can't be spent on things that should be paid for by government. At most, trustees can use charitable funds only to supplement the services that government must pay for. In our periodic MORI surveys of public attitudes there is some concern that charities are being required to pay for things that government should be paying for. Secondly, trustees can't just surrender their discretion. They have to decide who the charity is going to benefit and how. That means that joint projects can only get off the ground where what the funder wants coincides with what the trustees think will best achieve the charitiy's charitable purposes. It also means that trustees can't accept funding conditions that restrict their activities outside the funding agreement. They can't accept conditions, for example, that prevent them speaking out on behalf of their beneficiaries. In this context, the only constraints upon them are the restrictions - set out in the guidelines we publish - that limit the sort of political and campaigning activity that charities can engage in. One of these restrictions is the prohibition on engagement in any aspects of party politics, including - perhaps especially - at election time. Our evidence suggests that the public are generally happy with the way charities manage to stay out of politics in that sense. But it is equally clear the credibility of any charity getting improperly involved in party politics is likely to suffer at least in the short term and perhaps permanently. I want to turn now to the Commission's future work programme. Under the Chancellor's Comprehensive Spending Review the Commission has been given more funding to pursue some new initiatives, and to develop some of our existing functions. The funding amounts to an extra £4m plus a year from April 2002. The first area I want to mention is a new kind of Commission report on charity practice. We already produce a comprehensive range of booklets and other guidance for trustees - our "CC" range alone runs to 58 titles. Our intention now is to publish broadly based studies of themes and issues to show how practice is matching up to the precept in our best practice guidance - what works well; where the pitfalls are; what lessons can be learnt. This will enable us, as the regulator, to put the spotlight, not just on the best practice that we want to encourage and celebrate, but also what needs to change and improve. The reports will continue to focus on core commission concerns in the areas of governance, finance, organisation and administration. They will not seek to get into best practice in particular areas of service provision. CDFG is among the bodies that we have already consulted in drawing up our proposals both for possible themes and for ways of approaching the production of these reports, and I am very grateful for their help and support. While the funding for these reports will not be available until April 2002 we intend to run two pilot studies this year. One of the pilots will look from the commission's regulatory viewpoint at trustee induction, including the selection and recruitment of trustees. The second pilot study will look at charities and commercial partnerships. This is a topic which is increasingly relevant as charities seek to secure additional funds, or further their aims, by working with a commercial partner. A significant part of the new money will be used to fund an enhanced programme of visits to charities by commission staff. From last month, we have started to phase in new-style "review visits" with the aim of increasing their impact as a regulatory tool, as well as improving our relationships with charities and our ability to monitor developing trends and issues. 150 of the new-style visits will be conducted before April 2002, when the full launch takes place. Thereafter, we plan to conduct 600 visits per year. The new programme will complement, not replace, our current outreach activities involving seminars, roadshows, surgeries and so on. Review visits will use a modular structure based on the best practice framework in the commission's booklet 'Hallmarks of a Well Run Charity'. As well as reviewing the charity's published accounts, reports and other documentation, our staff will talk to trustees and others about the charity's activities, trusts, governance, and internal controls. For most of you, a detailed risk assessment for your organisation will underpin your internal control framework. Many of you, in your annual report, are already referring - in line with Turnbull recommendations and the new SORP - to that assessment, confirming that systems have been established to mitigate major risks. Some of you will have access to an internal audit facility. All of you here today are likely to have external auditors. In framing our finance modules for the enhanced visits programme, we are looking at the steps the charity has taken to control risk, how it has responded to the findings of internal and external auditors, and the quality of financial controls in general. We don't want to duplicate work already carried out and won't be appearing on the scene to carry out an audit by another name. We will, however, want to see evidence of appropriate controls and sound financial management. When appropriate, a commission accountant will take part in the review visit. We want to make the visits valuable for individual charities, giving them reassurance that they are following good practice. To ensure mutual benefit, we will agree in advance with the charity an agenda that includes issues nominated by the charity and ones nominated by the commission. The detailed report that we will provide to the charity will be structured to indicate areas where the charity must take some action because the law specifically requires it; things to be considered because the law generally requires it; and recommendations for good practice. Some cross-cutting issues highlighted by visits will feed into the thematic reports I've just been describing. The extra funding also includes an extra £1m a year which will enable us to increase our capacity to carry out statutory investigations. There will also be a project to enable clients to carry out all of their business with us electronically, if that is what they choose. I want to turn now to investments. Many of you will know that the commission has been looking at the treatment of investment returns. Specifically we have been considering whether endowed charities should be allowed to be more flexible in their treatment of investment returns. We've wanted to assess whether flexibility would lead to the better use of resources for the benefit of present and future beneficiaries. Charities and their financial advisers had been telling us for some time that the rules on the treatment of investment returns on capital funds were now so out of date that they often worked against the interests of beneficiaries. Last summer we sought views on this issue and received a large number of detailed submissions. These were helpful to us in thinking about the issues and we're grateful to everyone who put time and effort into giving us their views and ideas. The general thrust of these showed a high degree of support for our proposals. Since then we've been developing our approach to the question of how trustees could be given power to allocate investment returns in a flexible way. The introduction of such a power would enable charities more effectively to balance the needs of present and of future beneficiaries. I can confirm today that we are now willing to offer the trustees of endowed charities a power to allocate the total return received from investments at their discretion rather than in the way dictated by the standard rules. This power will enable charities to invest their funds in the way that they judge will produce the best returns for the charity, regardless of the form - capital or income - in which returns are received. It will also enable them to allocate the return between present and future beneficiaries in the way they consider best enables them to fulfil their duty to be fair to all beneficiaries. As with the use of any such powers, trustees must act prudently and reasonably and must use the power in the interests of the charity. The power will have to be given to charities one by one at their request - we can't introduce it in a blanket way. Trustees have an obligation to treat all their beneficiaries - present and future - fairly. The power will not remove or diminish that obligation. To ensure that the obligation is honoured, the power given to trustees will be subject to a number of directions. These are designed specifically to protect the interests of present and future beneficiaries, and to ensure that the wish of any donor wanting to establish an enduring charity can be upheld. The directions are key to the use of the power and take the form of duties that must be carried out before the power can be used. The directions require a duty of even-handedness and a duty of care similar to the duty of care in the new Trustee Act. Charities will also be under a duty to disclose publicly their use of the power. This was a point that was thought important by respondents to our consultation. The consensus was that disclosure of the use of the power would be an important feature in guarding against misuse. We agree. Obtaining professional investment advice will also be essential. It will give the trustees confidence that their overall pattern of investment and expenditure is sustainable. Under the new power, charities will have a wide discretion to allocate investment returns as they see fit, constrained only by the obligation to be even-handed. We will expect them to use the power in a way that doesn't prejudice the charity's ability to meet both present and future needs. The power doesn't, I stress, undermine the legal concept of permanent endowment - an endowment which can't be expended and must remain perpetually intact. Nor will the new power remove the ability of someone founding a charity to set it up in a permanently endowed form if he or she so wishes. We recognise the need for trustees to take a long-term view on the generation and the allocation of investment returns. The guidance we produce will therefore draw attention to the fact that investment returns and inflation fluctuate from year to year - if anyone needs to be reminded after the last few weeks, markets can go up and down in a volatile way. We will also in our guidance emphasise the duty to make fair decisions about the resources to be spent on current and future beneficiaries. We will be putting our guidance on the total return approach onto our website in the next week or so. One thing we are putting onto our website today is some guidance about charities' use of their funds for programme-related investment. A programme-related investment, a term that I want to make clear we didn't invent, is a form of social investment. It's a way of using funds to achieve charitable aims rather than to secure an investment return. Many charities, not just pure grant-makers, have the capacity to use their funds to make grants. But there's been some uncertainty about the extent to which charities can use their funds to make soft loans to, or equity investments in, businesses run for community benefit by social entrepreneurs. Our guidance has examples of the use of both income and capital funds for programme-related investment. Essentially we're saying that charities probably have more latitude to make programme-related investments than they might have thought - if indeed they'd thought about it at all. We hadn't thought about it ourselves before the chancellor's appointment last year of the Social Investment Task Force. It reported in October on ways of enabling under-invested communities to access investment funds. David Carrington, from whom we'll hear later, was a member of this Task Force.

fields.headline: Where journalists fear to tread
fields.standfirst: The freedom of the press is as big an issue as ever - 52 journalists were killed or murdered in 26 countries in 2000 and 71 journalists are being held in prison. There is no news media at all in Afghanistan, freedom of expression in China is virtually non-existent and Russia appears to be returning to its dark pre-glasnost days. Michael Williams of the Index on Censorship reports on the 25 countries most hostile to the press
fields.trailText: May 3: Michael Williams of the Index on Censorship reports on the 25 countries most hostile to the press.
fields.body:
Afghanistan
There are no domestic news media at all under the Taliban, which banned "news which could hurt people's feelings" in 1997. Most Afghans get information by word of mouth or from the BBC's daily Pashtu and Farsi services. The BBC's Kate Clark, the last foreign correspondent in Kabul, was given 24 hours to leave in March after she reported on the popular opposition to the Taliban's decision to blow up the magnificent standing Buddhas of Bamian, which were accused of "distracting" Moslems from Islam. Angola
Efforts to report the civil war - or the widespread trafficking of diamonds it conceals - meet punitive sanctions from the government of President Eduardo dos Santos. In October, Rafael Marques was one of three independent journalists banned for five years from speaking in public, reporting or travelling abroad. Bangladesh
Journalists are increasingly targeted under Prime Minister Sheik Hasina and the ruling Awami League. On July 16 last year, Shamsur Rahman, a regular BBC contributor, was shot dead in Jessore. On January 25, the hands and legs of the award-winning journalist, Tipu Sultan, were broken so badly by Awami thugs it was feared they would have to be amputated. Britain
For generations, the Official Secrets Act has served as an all-purpose ban on the disclosure of the inner workings of government. It hangs by a thread following the spate of bad publicity generated by the former spies, David Shayler and Richard Tomlinson, the British author, Tony Geraghty, and his alleged source for his banned book, the Irish War, Nigel Wylde, and the forthcoming memoirs of the former spy chief, Stella Rimmington. A meeting of the Reform of the Official Secrets Act group will be held on May 3 in the Jubilee Room of the House of Commons. Burkina Faso
Demonstrations continue to dog the government of this Sahelian state three years after the murder of the independent journalist, Norbert Zongo, in December 1998. Evidence points to the involvement of the president's brother, Francis Compaore, whom Mr Zongo had accused in print of murdering his own chauffeur. Burma
One of the least free media environments in the world. Last September, the 77-year-old lawyer, Cheng Po, was sentenced to seven years in Rangoon's dreaded Insein prison merely for "distributing" foreign news articles. Chile
Despite moves to prosecute the former president, Augusto Pinochet, "offending" the president, ministers, generals or judges is still punishable by up to five years in prison under the Domestic Security Law. In December, a judge upheld the arrest warrant on the exiled journalist, Alejandra Matus, whose banned book, Black Book of Chilean Justice, exposed the support given to General Pinochet by Chilean judges during the "dirty war". China
Few Chinese could discern any improvement in press freedom last year. A torrent of hate messages were spread by the official media against the Falun Gong, a movement of physical exercise practitioners that has put the fear of God into the government. Members of the group - or "sect" as the government describes it - continued to be arrested, jailed and beaten in their thousands, while several score have died in custody. In a speech in January, President Jiang Zemin told media chiefs: "The news media is the mouthpiece of the party and the people and should publicise the spirit of the part central committee in a precise, clear and vivid manner." The government considers the internet to be as direct a threat to its power as the Falun Gong, although web access is not widespread. Last year, Qi Yanchen was sentenced to an unspecified jail term for his contributions to the pro-democracy online magazine, VIP Reference. On 26 April 2001, Guo Qinghai was given four years for "subversion" as a result of his contributions to the website www.6-4tianwang.com. Chinese police hacked into foreign websites in order to track down Guo.
Useful link
www.indexoncensorship.org

Colombia
The most dangerous place in the world for journalists - 33 have been murdered there since 1991, mostly by the right wing paramilitary group, Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia, or guerillas of the leftist Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. On April 27, Flavio Bedoya, a 52-year-old journalist with the communist weekly, Voz, became the 11th victim in the past year. He was shot four times by unidentified men while stepping off a bus near the border with Ecuador.
Useful links
www.rsf.org
www.cpj.org

Czech Republic
Journalists occupied the premises of Czech TV over Christmas. They were protesting against political interference after the government imposed a new director less than a week after his predecessor was sacked. The government backed down after 100,000 people gathered on Wenceslas Square, although a new set of broadcasting laws have actually strengthened political control of the country's public television services.

Egypt
Fears of Islamic fundamentalism and the swelling tide of modernism led to a crackdown in 2000/01 that affected political reporting and mainstream publishing. The local correspondents of western news media were kicked and punched by police while they covered the campaigns of the banned Muslim Brotherhood candidates in the local elections on November 14. Charges of blasphemy, meanwhile, resulted in the torching of 6,000 books by the mediaeval poet, Abu Nawas, and the banning of Before and After by Tufiq Abderahman, Shivering of the Lights by Salaheddin Mohsen and A Banquet of Seaweed by Haidar Haidar.

Ethiopa
The country has the worst track record in Africa for jailing reporters. Garum Bekele, Tesfaye Deressa, Tamrat Gemeda and Solomon Namara have been in prison since 1997/98, while temporary detentions - usually for "publishing unpatriotic information" or "inciting ethnic tensions" - account for up to 15 more a year. Max Shine, the editor of Ethiop, is not expected to appear in court for two years following his arrest last November for an article about the war with Eritrea.

Iran
The three year flowering of free expression that followed the election of President Mohammed Katami in 1997 ended in 2000 when the conservatives gained the upper hand. A total of 30 liberal newspapers have been shut down - usually on grounds of "insulting Islam" or "criticising the clergy" - while editors and journalists have been sentenced to prison terms. The most significant of them was Akbar Ganji, who was sentenced to 10 years in prison and five years of internal exile for exposing the involvement of senior officials in the assassination of intellectuals in 1998. An exclusive interview with Mr Ganji forced the Guardian's Tehran correspondent, Genevieve Abdo, to flee the country on the night of February 2.

Kenya
Kenya is another African country whose leadership is increasingly out of step with the aspirations of its young population. It continues to prohibit privately owned radio stations "except for the purposes of evangelisation" and to repel the new freedoms of the internet. In December, the government ordered the closure of the Kenya Internet Exchange Point, only the second internet service provider to be set up in sub-Saharan Africa.

Macedonia
The government regularly tapped the phones of 25 journalists and 75 opposition figures after its near defeat in the September 2000 elections. This triggered a "Macedonian Watergate" when it was finally revealed to the public in January. One of those bugged, Julijama Kocovska-Krtolica of the daily paper, Denes, said: "This is a sign our rulers have become so paranoid they are scared of anything that resembles democracy."

Mozambique
The normally quiet backwater of Maputo, the country's capital, was shocked from its torpor on November 22 by news of the assassination of Carlos Cardoso, the country's premier editor and journalist. Mr Cardoso, who was fatally ambushed near his office, had been investigating corruption surrounding the IMF-backed privatisation of a state-owned bank in 1997.

Pakistan
Popular support for the 1999 coup, led by General Parvez Musharraf, has waned as civil liberties, which were never strong, have declined. In September, military forces occupied the office of the Dawn Group of Newspapers in Karachi following the publication of an article entitled: "Free press: is Musharraf having second thoughts?".

Peru
Investigative print and radio journalists braved death threats, arbitrary prosecution and surveillance by the intelligence services throughout the rule of President Alberto Fujimori. After a rigged election last April, Mr Fujimori fell from power when a TV news programme aired video footage in November of his intelligence chief bribing an opposition congressman. Nevertheless, five journalists remain in prison. They have been convicted by one of the "faceless courts" - introduced by the former president to stem terrorism - of being involved with the rebel Shining Path movement.

Russia
President Vladimir Putin spent 2000 consolidating his power by reducing whatever freedoms the media had acquired under the former president, Boris Yeltsin. Any reports on the situation in Chechnya were made all but impossible after the kidnapping and charging of RFE/RL reporter Andrei Babitsky. The journalists, Grigory Pasko and Sergei Nitkin, were both prosecuted for espionage after revealing Russia's dreadful environmental problems. By January, the government had siezed control of Media-Most's NTV, Russia's only independent television network, along with the daily paper, Segodnya, and the Sem Dnei publishing house, which are all owned by the media magnate, Vladimir Gusinsky. Mr Gusinsky was forced to fight a well publicised case to prevent his extradition from Spain to Russia, where he faced trumped-up charges of fraud. By early 2001, the brief history of Russian independent journalism was on the wane.

Serbia
On September 6, pro-democracy activists liberated the offices of Radio B92, one of several members of the ANEM network of independent media. Throughout the Slobodan Milosevic era, this group struggled for impartial and objective reporting. Independent journalism played a crucial role in overthrow of Mr Milosevic. Despite repeated prosecution, police harassment, exemplary fines and the confiscation of their equipment, these media continued to publicise the realities of the Balkan wars and government corruption to all who would listen. Since the revolution of October 2000, collaborating journalists have been weeded out and restrictive media legislation removed from the statutes.

Spain
The only EU country where journalists are targeted for murder. On May 7 2000, assassins loyal to the Basque separatist group, Eta, shot dead Jose Luis Lopez de Lacalle, a columnist with El Mundo. Letterbombs were also sent to TV and radio journalists last year. Some 100 journalists currently live under police protection from the Eta death squads.

Syria
On April 20, journalist Nizar Nayouf, Syria's best known dissident, entered the second week of a hunger strike. It began after the authorities reversed a decision to release him from a 10 year prison sentence for "disseminating false information". Mr Nayouf, the former editor of Sawt al-Democratiyya (Democracy's Voice), suffers from leukemia and is partially paralysed from beatings received in prison. He is a winner of Unesco's World Press Freedom prize.

Turkey
The government's suppression of Kurdish rights - and its liberal use of the charge of "insulting the military" as a means of silencing critics - mean Turkey is low on the list of countries likely to join the EU. Last year, the regulatory Radio and Television Supreme Board passed temporary closure orders totalling 4,832 days "or nearly 13.25 years" on the nation's electronic media, according to a December report. Nadire Mater, the celebrated author of Mehmet's Book, a collection of interviews with Turkish conscripts, was only acquitted of insulting the military in September 2000 after an international outcry.

Ukraine
Georgy Goradze, the 31-year-old editor of the internet newsletter, Pravade Ukrayiny, disappeared on December 16 after complaining of police harassment over his allegations of government corruption. In December, secret tapes of conversations between President Leonid Kuchma and the interior minister, Yuri Kravchenko - in which they can be heard plotting Mr Goradze's assassination - came to light. Amid continuing political turmoil, forensic scientists in Germany and Ukraine are quarrelling over whether the headless corpse discovered near Kiev in late November is the body of the missing journalist.

Zimbabwe
President Robert Mugabe's attempt to cling on to power amid a mounting economic crisis met resistance from a wide array of Zimbabwean groups, most notably its fledgling but plucky free press. Efforts to silence the voice of the opposition culminated in January with the bombing of the printing works of Harare's best selling independent newspaper, Daily News. At the same time, Mercedes Sayagues, the correspondent for South Africa's Weekly Mail & Guardian (which is part owned by the Guardian) and the BBC correspondent, Joseph Winter, were expelled from the country. The Daily News was back on the streets a day later with its trenchant criticisms of Zimbabwe's war in Congo, government corruption and attacks by the state on the independence of the judiciary.

fields.bodyText: Afghanistan There are no domestic news media at all under the Taliban, which banned "news which could hurt people's feelings" in 1997. Most Afghans get information by word of mouth or from the BBC's daily Pashtu and Farsi services. The BBC's Kate Clark, the last foreign correspondent in Kabul, was given 24 hours to leave in March after she reported on the popular opposition to the Taliban's decision to blow up the magnificent standing Buddhas of Bamian, which were accused of "distracting" Moslems from Islam. Angola Efforts to report the civil war - or the widespread trafficking of diamonds it conceals - meet punitive sanctions from the government of President Eduardo dos Santos. In October, Rafael Marques was one of three independent journalists banned for five years from speaking in public, reporting or travelling abroad. Bangladesh Journalists are increasingly targeted under Prime Minister Sheik Hasina and the ruling Awami League. On July 16 last year, Shamsur Rahman, a regular BBC contributor, was shot dead in Jessore. On January 25, the hands and legs of the award-winning journalist, Tipu Sultan, were broken so badly by Awami thugs it was feared they would have to be amputated. Britain For generations, the Official Secrets Act has served as an all-purpose ban on the disclosure of the inner workings of government. It hangs by a thread following the spate of bad publicity generated by the former spies, David Shayler and Richard Tomlinson, the British author, Tony Geraghty, and his alleged source for his banned book, the Irish War, Nigel Wylde, and the forthcoming memoirs of the former spy chief, Stella Rimmington. A meeting of the Reform of the Official Secrets Act group will be held on May 3 in the Jubilee Room of the House of Commons. Burkina Faso Demonstrations continue to dog the government of this Sahelian state three years after the murder of the independent journalist, Norbert Zongo, in December 1998. Evidence points to the involvement of the president's brother, Francis Compaore, whom Mr Zongo had accused in print of murdering his own chauffeur. Burma One of the least free media environments in the world. Chile Despite moves to prosecute the former president, Augusto Pinochet, "offending" the president, ministers, generals or judges is still punishable by up to five years in prison under the Domestic Security Law. In December, a judge upheld the arrest warrant on the exiled journalist, Alejandra Matus, whose banned book, Black Book of Chilean Justice, exposed the support given to General Pinochet by Chilean judges during the "dirty war". China Few Chinese could discern any improvement in press freedom last year. A torrent of hate messages were spread by the official media against the Falun Gong, a movement of physical exercise practitioners that has put the fear of God into the government. Members of the group - or "sect" as the government describes it - continued to be arrested, jailed and beaten in their thousands, while several score have died in custody. The government considers the internet to be as direct a threat to its power as the Falun Gong, although web access is not widespread. Last year, Qi Yanchen was sentenced to an unspecified jail term for his contributions to the pro-democracy online magazine, VIP Reference. Useful link www.indexoncensorship.org Colombia The most dangerous place in the world for journalists - 33 have been murdered there since 1991, mostly by the right wing paramilitary group, Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia, or guerillas of the leftist Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. On April 27, Flavio Bedoya, a 52-year-old journalist with the communist weekly, Voz, became the 11th victim in the past year. He was shot four times by unidentified men while stepping off a bus near the border with Ecuador. Useful links www.rsf.org www.cpj.org Czech Republic Journalists occupied the premises of Czech TV over Christmas. They were protesting against political interference after the government imposed a new director less than a week after his predecessor was sacked. The government backed down after 100,000 people gathered on Wenceslas Square, although a new set of broadcasting laws have actually strengthened political control of the country's public television services. Egypt Fears of Islamic fundamentalism and the swelling tide of modernism led to a crackdown in 2000/01 that affected political reporting and mainstream publishing. The local correspondents of western news media were kicked and punched by police while they covered the campaigns of the banned Muslim Brotherhood candidates in the local elections on November 14. Charges of blasphemy, meanwhile, resulted in the torching of 6,000 books by the mediaeval poet, Abu Nawas, and the banning of Before and After by Tufiq Abderahman, Shivering of the Lights by Salaheddin Mohsen and A Banquet of Seaweed by Haidar Haidar. Ethiopa The country has the worst track record in Africa for jailing reporters. Garum Bekele, Tesfaye Deressa, Tamrat Gemeda and Solomon Namara have been in prison since 1997/98, while temporary detentions - usually for "publishing unpatriotic information" or "inciting ethnic tensions" - account for up to 15 more a year.
