fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

The former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson, is guilty of misleading parliament over undeclared financial interests from his dealings with the late media tycoon Robert Maxwell, according to a committee of MPs. P1
Gary Day, 32, has been remanded in custody charged with the manslaughter of Monica Coghlan, the former prostitute at the centre of the Lord Archer libel trial. P2
IPC has closed Nova magazine for the second time. P3
Ted Rogers, the former host of ITV's 3,2,1, has died. P7
The Conservatives have unveiled a new poster featuring a picture of Tony Blair pregnant, saying "Labour still hasnÍt delivered". P11
Recordings of executions in the state of Georgia were broadcast on radio stations and on the internet across America yesterday. P14
Former Sunday Mirror editor Bridget Rowe and former Mirror boss David Banks have suddenly departed from Yava.com, the project set up by David Montgomery. P20
BT will leave its prestigious London headquarters in a bid to cut costs. P23
Japanese consumer spending plummets. P24
A new service allowing people to access all their online financial information in one place has gone live in Britain. P26
£3.5bn of Vodafone shares sold. P27
The British Horseracing Board has said the Go Racing consortium's media rights offer to the Racecourse Association is "flawed". P29

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

BBC rugby and Olympics commentator Nigel Starmer Smith talks of his despair at losing a second child to a rare blood disorder. P3
The former host of the ITV gameshow 3,2,1, Ted Rogers, has died. P10
A vicar has boosted parish funds by allowing his churchyard to be used in the making of a film about the late Dame Iris Murdoch, starring Judi Dench. P11
Culture secretary Chris Smith faced calls for his resignation yesterday in parliament. P14
Cabinet office minister Lord Falconer defended the government against allegations it had increased its spending on advertising just before the election. P14
The judge in the trial of Barry George, who is accused of murdering TV presenter Jill Dando, has been told to keep an open mind. P16

MEDIA SECTION
Kim Fletcher says the Daily Mail's insinuation that Stella McCartney is a lesbian doesnÍt tell him anything. P22
Economist editor Bill Emmott tells Tom Leonard why the paper is taking a more investigative role, as shown in its recent attack on Silvio Berlusconi. P22
Nova is closing just as it was beginning to find itself, reports Matt Born. P23
Vodafone has completed a £3.5bn share placing as strong demand from investors pushed the sale price above forecasts of £3bn.
Complaints of anti-competitive behaviour from a rival bidder have threatened to derail the Go Racing consortium's offer to British racecourses. P36

THE INDEPENDENT

Relaunched style bible Nova has closed again. P5
A New York radio station has broadcast a tape of the execution of Ivor Stanley, who was put to the electric chair in 1984. P14
Vodafone places £3.5bn stock. P16

THE TIMES

Tory MPs pressing for the publication of a report which they say will show that former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson failed to declare details of his business dealings with Robert Maxwell. P2
The French answer to Big Brother, Loft Story, has audiences in a lather over whether Jean-Edouard will seduce Laure. P3
Big Brother has been screened in 16 countries around the world. P3
The rising cost of medical negligence lawsuits is being blamed by the National Audit Office on television coverage of medical disasters such as ER. P4
The jury in the trial of Barry George, accused of murdering Jill Dando, has been told not to let media coverage influence their decisions. P6
The former host of ITV's 3,2,1, Ted Rogers, has died of heart failure. P9
Which? Magazine says diet books can damage your health. P11
Vodafone has raised £3.5bn in a London placing. P23
Go Racing's attempt to buy the rights to UK horseracing was dealt a blow as it emerged that an investigation would be launched into allegations of malpractice. P23
NTL has appointed Lord Holme, former chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission, as the first member of a new advisery board. P24

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

COMPANIES & MARKETS
Vodafone increased the value of its share issue yesterday to £3.5bn. P21
Appetite remains for £5bn BT rights issue. P22
Sir Ronald Hampel, the chairman of United News & Media, has defended the decision to pay a £649,000 special bonus to chief executive Lord Hollick. P22
NTL to axe jobs in cost-cutting drive. P24
Bright Station has only £2.9m in the bank, rather than the £7.4m it claimed earlier in the week. P26
Rupert Murdoch is nearing a breakthrough in the DirectTV deal. P30

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Vodafone has raised £3.5bn in a share placing. P1

THE DAILY MAIL

Penny Lancaster is pictured in "that dress", the day after rocker boyfriend Rod Stewart said marriage should be overhauled in favour of a "dog licence". P1
The Tories unveil their new campaign poster, a spoof of the Saatchi & Saatchi family planning advert. P21
How the stars' cleavages are being deflated by dieting. P24
Agony of the BBC man who has lost a second child. P27
Ted Rogers, host of ITVÍs 3,2,1, has died. P33
Is Johnny Vaughan really worth the £5m he has been offered by the BBC? P49
A bonus of £649,000 for United News & Media chief executive Clive Hollick has sparked a revolt by investors. P72

THE DAILY EXPRESS

Penny Lancaster stages an amazing PR recovery at the World Music Awards in Monte Carlo, the day after boyfriend Rod Stewart said he did not want to marry her. P3
Michael JacksonÍs Thriller was yesterday voted the best video ever. P5
Ian Beale will tonight pledge his troth to the long-suffering Laura in EastEnders. P15
Tara Palmer-Tomkinson has launched her own website. P27
Leonardo di Caprio will star as Frank Abagnale, a millionaire criminal, in a new film. P31
New pictures from the set of the next series of Absolutely Fabulous. P32
Star of 3,2,1, Ted Rogers, has died after a heart operation. P33
The new blonde star of Coronation Street is a former chorister. P34
Interview with Big Breakfaster presenter Donna Air. P38

THE MIRROR

World exclusive interview with Nicole Kidman, who spills the beans on her split with Tom Cruise. P1&12
3,2,1 star Ted Rogers has died. P15
The first pictures of EastEndersÍs little Mo Slater hitting wife-battering Trevor. P18
Hear'Say's Suzanne was the victim of a bizarre hoax last night as a hacker broke into the BBC website to claim she had killed herself. P21

THE SUN

TV campaigners are outraged at a steamy storyline which will see temptress EastEnders's Kat Slater in a three-in-a-bed romp. P7
3,2,1 star Ted Rogers has died. P9
Monte Carlo and busts, for Penny Lancaster and Carmen Electra. P19
More inside snaps from the set of the new series of Ab Fab. P21
Lisa Rogers, the new host of the BBC's Football Fever, is pictured in a revealing shot taken from an interview in this month's Loaded. P33

THE DAILY STAR

Lady Victoria Hervey is to star alongside Joanna Lumley in the next series of Absolutely Fabulous. P9
Ian and Laura to tie the knot. P15
Michael Jackson's Thriller is the best ever pop video. P17

AND FINALLY...

Chicago and former Big Breakfast star Denise Van Outen has revealed that she sometimes stuffs her bra with chicken fillets to boost her cup size. The Star P7

fields.headline: First Tuesday tries again
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The networking party that rode the dot.com wave and then spectacularly ran aground, has reinvented itself as a thinktank. By Amy Vickers.
15.02.2001: Members bail out First Tuesday
fields.body:
First Tuesday, the networking party that rode the dot.com wave and then spectacularly ran aground, has reinvented itself as a thinktank.

First Tuesday London said its first new-look event will be held this Thursday.

John Browning, a First Tuesday founder, said: "Only by reinventing itself can First Tuesday London do what it has always done - help the entrepreneur gain the insights and contacts needed to build a business."

Instead of the basic match-making concept which epitomised the heyday of First Tuesday, the new look event will focus on sewing the industry back together and look at options for survival.

A spokeswoman for First Tuesday explained that it was a natural evolution to fit the market's needs.

"The frenzy has died away and now people need help on how to maximise the value and potential of what's been built thus far - strategic mergers, acquisitions etc are high on everybody's agendas."

First Tuesday London is the first franchise of the global factions to change its direction in this way, although other franchisees, or "city leaders", are said to be looking at following suit.

Since changing ownership in February, First Tuesday has become a complicated franchise-structured business, owned by the workers and operated under licence on a country-by-country basis.

First Tuesday London is now run by John Browning, Adam Sodowick and Lissie Murray who were involved in First Tuesday Central and have now taken on the London licence and named their holding company Basic Cat Enterprises.

They bought First Tuesday from Yazam in February for £1m.

fields.headline: Charity staff face redundancy
fields.trailText: The National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO), the charities' representative body, has announced a restructuring programme which could lead to the departure of nearly 10% of its staff.
fields.body:
The National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO), the charities' representative body, has announced a restructuring programme which could lead to the departure of nearly 10% of its staff.

NCVO said it had suffered a downturn in income and would be making redundancies.

The decision is the latest of a spate of corporate restructurings in the charities sector, and follows in the wake of recent cutbacks made by the National Trust and Refugee Council.

A source inside the organisation said nine people were affected out of a payroll of about 100. NCVO spokesman Campbell Robb said the staff knew who would be made redundant but wouldn't confirm numbers.

He said: "We are consulting with staff and unions and will make further announcements after this process."

The representative body for charities blamed the tax incentives introduced by the government last year. In a complex arrangement, NCVO used to receive some of its income from the Charities Aid Foundation (CAF), which in turn charged charities a fee for administering tax efficient donations.

The tax changes launched last April by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, as part of his Getting Britain Giving Campaign, have made it easier for people to give tax efficiently without needing the services of CAF.

NCVO said in a statement that it was aware that the introduction of these incentives, which it lobbied for, might lead to a decline in one of its traditional sources of income but "felt that the potential boost to the sector far outweighed this consideration".

It also said one of its main drivers for restructuring was the "desire to maximise the services and benefits provided to its members and the wider voluntary sector". To achieve this it planned to expand its membership and increase its brokered services.

webTitle: Comment: May Day's lessons for the rootless

fields.headline: May Day's lessons for the rootless
fields.standfirst:
Let's face it, the street theatre in London was a bit of a McProtest

Special report: May Day 2001
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Let's face it, the street theatre in London was a bit of a McProtest.
fields.body:
The idea of turning London into a life-sized Monopoly board on May Day sounded like a great idea to me. The most familiar criticism lobbed at modern protesters is that they lack focus and clear goals such as "Save the trees", or "Drop the debt". And yet these protests are a response to the limitations of single-issue politics. Tired of treating the symptoms of an economic model - under-funded hospitals, homelessness, widening disparity, exploding prisons, climate change - there is now a clear attempt to "out" the system behind the symptoms. But how do you hold a protest against abstract economic ideas without sounding either hideously strident or all over the map?

How about using the board game that has taught generations of kids about land ownership? The organisers of yesterday's Mayday Monopoly protest issued annotated maps of London featuring such familiar sites as Regent Street, Pall Mall and Trafalgar Square, encouraging participants to situate their May Day actions on the Monopoly board. Want to protest against privatisation? Go to a railway station. Industrial agriculture? McDonald's. Fossil fuels? The electric company. And always carry your "Get out of jail free" card.

The problem was that by yesterday afternoon, London didn't look like an ingenious mix of popular education and street theatre. It looked pretty much like every other mass protest these days: demonstrators penned in by riot gear, smashed windows, boarded-up shops, running fights with police. And in the pre-protest media wars, there was more déjà vu. Were protesters planning violence? Would the presence of 6,000 police officers itself provoke violence? Why won't all the protesters condemn violence? Why does everybody always talk about violence?

It seems this is what protests look like today. Let's call it McProtest, because it's becoming the same all over. And of course this here is becoming a kind of McColumn, because I've written about all this before. In fact, almost all my recent columns have been about the right to assembly, security fences, tear gas, and dodgy arrests. Or else they've attempted to dispel wilful representations of the protesters - for instance, that they are "anti-trade", or longing for a pre-agrarian utopia.

It is an article of faith in most activist circles that mass demonstrations are always positive: they build morale, display strength, attract media attention. But what seems to be getting lost is that demonstrations aren't themselves a movement. They are only flashy displays of everyday movements, grounded in schools, workplaces, and neighbourhoods. Or at least they should be.

I keep thinking about the historic day, on March 11, when the Zapatista commanders entered Mexico City. This was an army that led a successful uprising against the state. And yet the residents of Mexico City didn't quake in fear - rather, 200,000 of them came out to greet the Zapatistas, including entire families. Streets were closed to traffic, yet no one seemed even slightly concerned about the inconvenience to commuters. And shopkeepers didn't board up their windows; they held "revolution" sidewalk sales.

Is this because the Zapatistas are less dangerous than a few urban anarchists in white overalls? Hardly. It was because the march on Mexico City was seven years in the making (some would say 500 years, but that's another story). Years of building coalitions with other indigenous groups, with workers in the Maquiladoras, with students, with intellectuals and journalists; years of mass consultations, of open encuentros (meetings) of 6,000 people. The event in Mexico City wasn't the movement; it was only a very public demonstration of all that invisible, daily work.

The most powerful resistance movements are always deeply rooted in community - and are accountable to those communities. However, one of the greatest challenges of living in the high consumer culture that was protested against in London yesterday, is the reality of rootlessness. Few of us know our neighbours, talk about much more than shopping at work, or have time for community politics. How can a movement be accountable when communities are fraying?

Within a context of urban rootlessness, there are clearly moments to demonstrate, but perhaps more importantly, there are moments to build the connections that make demonstration something more than theatre. There are times when radicalism means standing up to the police, but there are many more times when it means talking to your neighbour.

The issues behind Tuesday's demonstrations are no longer marginal. Yet something is gravely wrong when the protests still seem deracinated, cut off from urgent daily concerns. It means that the spectacle of displaying a movement is getting confused with the less glamorous business of building one.

fields.headline: America the confident
fields.standfirst:
We're so mean and backward-looking about immigation says Godfrey Hodgson. The US is more generous

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: We're so mean and backward-looking about immigation says Godfrey Hodgson. The US is more generous.
fields.body:
One of the many odd things about Margaret Thatcher was that she claimed, and still claims, to have a profound admiration for all things American; yet she rejected, and most British Conservatives still reject, some of the most fundamental of American values: republicanism, a written constitution, freedom of information, and of the press, as guaranteed in that constitution. And immigration.

All Americans, except for the one in eight who are descended from African slaves, are either immigrants or the descendants of immigrants. So it is not surprising that most Americans, most of the time, regard immigration fondly. But what is not widely understood in Britain is that the character of American immigration, and therefore the character of American society, were dramatically changed by a piece of legislation proposed and passed almost in a fit of absentmindedness 36 years ago.

In 1965, the same year in which African-Americans were assured of the right to vote, President Lyndon Johnson signed his name to another piece of legislation that would in the long run change the character of the American population as much as the former act would transform its politics. This was the Hart-Celler Immigration and Nationality Act. (Strictly speaking, it consisted of amendments to the McCarran- Walter Act of 1952.) Essentially it overturned previous legislation that had discriminated against immigrants from anywhere but northern Europe, and opened the golden door, as Americans call it, equally to migrants from every continent.

It was an act of public policy whose consequences, if not wholly unintended, were certainly not clearly foreseen. For the 1965 legislation, motivated by a wish merely to correct an injustice as between two groups of immigrants from Europe, ended up by setting off what has come to be called the second great migration. In the long run, it is possible that it will end the predominantly European character of the American population.

Most Americans do not interpret this momentous change, as Margaret Thatcher might, in terms of their being "swamped" by aliens, or of waking up, like William Hague, to find themselves in a "foreign land". They see the second great migration as strengthening their country and fulfilling its historic destiny to be a world society. The transformation of tens of millions of people, most of them from Asia and Latin America, into Americans is for them, not a matter for fear or resentment, but a cause for pride.

It was not always so. In the late 19th century, migration to the United States grew with an accelerating rhythm, bringing settlers from Asia and from southern and eastern Europe instead of the English, Irish, Germans and Scandinavians who had made up the bulk of earlier waves of immigration. The shift was quite sudden. In 1882, just under 650,000 immigrants arrived in the United States, of whom only 13% came from the south and east of Europe. By 1907, 81% of the 1.2m who immigrated in that year came from those countries.

The migrants of the first three-quarters of the 19th century, like the 4m white people who lived in the United States at the time of the first census in 1791, were largely Protestants; and the largest Roman Catholic group, the Irish Catholics, were English speaking and all too familiar with Anglo-Saxon politics and ways. The new immigrants from Austria-Hungary, Russia and Italy, many of them Roman Catholics, some Orthodox Christians, and a significant minority Jews, were culturally more "different". Their arrival provoked a revival of "nativism". The American majority responded angrily. Pressure built up steadily for restriction of the "wrong" kind of immigrants.

In intellectual circles, there was much genteel racism, based on measurement of people's skulls and suchlike pseudo-scientific nonsense. In popular papers, the stereotyping was less refined. Prejudice against Asians, Catholics and Jews was rampant. There was widespread fear that immigrants of "inferior stocks" would bring with them disease, madness and "degeneracy". Chinese immigration was restricted as early as 1886, and Japanese immigration by a "gentleman's agreement" of 1907. In 1924 Congress, surrendering to the public mood, passed the Johnson-Reed Act of 1924. Once it came into full effect, from 1929, it established quotas on the basis of the national origins of the population of the United States as of the census of 1920. Total immigration was to be limited to 150,000 people a year, of which more than half would be allotted to applicants from Great Britain, Ireland and Germany; the annual quota for most individual non-European countries was set at an insulting 100.

This quota system was reinstated, with minor adjustments, by the McCarran-Walter Act. It was the Kennedy administration, led by a family with a strong immigrant consciousness, and with many Jews and Catholics in influential positions, that decided to tidy things up. However, the legislation Johnson signed was seen as abolishing a historic injustice, not as introducing a historic change.

Yet that is exactly what the 1965 legislation achieved. The first great migration, which produced the backlash that led to the 1924 crackdown, has already been exceeded in numbers by a second great migration. In 35 years this new flood has already brought more than 30m immigrants to America. Just over half of them were born in Latin America, almost exactly a quarter in Asia, and fewer than one in six in Europe. Indeed, probably because living standards in Europe have risen since 1945, taking the period as a whole, even more dramatically than in the United States, emigration from western Europe has virtually dried up.

By the end of the 20th century, the new immigration was running at the rate of almost 1m legal and about one-third of a million illegal immigrants each year. Yet so far it has produced almost no backlash. No doubt the rhetoric of the Statue of Liberty and the golden door ignores the painful experience that immigration represented, especially for the first generation of migrants. That rhetoric ignores, too, the fact that, in the second migration as well as in the first, roughly a third of the immigrants went home.

There have been instances of anger directed at specific groups of immigrants at particular times and in particular places. Korean shopkeepers were singled out by the (largely black) rioters in the 1994 Rodney King riots in Los Angeles. Vietnamese shrimp fishermen in the Gulf of Mexico have had a bad time in isolated cases. Life can be hard for Mexican vegetable pickers in California and for Haitian refugees in Miami, for example. Occasionally a conservative intellectual writes a book questioning the wisdom of diluting American culture or the economic cost of immigration.

But overall there is no getting away from the fact that immigrants are welcome in America. The media celebrate the high proportion of Indians in the computer industry, the proportion of scholarship winners at great universities who are of Chinese or Japanese descent. There is a recognition that immigrant workers contribute to the American economy, whether they are computer programmers from Bangalore or road gangs from Honduras. Indeed, the growth rate of the American population would have dwindled to close to the low European rate were it not for immigrants and their big families.

Nothing is more striking than the comparison between the mean-spirited way in which British politicians, especially but not only in the Conservative party, draw up their miserly accounts of immigration, itemising the costs and ignoring the benefits, and the fundamental confidence of the American response. The contrast between an American national consensus on immigration that is essentially generous and forward-looking, and the British political debate, insular, backward-looking and mean, is not just shameful. It foolishly ignores the lessons we might draw from a country that has learned from its mistakes and profited from its liberality.

 Godfrey Hodgson is director of the Reuter Foundation Programme at Green College, Oxford.

No doubt the rhetoric of the Statue of Liberty and the golden door ignores the painful experience that immigration represented, especially for the first generation of migrants. That rhetoric ignores, too, the fact that, in the second migration as well as in the first, roughly a third of the immigrants went home. There have been instances of anger directed at specific groups of immigrants at particular times and in particular places. Korean shopkeepers were singled out by the (largely black) rioters in the 1994 Rodney King riots in Los Angeles. Vietnamese shrimp fishermen in the Gulf of Mexico have had a bad time in isolated cases. Life can be hard for Mexican vegetable pickers in California and for Haitian refugees in Miami, for example. Occasionally a conservative intellectual writes a book questioning the wisdom of diluting American culture or the economic cost of immigration. But overall there is no getting away from the fact that immigrants are welcome in America. The media celebrate the high proportion of Indians in the computer industry, the proportion of scholarship winners at great universities who are of Chinese or Japanese descent. There is a recognition that immigrant workers contribute to the American economy, whether they are computer programmers from Bangalore or road gangs from Honduras. Indeed, the growth rate of the American population would have dwindled to close to the low European rate were it not for immigrants and their big families. Nothing is more striking than the comparison between the mean-spirited way in which British politicians, especially but not only in the Conservative party, draw up their miserly accounts of immigration, itemising the costs and ignoring the benefits, and the fundamental confidence of the American response. The contrast between an American national consensus on immigration that is essentially generous and forward-looking, and the British political debate, insular, backward-looking and mean, is not just shameful. It foolishly ignores the lessons we might draw from a country that has learned from its mistakes and profited from its liberality.  Godfrey Hodgson is director of the Reuter Foundation Programme at Green College, Oxford. godfrey.hodgson@green.oxford.ac.uk

fields.headline: In the land of the Kims
fields.standfirst:
Europe has a role, whatever the US says

Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: Europe has a role in Korea, whatever the US says.
fields.body:
Sweden's prime minister, Göran Persson, was trying hard not to step on toes when he arrived at the head of an EU delegation in North Korea yesterday. "The main point is to do whatever we can to help the peace process on the peninsula move out of this sticky period," he said. "We are not here to act as a mediator between North Korea and the US or indeed between North Korea and South Korea." Which prompts the question: why not?

South Korean President Kim Dae-jung's promising "sunshine policy" of détente has indeed faltered since his watershed summit last June with Pyongyang's Elvis look-alike, Kim Jong-il. The Clinton administration dallied with, but ultimately ducked, a diplomatic truce with North Korea.

George Bush, true to form, then sent the process into reverse, telling Seoul's Mr Kim that North Korea was not to be trusted and halting US contacts pending a review. Many of the bilateral confidence-building steps proposed last year have simply not happened. The impoverished North Korean regime has meanwhile grown increasingly agitated at what it sees as Washington's belligerence in singling it out as a "rogue nation", a sponsor of terrorism and a principal reason why America needs missile defence.

It threatened in February to end its voluntary freeze on ballistic missile development and upped the ante last week, demanding that the 37,000 US troops based in South Korea be withdrawn. Kim Dae-jung has urged Mr Bush to complete his policy review and quickly resume talks with North Korea where a new food crisis threatens and more, not less international aid is needed. He fears the prospect of a follow-up North-South summit in Seoul next month is receding rapidly, jeopardising the peace process as a whole.

But there are no signs that Washington is really listening. The Pentagon needs North Korea to play the bad guy while it secures funding for its new missiles. It insists that Pyongyang threatens its neighbours and the US itself, has secretly built nuclear weapons and is a "major proliferator", selling to Iran and Pakistan.

This US posture worries friends (like Japan) and "foes" (like China) alike. It has allowed Russia a chance to make mischief. But for the EU, most of whose members (including Britain) now have diplomatic ties with Pyongyang, it is an opportunity. Fifty years after the Korean war, US policy is regressing. It is time, as elsewhere, for Europe to show a lead.

webTitle: Russia and Europe ready to hear Bush plan

fields.headline: Russia and Europe ready to hear Bush plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: China warned the US yesterday that President George Bush's "Son of Star Wars" missile defence plan could set off a new arms race.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor, and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
China warned the US yesterday that President George Bush's "Son of Star Wars" missile defence plan could set off a new arms race.

Russia and America's European allies masked their deep concern about the project by a more diplomatic stance.

The widespread scepticism in Europe about the need for such an ambitious, expensive, and - in the view of many - hugely destabilising system was reflected even by the British government, America's closest ally.

In a remarkably lukewarm response to the plan Mr Bush outlined in a speech in Washington on Tuesday, Tony Blair told the Commons it was too early to say whether Britain would support the US on this "highly sensitive" issue.

Taunted by the Conservative leader, William Hague, for dodging the issue, he replied: "It is important and right that we wait for a firm proposal before giving a firm decision."

Britain will be at the forefront of the project which, in all but one of its proposed formats, will involve the US eavesdropping centre at Menwith Hill, near Harrogate, an upgraded US early warning radar at Fylingdales on the North York Moors, and a new 6.8-hectare (17-acre) X-band radar nearby.

Privately, ministers say Britain will have to let these bases be used. But Washington has let them off the hook for the time being by proposing a "multi-layered" project.

A "theatre-based" system to intercept North Korean missiles from US ships in nearby waters or Iraqi missiles with land-based interceptors in Turkey might not involve radar stations in Britain.

China, fast becoming America's leading strategic antagonist, said the project violated the anti-ballistic-missile treaty [signed by Moscow and Washington in 1972], would destroy the balance of international security forces and could cause a new arms race.

But the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, while describing the ABM treaty as a key part of global security, said he was ready for talks with the US on new structures for international defence.

International security pacts agreed since then were extremely complicated. "That is why we are so insistent in keeping and strengthening ABM," he said, adding that Russia was "ready for consultations, we are ready to set out our position".

Moscow has told European members of Nato that it is ready to discuss a regional missile defence system as an alternative to the continental shield Washington says could be extended to Europe.

While the Europeans recognise the potential threat posed by what Washington used to call "rogue states" and now refers to as "states of concern" they believe the US is exaggerating the likelihood of them risking huge retaliation by firing missiles at the US.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, maintains that it is far more sensible to try to engage in dialogue with these regimes - he says it is in Britain's strategic national interest - and defence sources confirmed yesterday that Whitehall does not see any threat to Britain from rogue states.

The Nato secretary-general, Lord Robertson, said Mr Bush was right to focus on new challenges, and welcomed his commitment to close consultation with allies. The German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said that to avoid a global or regional arms race, cooperation which brought in Russia and China was necessary.

Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee, was predictably enthusiastic. "I greatly admire President Bush for his commitment to defend the American people against ballistic missile attack," he said. "I expect that our allies will be strongly supportive."

But the Democrat leader in the lower house, Dick Gephardt, said: "By announcing his intent to move forward with as yet unproven, costly and expansive national missile defence systems, the president is jeopardising an arms control framework that has served this nation and the world well for decades."

The independent defence analyst Sir Timothy Garden, a former senior RAF officer now attached to King's College, London, said: "It is sad that all the hard work to control nuclear weapons around the world is likely to be undermined by the Bush proposals."

 The veteran peace protester Anni Rainbow was arrested for obstruction at Menwith Hill yesterday during a protest against the project.

fields.headline: Wembley is 'only option' for stadium
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: A new national stadium is likely to be built on the existing Wembley site, despite appeals from Birmingham and Manchester that it should be located outside London, following the revelations of how deep the financial mire surrounding the current project has become.
fields.body:
A new national stadium is likely to be built on the existing Wembley site, despite appeals from Birmingham and Manchester that it should be located outside London, following the revelations of how deep the financial mire surrounding the current project has become.

Government and sports officials, including the Football Association and Sport England, which distributes national lottery money, believe it would be too costly and time consuming to move the stadium to a different site, outside the capital. Locating it at Wembley would also mean that £120m of lottery money given to the project would not have to be returned by the FA.

The Wembley option is also winning support from the home secretary Jack Straw's ministerial working group, which meets today to discuss how to salvage the project.

The government was asked to intervene after the FA said it could not be the sole financial backer for the project. The working group is made up of senior politicians such as John Prescott, the culture secretary Chris Smith and representatives from the Treasury and the Cabinet Office.

The original design for the stadium by Sir Norman Foster is to be scrapped and replaced with a completely new one that will not include hotel and office space, as in the original plans. A new design team is to be appointed after the election.

A spokesman for Mr Smith said: "The current design is dead in the water. It means all the plans for hotels and office space will go. The government is not in the business of building hotels and offices."

An 80,000 capacity stadium on the existing Wembley site, which would be cheaper to build, would also be closer to the original brief issued at the start of the project and would face fewer problems getting financial support from the City.

Despite the fact that cities such as Manchester and Birmingham spent most of yesterday claiming they could be alternative venues to Wembley, and politicians said they were keeping all options open, privately some of those involved in the project want it to remain in London.

The board of WNSL, the FA subsidiary set up to oversee the project also met yesterday and said it remained committed to building the stadium at Wembley despite the financial problems.

Members of Mr Straw's working group have hinted that if the cost of the stadium could be brought down then the government might be prepared to commit some public funds.

The working group is to appoint a special adviser today who has expertise in building stadiums. Candidates include Bob Murray, the Sunderland football chairman who was the driving force behind the club's £30m Stadium of Light.

Ministers are also sounding out key figures behind the Cardiff Millennium Stadium, as well as Patrick Carter, who advised the government on the Commonwealth games.

The working group will also examine football's finances and try to establish how much the game should contribute towards the stadium. Talks are to be held between the FA and Mr Straw in the coming days.

An FA statement said: "The Home Secretary has said he is keen to meet with senior FA officials as soon as possible. We have assured him we will play an active, positive role in the work of his group."

webTitle: Forum rallies to journalists in danger

fields.headline: Forum rallies to journalists in danger
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The Freedom Forum has called on the British press to take more responsibility for local journalists in conflict zones. By Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: world press freedom day
fields.body:
The Freedom Forum has called on British editors and newspaper owners to take greater responsibility for local journalists in conflict zones.

John Owen, the forum's European director, says editors should take "better care of their own local stringers, translators and fixers".

And in an article in a MediaGuardian.co.uk special report on press freedom, he urges the journalists to use their publications and airwaves to "condemn attacks on local journalists".

Mr Owen notes that the recent coverage of the wounding of the Sunday Times's Marie Colvin has drawn attention to what can be done to journalists in the name of censorship of freedom of speech.

But he stressed the importance of highlighting the plight of local journalists, working outside the spotlight of the world's media, whose disappearance can go unnoticed.

In particular, he writes, the recent murder of the BBC's local correspondent in Jaffna, Mylvaganam Nimalarajan, got no coverage in the British press.

In many countries being a journalist can lead to torture, expulsion or death; in some it is outlawed altogether.

The right to work, taken for granted in Britain, is a luxury for journalists in dozens of countries around the world.

The Taliban has outlawed all domestic news media on the basis that it "hurts people's feelings", while the atrocities it perpetrates against Afghan citizens go unreported.

Colombia is officially the most dangerous place in the world to be a journalist, with 33 murders of journalists reported since 1991.

Meanwhile, journalists who go missing while reporting on the war in Chechnya can simply "disappear" without a trace, as demonstrated by Russian journalist Anna Politkovskaya.

Last year, 52 journalists were murdered in 26 countries around the world, while over 70 are still detained in prison for articles they have written.

Our special reports on Press Freedom Day are designed to show British journalists why they should, as Mr Owen says "suspend their usual cynicism and self-promotion" to defend their trade and the right to free speech.

Because, as is demonstrated in our round-up of the world's flashpoints, British freedom of the press cannot be taken for granted.

World press freedom day

fields.headline: French turn backs on 'sexy' adverts
fields.trailText: 8.30am: France is to crack down on sexual imagery in advertising following protests from feminists and family groups, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Few nations have embraced the old adage "sex sells" as enthusiastically as France, where semi-naked women adorn poster advertisements for everything from mobile phones to yoghurts.

But following a series of protests from feminist and family groups, the French government is to crack down on the advertising industry to mend its ways.

Government ministers next month will host a round table on sexual imagery and violence in television advertising.

TV executives, advertisers and advertising agencies will all be invited to give their views, and the government hopes the exercise will force them to be more restrained.

The government is also putting together a report on the portrayal of women in advertising.

The report, to be published in July, will name and shame advertisers that use sexist images to incite violence against women, and could lead to new government controls on the industry.

The recent backlash against the pervasiveness of sex in French advertising has been led by a feminist group calling itself "Chiennes de Garde", or "guard bitches", which has campaigned for a boycott of products that are promoted in this way.

The Sophie Dahl poster for Opium perfume, which was the most complained-about advert in the UK, has come under fire from the group as has a poster campaign for the fashion retailer, The City, which showed a nearly nude woman kneeling next to a sheep above the line, "I need a sweater".

That campaign was recently banned by the French advertising watchdog.

webTitle: The truth about life after birth

fields.headline: The truth about life after birth
fields.standfirst: Women tend to be unprepared for the gruesome reality of the days and weeks following childbirth, new research suggests.  Katharine Shaw offers an eye-opener
fields.trailText: Women tend to be unprepared for the gruesome reality of the days and weeks following childbirth, new research suggests. Katharine Shaw offers an eye-opener.
fields.body:
Zero hour

A flood of utter relief and a ripped perineum, helped by a rush of endorphins. If you do not know what a perineum is, then I pray you never find out.

20 minutes after birth

Euphoria and all that. I am distracted by sight, feel, smell of a beautiful salty, messy baby until my legs are hoisted skywards and bright lights are shone on my private parts. Unable to cope with the carnage single-handedly, the midwife calls for the obstetrician who, she claims, is a "devil with a needle". Having endured childbirth you'd think the small matter of being injected in the perineum would be a piece of cake ... ah, but no. Despite the local anaesthetic, Doctor Needlepoint tugs and jabs as if stitching up a mainsail. It would seem silly under the circumstances to make a fuss.

45 minutes

The midwife wants to tell me all about my "tear" and is slightly taken aback that I don't want the details. She takes my husband outside to explain quite how bad it is down there. When she comes back (husband with a "bright smile") she says she should put a catheter in as it might be a "bit sore" to pee. I consume handfuls of painkillers in anticipation of the anaesthetic wearing off.

One hour

Warm, flooding feeling in the bed. I ring the bell in terror assuming I'm haemorrhaging but it's just the catheter bag "malfunctioning". My stomach is still vast, as if another baby is lurking in there. The midwife explains that it takes six weeks for my womb to shrink back to normal size. She prods it regularly over the next few days to see that it is doing this and that I have not retained any of the placenta, and presumably, to rule out any lingering foetuses.

Six hours

Still haven't dared get up. It feels like someone has snuck in and battered my parts with a baseball bat. Fortunately, my baby is a great distraction.

Seven hours

Catheter is removed and I am guided to the bathroom to "get cleaned up". The bed looks like a scene from The Godfather and I look and move like Frankenstein's monster. My legs shake and ache. My head is light. I have the distinct impression that my intestines and colon are going to fall out of my vagina. But, fortunately, I am still euphoric at having produced an actual baby. I daren't sit down in the bath and I watch in dismay as a lot of blood goes everywhere. The nurse rubs me down like I'm a horse, and gives me a pad that would be adequate for one. She also gives me a pair of paper knickers. They have small pink sprigs on them, a nice touch.

Day one

I have to recline, since sitting feels life-threateningly painful. I refuse to look down there and also refuse to let my husband look as I don't want him to retain this image. He thinks I'm mad, as he saw the baby come out. My stomach is still inflated. My shoulders, oddly, ache as if I've carried a piano around for several days. My breasts are producing weird pale liquid called colostrum, that my baby laps up round the clock but other than this they don't feel any different. I have been given "stool softener" pills but apparently may not be able to "go" for quite some time.

Day two

I am still having painful "contractions". This is my womb shrinking and shouldn't persist. Walking out of the hospital is a challenge. I have to stick my bum out and take tiny steps like an ancient tribal dancer. I am dismayed that I look heavily pregnant. I am unable to sit down in the car and have to perch, one cheek on the side of the seat, swearing.

Day three

I now see the need for stool softener and can confirm that it has failed. I am genuinely alarmed by my piles. Can still barely move, let alone sit down. My boobs have inflated to the size and texture of medicine balls; my nipples are bright red and sore. Exhaustion. I keep crying. The pregnancy book explains that this is a normal hormonal day-three thing - my oestrogen and progesterone levels have "dropped precipitously". I cannot see an evolutionary need for this. The authors suggests my husband gets us a nice takeaway. Lots of blood. Oh, and I'm incontinent and fat. Apart from that, motherhood is a breeze.

Day four

My husband finally insists on taking a look at my parts. I am sure he'll never want me again, but right now couldn't care less. He claims - to my astonishment - that they look almost normal. The mastitis takes three days of agony and gradually dissipating fever and four more of low-grade pain to disperse. And I have to keep breastfeeding through the pain. I can now walk, but after any time on my feet I feel, again, that someone has battered my perineum with a hard object.

My stretch marks are angry red and my belly looks like a crumpled, partially deflated balloon. I tried to do some pelvic floor exercises but was unable to locate a single responsive muscle. I have also just noticed another red lump on the same breast. Sexy?

Another week, another bout of mastitis, course of antibiotics. Fretful baby. I have been told that his elephantine wind problem could be a result of dairy produce in my diet and so have cut it out. fields.headline: Temper tantrum as chair sinks out of sight
fields.trailText: The poor old Speaker finally, as Neil Kinnock would have said, climbed out of his pram yesterday, spilling rattles, teddy bears and Fisher-Price mobiles all over the pavement.
fields.body:
The poor old Speaker finally, as Neil Kinnock would have said, climbed out of his pram yesterday, spilling rattles, teddy bears and Fisher-Price mobiles all over the pavement.

It should have been shocking, or sombre, or out and out funny. In fact it was just an excuse for sniggers. Day by day Mr Martin looks more like a supply teacher in a sink school. The pupils don't dislike him; for the most part they ignore him. Sometimes they even feel sympathetic. What they can't resist is the chance to wind him up.

You have to know the background. The Sun is Britain's new paper of record. Yesterday it published an opinion poll which implies that the Labour majority will actually rise to 227 in the vote we expect next month. The Tories would be reduced to fewer than 160 seats, barely three-quarters Labour's score in 1983, when the party was led by Michael Foot, a man whose nickname was Worzel Gummidge and whose voter recognition was probably lower.

I don't suppose the Tories will do so badly. But that's not the point. The Sun has announced that they are going to be creamed, and in the modern world that takes on a grisly reality, for the time carrying more political heft than the actual result.

So Tory MPs are in a terrible bind. They would be happy if Mr Hague were accidentally killed by Seb Coe stomping on his windpipe during a bout on the canvas. But since that's unlikely, they have to support him. Put it this way: they know they are up a certain brown-coloured creek, and would love to use their leader as a paddle.

At prime minister's questions yesterday, Mr Hague said that he didn't intend to take any lessons "from a man who last week let the whole of government policy be dictated by Phoenix the calf".

It was a good barb, and the prime minister didn't trouble to reply. The other week, he said, he had quoted a disenchanted Tory candidate. Now there was a new figure he wished to bring to the House. This turned out to be a Mr Ian Liddell-Grainger, the Conservative candidate for Bridgewater. A leaflet had been put out on his behalf...

At this the Tories pretended to be furious. Question time is for ministers to account for themselves, not to attack the Opposition. "Order, order!" they yelled, implying that the Speaker should shut the prime minis ter up. Like all poor disciplinarians (I know, because I was an appalling teacher myself once) he chose the wrong moment to put his foot down.

"Don't tell me how to do my job!" he almost screamed. I heard a voice say, "why not? Somebody ought to", then realised that it was my own.

Mr Blair continued. The leaflet had said: "We have to explain to Conservatives who do not like William Hague that the only way to find a new leader is to get the Conservatives in power under William Hague so that a new leader can emerge from the more unknown Conservative members..."

(This message, "vote for Hague in order to get rid of him", does seem confused, but they're quite desperate.)

"Disgrace, disgrace!" Tories yelled gleefully.

"Mr Howarth!" barked the Speaker, at the Tory MP for Aldershot. "I hope you're not attacking me! I HOPE you're not attacking the chair!"

Teething rings and fluffy pink pigs were flying onto the Tarmac.

"I know how to conduct my affairs! No one will shout at the chair!" he shouted, and a bottle of warm milk described a metaphorical arc over the chamber.

Mr Howarth later pretended that he hadn't been attacking the Speaker personally, and the Speaker pretended to believe him. But it was all huge fun while it lasted.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: • Yesterday, Stupidest MP 2001 contender David Lock was the subject of an ultimatum: unless he agreed to enter an anger management course (you will recall his bullying of a tiny Midlands free sheet) we would publish highlights of his call to For You editor Steve Percy. I must tell you that no such undertaking has been received, and so here they are.
fields.body:
 Yesterday, Stupidest MP 2001 contender David Lock was the subject of an ultimatum: unless he agreed to enter an anger management course (you will recall his bullying of a tiny Midlands free sheet) we would publish highlights of his call to For You editor Steve Percy. I must tell you that no such undertaking has been received, and so here they are.

On April 12, Mr Lock told Steve, who'd repeated a Private Eye story about his abandoning the campaign to save Kidderminster hospital on joining the lord chancellor's office (he is junior minister in charge of knee breeches): "I am going to bankrupt you and your colleagues... I will take out an injunction and see you never print again... You're in more hot water than you can possibly imagine and will be lucky to survive... Your magazine is far more influential than Private Eye."

Also intriguing is the threat in a later legal letter of a criminal prosecution under section 106 of the Representation of the People Act. Since this only applies once an election has been called, this suggests either harassment and abuse of the law, or a justice minister oddly ignorant of the law. Or both. Derry Irvine may wish to investigate.

 Worrying news from the world of e-commerce where Yava.com, the venture of my old friend David Montgomery, looks in trouble. The former Mirror Group boss set it up to provide an online tabloid for distribution solely to pubs - a brilliant idea even by the standards of internet start ups. Inexplicably, there are teething troubles, and both David's partners, ex-Sunday Mirror editor Bridget Rowe and onetime Mirror boss David Banks, have left hurriedly.

According to the receptionist, neither is expected back, and even Monty himself is hard to pin down. Details are sketchy, so we will as usual leave the business of unravelling the full story to proper journalists.

 Surveillance (1): IPPR think tank chief Matthew Taylor on Tuesday's Newsnight, inexplicably lying on a sofa in a central London square to discuss anti-corporatism in Britain. Matthew made a surprisingly convincing neutral, given that the IPPR enjoys substantial funding from companies such as Cisco Systems, ICL and KPMG.

Meanwhile, we gather this ultra-Blairite thinker has been lined up as a Newsnight election pundit - another wearying appointment given that he's one of Mr Tony's most sycophantic cronies, widely tipped to join the Number 10 policy unit after the election.

 Surveillance (2): on the same programme, anarchist supremo Chris Nineham, wiping the floor with the quite breathtakingly egregious Tory MP Oliver Letwin. Some of the chaps have been wondering what happened to Chris since school, where he was one of our top scholars; so good to see him on such form. Matthew Byam-Shaw sends his regards, Chris, as do I.

 Following technical analyses proving Robin Cook has lowered his voice, rumour arrives that he is now modelling his delivery on Miss Jean Brodie. My colleague Marina Hyde rings Karl Hill at ICM, Maggie Smith's agency, requesting confirmation that she has been giving Cookie elocution lessons. "Er... not to our knowledge," says Karl. "And it's likely we'd know." Should we try Geraldine McEwan who played Miss Jean on telly then? "Er, maybe..." Click brrr.

 Nike Lapite calls from the Institute of Sales and Marketing Management. "Would you be interested in the hottest sales date in the calendar?" she asks. Well, not real... "Neil Rackham, the big-shot US motivator, is coming to the UK to address salesmen and people like yourselves." Like us? "The angle for you guys is, we're entering a recession and companies are neglecting their best asset - the sales force." Aha. "The whole tone is very go, go, go, and I just thought it was a punchy enough one for the Diary." Nike, have you ever seen the Diary? "Er... no. But take my number and call if you need more info." Thanking you.

webTitle: Wait and see policy on Son of Star Wars

fields.headline: Wait and see policy on Son of Star Wars
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour party
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Conservatives last night tried to bounce Tony Blair into premature endorsement of US president George Bush's plans to create a national missile defence system in the face of the prime minister's determination to await "a firm proposal before giving a firm decision".
fields.body:
The government last night asserted that its options remain open over US president George Bush's controversial plans to create a national missile defence system - the so-called Son of Star Wars.

The defence secretary Geoff Hoon insisted last night that, despite Conservative efforts to force the issue, Britain did not yet need to make a decision since the Bush administration had not set out the form of defence shield they favoured.

However he added: "If there is a threat that we would have to deal with - either to the UK or to our deployed forces, and that could be made to work - then yes that would be a good idea."

Earlier, the Tory leadership had sensed a pre-election opportunity to draw blood by seizing upon a careless phrase by the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, shortly after his boss had crossed swords at question time with William Hague.

The row flared 24 hours after Mr Bush had confirmed that the US believed that the post-cold war threat from so-called "rogue" states had rendered obsolete the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, which severely restricted anti-missile deployments.

Pushed during exchanges with the Tory leader in the Commons, Mr Blair said that he would await "a firm proposal before giving a firm decision".

But 20 minutes later Mr Campbell was asked during a routine press briefing with reporters whether Mr Blair, who has been cautious on the delicate issue of national missile defence (NMD), thought it was a good idea.

Mr Campbell replied: "Broadly, yes, in that the Americans are the last remaining superpower."

Although Mr Campbell tried to qualify his remark, it was enough to make the Tory defence spokesman, Iain Duncan Smith, claim that the prime minister's spokesman was spilling the beans on No 10's inner thoughts. Officials later dismissed the claim.

During possibly the last prime minister's question time before the election, Mr Hague had quoted senior Labour backbenchers, some of whom want an early UK commitment to modernise British radars that will be needed for the NMD network of anti-missile missiles.

He demanded from Mr Blair the "the clearest possible public statement of principle" that NMD - if technically feasible -would be in Britain's interests too.

The Tory leader has already made that commitment himself, in contrast to scepticism from the EU, China and Russia.

In a foretaste of the coming election campaign, Mr Duncan Smith continued the Tory attack, protesting on Radio 4's PM programme that it was "outrageous" that the apparent change of policy had been announced to journalists rather than by Mr Blair to the Commons.

Downing Street was quick to retaliate. "This is a complete fuss about nothing. As we have said repeatedly, we sympathise with and understand the concerns of the US administration about the threat from rogue states," a spokesman said. "Nothing was said this afternoon which takes us into a different position."

However, Whitehall remains sceptical about the practical possibilities of the "Son of Star Wars" project, which has seen a series of abortive tests since the Reagan era. It also fears that it will damage restraint and encourage proliferation.

webTitle: Hatfield crash firm in tube deal

fields.headline: Hatfield crash firm in line for tube deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Balfour Beatty, the construction giant accused of responsibility for last October's Hatfield rail disaster, was named yesterday as one of the firms chosen to take over a string of London Underground lines under the government's part-privatisation plans for the tube.
fields.body:
Balfour Beatty, the construction giant accused of responsibility for last October's Hatfield rail disaster, was named yesterday as one of the firms chosen to take over a string of London Underground lines under the government's part-privatisation plans for the tube.

In a move described as a "sad day for London" by the London transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, London Transport announced two private consortiums - including Balfour Beatty and other firms in volved in rail privatisation - as "preferred bidders" to run the city's deep lines for the next 30 years.

The boost for Balfour Beatty, which yesterday announced profits of £114m, came on the day its chief executive, Mike Welton, conceded at its annual meeting that the firm could have ordered speed restrictions or the closure of the Hatfield linewhen it found defects before the crash - in which four people died - but decided not to do so.

The announcement, ahead of next month's high court challenge to the public-private partnership, was made as the Rail, Maritime and Transport union called off today's planned tube strike over jobs and safety, following an appeal by the TUC leader John Monks and criticism from Tony Blair.

The union, which has won concessions in its dispute with Underground managers over the impact of the sell-off plans, suspended their walkout for two weeks after coming under intense pressure, but decided to go ahead with a strike today on South West Trains.

"The government is bringing in the system, and in some cases the firms, responsible for the debacle on the national rail network which led to tragedies like Hatfield," he said.

Metronet - comprising Balfour Beatty, WS Atkins, Thames Water, Seeboard and Adtranz - has been chosen for the Bakerloo, Central, Victoria and Waterloo and City lines.

fields.headline: Mask lands accountant in court
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: A Daily Telegraph-reading accountant yesterday claimed he was preparing for a fancy dress party when he was arrested at the May Day anti-capitalist protests in London.
fields.body:
A Daily Telegraph-reading accountant yesterday claimed he was preparing for a fancy dress party when he was arrested at the May Day anti-capitalist protests in London.

Nigel Lovell pleaded not guilty before Bow Street magistrates to failing to remove a scarf from his face when police told him to do so.

He said: "It's ridiculous. I was going to a fancy dress party dressed as General Custer and was on Bond Street on my way to Hamley's to buy a toy gun.

"I had nothing to do with the protest. I was wearing a scarf as part of my costume and I didn't refuse to remove it, I just asked whether I would get it back."

Lovell, who was bailed to reappear in June, was the first of 13 people to appear in court yesterday following the demonstrations on Tuesday.

Faure Perez, 21, of Forest Hill, south-east London, was fined £100 with £50 costs for failing to remove a cyclist's mask when challenged as he protested in Trafalgar Square. The police can demand that people remove masks under the Public Order Act.

Brian Kennedy, defending, said: "He asked for proof that the provision existed and was not given any... There were photographers around and if there was trouble he didn't want to be pictured in the papers because people might think he had caused the trouble."

But magistrate Christopher Pratt said: "You were wearing the mask to conceal your identity and that's the reason why police wanted you to remove the mask."

Nicholas Gray, 32, of Southwark, south-east London, was remanded on bail to June 20 after pleading not guilty to failing to remove his cap and sunglasses.

Peter Zephar, 28, of Shepherd's Bush, west London, and Godson Chigbu, 33, of Lambeth, south London, were both remanded on bail to June 19 after they denied assaulting police officers. Chigbu shouted: "Power to the people" as he left the court.

Ryan Fowler, 23, of Colehill, Dorset, pleaded not guilty to assault and was remanded on bail to appear on June 21.

Two men pleaded guilty to being drunk and disorderly. Bruce Jonathan Guy Lisle-Fennick, of no fixed address, was fined £40 after the court heard that he had shouted obscenities at police and struggled when officers tried to arrest him. He was remanded in custody when the court heard arrest warrants for him had been issued in Wales and Warwickshire on unrelated offences.

Michael Mower, 32, of Ely, Cambridgeshire, was fined £40 for being "loud and aggressive" and £50 for possessing cannabis resin. He already owes £400 in fines.

Three others were charged with possessing cannabis. Mark Covell, 33, of Ladbroke Grove, west London, will be cautioned at his local police station, while Claire Woolstone, 21, from Sydenham, south London, pleaded not guilty and opted for a crown court trial. Pascal Hasselle, 36, a Belgian, was given a conditional discharge after magistrates heard that he had spent the night in custody and planned to return to Brussels last night.

Two men were remanded on bail after pleading not guilty to carrying knives. David Randall, 32, of Glastonbury, Somerset, opted for a crown court trial while US citizen Adam Volk, who lives in Brighton, will appear before magistrates on May 4.

webTitle: Blair praises Met for control of protesters

fields.headline: Blair praises Met for control of protesters
fields.standfirst:
May Day aftermath: Detainees threaten to take legal action over police tactics at Oxford Circus

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: The prime minister yesterday led the praise for the police operation in controlling the May Day protesters that kept potentially politically embarrassing scenes of mass disorder to a minimum.
fields.body:
The prime minister yesterday led the praise for the police operation in controlling the May Day protesters that kept potentially politically embarrassing scenes of mass disorder to a minimum.

But authorities on civil rights law said the police tactic of detaining more than 1,000 people at Oxford Circus, the protest's epicentre, was unlawful.

One protester said that she and others who were held for up to seven hours were planning to sue the police.

Scotland Yard had mounted an elaborate media briefing operation warning that a hard core would use the anti-capitalist protest to riot through central London.

Concern over whether police broke the law is focused on several areas. The tactic used by officers, which was seen as keeping the violence and damage from this year's protests at a far lower level than last year, saw demonstrators encircled by lines of riot police. They were released slowly with many being searched or photographed after being held until well into the evening.

The Met said that detaining large numbers of people on Tuesday as they did on several occasions was lawful under common law as they feared a breach of the peace "based on the behaviour demonstrated combined with intelligence".

A spokesman said officers had "tried to identify those not protesting and tried to allow them out". He added: "The officers had reasonable grounds that the public would be subjected to violence and that there would be widespread damage to property if this action was not taken."

But John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said this tactic could be unlawful on several grounds. He said the police could not lawfully detain people without arresting them, which they had not done. The Home Office rejected this point.

Mr Wadham said that the police had taken a "blanket approach" and detained everyone in the Oxford Circus area.

He said: "What happened on May Day was unlawful. Individuals should be free from arrest and detention unless the police have clear powers and exercise these in a justifiable way, and they didn't."

The police justified searching some of those they had detained saying they had the power under section 60 of the 1994 Criminal Justice Act.

But Mr Wadham said Liberty had helped the Met carry out an audit of the powers to see whether it was compatible with the Human Rights Act and had found that section 60 was not.

Barrister Richard Clayton said: "If they detained everyone in Oxford Circus at the time, that's unlawful. They have to differentiate between the individuals they detain. The difficulty people who sue will face, although the police are probably acting at the edge of their legal powers, [is that] it will be said that the police should be given a degree of latitude as they were facing a difficult public order situation."

One of those encircled by police at Oxford Circus said she and up to 300 people wanted to take a collective legal action against the police. Lois Austin, 32, said she was held from 2pm to 9.30pm and had been supposed to collect her 11-month-old daughter from nursery at 5.30pm. When she asked to leave, she claimed a sergeant told her: "You should have thought of that before you came."

One of those detained was an actress who played a police chief in a BBC series. Anna Cartaret, star of Juliet Bravo, was held for five-and-a-half hours and only let out when an officer recognised her: "People began to get irritable because they couldn't eat, couldn't go to the loo, they weren't told why they were being kept penned up," she said.

Tony Blair yesterday telephoned the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, to congratulate him and his officers. "The prime minister said it had been a very big challenge for the police and that the Met had passed it magnificently and every one of his officers could be very proud of themselves," said a spokesman.

The Met won praise from the home secretary and from the London mayor, Ken Livingstone. Scotland Yard said they had made 92 arrests, with 32 people charged.

Twenty-three people had minor injuries and three officers were hurt.

Yesterday morning Oxford Street was getting back to normal. The most severe damage was on Tottenham Court road, where several banks had their windows smashed, as did camera shops and a futon store.

fields.headline: Minister defends smack and smoke rules for childminders
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Controversial new rules allowing childminders to smack their charges and smoke in front of them will be included in the first national childcare standards due to be published next week.
fields.body:
Controversial new rules allowing childminders to smack their charges and smoke in front of them will be included in the first national childcare standards due to be published next week, the education minister, Margaret Hodge, revealed yesterday.

She defended her decision to allow childminders to do so - with parents' agreement - and said she had been infuriated by professional representatives who insisted they were better placed than families to judge such issues.

Smacking and smoking by workers in all other childcare settings will be outlawed.

Giving evidence to the all-party select committee for its inquiry into early years education, Mrs Hodge insisted the government had been right to resist pressure, after a poll showed 83 % of parents felt it was a decision they should make themselves. "This is an issue for parents. The idea that we, as politicians, have a better understanding of the welfare of their children is insulting to parents."

Hailing a revolution in childcare since Labour came to power, Mrs Hodge said it was now the second fastest-growing sector in the labour market. Record numbers of men had expressed an interest in a career in the sector, she said.

The new childcare standards will be published next week and will come into force in July under a new inspection regime overseen by the office for standards in education. Mrs Hodge said the first national standards for under-eights daycare and childminding will cover all private and public sector day nurseries, playgroups, creches and after-school clubs.

Mrs Hodge came under fire from the Conservative MP, Nick St Aubyn, who said the issue of smacking and smoking was so important that it should have been debated in parliament.

The Labour committee chairman, Barry Sheerman, added: "There is a unanimous view on this committee that you are wrong."

fields.headline: Last orders for 'outdated' drinking laws
fields.standfirst:
Move to end closing time trouble backed by police

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The compulsory 11pm closing time for pubs across England and Wales is expected to be ended next year after ministers confirmed yesterday they would press ahead with plans to modernise the "antiquated licensing laws".
fields.body:
The compulsory 11pm closing time for pubs across England and Wales is expected to be ended next year after ministers confirmed yesterday they would press ahead with plans to modernise the "antiquated licensing laws".

The Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, said the government had decided to forge on with reform of the drinking laws to change the "get it down your neck" culture of binge drinking and to boost the tourism industry.

The reform plans to be introduced into parliament this autumn will mean that local pub closing times will be varied on police advice to stop rowdy drinkers all emptying out onto the streets at the same time. Pubs will, in theory, be able to open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, but residents will be able to challenge such licensing applications.

The decision to press ahead with the changes follows a year long consultation which saw police and pub landlords backing the reform plans.

A spokesman for the Association of Chief Police Officers, said: "We believe that relaxation of laws of opening hours will reduce binge drinking when people are trying to drink as much as possible before closing time and then going on to the streets at once."

But Westminster city council, which covers the greatest number of bars and clubs with late licences in Britain, warned that a 24 hour drinking culture also meant 24 hour street cleaning and policing.

"An open all hours culture may be good for business and for those on a night out but ill thought through reform could destroy communities," said Simon Milton, Westminster's Conservative leader.

Alcohol Concern also warned new relaxed laws could be a "recipe for violence and disorder" in towns and city centres and a nightmare for residents unless the proposed changes in legislation were accompanied by guidelines for councils granting licences. But Mike Benner, head of campaigns at the Campaign for Real Ale, said: "We've been working towards this outcome for 30 years, and we're keen to celebrate success with a late night pint."

The Home Office hopes that the legislation to introduce the reforms will be one of the first acts of Labour's second term in office.

Mr O'Brien said he hoped it would help end the "get it down your neck culture that has developed amongst some young males, and all too often these days, amongst some young females as well" and the drunken scenes witnessed too often on city streets after closing time.

"Eventually we would hope to encourage more sensible drinking seen in other European countries. The current ritual of late night drinkers pouring onto the streets at closing time, with its subsequent crime and disorder problems, has been an unwelcome tradition for far too long in our towns and cities."

The main change made in the government's plans as a result of consultation will mean that appeals against licensing decisions will be heard by local magistrates' courts, rather than the original proposal for crown courts to handle them.

Open all hours

 Flexible opening hours up to 24 hours, seven days a week

 Personal licences for pub landlords issued for 10 years

 Local authorities rather than magistrates to make licensing decisions

 Increased access for children to licensed premises

 One stop drinks and entertainment licensing system for pubs and clubs including conditions on hours, noise limits and capacity

The Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, said the government had decided to forge on with reform of the drinking laws to change the "get it down your neck" culture of binge drinking and to boost the tourism industry. The reform plans to be introduced into parliament this autumn will mean that local pub closing times will be varied on police advice to stop rowdy drinkers all emptying out onto the streets at the same time. Pubs will, in theory, be able to open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, but residents will be able to challenge such licensing applications. The decision to press ahead with the changes follows a year long consultation which saw police and pub landlords backing the reform plans. A spokesman for the Association of Chief Police Officers, said: "We believe that relaxation of laws of opening hours will reduce binge drinking when people are trying to drink as much as possible before closing time and then going on to the streets at once." But Westminster city council, which covers the greatest number of bars and clubs with late licences in Britain, warned that a 24 hour drinking culture also meant 24 hour street cleaning and policing. "An open all hours culture may be good for business and for those on a night out but ill thought through reform could destroy communities," said Simon Milton, Westminster's Conservative leader. Alcohol Concern also warned new relaxed laws could be a "recipe for violence and disorder" in towns and city centres and a nightmare for residents unless the proposed changes in legislation were accompanied by guidelines for councils granting licences. But Mike Benner, head of campaigns at the Campaign for Real Ale, said: "We've been working towards this outcome for 30 years, and we're keen to celebrate success with a late night pint." The Home Office hopes that the legislation to introduce the reforms will be one of the first acts of Labour's second term in office. Mr O'Brien said he hoped it would help end the "get it down your neck culture that has developed amongst some young males, and all too often these days, amongst some young females as well" and the drunken scenes witnessed too often on city streets after closing time. "Eventually we would hope to encourage more sensible drinking seen in other European countries. The current ritual of late night drinkers pouring onto the streets at closing time, with its subsequent crime and disorder problems, has been an unwelcome tradition for far too long in our towns and cities." The main change made in the government's plans as a result of consultation will mean that appeals against licensing decisions will be heard by local magistrates' courts, rather than the original proposal for crown courts to handle them.
