fields.headline: Blair sees end to foot and mouth crisis and prepares to announce election
fields.standfirst:
Election 2001: foot and mouth
Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will announce that the country is on the home stretch in the battle over foot and mouth when he holds his first press conference on the crisis today - the day he had originally set aside for the general election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will announce that the country is on the home stretch in the battle over foot and mouth when he holds his first press conference on the crisis today - the day he had originally set aside for the general election.

He will set out figures showing that the army and vets are getting control of the crisis, paving the way for the election on June 7 which will probably be announced next Tuesday.

With his opinion poll standing unshaken, Mr Blair's decision to delay the ballot from the original May 3 date is now likely to be seen as justified.

Mr Blair will be flanked by the chief vet, Jim Scudamore, and the government chief scientist, David King.

Figures coming into the Ministry of Agriculture show the government is finally reducing the backlog of unburied animals.

Mr Blair will also confirm that the number of new cases has fallen to 7-10 a day, from the average of 16 in the seven days before April 22.

He will reveal that in every region of the country the vets and army are reaching their target of slaughter within 24 hours of detection.

As recently as a week ago the figure was less than 50% .

He is expected to report that fewer than 90,000 of the 2.5m slaughtered animals still remain to be disposed of.

Mr Blair will also report there are only 118,000 animals waiting to be slaughtered. The number disposed of daily had reached 51,000 in the week ending April 22, up from 28,000 in the week ending March 25. More areas are being declared foot and mouth free.

However, Mr Blair's problems are not yet over. The National Farmers Union is threatening to take the government to court over recent cuts in compensation for slaughtered animals.

The English tourist industry is furious that it is not receiving extra cash to promote the tourist industry at home. Ministers announced yesterday only extra cash to promote England abroad.

At today's press conference Mr Blair will counsel caution, pointing out that the previous foot and mouth outbreak had a long tail and continued vigilance is required.

He will also face questions about the future direction of farming.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, has indicated that he would like to see farming move towards a subsidy system based on acreage rather than numbers of livestock.

Change has already occurred with the hill farmers' allowance, but he would like to see the same change implemented for the sheep annual premium scheme.

The government is also likely to increase the amount of cash it spends on environmental farming. Further change awaits a meeting of EU agriculture ministers in the autumn at which Mr Brown will use his new alliance with the German Green agriculture minister to push for further changes to the CAP.

webTitle: Labour's pledge to boost women MPs

fields.headline: Labour's pledge to boost women MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Labour is preparing to reveal a manifesto commitment to change the law to allow all-women shortlists for parliamentary candidates, as new figures forecast a fall in the number of female MPs for the first time in 30 years at the coming general election.
fields.body:
Labour is preparing to reveal a manifesto commitment to change the law to allow all-women shortlists for parliamentary candidates, as new figures forecast a fall in the number of female MPs for the first time in 30 years at the coming general election.

The party is finalising details of the legal change, which would allow political parties to take steps to redress the gender imbalance at Westminster without breaching the Sex Discrimination Act.

The move comes as the Fawcett Society, a pressure group campaigning for sexual equality, blamed sexism within political parties for the expected reduction in women MPs.

The society published figures showing that women make up fewer than 20% of candidates chosen by the five main parties (including the Scottish Nationalists and Plaid Cymru) to contest seats at the next election.

Even if all the parties hold the same seats as last time, 114 women will be returned - down seven from the record 121 elected in 1997.

Labour's total of 101 women MPs will fall to 97, while the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats each have one female MP standing down at the next election and have both selected male candidates to replace them.

Despite specific encouragement from Labour general secretary Margaret McDonagh to select female candidates, local parties have chosen only 11 women to fight Labour's top 50 target seats.

Under new legislation set to be included in the manifesto, political parties would be freed to introduce measures to "redress gender imbalance" in the selection of election candidates - a formula which should get round sex discrimination laws because it would permit all-male shortlists in the unlikely event of the gender gap swinging the other way.

fields.headline: Lib Dems link green fight with social justice
fields.standfirst: Special report: Liberal Democrat party
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats yesterday put a commitment to end fuel poverty in low income homes at the heart of an environmental mini-manifesto which also seeks to link green policies to social justice across the planet.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats yesterday put a commitment to end fuel poverty in low income homes at the heart of an environmental mini-manifesto which also seeks to link green policies to social justice across the planet.

With an endorsement from Friends of the Earth, Charles Kennedy outlined a series of policies aimed at improving Britain's record as well as the lives of poorer citizens.

In an update of Lib Dem policy - which would aim to see 10% of UK energy generated from renewable sources by 2010 - the party would seek to halve the time, from 30 years to 15 years, planned to provide decent levels of home insulation.

The resulting lower CO2 emissions, better health and smaller fuel bills would be achieved through a programme of investment funded by the energy savings trust and energy supply companies.

"This will tackle the damp and cold which affect the health of millions of people, and reduce winter deaths caused by fuel poverty. We will work with colleagues in Europe to agree zero rating of VAT on all energy conservation materials within the EU," said the Lib Dem mini-manifesto.

In terms which ministers may say are unachievable, it continued: "We will ensure that Britain achieves its own target well before the deadline, and establishes a new target of a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2010, setting an example to the world. "

The party - which vies with the Greens for protest voters - committed itself to sustainable agricultural technologies, and to seek an EU-wide moratorium on commercial growing of genetically modified crops until 2004.

fields.headline: £100m boost for maternity units
fields.trailText: Every woman will have continuous one to one care from a midwife during labour under plans for a rapid expansion of maternity services announced yesterday by Alan Milburn, the health secretary.
fields.body:
Every woman will have continuous one to one care from a midwife during labour under plans for a rapid expansion of maternity services announced yesterday by Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

He promised to recruit 500 extra midwives in England this year and a further 1,500 by 2005 to relieve staff shortages that have resulted in too many women being left alone during labour, or receiving care from staff they did not know.

All 250 NHS maternity units in England will share in a £100m modernisation fund. The money will be used over the next two years to provide single rooms giving more privacy to families, home comforts such as television and telephones, and rooms for fathers to stay when their babies need special care.

Mr Milburn said a new national service framework for children and maternity services would set a "gold standard" of providing a dedicated midwife for each woman in labour for 100% of the time. Under the present system, only 70% of maternity units are able to provide this level of continuous support for women. Recruitment incentives would include £1,500 for former midwives returning to the profession and assistance with childcare costs worth up to £150 a week.

Mr Milburn said the framework would end the "lottery of childbirth choices" for women in England."Those parts of the country with the greatest need and the biggest shortages will benefit from the biggest expansion in midwife numbers," he told the Royal College of Midwives' annual conference in Torquay.

Belinda Phipps, chief executive of the National Childbirth Trust, said two-thirds of women were left without professional support at some time during labour and a quarter were worried when left alone.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, called the announcement a smokescreen. "The Department of Health's own figures show that the drop in the number of midwives since 1997 has been 390. The number of midwifery posts vacant for more than three months has risen by a third over the last year from 370 to 490. So where does the secretary of state think he can find an extra 2,000?"

webTitle: 12 candidates, one mayor - where are they now?

fields.headline: 12 candidates, one mayor - where are they now?
fields.standfirst: It was the cuddliest British election and the cause of a weird roadshow of ageing ambition: 11 men and one woman battling to become London's first directly-elected mayor. But what happened to them after polling day? Julian Glover explains
fields.trailText: It was the cuddliest British election and the cause of a weird roadshow of ageing ambition: 11 men and one woman battling to become London's first directly-elected mayor. But what happened to them after polling day? Julian Glover explains.
fields.body:
As was obvious from the moment in March 2000 when Ken Livingstone announced that he would run as an independent candidate, the election of London's first mayor proved a rebuff for all Britain's main political parties and mini-triumph for fringe politics.

And that curious outcome led to another - inter-candidate solidarity survived the last 12 months as mayor Livingstone copied Tony Blair's "big tent" politics and brought his defeated rivals into office with him.

In his post-election speech Mr Livingstone offered jobs in his administration to defeated candidates from all three main parties. Today, four of the top eight candidates - Mr Livingstone, the Tory Steve Norris, Lib Dem Susan Kramer and the Green, Darren Johnson - play some part in governing London.

All this is thanks to the anti-party dynamic of the mayoral campaign.

Norris, with his bluff pro-gay, pro-hanging, anti-abortion policy slate and anarchic sense of humour, was hardly a typical Tory just as Dobson, equally funny, even more foul mouthed and sceptical of New Labour, was no Millbank clone.

Even Ms Kramer, an ambitious transport specialist married to an American banker, came from outside her party's traditional roots.

And three other candidates stood out, too. As well as Livingstone - whose status outside the big three parties was perhaps only nominal - the mayoral election brought into the limelight Darren Johnson, the Green candidate who campaigned from a bike.

He was beaten by an even more unexpected figure, Ram Gidoomal of the Christian People's Alliance, who gained 2.4% and plenty of respect, particularly from traditionalist Conservatives put off by Steve Norris' liberated attitude to sex.

Within weeks of the election, Ms Kramer, had accepted a post on the board of Transport for London, the body responsible for sorting out the tube.

Instead of seeking a seat in parliament - as was widely expected - she focussed her political energies on London and has, so far, worked closely with the mayor.

Her media presence has been at least as high as Mr Livingstone's nominal deputy, Labour's Nicky Gavron.

So has that of Steve Norris - once, as a Tory MP, a tabloid favourite for his sexual antics. He is now a vice chairman of the Conservative party and as such part of William Hague's campaign team for the general election.

However he also sits on the board of Transport for London and admits he finds the mayor an "engaging person privately who it is very easy to like" - although he opposes the mayor's plans to charge drivers entering central London.

Mr Norris has also spent the past year doing what he has always been good at - making money. He was tipped at one stage as the next chairman of Railtrack.

Mr Dobson, Labour's fall-guy in the election, has slipped from the public eye. Still well-connected and popular inside his party and at Westminster, he has become a rare sight in the media despite his nominal role as an official anti-Tory campaigner for his party. This post, announced by the prime minister in December 2000, has not, so far, borne fruit.

However he will remain in the House of Commons after the election and some sort of future ministerial post, as a safe pair of hands, cannot be ruled out.

Of the smaller party candidates, Darren Johnson, who ran as a Green candidate and sits as such in the London assembly but now spends part of his time advising the mayor.

Peter Tatchell, the gay rights activist, has continued his campaigning - most recently clashing with Zimbabwe's president Robert Mugabe in Belgium. He won plaudits from the Daily Telegraph for doing so.

And what of Ram Gidoomal of the Christian People's Alliance? After a much better than expected showing on polling day he has persisted with his party and his business career. His party almost won a seat on Newham council in March.

That might not be quite as glamorous as winning the mayor's job, but it's an outcome entirely in line with an unpredictable last 12 months for London's mayoral candidates.

fields.headline: 3-2-1 host Ted Rogers dies
fields.trailText: The entertainer Ted Rogers - known to a generation of ITV viewers for his game show 3-2-1 -has died, his agent, Phil Dale, said last night. By David Brown.
fields.body:
The entertainer Ted Rogers - known to a generation of ITV viewers for his game show 3-2-1 -has died, his agent, Phil Dale, said last night.

Rogers, 65, died yesterday morning in St Thomas's hospital in south London where he was being treated for a heart problem. He had been diagnosed with an irregular heartbeat about six months ago and was admitted to hospital at the weekend.

Rogers was noted for his dextrous hand gesture in the gameshow. Contestants had to solve cryptic clues to land rewards - and avoid the booby prize, Dusty Bin.

When the show ended its 10- year run in 1987, Rogers said: "The Oxbridge lot got control of TV and they didn't want it. It was too downmarket for them. We were still getting 12m viewers when they took it off. These days if a show gets 9m everyone does a lap of honour."

During his career he shared the bill with such stars as Frank Sinatra, Bing Crosby and Shirley Bassey.

Mr Dale said: "Fashions changed and a generation of alternative comics came along which meant the type of work he did changed. This year he was due to work with his old friend Jackie Mason instead of doing panto and they were going to do an old vaudeville-type act in America."

Mr Rogers, who lived in Haslemere, Surrey, had two teenage children from his second marriage, and two children from his first marriage.

He had been diagnosed with an irregular heartbeat about six months ago and was admitted to hospital at the weekend. Rogers was noted for his dextrous hand gesture in the gameshow. Contestants had to solve cryptic clues to land rewards - and avoid the booby prize, Dusty Bin. When the show ended its 10- year run in 1987, Rogers said: "The Oxbridge lot got control of TV and they didn't want it. It was too downmarket for them. We were still getting 12m viewers when they took it off. These days if a show gets 9m everyone does a lap of honour." During his career he shared the bill with such stars as Frank Sinatra, Bing Crosby and Shirley Bassey. Mr Dale said: "Fashions changed and a generation of alternative comics came along which meant the type of work he did changed. This year he was due to work with his old friend Jackie Mason instead of doing panto and they were going to do an old vaudeville-type act in America." Mr Rogers, who lived in Haslemere, Surrey, had two teenage children from his second marriage, and two children from his first marriage.

fields.headline: BT to quit headquarters
fields.standfirst: Telecoms group on target to cut debt by £10bn but rights issue is still expected
fields.trailText: BT is to quit its prestigious London headquarters in a move which could raise up to £700m as the group's attempts to slash its crippling £30bn debt burden gather pace. By Neil Hume, Mark Milner and Jonathan Watts.
fields.byline: Neil Hume, Mark Milner and Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.body:
BT is to quit its prestigious London headquarters in a move which could raise up to £700m as the group's attempts to slash its crippling £30bn debt burden gather pace.

News of the plan to vacate the Newgate Street building, close to St Paul's, came as a shrunken BT confirmed the sale of its stakes in Japan Telecom, J-Phone and Spain's Airtel to rival Vodafone for £4.8bn.

Coupled with the sale and lease back of other parts of its property portfolio the deals leave BT on target to cut £10bn from its estimated £30bn debt.

BT shares closed 7p lower at 592p yesterday, while Vodafone fell 7.25p to 199p.

Analysts believe BT will still opt to bolster its balance sheet through a rights issue to supplement asset disposals which are expected to include the sale of its directories business.

Yesterday chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield refused to be drawn directly on a rights issue though he acknowledged the Vodafone deal alone was not enough. "We have talked about property and Yellow Pages [Yell] and there are other things we have got on the stocks." Yell could be worth up to £3bn.

According to Ralph Brook-Fox, an investment manager at Britannic Asset Management, the rights issue may be smaller than the market had originally feared. He said: "At one point the numbers were being talked up to potentially £10bn. Now it looks like a maximum of £5bn and possibly less."

Chris Godsmark, telecoms analyst at Investec Henserson Crosthwaite, said BT might want to catch "the wind of the market". He said: "They feel like they are on a bit of a roll. The share price has gone up, they are being perceived as a bit more decisive and they might want to take advantage of this to raise some more cash."

Vodafone is selling some £3.5bn of its own shares to help pay for the acquisitions from which will take its stake in Japan Telecom, Japan's third largest fixed-line operator, to 45% and to 46% of its subsidiary J-Phone, the nation's third biggest mobile phone company with 10m customers, while it will now have 91.6% of Airtel.

The sale of its Japanese stakes has netted BT a £2bn profit in less than 18 months but the deal represents a set back for its strategy, coming less than a year after Sir Peter underlined BT's commitment to the Japanese market.

"It is a matter of real regret that British Telecom will not be playing a major part in these companies going forward," Pat Gallagher, group director of strategy and development for BT, said. "It was an offer we had to accept. It was approved by our board and it is good value for our shareholders."

Despite recent uncertainties over the telecoms sector Vodafone's share sale was well received, with the issue almost twice subscribed. The size of the Vodafone offer is not seen as a deterrent to a BT rights issue. "Just because Vodafone is in the market place, I don't think that locks everyone else out," said Sir Peter.

Andrew Hobson at Exeter Asset Management said: "If you want the company to work for you you'd have to back [a rights issue]." according to fund manager Andrew Hobson at Exeter Asset Management.

Sir Peter said that the company had decided to withdraw from the headquarters building next year "because the headquarters function is reduced in size".

The Newgate building can accommodate up to 1,500 people but, as BT devolves more of its functions to its individual businesses, head office staff will fall to between 500 to 600. According to a company spokeswoman the move would not involve job losses.

Yesterday's agreement leaves Vodafone well placed to launch a challenge to NTT DoCoMo, Japan's biggest mobile phone group.

"Our aim is to increase the competitiveness of J-Phone to give DoCoMo a hard time in Japan," said Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent.

However, the sale of the Japanese interests, coupled with the likely sale of stakes in other telecoms operators in Asia will leave BT focused on Europe, with its global Concert business "out on a limb", according to one analyst.

BT is still likely to face further shareholder pressure to make its strategic vision clear. "BT needs to tell everybody what the strategy is going forward; what it's going to hold, where it's going to invest. The full works needs to be unfolded, not just bits and pieces," said David Manning, head of equities at money manager F&C.

webTitle: Russian writer warns of attacks on press freedom

fields.headline: Russian writer warns of attacks on press freedom
fields.trailText:
8.30am: A Russian journalist captured by the army in Chechnya has delivered a stark warning about restrictions on press freedom in Russia, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: world press freedom day
fields.body:
A Russian journalist who was captured by the military while reporting from behind Chechen lines has warned that restrictions on press freedom in Russia are reverting to cold war levels.

Anna Politkovskaya, who works for the Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta, said it was "very important" for journalists in Britain and the west to show their solidarity with journalists in Russia and put pressure on the government.

She warned that pressures on journalists operating within the Russian federation were reverting to levels last experienced during the cold war.

After going behind rebel lines in Chechnya, Ms Politkovskaya was captured by the Russian army, who tortured her and subjected her to a series of harrowing intimidations.

Her captors told her it was "time to pay" for her reports on Chechnya.

Ms Politkovskaya said when she was released and returned home to in Moscow, she turned on the television to see a newsreader denouncing her as "an enemy of the country".

"It's horrific to hear these things and to hear them reverting to the terminology of the 70s," she said.

Ms Politkovskaya, who is to meet the prime minister, Tony Blair, later this week, said she wanted to ask him why he was the "number one friend" of the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, who has been responsible for clampdowns on the media.

"Whether this question of extinguishing freedom of speech has ever been discussed between Mr Blair and Mr Putin, I would like to know," she said, adding: "If Blair is a democrat, how can he not discuss it?"

The war between the Russian federation and Chechen rebels has already claimed several journalist victims.

Last weekend French journalist Brice Fleutiaux, who was captured by Chechen rebels, committed suicide. Another journalist, Andrei Babitsky, last year was kidnapped behind enemy lines and held for over a month.

webTitle: Former minister guilty of Maxwell deceit

fields.headline: Former minister guilty of Maxwell deceit
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: The former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson, is guilty of misleading parliament over undeclared financial interests from his business dealings with the disgraced tycoon Robert Maxwell, a committee of MPs agreed last night. By Michael White and David Hencke.
fields.body:
The former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson, is guilty of misleading parliament over undeclared financial interests from his business dealings with the disgraced tycoon Robert Maxwell, a committee of MPs agreed last night.

The cross-party standards and privileges committee reached its verdict following two private sessions after hearing an unconvincing explanation from Mr Robinson earlier this week.

They did so on the basis of the fourth investigation into the Coventry North-West MP's tangled business affairs during the 1997 parliament - on what is virtually certain to be its last full working day before Tony Blair calls the expected general election.

The MPs had in front of them the latest report from the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, who is under attack from MPs for the rigour of her investigations into allegations that some MPs are not declaring all their private interests in the Commons register.

The inquiry centred on a £200,000 payment from Hollis Industries, an engineering company which Mr Robinson bought from Mr Maxwell - and later resold. He has persistently denied claims, most recently in journalist Tom Bower's biography, that he received the payment.

Senior ministers and MPs, as well as the department of trade and industry, were told he had not received the money - though evidence of it existed in the Hollis accounts. Mr Robinson, who left Gordon Brown's treasury team in 1998, said the accounts were wrong.

Weekend reports suggested that Mrs Filkin had discovered that the MP had solicited such a payment from the then-owner of the Daily Mirror, who drowned in 1991 after robbing the paper's pension fund, and that the money may have been directed to an overseas trust, bank account or individual with which Mr Robinson could be linked.

There was no confirmation of such claims or any indication of how much of Mrs Filkin's evidence the standards committee, chaired by the fastidious Labour veteran, Robert Sheldon, has accepted.

But the MPs have concluded that Mr Robinson did have a declarable financial interest because he worked for Hollis - whether he actually got the money or not.

Mr Robinson, 61, who is standing again at the election, has already been obliged to apologise to the Commons for non-declarations of interest, a 54-second apology in 1999. What punishment he may now face was unclear last night - though there will be no time for action before the election.

With evidence and annexes also likely to be published at the same time, so fellow MPs can judge what may be a controversial verdict, the report could appear this week - though next Tuesday or Wednesday may be more likely.

At question time yesterday, the Tory MP, Jacqui Lait, challenged Tony Blair to make sure the committee's findings were not kicked into the long grass before the election - or to publish the DTI inspector's report into Mr Robinson's affairs. Mr Blair said it was up to the committee.

The committee has been criticised in the past for not being tough enough on Labour ministers or backing Mrs Filkin firmly enough. They insist they have not been playing party politics - and that all the decisions have been unanimous, including those involving high profile MPs such as Peter Mandelson, Keith Vaz and the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid.

One casualty of persistent controversy has been Mrs Filkin whose three year contract - after she succeeded Sir Gordon Downey - is due to end in January. "There are plenty of people on both sides who would love her to go, they feel she's overstepped the mark," one senior Labour MP said last night.

Mrs Filkin's fate lies in the hands of the House of Commons Commission, chaired by the Speaker Michael Martin, who is keen to maintain parliament's reputation in the post-Nolan era when rules on interests are being tightened.

fields.headline: WorldCom wields axe in Europe
fields.standfirst:
Britain is expected to bear brunt of redundancies

More internet news
Special report: global recession
fields.trailText: WorldCom yesterday confirmed that about 832 employees would be made redundant by the end of the month, reports David Cohen.
fields.body:
WorldCom yesterday confirmed that about 832 employees would be made redundant by the end of the month.

The internet service provider employs 11,000 people across Europe - including part-time and contract staff - 5,500 of whom are based in Britain.

The redundancies will affect staff across the continent, although sources say the lion's share will be at the Cambridge and London offices.

A spokesman for WorldCom said: "The figure [of 832 redundancies] is pretty accurate, but it's not a final number - we expect to make a concrete announcement by the end of the month.

"At present we are consulting with employees to work out where best to make the cuts."

The redundancies are part of a restructuring programme at the company which aims to absorb the operations of its subsidiary UUNet into WorldCom and dispense with the facade of UUNet brand completely.

"Once the restructuring plan is complete the UUNet brand will no longer exist," said Richard Woods, director of public relations at UUNet.

The news of the redundan cies confirms speculation that began in March when WorldCom laid off 6,000 employees at its US operations - equivalent to around 7% of the company's global workforce.

Insiders say that employees have expected the cuts since January and the long wait has driven some to jump ship.

The spokesman said no union representatives operated in the company, but employees were being consulted individually to break the news where necessary.

"We want to be the first to tell them," the spokesman said.

Last week WorldCom reported net income for the first quarter of the year had fallen by 49% in comparison with the same period last year, from $1.2bn (£839m) in March 2000 to $610m.

Next week the company plans to sell an estimated $8bn worth of bonds to raise much-needed capital for investment and debt clearing.

Analysts expect a portion will be offered in euros and possibly sterling, the first time the company has raised such funds in Europe. Executives are touring the continent to raise investor interest.

Analysts said that WorldCom was likely to use part of the money to pay off debts of $3.1bn due for settlement this November.

webTitle: Punters sold on text message adverts

fields.headline: Punters sold on text message adverts
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Nine out of 10 participants in a text message advertising trial claimed they were not irritated by the adverts, writes Julia Day.
22.03.2001: UK firm trials text message advertising
19.03.2001: Hard sell in your hand
fields.body:
Nine out of 10 people who took part in a text message advertising trial claimed they were not irritated by the adverts.

The news comes as more and more companies are using mobile phones to contact consumers - Big Brother supremo Peter Bazalgette revealed he is to launch a text message service for its new series.

Mobile phone marketing company The Mobile Channel sent text message adverts to 1,000 people aged 16-30 who had detailed their interests to make sure the adverts were relevant to them.

The results reveal that 94% of the users were satisfied with the service and 85% of them would recommend it to a friend.

According to the survey more than seven out of 10 of participants read between 75% and all of their text message adverts and 81% agreed the adverts were interesting or appropriate.

But the news that the text adverts typically received response rates of between 10% and 20% with the highest achieving 28% will be the most important factor to brands considering advertising over mobile phones.

It means that consumers are very willing to interact with brands who text them.

In comparison, a successful direct mail campaign can expect to elicit a 3% response rate.

Thirty-five brands have taken part in a text message advertising trial which has produced customer response rates of up to 28%.

Brands including Cadbury's, Carlsberg, Sega, GlaxoSmithKline, Blockbuster, Camelot, Tango and Thomas Cook took part in the six week trial conducted by NOP and on behalf of The Mobile Channel.

The trial was carried out in conjunction with the London Business School, was endorsed by The Incorporated Society of British Advertisers and sponsored by media buying company MediaCom.

Mediacom head of account research Andy Richmond says: "The Mobile Channel's model will allow us insights into what it takes to establish a one to one relationship with the consumer, which is every advertiser's ultimate aim."

Carlsberg-Tetley brand manager Simon Pick says: "Mobile has the potential to allow us to communicate in a timely manner with our target market when and where it is most appropriate - for example when they are out drinking, or immediately following one of the sports events we are part of."

webTitle: Yahoo! faces fury from 'betrayed' porn fans

fields.headline: Yahoo! faces fury from 'betrayed' porn fans
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Yahoo! is bracing itself for a spat after instigating a pornography crackdown on its website, reports Amy Vickers.
17.04.2001: Q&A: Yahoo! and porn
12.04.2001: Yahoo! banks on porn sales to boost profits
fields.body:
Yahoo! is bracing itself for a spat after instigating a pornography crackdown on its website.

Sections of Yahoo!'s online community have grouped together to prepare petitions fighting for the survival of their online clubs, message boards and chatrooms.

They say that the company's extended ban on the sale of porn is tantamount to a complete purge and censorship.

The revolt comes less than a month after Yahoo! said it was banning the sale of pornography on its shopping section because public opinion was mounting against it.

Over the past few weeks, Yahoo! has quietly reconfigured its adult-themed online clubs, message boards and chat rooms, removing links and making them harder to find.

Many users say they feel betrayed, and fear the clubs will fail to attract new members and ultimately disappear altogether. The issue underscores the popularity of the porn on the internet.

Ken Bradman, a 23-year-old web developer who has organised a protest club, said: "If they completely eliminate adult material from the site, they're going to lose a lot of members. I can guarantee you it's going to be a huge chunk of Yahoo's user base."

Some also say Yahoo's action actually makes it easier for children to see adult content.

Yahoo spokesman Jackson Holtz confirmed the company has made several changes as "part of the evaluation of adult content across the network" .

But he said no decisions have been made on whether the changes will be permanent. "It's the internet, so lots of things are possible," he said.

The porn issue blew up in March following press reports criticising Yahoo! of profiting from the sale of hardcore videos and DVDs.

Yahoo had sold X-rated products for two years and had planned to expand this before it quickly back-peddled after a media frenzy.

Ken Bradman, a 23-year-old web developer who has organised a protest club, said: "If they completely eliminate adult material from the site, they're going to lose a lot of members. I can guarantee you it's going to be a huge chunk of Yahoo's user base." Some also say Yahoo's action actually makes it easier for children to see adult content. Yahoo spokesman Jackson Holtz confirmed the company has made several changes as "part of the evaluation of adult content across the network" . But he said no decisions have been made on whether the changes will be permanent. "It's the internet, so lots of things are possible," he said. The porn issue blew up in March following press reports criticising Yahoo! of profiting from the sale of hardcore videos and DVDs. Yahoo had sold X-rated products for two years and had planned to expand this before it quickly back-peddled after a media frenzy. fields.headline: ITV extends news for election
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV will run an extended News at Ten five nights a week throughout the election period hosted by Sir Trevor McDonald. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITV will run an extended News at Ten five nights a week throughout the general election period, hosted by Sir Trevor McDonald.

It is hoping to steal a march from the BBC, which announced recently that it would not be extending its Ten O'Clock News programmes, because it feared a boredom factor among viewers.

ITV will also show four midweek election programmes, hosted by Jonathan Dimbleby, from studios across Britain, which will kick off with an opportunity for the audience to quiz Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy, finishing off with questions for leaders of the SNP and Plaid Cymru.

A special election night coverage will be screened, headed by Mr Dimbleby, with John Sergeant, Dermot Murnaghan, Mary Nightingale and Katie Derham.

ITN has designated special correspondents to each party leader on their campaign trails, with Bill Neely covering Tony Blair, Juliet Bremner following William Hague and Mark Webster following Charles Kennedy.

Meanwhile John Sergeant, Jo Andrews, Lauren Taylor and John Ray will make up its core reporting team.

ITV's controller of news and current affairs, Steve Anderson, said: "We have a high-calibre team the viewers know and trust".

fields.headline: Britain takes lion's share of investment
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Britain increased its share of inward investment last year, according to new figures, dispelling fears that its failure to join the euro would threaten its leading European position for attracting foreign investors.
fields.body:
Britain increased its share of inward investment last year, according to new figures, dispelling fears that its failure to join the euro would threaten its leading European position for attracting foreign investors.

Anti-euro campaigners said that Britain's success in attracting 26% of total investment into Europe was evidence that being outside the single currency was not deterring foreign companies.

"This is yet more evidence that Britain is continuing to attract to the lion's share of foreign investment," said Janet Bush from the pressure group New Europe.

However, the rival lobby group, Britain in Europe, said a 15% fall in investment in the export-intensive manufacturing sector showed the single currency was a key factor for firms making location decisions. "In the sector where access to European markets is important, Britain is losing out dramatically to other European countries," said Kitty Usshers, the group's chief economist.

The financial analysts Ernst & Young, who produced the figures, said foreign investment in telecoms, software and business services had offset the decline in manufacturing investment. But these sectors could prove vulnerable to the global slowdown.

Much of the technology investment had come from the United States, said Mark Hughes, a location adviser with Ernst & Young. "If the US does retrench as a result of a downturn or a halt in growth, the UK will suffer, probably more so than the rest of Europe because of its dependence on the US and these service sectors."

Britain increased its share of investment last year from the 24% share it won in 1999, and is well ahead of its nearest rival, France, which attracted 15%.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, hailed the figures as a ringing endorsement for the government's economic record, but acknowledged that there was no room for complacency in the current uncertain economic climate.

fields.headline: Chinese berets become military issue
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: China
fields.trailText: There is nothing America likes better than a military parade. But the prospect of seeing its proud soldiers marching past wearing Chinese-made berets has finally proved too much for the Pentagon.
fields.body:
There is nothing America likes better than a military parade. But the prospect of seeing its proud soldiers marching past wearing Chinese-made berets has finally proved too much for the Pentagon.

Free trade may be desirable, but the idea that the world's most powerful country will dress its soldiers in clothing manufactured by Washington's new global enemy number one is not the sort of message George Bush's administration wished to send.

So yesterday the defence department said it would abandon an order for 600,000 Chinese-made berets after US politicians publicly insisted that the nation's soldiers should be exclusively kitted out in "made in the USA" uniforms.

"The army chief of staff has determined that US troops shall not wear berets made in China or berets made with Chinese content," the deputy defence secretary, Paul Wolfowitz, said. "Therefore I direct the army and the defence logistics agency... to recall previously distributed berets and dispose of the stock."

The decision is a costly snub for the army chief of staff, General Eric Shinseki, who last year decided that most US soldiers should wear black berets from next month. The Pentagon has placed new orders worth $26m (£18m) for up to 3m new berets.

The U-turn also means that nearly half of the Chinese-made black berets, which have already been delivered but have not been issued or worn, will become army surplus.

fields.headline: Pentagon reviews contacts with China
fields.standfirst:
Special report: China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The US announced the immediate suspension of  military contacts with China last night, and  quickly amended the Pentagon statement from "suspend" to "review".
fields.body:
The US announced the immediate suspension of military contacts with China last night, and quickly amended the Pentagon statement from "suspend" to "review".

The first statement said the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, had ordered the suspension on Monday, with immediate effect. The second said future contacts were under review.

The Pentagon spokesman, Admiral Craig Quigley, told reporters that the Rumsfeld aide who wrote the memo had "misinterpreted the secretary's intentions".

"His actual intention is for all elements of the military-to-military programme to be reviewed and approved on a case by case basis by the department of defence."

The original announcement was made as US civilian technicians prepared to spend their second day on the EP-3 spy plane grounded on Hainan island.

In the interim, officials would give no clue to the reason or the timing, but the decision follows the the 11-day detention of the EP-3 crew of 24 and Chinese protest at Washington's decision give Taiwan's former president an entry visa.

Military contacts between the two are limited, and none are due this month, but the US publicly refused to suspend them during the Hainan island stand-off.

The technicians examining the EP-3 are employed by the manufacturer Lockheed Martin and would not have been covered by a suspension order.

fields.headline: Kurds threaten dam contractor
fields.trailText: The leading Kurdish dissident group, the PKK, would take up arms against the contractor Balfour Beatty if the firm built the Ilisu dam in Turkey and flooded the Kurds' homeland, company chairman Lord Weir was warned at its annual meeting yesterday.
fields.body:
The leading Kurdish dissident group, the PKK, would take up arms against the contractor Balfour Beatty if the firm built the Ilisu dam in Turkey and flooded the Kurds' homeland, company chairman Lord Weir was warned at its annual meeting yesterday.

Diyardi Kurdi, who had bought shares in the company to attend, said the guerrilla group's two-year ceasefire would end if the company went ahead with the plan. "I have lost 24 close relatives and my house has been destroyed but we will not give up the fight."

Kurdish opposition to the dam for which Balfour Beatty is lead contractor was voiced by several shareholders who demanded the company withdraw rather than flood the city of Hasankeyf and the homes of 72,000 people.

Lord Weir said it was not his company's decision to build the dam. The Kurds should make representations to the Turkish government which proposed it and the British government, which had been asked to provide a £200m export credit guarantee to back the project.

Balfour Beatty objected to a proposal by Friends of the Earth, which has bought a £20,000 stake in the company, to adopt a World Commission on Dams report this year that required contractors to consider human rights and environmental issues when deciding to build dams.

Charles Secrett, director, of FoE, said not adopting the commission's principles damaged the company's reputation and was bad for long term business.

Lord Weir said he did not feel the "distance between us and Friends of the Earth is very great" but said the commission's 26 principles on dam construction were "issues for the people that propose dams, not the companies that build them". But he said the company had adopted an ethical policy that included respect for the universal declaration of human rights.

Asked whether he regretted getting involved in the decision to build the dam, Lord Weir said "If we had known then how controversial this project would be we could have saved ourselves a lot of trouble by not taking part in it, but this was not the case at the time."

webTitle: Leicester TB toll continues to rise

fields.headline: Leicester TB toll continues to rise
fields.trailText: The toll in the tuberculosis outbreak in Leicestershire rose again yesterday when public health officials revealed that 62 people have now been confirmed with the disease, one of whom is in hospital and said to be poorly.
fields.body:
The toll in the tuberculosis outbreak in Leicestershire rose again yesterday when public health officials revealed that 62 people have now been confirmed with the disease, one of whom is in hospital and said to be poorly.

The outbreak which began at Crown Hills community college in Leicester is the largest of its type since records began.

"There has not been a recorded outbreak of TB of this size in a school," said Gerry Bryant, specialist registrar in public health for Leicesterhsire health authority. The largest previous outbreak was in Uppingham, also in Leicestershire, where there were 30 cases in 1978-79.

The hospital patient is a relative of one of the pupils at Crown Hills community college. All the relatives of children with the disease at the school have now been screened, and two cases were found. The other is at home on antibiotics.

Ten more pupils have the disease, it was announced yesterday by Leicestershire health authority, after they underwent chest x-rays. Two of those have been admitted to hospital for investigation and all of them are on a course of antibiotic treatment which generally lasts for six months.

Four more students who had normal chest x-rays had positive Heaf tests - the skin test that detects exposure to the tuberculosis germ. This means that although they do not have the disease, they might go on to develop it, so they have been given a shorter course of antibiotics.

Dr Bryant said it was unsurprising that they had found more cases during screening of pupils who had been absent or ill for the earlier sessions. All but a very few pupils have now been screened and if there are further cases result ing from the Crown Hills infection, they are likely to be among relatives and friends of pupils with the disease who are still being traced and screened.

In the last few days, the authority said, a separate case of tuberculosis has been identified in a teacher at Ratcliffe college, but it is not thought to be connected with the Crown Hills outbreak.

Leicestershire normally averages around 200 cases a year and 17 or 18 deaths - a rate that is among the highest in the UK. Most are in Leicester city itself and 76% are in people of Indian ethnicity.

Screening arrangements are also being put into place at Whitehall primary school after a member of staff was found to have the infectious form of the disease. Lynda Valentine, the headteacher, said the staff member had already begun treatment and was no longer infectious and that lessons were carrying on as normal.

"It is an isolated case from our point of view and is not connected to the cases at Crown Hills as far as we know," said Mrs Valentine.

Five schools in total now have one or more case, but Dr Bryant stressed that the high incidence in Leicestershire meant that they could all be unconnected.

"We haven't identified links except that these people all live in Leicestershire," she said. Molecular tests are now taking place, however, to see whether they have the same strain of the disease.

Dr Bryant said the Crown Hills strain was not a more virulent form of the disease but it had been more efficiently spread than usual.

It was possible this could be because whoever was the original source of the infection was "an unusually efficient transmitter of the disease" rather than due to some peculiarity of the strain.

fields.headline: NHS faces £3.9bn negligence claims
fields.trailText: The NHS is facing claims totalling £3.9bn in England for negligence by hospital doctors and other staff, according to a report today from the national audit office, the official watchdog on public spending.
fields.body:
The NHS is facing claims totalling £3.9bn in England for negligence by hospital doctors and other staff, according to a report today from the national audit office, the official watchdog on public spending.

The 23,000 claims outstanding total £2.6bn, with another £1.3bn estimated as the likely cost of claims not yet received for mishaps which have already occurred.

Sums paid in damages and costs to settle negligence claims have spiralled from £50m in 1997-98, through £107m in 1998-99, to £386m in 1999-00.

The study, which excludes claims against GPs, is the first survey to look at all negligence claims in every NHS trust in England. It paints a picture of a slow, expensive and inefficient system in which claims settled in 1999-00 had taken an average of 5 years and costs often exceeded the damages received.

Eight per cent of cases took 10 years or more. The report highlights a huge backlog of old cases, with claims which are still open averaging more than eight years on the books and 22% of open claims dating back more than 10 years.

For nearly half the claims settled in 1999-00, legal and other costs were higher than the damages. For settlements up to £50,000, the costs were higher than the damages in two out of three cases.

The rising bills are partly down to increased numbers of patients suing: the rate of clinical negligence claims went up by 72% from 1990 to 1998. The size of settlements has also risen following a court ruling covering a number of test cases which changed the way awards are calculated.

The report recommends new ways of dealing with claims, for instance by mediation rather than litigation, or by claims managers who can offer a range of remedies tailored to patients' wants.

A "package" approach recommended by the report could include a reasonable settlement offer at an early stage, an explanation, meetings with medical staff to explore what went wrong, an apology, and action to prevent a recurrence.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "The NAO is absolutely right to highlight the issue of rising claims, but the fact is that the total £3.9bn is an estimated figure for potential costs spread over future years."

In 1999-00 the NHS in England paid out under £400m in clinical negligence costs, while the total NHS budget in England was just over £40bn.

"There are two ways to reduce clinical negligence costs. We are working on reducing clinical errors in the first place by introducing an independent patients safety agency to record errors, mistakes and near misses, and to speed up the process of sorting them out", said the spokesman. "But we also need to ensure that money spent on claims is going to patients who deserve it - not on spiralling legal costs."

webTitle: Why football may stay at home

fields.headline: Why football may stay at home
fields.standfirst:
Vivek Chaudhary says the capital may still be the best venue
Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: As a salvage plan swings into action, it is becoming clear that we may end up with a national stadium close to the plans originally submitted around three years ago.
fields.body:
If the government and the Football Association had paid a little more attention three years ago they would saved themselves a lot of embarrassment and a lot of expense. The cost of keeping Wembley open is thought to be around £2m a month.

As a ministerial working group gets underway today on how to salvage the farce that is the Wembley project, all the indications are that the country is going to end up with a national stadium close to the plans originally submitted around three years ago.

An 80,000-capacity stadium with the frills of a hotel and office space was envisaged by the Chelsea chairman Ken Bates who was also the former chairman of Wembley. A straightforward stadium would cost under £200m to build on the site currently occupied by Wembley stadium.

The FA, government and Sport England feel tied to Wembley. While there may be a number of options outside the capital, which have better transport facilities and lower construction costs, Wembley has emerged as the place where the national stadium must be constructed.

WNSL, the FA subsidary company set up to oversee the project, said at its board meeting yesterday that it was still committed to building a national stadium at Wembley. Present at the meeting was the FA chief exeuctive Adam Crozier, who only a day earlier had said that England could do without a national stadium. The message coming from those involved in the project is loud and clear - if it is going to be built then it has to be Wembley.

There are a number of advantages to keeping the national stadium at Wembley, the most important among them a financial one. If the stadium stays in north-west London then £120m of lottery money given to the FA to buy the Wembley site would not have to be paid back. This would save a lot of administrative hassle and arguing, which is likely to take place given that all the money has been spent.

The bulk of the £120m has been used to buy the Wembley site, which is now owned by the FA. If a new location was to be found then not only would that money have to be returned to Sport England but more money would have to be spent on buying new land for the stadium. This would push up costs, something the project can ill afford.

Officials involved in the Wembley project believe that it is also the best location in the country, despite constant criticism from those who attend matches there.

When invitations were first invited from English cities for the national stadium's location, Birmingham followed by Manchester was considered to have the best site. However, Sport England, which was involved in the selection process was soon informed by transport specialists that there would be severe congestion on motorways around the city with the M6 and M42 clogged for several hours after matches.

Wembley does not have the same problems. It is well serviced by a number of stations and despite complaints, football fans can get away relatively easy.

Congestion on the motorways still remains a problem with Birmigham's current attempt to become the national stadium's new home.

Manchester is the second favourite city to host the national stadium. However, it is felt that the stadium currently being constructed for next year's Commonwealth Games in the city is not big enough for a national stadium. At its peak the Manchester stadium would only have a capacity of 50,000 and it is to be the home of Manchester City.

The Wembley area is some of the poorest in the country and both Brent council and central government are keen to ensure that the national stadium is constructed there as a way of sparking economic regeneration. According to the local authority, around 20,000 jobs depend on the stadium being built and that not locating it at Wembley would cost the area an estimated £170m.

The ministerial working group appointed to look into the Wembley debacle was originally formed to examine the economic benefits of the Commonwealth Games on Manchester. The same group believes that the national stadium could benefit the area of Brent.

A Wembley official said: "We all know that the stadium comes in for a lot of criticism but the location of a new national stadium has been carefully thought out. We examined a lot of research. Wembley might not be the best place for a massive stadium but it's miles ahead of the others."

New planning permission would also have to be sought if the national stadium is moved to another site. This would cause further delays given that it is a long process to begin with.

Both the culture minister Chris Smith and the home secretary Jack Straw have expressed support for a new national stadium at Wembley. They are supported by the FA and Sport England. The feeling is that the entire project has been delayed enough and that starting from scratch at a new location is something that the project just cannot afford.

An 80,000-capacity stadium with the frills of a hotel and office space was envisaged by the Chelsea chairman Ken Bates who was also the former chairman of Wembley. A straightforward stadium would cost under £200m to build on the site currently occupied by Wembley stadium. The FA, government and Sport England feel tied to Wembley. While there may be a number of options outside the capital, which have better transport facilities and lower construction costs, Wembley has emerged as the place where the national stadium must be constructed. WNSL, the FA subsidary company set up to oversee the project, said at its board meeting yesterday that it was still committed to building a national stadium at Wembley. Present at the meeting was the FA chief exeuctive Adam Crozier, who only a day earlier had said that England could do without a national stadium. The message coming from those involved in the project is loud and clear - if it is going to be built then it has to be Wembley. There are a number of advantages to keeping the national stadium at Wembley, the most important among them a financial one. If the stadium stays in north-west London then £120m of lottery money given to the FA to buy the Wembley site would not have to be paid back. This would save a lot of administrative hassle and arguing, which is likely to take place given that all the money has been spent. The bulk of the £120m has been used to buy the Wembley site, which is now owned by the FA. If a new location was to be found then not only would that money have to be returned to Sport England but more money would have to be spent on buying new land for the stadium. This would push up costs, something the project can ill afford. Officials involved in the Wembley project believe that it is also the best location in the country, despite constant criticism from those who attend matches there. When invitations were first invited from English cities for the national stadium's location, Birmingham followed by Manchester was considered to have the best site. However, Sport England, which was involved in the selection process was soon informed by transport specialists that there would be severe congestion on motorways around the city with the M6 and M42 clogged for several hours after matches. Wembley does not have the same problems. It is well serviced by a number of stations and despite complaints, football fans can get away relatively easy. Congestion on the motorways still remains a problem with Birmigham's current attempt to become the national stadium's new home. Manchester is the second favourite city to host the national stadium. However, it is felt that the stadium currently being constructed for next year's Commonwealth Games in the city is not big enough for a national stadium. At its peak the Manchester stadium would only have a capacity of 50,000 and it is to be the home of Manchester City. The Wembley area is some of the poorest in the country and both Brent council and central government are keen to ensure that the national stadium is constructed there as a way of sparking economic regeneration. According to the local authority, around 20,000 jobs depend on the stadium being built and that not locating it at Wembley would cost the area an estimated £170m. The ministerial working group appointed to look into the Wembley debacle was originally formed to examine the economic benefits of the Commonwealth Games on Manchester. The same group believes that the national stadium could benefit the area of Brent. A Wembley official said: "We all know that the stadium comes in for a lot of criticism but the location of a new national stadium has been carefully thought out. We examined a lot of research. Wembley might not be the best place for a massive stadium but it's miles ahead of the others." New planning permission would also have to be sought if the national stadium is moved to another site. This would cause further delays given that it is a long process to begin with. Both the culture minister Chris Smith and the home secretary Jack Straw have expressed support for a new national stadium at Wembley. They are supported by the FA and Sport England. The feeling is that the entire project has been delayed enough and that starting from scratch at a new location is something that the project just cannot afford.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Stadium stasis
fields.standfirst:
Manchester or Birmingham have a claim

Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: Manchester or Birmingham have a claim.
fields.body:
"It's pretty humiliating for the image of this country," admits one senior cabinet minister, "that Britain keeps screwing up these big projects." What he had in mind was the attempt to build a national stadium, rapidly taking the place of the Millennium Dome as a monument to national incompetence and cock-up.

Now the Football Association has thrown up its hands in defeat, admitting that it cannot finance the project alone and that the government needs to step in. This despite the fact that football is the country's richest sport and the FA has just signed a television deal worth £400m over three years. What should the government do? Walk away and leave football to sort itself out - or take control?

The dilemma is a sharp one - and not only for those who care about sport. For this choice goes to the heart of a wider conundrum faced by the government: to what extent can the private sector be trusted with national responsibilities? When must government take charge?

The previous attempt, which the FA has now declared dead, was a compromise between the two approaches. The FA were meant to steward the project, but they received public money - in the form of £120m from the lottery - to help them on their way.

This is the same half-in, half-out principle which worked such magic with the dome: the government claiming partial responsibility, and spending public money, but getting an outside concern to run the project. Indeed, this is the spirit which animates the entire public-private partnership approach which has so bewitched Labour.

The stadium saga, like the dome and the sorry story of the railways, suggests that such hybrid set-ups do not work. A clearer arrangement would be either private or public - and not this messy amalgam of the two.

The private option would simply tell the FA to get on with it - not implausible, given the huge wealth of that organisation. The FA could underwrite the entire £400m loan needed to build the stadium, as the City requested - and then rent it out to concert promoters and any other sport which wanted to use it. They would soon recover their costs. The FA might well build a football stadium, rather than the multi-purpose structure sought by the original brief. But, since they were paying for it, that would be their prerogative.

If that does not appeal to the government, which wants a national stadium capable of hosting more than football, then it must take the lead. It can build the new venue itself using lottery money - and then charge the FA, athletics or any other customers for use of it. It, too, would surely pay its way before too long.

Either option would work. What cannot make sense is for the FA to take public money for a stadium that serves only its own sport. Nor can it be right for government to demand an asset for national purpose - and yet ask the private sector, with its own motives, to do the job on its behalf. If this is truly a national resource, then the government cannot shirk its responsibility. Jack Straw and his new committee should get a grip on the venture, drive it through and make it work.

And Mr Straw should think imaginatively. The only argument for a national stadium remaining in London - which already has more than its fair share of national jewels - is if the capital plans to bid for a future Olympic games. Otherwise the case for Birmingham or Manchester, served by improved, integrated transport systems, must be compelling. If Labour is serious about decentralising, it could demonstrate its commitment by devolving our national game.

fields.headline: The People's Paradise crumbles
fields.standfirst:
The North presents a new face - much like the old one

Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: From the upper floors of the hotel, the city spreads out as a series of dark patches between apartment blocks. Not a single street lamp can be seen. Like the term itself, the People's Paradise has fallen into disuse.
fields.body:
From the upper floors of the hotel, the city spreads out as a series of dark patches between apartment blocks. Not a single street lamp can be seen. The neon signs of a dozen restaurants shine along Changgwang Street, but the doors are locked and fairy lights flicker eerily over the empty tables.

Like the term itself, the People's Paradise has fallen into disuse.

The Great General Kim Jong-il was reported last night to be in "open and lively mood" but the large group of journalists accompanying Chris Patten, Javier Solana and the Swedish prime minister Göran Persson for a ground-breaking EU visit remained a troublesome novelty.

"You must stick together and act with a team spirit," we were told. As a new day dawned, North Korea, now in its fifth year of economic crisis, was harder to read than its diplomacy.

Groups of travellers waiting outside the station for trains (often delayed for hours by the power cuts ) ate their midday rice cheerfully: several offered me a spare pair of chopsticks to join in.

Parties of schoolkids up from the provinces to view the city's revolutionary monuments stopped to buy lollipops: there were queues for roadside phones, and more bicycles than in the past.

Elderly women gossiped outside the austere apartment blocks; children played with hoops and sticks.

In a city which used to be obsessively clean, cats and dogs are now allowed as pets and one flat-dweller opposite the station has turned his balcony into a pigeon loft.

Yet the shops remain as lifeless and empty as on my previ ous visits to Pyongyang - the first occasion 25 years ago and twice more in the 1980s.

"People don't need to buy goods so much," explains North Korean journalist Sin Song Chal. "Our government supplies the essentials through the public distribution system. There may be less quantity compared to the past, but we equalise the rich and the poor."

This still does not explain the difficulty in seeing anyone, anywhere, buy anything at all. An entire department store was void of customers. A smaller shop, also empty, contained nothing but plastic school satchels. Another had dusty displays of hundreds of identical soft drink bottles. Most expensive goods seemed to be only for display.

Finally I found a shop which by contrast was buzzing with activity. Behind a long counter, eight watch-repairers had their heads bent in work while customers waited. At the end, five sewing-machines whirred over clothes being mended.

The staff smiled at me, content in their work. The lesson seemed to be that North Koreans have to make do rather than buy new.

North Koreans also have become used to severe power shortages. The slowdown so visible in the capital is hardly surprising when Korean officials explain that per capita GDP is three to four times less than before the crisis began.

North Koreans stress three causes: the repeated floods since 1996, the loss of aid - particularly in the form of cheap oil - from the former Soviet Union, and alleged western economic pressure.

UN experts acknowledge these factors but point out (usually in private) that the system was failing before.

On my last visit, workers lounged outside a showcase factory in front of workshops where the machinery was idle. They wore flat caps as in the propaganda posters but without the smiles.

Apart from a few furtive vegetable sellers, food was strictly rationed, though said to be a first step to communism, not because of shortages. A child nutritionist detected early signs of stunted growth among young children, long before Unicef in the late 1990s.

Whatever else may have changed, the Great General is as dominant as his father, the Great Leader, Kim Il-sung, was before. "What other world leader," a young interpreter said excitedly, "would spend his birthday giving on-the-spot guidance." For better or for worse, no detail seems too small to require his personal intervention (as the South Koreans discovered last year when setting up the North-South summit).

There is a new tram line in Pyongyang, packed during the rush hour, and a few double-decker buses. "The Great General bought the buses because of his love of the people," the interpreter enthused.

In a typical on-the-spot visit last month, the Great General inspected a new goat farm established by an army unit in order "to learn about its construction and goat breeding".

Kim Jong-il's rise to power has leant heavily on promoting his father's Juche doctrine that man should be master of his own environment. Kim, said a Kim Il-sung University graduate last night, is "a genius of philosophy".

On my first visit to North Korea in 1976, belief in Juche seemed widespread. When struck down by pneumonia, and treated by the leadership's own doctors, I was lectured at my bedside by a professor in Kim Il-sungism whom I privately labelled the "high priest".

Ten years later the cult appeared more routine, as Kim the Younger built up a new elite of post-revolutionary leaders more interested in the good life. Planeloads of foreign goodies began to be imported from abroad and the Changgwang Street restaurants were opened.

It would be unsurprising today if there were fewer genuine believers, although those questioned yesterday spoke with an apparent fervour.

Yet there is a strong sense of timewarp in Pyongyang. The road from the airport is as empty as ever; the biggest change is the increase in massive monuments. The late Kim Il-sung's presidential palace has been turned into a memorial, served by a separate tram line - completely empty of passengers yesterday. The Arch of Triumph - slightly larger than the other one in Paris - is now matched by the Tower of Eternity with its message that the Great Leader Will Live with us Forever.

How and when the system will change from within remains as baffling a question as ever. "We believe that nothing has changed on the ground," an EU official says, "and that North Korea as far as its daily life and the (political) message to the people is the same."

My 1976 Korean language textbook suggests that it is appropriate for a visitor to call out "Let's Mutilate US Imperialism". Though that sounds dated now, Mr Bush's re-labelling of North Korea as a potential enemy will reinforce mutual feelings of hostility.

"Perhaps we shall tell the Americans to take their aid and go home," an angry young North Korean said last night. "It's like a game of ping-pong: we have to hit the ball back."

In the longer-term, the problem of transition must be solved, as South Korean president Kim Dae-jung has urged Kim Jong-il for the last three years.

Shortly before the EU delegation arrived, the Great General saw a comedy about the construction of a new motorway by "youth heroes". He said that it showed how young Koreans could create miracles with their bare hands even when "the country was hard pressed for everything".

The motorways are as empty as they have been for the last decade. The future of North Korea, and perhaps of the Great General too, must depend on whether Korea's youth will continue to have faith in his miracles.

Out in the cold

 Since the second world war ended, the Korean peninsula has been divided in two

 Chinese and Russian-backed North Korean troops invaded the south in 1950. The Korean war, involving US and British troops, left more than 2m dead

 The capital, Pyongyang, is at the heart of one of the most centrally planned and isolated economies. State-owned industry produces nearly all manufactured goods

 With 1m recruits, North Korea's army has been ranked as the fifth largest in the world

 Kim Jong-il is reputed to visit military bases, presenting troops with gold-plated machine guns and binoculars
