webTitle: Trouble for old masters of the auction

fields.headline: Trouble for old masters of the auction
fields.standfirst: Former Christie's and Sotheby's chairmen accused of colluding over price fixing
fields.trailText: The US government yesterday indicted Sir Anthony Tennant, a pillar of the British business establishment, and Alfred Taubman, the US shopping mall tycoon, for masterminding an alleged price-fixing scandal at the world's leading art auction houses.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in New York and Julia Finch
fields.body:
The US government yesterday indicted Sir Anthony Tennant, a pillar of the British business establishment, and Alfred Taubman, the US shopping mall tycoon, for masterminding an alleged price-fixing scandal at the world's leading art auction houses.

Sir Anthony, best known as the man called in to restore the reputation of Guinness after the 1980s share scandal, and the former chairman of Christie's, and Mr Taubman, the owner and former chairman of Sotheby's, face up to three years in prison if they are found guilty of colluding to fix commission charges - but Sir Anthony immediately made it clear he would refuse to answer the charges.

Yesterday's criminal charges follow a four-year investigation into the £2.5bn a year art auction market which has thrown the rarefied and exclusive world into turmoil.

The scandal - which has already led to a $512m (£360m) fine for the two auction houses - now threatens to drag both septuagenarians into a courtroom after impressive careers on either side of the Atlantic. The bulk of the evidence against them - said to include memos and other documents - has been provided by their previous underlings, who insist that they are not prepared to take any blame.

The two auction houses, which control more than 90% of the world's live auctions of art works, jewellery and furniture, are said to have conspired to fix prices for a period of six years, and the US department of justice claims the arrangement was thrashed out in private meetings between Mr Taubman and Sir Anthony. The former Christie's chairman admits the two men held meetings, but insists they were "innocent" and that there was no collusion to rip off the auction houses' wealthy clients.

The justice department said the two undercut each other's offers to sellers, costing sellers their principal bargaining tool. It calculates that the agreement cost US sellers at least $400m in commissions. James A Griffin, deputy attorney general in charge of the criminal antitrust enforcement programme, said: "This case will show that these individuals mastered the art of price fixing."

Last night Sir Anthony, 70, said he would refuse to answer the charges. They are not a criminal offence in the UK or throughout Europe and therefore the US authorities have no power to extradite. But Sir Anthony will never again be able to travel to America. If he did he would be arrested.

British citizen

In a statement, lawyers for the former Guinness boss said: "Sir Anthony wishes to make it clear that he is completely innocent of any involvement in price fixing.

"As a UK subject, Sir Anthony is not subject to the jurisdiction of the US courts and, accordingly, he will not be taking part in any pending proceedings."

The statement added that Sir Anthony's role as chairman of the auction house was to "chair the board and to perform high-level ambassadorial and client relationship duties on the company's behalf".

It added that "executive responsibilities rested with the chief executive". Sir Anthony's chief executive was Christopher Davidge, who stepped down from his post after agreeing to help the US authorities in return for immunity from prosecution. To retain that immunity, however, he must be able to show that he was acting under orders.

A friend of Sir Anthony's said last night: "He won't go and stand trial. He is 70 and he has done nothing wrong. Why should he spend a great bundle of his time and money on something he has no responsibility to answer? His job was just to go round shaking hands and being nice to clients. He has no faith in the US justice system."

However, in refusing to take the stand and deny that he colluded in the case, Sir Anthony will strengthen the US government's case against Mr Taubman. The 75-year-old Detroit shopping mall tycoon, who bought Sotheby's in 1983, is expected to defend himself vigorously against charges that he fixed prices in a bid to increase profits.

In a statement yesterday, he said: "I am surprised and deeply disappointed by the charges made against me. I am absolutely innocent."

Mr Taubman has conducted a very public defence of his career ever since his former deputy, Diana "DeDe" Brooks implicated him in the case last year. He took a lie detector test, which he said yesterday proved his innocence. "The truth is on my side. While any trial is difficult, I look forward to the opportunity to clear my name in court."

Price fixing

The scandal first unfolded when senior executives at Christie's - which was bought by French billionaire François Pinault in 1998 - decided to cooperate with the US authorities in return for immunity from prosecution. They outlined details of price fixing which led to the $512m fine to pay for damages last year.

DeDe Brooks, one of the best-known and most powerful women in the global art world when she was the chief executive of Sotheby's, appeared in court to plead guilty to antitrust violations last October. She said she was acting "at the direction of a superior at Sotheby's". Her only superior was Mr Taubman.

Mr Taubman again refuted his former protege's statement yesterday and said she was acting "without my authorisation".

He has sought to subpoena documents from Christie's and question Mr Davidge, who left Christie's in December 1999 and is reportedly travelling in India.

Mr Taubman resigned as chairman of the company last year and is understood to have put his 63% stake up for sale.

Sir Anthony, who receives a £500,000 a year pension from Guinness, was relaxing at his Hampshire home yesterday. He was said to have been expecting the indictment. His name has been on "border watch" in the US for some time, and he recently stood down as a senior adviser to US investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter as he was unable to travel to the US.

Michael Sovern, who took over as chairman of Sotheby's when Mr Taubman stepped down last year, said: "We cannot but feel for Alfred Taubman and his family at this difficult time."

He made no further comment, apart from stressing that all civil and criminal charges against the company itself had been settled.

Accused: Sir Anthony Tennant

Sir Anthony Tennant was the "Mr Clean" brought in to restore Guinness's reputation after the share-rigging scandal of the 80s which put the brewer's chief executive Ernest Saunders in jail.

By the time he left Guinness in 1993 Sir Anthony had become a grandee of British business.

Educated at Eton and Cambridge, and after a spell in the Scots Guards, he spent his career in the brewing and drinks industry before joining the auctioneers Christies.

He was knighted in 1992 and now chairs the Royal Academy Trust. He retired from Guinness on a £500,000 a year pension.

Recently he has taken a campaign to the high court to prevent the Olympic champion marksman Richard Faulds from practising his shooting on his family's Hampshire farm . Sir Anthony claimed the noise affected house prices.
Julia Finch


Accused: Alfred Taubman

Adolph Alfred Taubman had made himself a billionaire many times over through a successful shopping mall business by the early 1980s. But his life lacked glamour.

That changed in 1983 when he married a former Miss Israel 22 years his junior and was approached by Sotheby's about a takeover.

For the avid art buyer, the chance to own the 256-year-old auctioneer was a dream come true. It was also said to be a fitting wedding present for his wife.

The couple were soon a fixture at all the best parties. They flew in their own Gulfstream jet, owned five homes, which they decorated with priceless works of art, and had a retinue of servants.

His fortunes survived the economic downturn in the early 1990s before being rocked by the price-fixing scandal, which has already cost him personally $156m.
Jane Martinson
fields.bodyText: The US government yesterday indicted Sir Anthony Tennant, a pillar of the British business establishment, and Alfred Taubman, the US shopping mall tycoon, for masterminding an alleged price-fixing scandal at the world's leading art auction houses. Sir Anthony, best known as the man called in to restore the reputation of Guinness after the 1980s share scandal, and the former chairman of Christie's, and Mr Taubman, the owner and former chairman of Sotheby's, face up to three years in prison if they are found guilty of colluding to fix commission charges - but Sir Anthony immediately made it clear he would refuse to answer the charges. Yesterday's criminal charges follow a four-year investigation into the £2.5bn a year art auction market which has thrown the rarefied and exclusive world into turmoil. The scandal - which has already led to a $512m (£360m) fine for the two auction houses - now threatens to drag both septuagenarians into a courtroom after impressive careers on either side of the Atlantic. The bulk of the evidence against them - said to include memos and other documents - has been provided by their previous underlings, who insist that they are not prepared to take any blame. The two auction houses, which control more than 90% of the world's live auctions of art works, jewellery and furniture, are said to have conspired to fix prices for a period of six years, and the US department of justice claims the arrangement was thrashed out in private meetings between Mr Taubman and Sir Anthony. The former Christie's chairman admits the two men held meetings, but insists they were "innocent" and that there was no collusion to rip off the auction houses' wealthy clients. The justice department said the two undercut each other's offers to sellers, costing sellers their principal bargaining tool. It calculates that the agreement cost US sellers at least $400m in commissions. James A Griffin, deputy attorney general in charge of the criminal antitrust enforcement programme, said: "This case will show that these individuals mastered the art of price fixing." Last night Sir Anthony, 70, said he would refuse to answer the charges. They are not a criminal offence in the UK or throughout Europe and therefore the US authorities have no power to extradite. But Sir Anthony will never again be able to travel to America. If he did he would be arrested. British citizen In a statement, lawyers for the former Guinness boss said: "Sir Anthony wishes to make it clear that he is completely innocent of any involvement in price fixing. "As a UK subject, Sir Anthony is not subject to the jurisdiction of the US courts and, accordingly, he will not be taking part in any pending proceedings." The statement added that Sir Anthony's role as chairman of the auction house was to "chair the board and to perform high-level ambassadorial and client relationship duties on the company's behalf". It added that "executive responsibilities rested with the chief executive". Sir Anthony's chief executive was Christopher Davidge, who stepped down from his post after agreeing to help the US authorities in return for immunity from prosecution. To retain that immunity, however, he must be able to show that he was acting under orders. A friend of Sir Anthony's said last night: "He won't go and stand trial. He is 70 and he has done nothing wrong. Why should he spend a great bundle of his time and money on something he has no responsibility to answer? His job was just to go round shaking hands and being nice to clients. He has no faith in the US justice system." However, in refusing to take the stand and deny that he colluded in the case, Sir Anthony will strengthen the US government's case against Mr Taubman. The 75-year-old Detroit shopping mall tycoon, who bought Sotheby's in 1983, is expected to defend himself vigorously against charges that he fixed prices in a bid to increase profits. In a statement yesterday, he said: "I am surprised and deeply disappointed by the charges made against me. I am absolutely innocent." Mr Taubman has conducted a very public defence of his career ever since his former deputy, Diana "DeDe" Brooks implicated him in the case last year. He took a lie detector test, which he said yesterday proved his innocence. "The truth is on my side. While any trial is difficult, I look forward to the opportunity to clear my name in court." Price fixing The scandal first unfolded when senior executives at Christie's - which was bought by French billionaire François Pinault in 1998 - decided to cooperate with the US authorities in return for immunity from prosecution. They outlined details of price fixing which led to the $512m fine to pay for damages last year. DeDe Brooks, one of the best-known and most powerful women in the global art world when she was the chief executive of Sotheby's, appeared in court to plead guilty to antitrust violations last October. She said she was acting "at the direction of a superior at Sotheby's". Her only superior was Mr Taubman. Mr Taubman again refuted his former protege's statement yesterday and said she was acting "without my authorisation". He has sought to subpoena documents from Christie's and question Mr Davidge, who left Christie's in December 1999 and is reportedly travelling in India. Mr Taubman resigned as chairman of the company last year and is understood to have put his 63% stake up for sale. Sir Anthony, who receives a £500,000 a year pension from Guinness, was relaxing at his Hampshire home yesterday. He was said to have been expecting the indictment. His name has been on "border watch" in the US for some time, and he recently stood down as a senior adviser to US investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter as he was unable to travel to the US. Michael Sovern, who took over as chairman of Sotheby's when Mr Taubman stepped down last year, said: "We cannot but feel for Alfred Taubman and his family at this difficult time." He made no further comment, apart from stressing that all civil and criminal charges against the company itself had been settled. Accused: Sir Anthony Tennant Sir Anthony Tennant was the "Mr Clean" brought in to restore Guinness's reputation after the share-rigging scandal of the 80s which put the brewer's chief executive Ernest Saunders in jail. By the time he left Guinness in 1993 Sir Anthony had become a grandee of British business. Educated at Eton and Cambridge, and after a spell in the Scots Guards, he spent his career in the brewing and drinks industry before joining the auctioneers Christies. He was knighted in 1992 and now chairs the Royal Academy Trust. He retired from Guinness on a £500,000 a year pension. Recently he has taken a campaign to the high court to prevent the Olympic champion marksman Richard Faulds from practising his shooting on his family's Hampshire farm . Sir Anthony claimed the noise affected house prices. Julia Finch Accused: Alfred Taubman Adolph Alfred Taubman had made himself a billionaire many times over through a successful shopping mall business by the early 1980s. But his life lacked glamour. That changed in 1983 when he married a former Miss Israel 22 years his junior and was approached by Sotheby's about a takeover. For the avid art buyer, the chance to own the 256-year-old auctioneer was a dream come true. It was also said to be a fitting wedding present for his wife. The couple were soon a fixture at all the best parties. They flew in their own Gulfstream jet, owned five homes, which they decorated with priceless works of art, and had a retinue of servants. His fortunes survived the economic downturn in the early 1990s before being rocked by the price-fixing scandal, which has already cost him personally $156m. Jane Martinson

fields.headline: Medium-sized poems
fields.standfirst:
Text messaging unleashes creative forces

More internet news
fields.trailText: Text messaging unleashes creative forces.
fields.body:
A church in Hanover, Germany, has found a new way of spreading the message. This afternoon it will relay part of its service by text message (SMS) to anyone who has registered on their web site.

One of the problems it has had to overcome is reducing the 325 characters in the Our Father prayer to the 160 maximum in a text message.

This problem will by now be well known to those who have taken part in the Guardian's pioneering SMS poetry competition which attracted almost 7,500 entries (see our Online section today for the winning poems). A unique feature was that each entrant was sent all the shortlisted poems to their mobile phone (one a day for seven days): they then sent a message back with a mark out of 10 - so the outcome was decided by the participants.

Text messaging has experienced explosive growth (900m a month are exchanged in the UK), mainly as a condensed way of communicating. Our aim was to test the creative potential of the new medium and were delighted to find that most entrants had never written a poem before. Texting is often blamed for a deterioration in the standard of English. Ironically, the winning entry is about the poet's grandmother complaining that the standard of her letters had declined since going to university. But she, and thousand of others, proved how the marriage of language to new technology can unleash fresh creativity.

Six of the seven poems on the short list were written by women and four out of the five winners came from the north of England. Thousands of people wrote a poem for the first time in a contest that had no rules. Text messaging came from nowhere. It never occurred to the designers that the tiny 160-character space they left in the phones would trigger the fastest growing cult in recent memory. Out of this may now come a new form of creative expression. But whether it drives people back to church as well remains to be seen.

fields.headline: Met chairman's son 'caught with drugs' case
fields.standfirst:
Peer accused of delaying report of nightclub seizure

Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The chairman of the Metropolitan police authority took more than two days to inform police that his son had allegedly been caught with class A drugs at a nightclub.
fields.body:
The chairman of the Metropolitan police authority took more than two days to inform police that his son had allegedly been caught with class A drugs at a nightclub.

Lord Harris of Haringey heard early on Saturday that door staff at the Fridge club in Brixton, south London, had claimed to have found ecstasy tablets on his 17-year-old son Matthew.

But Lord Harris did not refer the matter to Scotland Yard until Monday - after a national newspaper had contacted him about the episode.

If detectives discover that Lord Harris tried to cover up the incident, it could make his position as chairman of the Metropolitan police authority, which oversees the running of the capital's force, untenable.

His office insists that he always planned to go to the police after consulting the parents of his son's friends who were at the club. A spokeswoman denied that he had been prompted to go to the police only when it became clear that the incident was to be made public.

The episode also puts the spotlight on how nightclubs deal with visitors found in pos session of drugs. The Fridge admitted that its policy was to destroy drugs on the spot and inform parents rather than immediately handing those found with drugs over to the police.

Lord Harris, 47, who was made a life peer by Tony Blair in 1998 and is the leader of the Labour group on the Greater London authority, was telephoned by staff at the Fridge at 12.40am on Saturday.

He was told that his son and a 16-year-old friend had been caught allegedly with almost 50 tablets between them. It is claimed that Matthew Harris had 19 pills.

The pills were destroyed in front of the young men, security staff and management and the pair were sent home in a taxi. The peer did not make a formal report of the incident until soon before 7pm on Monday when he and his son went to Brixton police station. By then, it is claimed, he had been approached by a newspaper and thus knew that the incident would almost certainly come to light.

A spokeswoman for Lord Harris said he had asked the police to treat his son as they would anyone else. The spokeswoman said he had always planned to go to the police af ter speaking with the parents of the nine friends Matthew was with. He had also been busy in the run-up to the May Day protests and had been awaiting a hernia operation.

Andrew Czezowski, owner of the Fridge, said Matthew Harris and his friend had not been given any preferential treatment.

He said if a clubber was suspected of dealing drugs, the police were called. However if he or she was found with a "smallish" amount, the drugs would be destroyed, the incident recorded in a logbook and the person ejected. In this case, Mr Czezowski said the amount was considered "smallish".

But Lord Harris said that the club had told him that they had informed the police, but had been told to "deal with the situation themselves".

Even though the substances allegedly carried by Matthew Harris and his friend have been destroyed, it is still possible that they could be cautioned or charged.

Lord Harris has been a member of the London drug policy forum since 1990. As the first chairman of the Metropolitan police authority he is responsible for helping to frame policy for the force.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man remanded in Coghlan case | MPs attack housing body | Bomber given time to appeal | Prison officer sacked | 20 held in swoop on immigrants
fields.body:
Man remanded in Coghlan case

Gary Day, 32, was remanded in custody when he appeared before Huddersfield magistrates yesterday charged with the manslaughter of Monica Coghlan, the former prostitute at the centre of the Lord Archer libel trial.

MPs attack housing body

The Commons public accounts committee yesterday attacked the housing corporation for its weak oversight and failure to act fast enough to stop a corruption scandal that cost Focus, the biggest housing association in the west midlands, over £1.5m.

Bomber given time to appeal

Lockerbie bomber Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, jailed for life for the murder of 270 people, was yesterday granted another six weeks to submit the grounds for his appeal.

Prison officer sacked

An officer from Frankland prison, Durham, was sacked yesterday for wearing swastika tie pins and a German SS badge to work. He was warned not to wear nazi symbols but refused to comply.

20 held in swoop on immigrants

Police and immigration officers detained more than 20 suspected illegal immigrants from eastern Europe in Southampton yesterday. So far Operation Leighton, Britain's biggest operation against illegal immigrants, has resulted in 113 arrests.

fields.headline: Morning after pill challenged
fields.trailText: Birth control organisations yesterday expressed their "surprise and disappointment" after an anti-abortion group was given permission to proceed with a high court action to halt counter sales of emergency contraception to women over 16.
fields.body:
Birth control organisations yesterday expressed their "surprise and disappointment" after an anti-abortion group was given permission to proceed with a high court action to halt counter sales of emergency contraception to women over 16.

Women have been able to buy the Levonelle-2 "morning after" pill from pharmacists without a prescription since January. But the Society for the Protection of Unborn Children claimed the change was unlawful because it permitted a criminal offence - the administration or supply of poisons or instruments with the intent to procure miscarriage - under a law dating back to 1861.

Granting permission for a full hearing, which will take place by July, Mr Justice Scott Baker said there was "an arguable case on what is fundamentally a very important question".

He added that it would be better to deal with it in the civil courts than via private prosecutions of pharmacists for supplying the pill.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health confirmed that the government would contest the high court application.

fields.headline: Policeman cleared over killing
fields.trailText: A police marksman was cleared yesterday of unlawfully killing a man he shot during an authorised raid on a flat in East Sussex.
fields.body:
A police marksman was cleared yesterday of unlawfully killing a man he shot during an authorised raid on a flat in East Sussex.

PC Christopher Sherwood, 34, admitted firing a single shot at James Ashley, 39, during the operation in St Leonards, which was launched at 4am on January 15 1998.

But PC Sherwood told the Old Bailey that he acted in self defence believing, albeit mistakenly, that Mr Ashley was about to shoot him.

The Sussex police officer went on trial last month.

The judge, Mrs Justice Rafferty, ruled yesterday there was no evidence to suggest that PC Sherwood had fired his gun "in anything other than lawful self-defence". She directed the jury to return not guilty verdicts. Following the acquittal, PC Sherwood's solicitor, Ben Brandon, read a statement on behalf of the officer.

"I am hugely relieved and pleased," it said.

"I greatly regret that a man was killed by a shot I fired."

Mr Ashley's brother Tony, 32, a customs and excise worker from Dingle, Liverpool, said his family was disappointed at the outcome of the case.

fields.headline: Murder victim's heart donated
fields.trailText: A Derry murder victim may have saved his uncle's life after his heart was donated to his critically ill relative.
fields.body:
A Derry murder victim may have saved his uncle's life after his heart was donated to his critically ill relative.

Mark Robinson, 22, died on Monday night two days after he was stabbed 11 times in an attack near his home.

Just two weeks ago, he signed an organ donor card after visiting his uncle, Lawrence McMonagle, in hospital.

Mr McMonagle was flown from Belfast to the Freeman hospital in Newcastle-upon-Tyne for the transplant and was on a life support machine after surgery in the early hours of yesterday.

Lynne Holt, clinical transplant coordinator at the Freeman hospital, said it was a coincidence that Mr Robinson's heart had been given to his uncle.

The family would not have been allowed to request Mr Robinson's heart. It was also the first time that the hospital had transplanted an organ from a donor related to a recipient.

"When a donor organ becomes available it is matched by the hospitals to a patient awaiting a transplant on the basis of blood group and the size of the organ. It just so happened Mr McMonagle was the sickest in that blood group."

The dead man's brother, Warren Robinson, said: "We are devastated by what happened to Mark.

"We thought we were coming home to two funerals because we thought Lawrnie wasn't going to make it either. Mark visited him two weeks ago and when he saw how weak he was, he immediately filled out a donor card. He was a young man and we never imagined anything would happen to him but it is a strange twist he should save Lawrnie.

"It says a lot for Mark, he's responsible for saving people's lives, but the people who killed him have no respect for life."

Police have ruled out a sectarian motive for Mr Robinson's murder and are appealing for a group of teenagers who were in the area at the time to come forward.

fields.headline: Gift keeps homeless artist afloat
fields.trailText: A homeless pavement artist whose work was displayed at the Tate Britain gallery in London so impressed two art lovers from the US that they bought him a £30,000 narrow boat.
fields.body:
A homeless pavement artist whose work was displayed at the Tate Britain gallery in London so impressed two art lovers from the US that they bought him a £30,000 narrow boat.

The 50-year-old artist, known only as Simon, had spent five years sleeping rough on a bench by the Kennet and Avon canal in Bath and sold his sketches to passersby from his regular pitch at Bath Abbey.

His talents were recognised when artists Jeremy Deller and Alan Kane bought one of his sketches, which was then featured in the Intelligence: New British Art 2000 exhibition last July.

Signed "Simon, Homeless, Bath", it captured the interest of a wealthy American couple and they tracked him down. "They asked me where I would like to live and I said a narrow boat because I have been on them before," said Simon.

He has named the narrow boat Jolly Wassail and plans to refurbish it using wood donated by friends.

He refused to name his benefactors but thanked them for their generosity. "They just wanted to make me happy and they have," he said.

fields.headline: Duchess's aide 'lied over killing of her lover'
fields.trailText: The Duchess of York's former dresser yesterday admitted repeatedly lying to friends and the police when she told them she had left the lover she is accused of murdering alive and barely harmed.
fields.body:
The Duchess of York's former dresser yesterday admitted repeatedly lying to friends and the police when she told them she had left the lover she is accused of murdering alive and barely harmed despite confronting him with a cricket bat and 8in knife.

Jane Andrews, who worked for the duchess for nine years until 1997, had initially told detectives she believed she had merely "scratched" her wealthy boyfriend Tom Cressman during the scuffle, and did not believe she had harmed him badly as there appeared to be little blood.

But yesterday she told the Old Bailey she knew he was dead when she fled the £400,000 mews house they shared in Fulham. Cross-examined as to how she knew this, she admitted: "Because I was covered in blood."

Questioned by her counsel, John Kelsey-Fry QC, why she had lied to officers, she said : "It doesn't make sense. I just kept thinking that no one would believe me."

She had left the house to drive for three days to Cornwall without seeking help for her bleeding lover "because I panicked".

Asked to elaborate on this, a tearful Andrews - who the prosecution alleges stabbed her partner of two years when she realised he would not marry her - suggested she would be presumed guilty "because of all the arguments we had had that day and the fight in the morning when he called the police, and I had been ringing everyone telling them that the relationship was over ... and I had taken the bat and knife to protect myself and I was the only one who ever saw the other side of Tommy."

Earlier, the 34-year-old former royal aide told how Mr Cressman's death, in the early hours of September 17 last year, occurred after he tried to anally rape her for the second time that day.

That morning, the 39-year-old businessman had sexually assaulted her in this way after she threatened to expose "all his dirty little habits" - including pornographic emails he had sent to a woman in Las Vegas, she claimed.

The alleged assault followed a frenzied argument in which Mr Cressman "cuffed" and throttled her, before telephoning for police help to prevent the argument worsening. As he spoke to a police operator, she screamed out that she would expose him, before rushing to the bedroom to telephone her ex-husband on her mobile.

Mr Cressman, she claimed, raced after her, knocked the mobile from her hand, and grabbed her before placing a pillow over her head and tying her face down to the bed.

"He was in a frenzy. He was furious. He was screaming at me because I said to him that I was going to tell everybody about all his dirty little habits," she said. "I was screaming because it hurt so much. He just kept laughing at me. He said he would do something that I would really remember."

After the alleged assault, she reiterated her threat to "tell everyone, to ruin him" and mentioned telling former motor racing driver Sir Stirling Moss, a business associate of Mr Cressman's.

Much later that night, after Andrews had left her lover but then returned in the belief they could solve their problems, he allegedly tried to rape her again - a move which led her to run downstairs and grab a cricket bat "as a comfort and a protection" for when she returned to bed. She also fetched a "protective" kitchen knife after the couple resumed their rowing.

Bruce Houlder, QC, prosecuting, questioned why she had not mentioned his threat to "kill her", or the alleged anal rape previously, and queried how she could have left the man she loved "lying there in his death throes, his life blood slipping away".

The trial continues.

Jane Andrews, who worked for the duchess for nine years until 1997, had initially told detectives she believed she had merely "scratched" her wealthy boyfriend Tom Cressman during the scuffle, and did not believe she had harmed him badly as there appeared to be little blood. But yesterday she told the Old Bailey she knew he was dead when she fled the £400,000 mews house they shared in Fulham. Cross-examined as to how she knew this, she admitted: "Because I was covered in blood." Questioned by her counsel, John Kelsey-Fry QC, why she had lied to officers, she said : "It doesn't make sense. I just kept thinking that no one would believe me." She had left the house to drive for three days to Cornwall without seeking help for her bleeding lover "because I panicked". Asked to elaborate on this, a tearful Andrews - who the prosecution alleges stabbed her partner of two years when she realised he would not marry her - suggested she would be presumed guilty "because of all the arguments we had had that day and the fight in the morning when he called the police, and I had been ringing everyone telling them that the relationship was over ... and I had taken the bat and knife to protect myself and I was the only one who ever saw the other side of Tommy." Earlier, the 34-year-old former royal aide told how Mr Cressman's death, in the early hours of September 17 last year, occurred after he tried to anally rape her for the second time that day. That morning, the 39-year-old businessman had sexually assaulted her in this way after she threatened to expose "all his dirty little habits" - including pornographic emails he had sent to a woman in Las Vegas, she claimed. The alleged assault followed a frenzied argument in which Mr Cressman "cuffed" and throttled her, before telephoning for police help to prevent the argument worsening. As he spoke to a police operator, she screamed out that she would expose him, before rushing to the bedroom to telephone her ex-husband on her mobile. Mr Cressman, she claimed, raced after her, knocked the mobile from her hand, and grabbed her before placing a pillow over her head and tying her face down to the bed. "He was in a frenzy. He was furious. He was screaming at me because I said to him that I was going to tell everybody about all his dirty little habits," she said. "I was screaming because it hurt so much. He just kept laughing at me. He said he would do something that I would really remember." After the alleged assault, she reiterated her threat to "tell everyone, to ruin him" and mentioned telling former motor racing driver Sir Stirling Moss, a business associate of Mr Cressman's. Much later that night, after Andrews had left her lover but then returned in the belief they could solve their problems, he allegedly tried to rape her again - a move which led her to run downstairs and grab a cricket bat "as a comfort and a protection" for when she returned to bed. She also fetched a "protective" kitchen knife after the couple resumed their rowing. Bruce Houlder, QC, prosecuting, questioned why she had not mentioned his threat to "kill her", or the alleged anal rape previously, and queried how she could have left the man she loved "lying there in his death throes, his life blood slipping away". The trial continues.

fields.headline: Credit act 'denies fair deal'
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The Consumer Credit Act 1974 is incompatible with human rights, three court of appeal judges ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
The Consumer Credit Act 1974 is incompatible with human rights, three court of appeal judges ruled yesterday.

The judges used new powers under the Human Rights Act to declare that the act violated the European convention on human rights by denying a fair deal to commercial lenders.

The "declaration of incompatibility" is only the second to be made since judges were given the power last October, when the Human Rights Act came into force, and the first by the court of appeal.

Neither of the parties to the case - a pawnbroker, First County Trust, and Penelope Wilson, from Knightsbridge, central London, who pawned her BMW - had relied on the Human Rights Act in the appeal from a county court judgment over a £5,000 loan.

The judges - the vice-chancellor, Sir Andrew Morritt, Lord Justice Chadwick and Lord Justice Rix - adjourned the appeal last November to allow the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, time to brief lawyers to oppose the declaration, but had provisionally concluded that a section of the act which barred FCT from enforcing the credit agreement because of a technical error breached its human rights.

In drawing up the agreement FCT wrongly added the £250 charge for preparing the document to the £5,000 loan. The document declared the amount of the loan as £5,250, instead of £5,000.

Under the act, the court has power to enforce an agreement despite certain errors, but not if the amount of the loan is not stated correctly. The result was that Mrs Wilson got back her car and the £6,900 she paid for the loan, interest and charges.

The government now has to decide whether to appeal or amend the law.

webTitle: Breare gives up chasing after Wolves

fields.headline: Breare gives up chasing after Wolves
fields.trailText: Leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare has given up his nine-month pursuit of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries and settled for picking up 290 pubs from rival bidder Pubmaster.
fields.body:
Leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare has given up his nine-month pursuit of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries and settled for picking up 290 pubs from rival bidder Pubmaster.

Mr Breare, who was backed by venture capitalist Botts & Co, was frustrated at Wolves' refusal to clarify whether it would recommend a 500p-a-share bid, worth £472m.

His backers were unwilling to contemplate a hostile offer, and insiders say he was concerned that a personality clash with Wolves' deputy chairman David Thompson could jeopardise a friendly deal.

Mr Breare said: "We believe a transaction between Pubmaster and ourselves is the way most likely to enable a successful bid for Wolves."

Pubmaster has said it will pay up to 510p a share for Wolves & Dudley, which has 1,750 pubs and four breweries, producing traditional ales such as Cameron, Banks's and Mansfield Bitter.

Under the terms of yesterday's agreement, Pubmaster will sell 290 of the estate's prime managed houses, including the Pitcher & Piano and Varsity chains, to Mr Breare for £250m.

Wolves has been in play since last year when it struggled to integrate acquisitions - Mansfield Brewery and Marston, Thompson & Evershed. The firm last week detailed a strategic review, which involves closing one brewery, selling another and concentrating on high-quality neighbourhood pubs.

fields.headline: Smuggling inquiry scrapped
fields.trailText: British American Tobacco has scrapped an independent inquiry by law firm Allen & Overy into allegations that it exploits smuggling of cigarettes, on the grounds that it is no longer necessary.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco has scrapped an independent inquiry by law firm Allen & Overy into allegations that it exploits smuggling of cigarettes, on the grounds that it is no longer necessary.

Martin Broughton, the chairman, told yesterday's AGM that the board decided to "stay" the investigation in October when the Department of Trade and Industry began an investigation into the firm.

He said: "They're both on the same subject. There's no point having two inquiries."

The Guardian revealed last year that BAT supplied huge numbers of cigarettes to relatively small markets in eastern Europe and Africa, knowing they would end up in the hands of smugglers.

Allen & Overy spent five months investigating BAT's business practices before being stayed. The law firm presented its unfinished findings to directors, but Mr Broughton would not discuss the contents.

Pressure group Action on Smoking and Health criticised the move. Its spokesman, John Connolly, said: "I would have thought that, with or without a DTI inquiry, they would want to know what's going on within their own company. They must be preparing evidence for the DTI, and surely Allen & Overy's findings could help."

The news emerged as BAT announced a 10% increase in first-quarter profits to £597m excluding exceptional items. The company is discussing the establishment of a joint venture company with the Chinese government in an at tempt to break into the country which accounts for a third of the world's cigarette sales.

Shareholders gave directors a rough ride on BAT's claim that it does not target cigarettes at young people. One investor asked: "Isn't it a bit illogical telling people you don't want to hook young people, yet at the same time sponsoring formula one, which is of great interest to teenagers, and backing the Cambridge Footlights?"

Former chancellor Kenneth Clarke took some flak for his role as deputy chairman. He was asked to justify his £100,000 salary, and about whether he would resign "when the Conservative party gets back in on June 7".

Mr Clarke said he would address this issue "when and if" he was offered a position serving in a Tory government.

fields.headline: We made mistakes, says Body Shop chief
fields.standfirst: Cosmetics company returns to foundations
fields.trailText: Green cosmetics retailer Body Shop yesterday made public the mistakes which left the company with a huge slump in profits.
fields.body:
Green cosmetics retailer Body Shop yesterday made public the mistakes which left the company with a huge slump in profits.

The company said it had mistakenly ditched products which were customer favour ites, replaced them with products with little appeal and low margins and badly managed its stock levels.

The company - which had been forced into a profit warning after poor Christmas sales - announced its annual profits had dived by more than 50% from £28.8m to £12.8m, and warned that first-half profits this year would not match last year's levels.

But chief executive Patrick Gournay denied the caution on first-half results was another profit warning, and insisted steps had been taken to address the problems. He said: "In the current year, we are anticipating a reasonable improvement in profit as the benefits of our actions begin to feed through to our results."

Body Shop's mistakes, he said, included new look ranges like PalmShine shampoo and Juice It shower gels. "They were not Body Shop ranges", he said. "The packaging didn't look like Body Shop. It didn't look like the brand."

He has reintroduced several top selling "heritage" products, like Ice Blue and camomile shampoos.

The decision to concentrate on new products was Mr Gournay's own strategy. Last year he said he wanted to generate 40% of sales from new products, and yesterday he insisted the strategy was not wrong, just badly executed.

"We tried to do too much too quickly, not respecting our brand heritage. It would have been better to have a small number of big ideas than a big number of small ideas," he said.

Co-op swings back into the black

Elsewhere on the high street the Co-operative Group has revealed that it swung back into profit last year. The Co-op Group was formed last year when former rivals the Co-operative Wholesale Society and the Co-operative Retail Society merged. The CRS posted a £80m loss last year and the merger cost £23.2m, but the new group still chalked up profits of £130.7m. Sales rose 29% to £5.1bn. "The haemorrhage suffered by CRS has been stopped", said chief executive Graham Melmoth.

Profits at the food retailing business - which is being restructured to concentrate on convenience stores and market town supermarkets - grew 5% to £27.2m.

Specialist retailing, which includes opticians, the Priory motor dealers, Travelcare and funeral services, doubled its profits to £26.3m.

But the biggest earner is the Co-op bank, which reported record profits for the seventh successive year, up 9% at £97m.

webTitle: Starbucks is to offer caffe laptop

fields.headline: Starbucks is to offer caffe laptop
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Patrons of Starbucks, the retail chain for designer coffee drinkers, will now be able to email friends and listen to online music while they sip their caffe lattes or frappacinos.
fields.body:
Patrons of Starbucks, the retail chain for designer coffee drinkers, will now be able to email friends and listen to online music while they sip their caffe lattes or frappacinos.

The coffee company which had its origins in Seattle has joined forces with the computer firm Compaq in a five-year deal, thought to be worth $100m, to provide wireless internet access to Starbucks outlets. The partners say the pact will improve brand loyalty and revenues.

"The two innovative companies will work together to blend technology and lifestyle, thereby enhancing the Starbucks experience and supporting global growth," Starbucks said.

Customers in North America will be offered the service on a trial basis this the summer and the two companies plan to extend the service by 2002 to almost 3,000 of the more than 4,000 Starbucks stores around the world. Starbucks operates about 150 outlets in Britain.

According to the firm, customers will be able to access broadband content and services on pocket PCs in the coffee shops or on their own computers.

"Working closely with Compaq on enterprise and consumer-facing innovations will ultimately help us improve store operations and enhance the experience of our customers," said Darren Huston, senior vice-president of new ventures at Starbucks.

Under the agreement Compaq will provide information technology infrastructure, such as data storage, and desktop, handheld and laptop computers, to Starbucks stores and its head office.

Starbucks already has an agreement with Microsoft, which Compaq will now join. The companies have been working together to offer North American customers a range of broadband internet services, including being able to work remotely through Microsoft's MSN network.

Analysts have predicted that technology that enables devices to be connected to the internet without wires will be made widely available at places such as airports, conference halls, shopping malls - and now coffee shops - where there is a captive audience.

fields.headline: Common ground for think tank
fields.trailText: A think tank set up to promote common ownership and mutual businesses was launched yesterday with the support of the cooperative movement, building societies and mutual insurers.
fields.body:
A think tank set up to promote common ownership and mutual businesses was launched yesterday with the support of the cooperative movement, building societies and mutual insurers.

Believed to be the first of its kind in Britain, the think tank will aim to defend established societies and push for an extension of mutual ownership across a range of business sectors.

A spokesman for the group, called Mutuo, said the main thrust of its work "will be towards influencing decision makers and opinion formers that mutual business models offer eminently practical solutions and are politically and economically viable".

In a pamphlet published to mark the launch, the group argues that while there is little appetite for key companies and industries to be re-nationalised, there are forms of common ownership that could support the search for a "third way" between state ownership and privatisation.

The group, which is based in the Co-operative Party offices in London, points to the takeover of Lincoln and Chesterfield football clubs by supporters as an example of mutual ownership in new and unexpected areas.

It argues that mutual financial institutions that resist carpetbaggers provide a bulwark against greedy banks that need to find ways to boost their profits following demands for greater returns from shareholders.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The battle for control of the Meridien luxury hotel chain remains wide open, insiders said yesterday, despite Nomura clinching "preferred bidder" status with a £1.85bn offer.
fields.body:
Meridien battle 'still open'

The battle for control of the Meridien luxury hotel chain remains wide open, insiders said yesterday, despite Nomura clinching "preferred bidder" status with a £1.85bn offer.

Marriott International, the US operator, is considering an increase on its initial offer, thought to be £1.7bn, in an attempt to snatch back the initiative.

The Meridien chain includes London landmarks such as the Grosvenor House Hotel, the Waldorf and Café Royal. It has been put up for sale by hospitality firm Compass, which wants to concentrate on contract catering and roadside restaurants.

MP acts on overdrafts

A bill introduced in parliament yesterday calling for an investigation to bank overdrafts followed Guardian reports on the £150m annual charge to 11m customers. Labour MP Christopher Leslie cited research by NOP, commissioned by Halifax, which showed that the typical bank customer is overdrawn for 80 days a year. The "big four" banks charge rates of over 18%.

Whitbread hails healthy change

Whitbread said it had made a "flying start" to its new role after selling its pubs and bars division last month for £1.63bn to concentrate on higher growth markets.

Overall group pre-tax profit fell 4% to £335m before exceptionals in the year to March 3, and group turnover slipped 17% to £3.1bn. Whitbread said its new core businesses - including Marriott Hotels, David Lloyd Leisure and Costa Coffee - had shown strong earnings growth.

Operating profit across the hotels, restaurants and health club divisions rose 22% before one-off costs to £241m.

Volvo makes job cuts

Volvo, the Swedish truck and bus maker, is to restructure at a cost of many jobs and more than SKr4bn (£270m) over three years to achieve big savings and boost profitability. Volvo's first-quarter losses amounted to SKr1.25bn after financial items.

Banks on too rich a diet

Too many banks are chasing the wealth of some 4.5m British people who have at least £50,000 to invest, a survey concluded yesterday. The dash to attract the "mass affluent" is accelerating at a time when the economic backdrop is faltering, said Ian Woodhouse of PricewaterhouseCoopers, which conducted the survey.

Retail sales keep rising

Retailers saw increased sales growth in April, according to the Confederation of British Industry. Its distributive trades survey showed that 55% of retailers reported April sales volumes higher than a year ago, while 23% reported a fall.

webTitle: Sharon pulls rug from under Peres

fields.headline: Sharon pulls rug from under Peres
fields.standfirst:
Palestinians are partners, says foreign secretary in truce talks. Jordan valley is Israel's forever, says prime minister

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister and foreign minister split yesterday over a proposed truce in their country's conflict with the Palestinians, laying bare the fractures in their unwieldy coalition government.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister and foreign minister split yesterday over a proposed truce in their country's conflict with the Palestinians, laying bare the fractures in their unwieldy coalition government.

The search for a ceasefire deal with the Palestinians by Shimon Peres, the foreign secretary, was undermined all through the day by the government leader, Ariel Sharon.

Mr Peres, the dove in the cabinet, was in Washington yesterday to try to get the US president, George Bush, and the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, to support a ceasefire plan sponsored by Jordan and Egypt. His tone towards the Palestinians was conciliatory.

But Mr Sharon, a hardline rightwinger, repeatedly scuppered his efforts. Among other moves, he ordered another army incursion into Palestinian land at Rafah in the Gaza Strip. During this, a 17-year-old Palestinian was killed. The Israelis quickly withdrew, after bulldozing buildings.

Last month, a similar incursion - also into land handed over to the Palestinians under the 1993 Oslo peace accords with Israel - was reversed by Mr Sharon after a rebuke by Mr Powell.

In a declaration guaranteed to provoke the Palestinians, Mr Sharon announced during a West Bank tour that the Jordan valley, which forms the West Bank's border with Jordan, would be Israel's forever.

Earlier this year, Israel's previous Labour government promised during negotiations with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to withdraw from the Jordan valley after six years.

Mr Sharon also ruled out a freeze on Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza, one of the Palestinian demands in the Jordan-Egypt plan.

Visiting the West Bank settlement of Ofra to express condolences to the family of a settler killed on Tuesday, Mr Sharon rejected concessions for the Palestinians in return for a ceasefire: "There is no payment for stopping terror."

He held out little prospect of a truce, and his deputy public security minister, Gideon Ezra, went further, saying publicly that a ceasefire might make matters worse for Israel by giving the Palestinians an opportunity to re-arm.

After a meeting of his "security cabinet" in Ofra, Mr Sharon told settler demonstrators: "If Arafat does not deal with terror, we will deal with terror... We have an interest in preventing an escalation. But we haven't used all the possibilities to bring an end to terror. And these things we will do."

Some of those methods, he said, may not be overt - a reference to assassinations and bombings carried out by the Israeli intelligence service.

Mr Peres, speaking to the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, reiterated that he regarded Mr Arafat as a partner in peace and said: "We want to help the Palestinians. The stronger they will be, the better partner they will be."

He added: "We don't demonise the Palestinians, who have gone through tragedies."

An Israeli foreign ministry official denied there was a rift between the two leaders: "There are differences in views between the two but they are quite coordinated between themselves."

As well as the peace proposal, Mr Peres will discuss with Mr Powell an impending US report on the causes of the Palestinian uprising. The 30-page report by a team led by George Mitchell - the US senator who played an important part in the Northern Ireland peace process - is nervously awaited by Israel and the Palestinians in case blame is apportioned mainly to one side. The report was handed to the administration in Washington on Tuesday.

fields.headline: At this price?  Arc International
fields.trailText: Arc International, the Hertfordshire-based microchip designer, bucked the negative trend in the technology sector by posting positive sales yesterday.
fields.body:
Arc International, the Hertfordshire-based microchip designer, bucked the negative trend in the technology sector by posting positive sales yesterday. The company said demand for its products had remained strong.

Arc, which raised £126m by listing on the London stock exchange last September, posted revenues of £3.7m, up 5% from the previous quarter, and a pre-tax loss of £4.4m, compared with £4.7m for the last quarter. However, the losses were twice as big as in the same period in 2000.

The company, which generates 70% of its business from the United States and has £140m cash in the bank - "more than enough to take us through to profitability," according to its finance director Simon Paulton - said it had not been hit by the US slowdown.

Bob Terwilliger, Arc's chief executive, said: "Our business model of licensing our intellectual property to customers who are developing next-generation products limits our exposure to the stock adjustments and production cutbacks being experienced by many technology companies."

The City, however, did not react with glee. Arc's shares, which closed nearly 5% down on Tuesday at 112p and have underperformed their sector by about 20% since the start of the year, fell a further 2p to 110p. Analysts raised concerns about a fall in operating costs - unusual for a young growing firm - a drop in royalties from £165,000 to £128,000 and no sign of big customers.

Arc, which designs chips for computer operating systems and gadgets, said it had signed six customers this quarter, but analysts said they were all small companies. Dealers also said the stock was affected by Nomura placing 8m of Arc's shares in the market at £1.

Arc, which employs 302 people, ruled out job losses and said it expected to take on another 100 people this year - including more sales staff. Mr Paulton said they were looking for acquisitions.

fields.headline: Viatel seeks bankruptcy protection
fields.trailText: Viatel, a New York-based European telecommunications network builder that lost $1.57bn last year, yesterday filed for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors and said it sacked 350 people.
fields.body:
Viatel, a New York-based European telecommunications network builder that lost $1.57bn last year, yesterday filed for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors and said it sacked 350 people, after making 700 redundant in February.

Viatel said it would try to restructure its balance sheets, wind up unprofitable businesses - mostly in the United States - and support its core European business. Its board authorised it to try to run its business as a debtor in possession as it restructures.

Shares in Viatel traded on Nasdaq at 26 cents, having fallen 99% in the past year, before trading was halted yesterday. The company has shed about 45% of its staff this year.

With a pan-European network spanning more than 6,400 miles, Viatel is one of many young, ambitious "business plan" telecom companies which in the late 1990s found it easy to raise cash, even if profits were years away.

Viatel listed $2.12bn of assets, $2.68bn of debts and more than 1,000 creditors in its filing with the bankruptcy court in the district of Delaware. - Reuters

fields.headline: Top placing for Vodafone
fields.trailText: Now we know for sure: there is still appetite for telecoms paper.
fields.body:
Now we know for sure: there is still appetite for telecoms paper. Ever since the disastrous flotation of Orange earlier this year it has been thought that institutions would only subscribe for new telecom shares at fire sale prices.

But yesterday UBS Warburg and Goldman Sachs comfortably managed to sell £3.5bn worth of Vodafone stock to City investors, in what was the second largest one-day share placing ever.

The speed and the level at which the operation was completed stunned even the most seasoned market professionals.

According to market sources the offer had to be increased from £3bn to £3.5bn to satisfy demand and the shares are likely to be placed at 194p - a small discount to Vodafone's closing price of 199p, down 7.25p.

Vodafone will use the proceeds to help fund the purchases of BT's stakes in Japan Telecom and Airtel, the Spanish mobile phone company. BT shares fell 7p to 592p.

"It went better than anyone could have expected. They [UBS and Goldman] are very pleased with the outcome," the source said.

All things considered it was not a bad day for the London market. The blue-chip index finished just 23.8 points lower at 5.904.2, with weakness in Vodafone offset by rising tech stocks. The FTSE Techmark 100 index rose 23.16 points to 2,103.84, with bears being forced to square short positions after a robust overnight showing from Nasdaq. CMG, up 44.5p to 407.5p, led the way, closely followed by ARM Holdings, 12p better at 410p, and Bookham Technology, 22.5p stronger at 364p.

Logica, however, underperformed, rising just 23p to £10.08 after Goldman Sachs lowered its rating on the stock to "market perform" from "trading buy". After rising 30% in a week, the US investment bank thinks Logica's share price is now up with events.

Royal & Sun Alliance also made an appearance on the blue-chip leaderboard, rising 15.5p to 511p after CSFB raised its target price to 595p from 550p and repeated its "buy" advice.

Colt Telecom was another solid performer, advancing 82p to £10.17 thanks to late speculation that Cable & Wireless, up 4p to 504p, was casting its eye over the long-distance telecoms specialist. Sector specialists dismissed the tale as far fetched.

Among the mid-caps, late selling pushed Morse, the computer hardware reseller, down 12.5p to 317.5p. Rumours abound that the company is about to issue a gloomy trading update.

Despite posting a reasonable set of first-quarter figures, chip designer ARC International slipped 2p to 110p. Dealers put the weakness down to a placing of 8m shares - around 3% of the company's equity - by Japanese investment bank, Nomura. According to the gossips the shares, which were placed with institutions at 100p, belonged to one of ARC's early-stage venture capital backers.

The recovery of Cookson, the electronics and precious metals group, continued. The shares, which hit 146p in the wake of last Thursday's poor trading update, closed at 173p, up 1p, with the performance attributed to short covering. Apparently Deutsche Bank has been buying back Cookson stock for clients.

But with the majority of the short positions now closed, marketmakers reckon the stock will move lower in the next couple of sessions.

Bright Station closed 2p higher at 13.5p and further gains are expected today. After the market closed, the company said it was confident of finding additional finance.

"Discussions regarding additional funding for group continue to progress, with additional opportunities having emerged since the statement on April 30," the company said. On Monday, Bright Station announced plans to restructure its business to focus on its Smartlogik subsidiary.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Probing: The in-building communications operator, EuroTelecom Communications, whose operating business went into administration in February, says it is to appoint a special investigative committee to look into how the business collapsed.
fields.body:
 Probing: The in-building communications operator, EuroTelecom Communications, whose operating business went into administration in February, says it is to appoint a special investigative committee to look into how the business collapsed.

The committee will be chaired by the company's chairman, Christopher Akers. The main focus of the committee's work is likely to be the role of former chief executive Philip Derry, who stood down last month.

 Thinking global PC chip maker Intel said it would continue to hire people at its units outside the United States despite 5,000 job cuts announced this year as a result of a slowing economy. The hiring and fresh investment would help it develop technologies and uses for products that would offer business potential when the economy picked up, Patrick Gelsinger, a vice-president at Intel, said. "Our headcount is shrinking in the US and increasing globally," said Mr Gelsinger, who is also Intel's chief technology officer for its technology and research labs.

"Despite the cut in people from 89,000 to 84,000, we will increase headcount internationally including in India."

 Buying in Prospective non-executive chairman John Barnes and chief financial officer Robert Deri have bought 660,000 shares and 132,000 shares respectively in Kazoo3D at 7.5p per share. Their appointments depend on the proposed acquisition of Zoo Media receiving shareholder approval.

fields.headline: British Biotech cancer drug wins reprieve
fields.trailText: British Biotech has performed a shock u-turn by reviving hopes for its controversial cancer drug marimastat, following a fresh analysis of clinical data and intense lobbying for a re-think from senior scientists.
fields.body:
British Biotech has performed a shock u-turn by reviving hopes for its controversial cancer drug marimastat, following a fresh analysis of clinical data and intense lobbying for a re-think from senior scientists.

Two months after chief executive Elliot Goldstein declared that the product was a failure, the Oxford-based company yesterday revealed that marimastat was showing positive signs in a last-ditch trial on pancreatic cancer sufferers.

Finance director Tony Weir said: "This is encouraging. In February, we thought it really was the end for marimastat. We were surprised when data on pancreatic cancer showed patients may be benefiting."

In addition, a fresh look at a trial on victims of gastric cancer has shown that after two years of treatment, 17 patients are still alive on marimastat, compared to just five survivors in a group taking a placebo.

British Biotech's change of heart yesterday followed concerted lobbying by senior clinicians, who were unhappy at the company's dismissal of its efficacy, which was well received in the City.

A key scientist working on the drug, Peter Brown, recently circulated a memo within the company questioning the management's attitude towards the product, and urging a more positive rethink.

Dr Brown said: "My job as project director is to be an advocate for the drug. In the memo, I made the strongest possible case for marimastat to be continued."

Other scientists supported Dr Brown. A source close to the company said: "This is effectively an internal coup. Goldstein has tried to ditch marimastat, but he's failed."

The encouraging data on survival rates among gastric cancer sufferers relates to research carried out in January. It showed that after two years, 18% of patients taking marimastat were still alive, compared with 5% of those taking a placebo.

Dr Goldstein maintained that it was new data which had changed his mind: "I promote debate in this company. I have an open and transparent policy. Anyone who suggests that scientists have been putting vigorous pressure on me is wrong."

British Biotech is discussing the prospects for marimastat with its development partner, US group Schering-Plough. The American company may decide to fund further trials, or may apply for regulatory approval based on the gastric cancer study.

Analyst Bill Blair of Nomura said: "This may be a case of marimastat rising from the ashes. They now have pretty clear cut evidence of marimastat having an effect."

The news is the first glimmer of hope for marimastat since the beginning of phase three trials in 1996. The drug was presumed dead after it failed in eight successive studies. Differing views about its potential prompted a catastrophic management bust-up in 1998, when dissident scientist Andrew Millar went public with concerns about the company's over-optimism. This led to the departure of founder Keith McCullagh.

Dr Goldstein has licensed a series of promising drugs into British Biotech's portfolio, in an attempt to broaden its activities away from marimastat. These include a new class of antibiotics, which he believes could be highly profitable but which are still in the early stages of clinical trials.

British Biotech's shares increased 1p to 20p, valuing the business at £133m.

The company has about £75m of cash in the bank.

fields.headline: Riversoft chief exits with £5m to make stage entrance
fields.trailText: The chief of a newly floated, loss-making software company quit yesterday with a pay-off that could top £5m.
fields.body:
The chief of a newly floated, loss-making software company quit yesterday with a pay-off that could top £5m.

Dominic Gattuso of Riversoft, the company whose software detects faults on data networks, is believed to be retiring to Hawaii to write plays.

Riversoft, which raised £86.1m when it joined the London Stock Exchange techMARK in December, emphasised Mr Gattuso had decided to retire and would act as a consultant for the business. Chairman and chief technology officer Philip Tee will take over as chief executive officer while the company searches for a replacement.

Mr Tee said the terms of Mr Gattuso's golden handshake had not been finalised. Last year Mr Gattuso, whose contract runs until November 2003, earned £309,000, including a bonus, and he has 90 days to exercise more than 7m share options at 26p, worth £4.4m at yesterday's price.

"Dominic Gattuso is an option holder in the company which is where his principle benefit lies," Mr Tee said.

The news came as the firm announced it was shedding 20 of its 296 staff. Riversoft said the job cuts would save it almost £1m a year and it hoped to become profitable ahead of the original target of the fourth quarter of 2002.

"The measures that we've taken, against the backdrop of strong demand for the software, mean the management team is quietly confident we can beat that target," Mr Tee said.

The firm also reduced the number of people it aimed to recruit this year to 360 from 400.

Riverside said it has £81.7m cash in the bank - enough to see it through to profitability - and posted a pretax loss of £8m, compared with £11m for the previous quarter, but the loss was just £3m for the same period last year.

Turnover rose from £2.3m to £2.6m for the quarter to the end of March.

Mr Tee said Riversoft, which generates 60% of its business from the United States, has not been affected by the slowdown in the American economy.

"The group continues to sign new customers and secure repeat orders at a solid pace in conditions that other segments of the technology market are finding challenging."

fields.headline: Trevor Philipson
fields.standfirst: Britain's leading civil aviation QC, he brought a sparkle to the commercial bar
fields.trailText: Britain's leading civil aviation QC, he brought a sparkle to the commercial bar.
fields.body:
Trevor Philipson, who has died of liver failure aged 53, infused glamour and sparkle to the commercial bar, a branch of the legal profession that does not attract much public attention or produce media stars. The country's leading practitioner in civil aviation law, both as counsel and arbitrator, he first made his mark in the early 1980s, at the Heathrow Terminal 4 inquiry.

For Trevor, the courtroom was a stage, on which he demanded of himself the highest standards of performance. His style was characterised by the sheer hard work that went into preparation, his courtesy and charm, and his devastating skills in cross-examination. A trade-mark of his was to beguile a witness with the charm, then to strike with a rapier-thrust when it was least expected. Very theatrical, very effective. He used spectacles as a stage prop in cross-examination, rather than for ophthalmic purposes, and once drove through the night before a case, to retrieve them from a car that had broken down on him in north Wales.

Trevor was able, professionally, to grasp the most complex technological detail, ranging from aircraft avionics systems to yogurt production processes. But in his personal life he was notoriously impractical: even his mobile telephones seldom worked.

Trevor was born in the north-east, and educated at the Royal Grammar School, Newcastle, where he was head boy, played Hamlet and wondered seriously about the stage as a career. He read law at Wadham College, Oxford, but glandular fever prevented him from sitting his finals, which enraged him, and he duly took a first in the bachelor of civil law exam at Oxford the following year.

The definitive work on civil aviation law, to which he was the principal contributor, is The Law Of Carriage By Air, which was published earlier this year. He became a QC in 1989, and developed a strong reputation in the field of professional negligence and trusts, acting in a number of landmark cases.

Success allowed him to spend much time in his lovely chateau in the foothills of the Pyrenees. This in turn allowed him to indulge in three passions: gardening, interior design and strenuous hill-walking.

In the mid-1970s, Trevor married Victoria Haskard, an Oxford friend. The marriage did not last and they had no children, but they remained good friends. By the early 1980s, work took Trevor to south-east Asia, where he met Thai Ping Wong, a man who shared his passions for spectacle, theatre, art, gardening and interior design. Thus began a partnership that has been a strong creative force for the last 16 years.

It took not a little courage, on his part, to confront a conservative profession with the challenge of being gay. To the bar's credit, and his own, his career appeared to have suffered not a scrap. For Trevor, the courtroom was a stage, on which he demanded of himself the highest standards of performance. His style was characterised by the sheer hard work that went into preparation, his courtesy and charm, and his devastating skills in cross-examination. A trade-mark of his was to beguile a witness with the charm, then to strike with a rapier-thrust when it was least expected. Very theatrical, very effective. He used spectacles as a stage prop in cross-examination, rather than for ophthalmic purposes, and once drove through the night before a case, to retrieve them from a car that had broken down on him in north Wales. Trevor was able, professionally, to grasp the most complex technological detail, ranging from aircraft avionics systems to yogurt production processes. But in his personal life he was notoriously impractical: even his mobile telephones seldom worked. fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: The portrayal of Richard III by Paul Daneman (Obituary, May 1) in the BBC's marathon staging of Shakespeare's history plays, An Age of Kings (1960), will no doubt be well recalled by those who were lucky enough to see it at the time of the original transmission.
fields.body:
 Gavin Gaughan writes: The portrayal of Richard III by Paul Daneman (Obituary, May 1) in the BBC's marathon staging of Shakespeare's history plays, An Age of Kings (1960), will no doubt be well recalled by those who were lucky enough to see it at the time of the original transmission.

His lizard-like portrayal of Richard was all the more impressive as, apart from the final Battle of Bosworth Field being pre-filmed, the whole series was live: a particularly memorable moment, prior to Richard's ascension and prefiguring the later murders, was his resentful, knowing glare into camera at the end of one episode, as Clarence beats him to a helping of wine.

It should be remembered that the screenings at the National Film Theatre, in 1994, proved equally captivating, and were sold out throughout the run: when Daneman turned up, in person, for the last few episodes, and gave a rather charming talk to the audience beforehand, he mentioned that at first, he hadn' t even got a ticket for himself.

 Bill Roberts writes: When the historian Alastair Parker (Obituary, April 25) began teaching at Queen's College, Oxford, his main interests were the French Revolution and 18th-century agriculture. If importuned by a student about the career of Robespierre, he would remark that, although he found the subject fascinating, he was at that time concentrating on Norfolk turnip cultivation.

When faced with an urgent inquiry about Coke of Holkham, he would reply that he would be willing to respond, but over the next few months he was researching on the committee of public safety.
