fields.headline: 'I have been stuck in a cinematic bubble without light or speech for six hours'
fields.standfirst: Four Guardian writers embark on their own cultural marathons
fields.trailText: Four Guardian writers embark on their own cultural marathons.
fields.body:
Tim Dowling does art

If you are going to do anything for 12 hours and 40 minutes, it seems sensible to get an early start. Standing at a bus stop at 7:45am, copy of Time Out in hand, I am determined to look at as much art as possible before the rush, if there is a rush.

8.55am: Piccadilly Pret a Manger. While not strictly an art gallery, Pret a Manger does at least have the distinction of being open at 8:55am. By common consent, virtually all galleries and museums open at 10am and shut at 6pm. My task has gone from uphill struggle to impossible mission in the space of an hour. Now I'm looking at a poster and drinking latte. Does this count?

9.30am: Agnew's Gallery, Old Bond Street. Agnew's is the only gallery in the West End which opens at 9.30, getting a half-hour jump on the competition. I push the buzzer, pull the door and find myself face to face with the tapestries of Louis Le Brocquy, "Ireland's most important living artist". A woman comes up the stairs and says, "Can I help you?" in a tone which unmistakably means: "Please go away." She tells me the exhibit doesn't open until Thursday. I attempt to spin out this conversation for another 26 minutes, until the Royal Academy opens. It lasts a further 45 seconds. I am reduced to walking up and down Duke Street examining paintings of ships through security grilles.

10am: Royal Academy, Piccadilly. At last, some art. There are extra security guards laid on in anticipation of today's May Day riots, but my art lover disguise (rucksack, wind cheater, sensible shoes) fools them all. Tickets to see Botticelli's drawings for Dante's Divine Comedy cost £7, but it's nice to be indoors. The Sackler wing has been divided into three galleries, Hell, Purgatory and Heaven, and the seven quid entitles me to headphones. I wander through Hell, listening to the commentary and congratulating myself for having never committed the sin of simony (the buying or selling of ecclesiastical pardons, offices, or emoluments).

The drawings are beautiful, but most are quite small, and the lighting in the gallery is low. An elderly woman and I are almost cheek to cheek as we examine a tiny sketch of a devil farting. By the time I get to Heaven I am fast-forwarding through the commentary. The later drawings look a bit dashed off. Frankly, if Botticelli can't make the effort, neither can I.

10.50am: National Portrait Gallery, Charing Cross. Every horrible painting featuring the Royal Family that you have ever seen is here, which makes for utterly compelling viewing. One particularly spooky portrait has eyes which seemed to follow you round the room. Unfortunately, it's of John Major.

11.20am: National Gallery, Trafalgar Square. The National Gallery currently has a special exhibition selected by the children's illustrator Quentin Blake, which is better than it sounds: 26 illustrative works arranged in alphabetical order by artist's surname. After just 35 minutes I have to leave to get to my only pre-arranged appointment of the day - lunch.

12.30pm: Tate Modern, Bankside. Roast cod and half a bottle of wine at a table overlooking the Thames. Does this count? Yes, I think so. Afterwards the Mondrians and Warhols whizz by in a pleasing blur. I sit for a few minutes watching an old silent film by Fernand Léger, Le Ballet Mécanique, in a stupor. What next?

3.10pm: Green Park station. A defective train has halted service in both directions until nobody knows when. Note to tourists: do not attempt to use the London Underground. It's broken and at present there are no plans to fix it.

3.55pm: Tate Britain, Millbank. Out of breath after my sprint from Green Park, I pay £4.50 to watch Tacita Dean's exhibition of stately 16mm films, guessing there will be chairs. By now my back aches, my feet hurt and my eyes itch. One film in particular, a 44-minute excursion through an evening at a German revolving restaurant, turns out to be just my cup of tea. I could stay here all day. Not really.

5.40pm: I arrive at the White Cube2 gallery for the new Tracy Emin show, 20 minutes before closing, queuing up before the open door of an outhouse to watch a video in which two Tracey Emins (hell's teeth!) argue about whether one is going to let the other into her flat. The bloke in front of me says: "She's a very angry young lady." Idiot.

6.55pm: Portland Place. Most galleries have a day when they open late, but it isn't Tuesday. I discover that the Royal Incorporation of British Architects has an exhibition about recent lottery-funded buildings, which is open until 9pm. I go to Great Portland Street instead and walk down Portland Place past legions of idle coppers, still there because of the May Day demonstrations. On arrival, a security guard informs me that the Riba building is closed. "Because of this?" I ask, indicating the silent, deserted streets all around us. He says yes. I give up.

7:45pm: I arrive home exactly 12 hours after I set off, and spend 40 minutes staring at the painting above the television. Does that count?

Cultural endurance: 12hrs, 00 mins

Emma Brockes does television

8.30am: I have been training for this all my life: 12 uninterrupted hours of soaps, panel shows, phone-ins, Moira Stewart, a history of the U-boat, and that blissful slide into evening in the company of William G Stewart and the cast of Neighbours. Other people are arriving at work, but I am learning how to make a wrestling ring from a pizza container and some red insulation tape (Blue Peter repeat, BBC2).

"Video the Wombles for me," says my flatmate, choked with envy, and slams the outside door as I sink further into the sofa and assume a position I am confident of maintaining for the rest of the day.

9.30am: Ricki Lake is just visible through the snow which passes for Channel 5's picture. I can't make out what she's saying. Nausea prickles through me as I deal with the fact that, if C5 dies, it blows Beachcomber Bay, Oprah, The Bold and the Beautiful and the Wonder Years out of my schedule. Grabbing the extension cord, I reel in the phone and place a panic call to my flatmate. "Reception clears up as the day goes on," he says, relating the time he tried to watch Team Knight Rider on a Sunday morning, but could only comprehend half of it. It is a moment of unexpected pathos.

I flick over to Kilroy for a discussion on "sex and the over 50s", where a woman is saying, "We have it five times a week, but I know my husband would like me thinner." The day suddenly darkens. At 9.50am I sit up and am knocked flat by the blood rush.

10am: Thank God, a double episode of ER. It's the one where Dr Carter leaves the surgical programme and Dr Green trashes the day room after being assaulted in the gents. At 10.08 a charge nurse turns to an exhausted Dr Benton and says: "Why don't you go and take a shower?" I get the weirdest sensation that my television is talking to me, but decide to wait for further signs before acting. Twenty minutes later, Jeannie, the nurse with HIV, turns to Dr Weaver.

"I'm not afraid," she says.

"To die?" says Dr Weaver.

"To live," says Jeannie simply.

Inspired, I take a shower. My relationship with the television is definitely changing.

11.04am: A woman rings the flat with a wrong number and I try to keep her talking. "Richard doesn't live here, but maybe I can help?" Does she think I'm a slob, I wonder, or someone vital to the machinery of capitalism who has been kept off work on account of the riots? I have grown a little insecure since noticing that all the adverts at this time of morning are for weight-loss products and debt relief.

"Please," I say. "Don't go."

"Sorry?" she says.

"I just, er, want to chat."

The line goes dead and I am forced to return to Raj Persaud, who is steering a phone-in on bereavement entitled, "get over it". Competing with him for insights is an American psychologist named Rhonda. "The night before my father killed my mother and then killed himself ..." she begins. Persaud looks gutted. I am momentarily cheered.

1pm: I haven't heard the sound of my own voice for hours. People walk purposefully past my window and I hate them, albeit listlessly. A children's programme called Songcatcher is on, in which a woman ambushes young children and makes them listen to her singing. "Sandwiches, apples, biscuits, juice," she trills. "Now, you sing." "Sandwiches, apples, biscuits, juice," I chime. Then Floella Benjamin comes on in a blue jumpsuit. Only one thing can save me: satellite.

3pm: My local TV shop can send an engineer around this afternoon. "You mean, I could be watching old episodes of Neighbours on UK Gold by evening?" I ask, scarcely daring to believe it.

"Sky will send you a card, yes, and you can be up and running in three days."

There is a short, hysterical pause.

"You don't understand. I need it NOW."

The telephonist laughs a little nervously. "Of course, there are two channels you can access instantly." And they are? "Sky News and the shopping channel." Is she mocking me? I hang up in despair.

4.30pm: "A nice ball of wool," the children's presenter soothes. I think I am loosing it.

9.10pm: Ten fuscia crescents on the arm of the sofa, my fingernails. It is dark in here. The TV fluoresces in the corner. Talk, talk, talk, they never stop talking or wait for an answer or show any sign of acknowledging MY needs. I crave reality, but I can't remember where I put it. Huw Edwards is doing the news, pretending to ignore me. These people aren't my friends, I know that now. But when will the voices stop? When?

Cultural endurance: 12 hours, 40 minutes

Stephen Moss does music

10am: Sporting a stetson (for reasons which will become clear), I begin my musical odyssey in Covent Garden. London is empty and edgy, with the police and May Day protesters already camcordering each other. While other minds turn to anarchy, mine is focused on art. Unfortunately, the buskers who usually throng Covent Garden aren't in evidence so far. Valuable time is being lost. Worryingly, the opera house is boarded up, and St Martin's in the Fields has cancelled its 1pm organ recital. I hear the distant thrum of what I think is a bass guitar to the north of the piazza, and rush around to embrace the player. Unfortunately, it turns out to be an electrical generator on a building site; desperate, I listen for 15 minutes and pretend it's a piece of Stockhausen.

Noon: At last, action. The Sigma string quartet are playing in the well of the market. They whoop along to Bolero and the William Tell overture, and the audience loves them. A pleasurable, coffee-fuelled half an hour.

1pm: Head for St James's Piccadilly in the hope that there might be a lunchtime recital, but no show. Just when I'm starting to despair, I hear celestial voices from the paved area in front of the church. A market trader and a middle-aged woman are singing songs from My Fair Lady to keep their spirits up. This counts, I tell myself, and I go over to encourage them to continue. The stall-holder turns out to be Malcolm Holland, who used to be in Edison Lighthouse (number one with Love Grows Where My Rosemary Goes in 1970, remember?). A God-given half an hour.

2pm: Head back to Covent Garden. An all-female string trio called Oopsie Mamushka are now in residence in the market. The violinist spends much of her time lying on the floor, which does not improve bowing. Did Jascha Heifetz ever play while supine? I don't think so. The Sigmas are back at 2.30, so this is a highly successful hour, though I never want to hear Pachelbel's canon again.

3pm: Cats in Drury Lane, playing to a small but enthusiastic house comprising elderly women, schoolgirls in neat uniforms, and Japanese tourists. Memory is wonderful, on all six occasions it is sung. Close to three hours, and suddenly I'm back in the game.

6pm: But not for long. I was relying on having a meal in the Savoy's American bar while listening to the pianist, but my highly respectable pair of jeans are deemed inappropriate by some bloke in a bow-tie. Distressed, I head for Oxford Street to join the demo, stopping to take in 10 minutes of reggae (courtesy of a somnolent busker) in Leicester Square.

8pm: Last chance saloon. The Borderline off Charing Cross Road (jeans more or less obligatory) for some Texan country-rock. This is why I wore the stetson, though I needn't have bothered as there's only one other cowboy hat in the house. What's wrong with these people? The excellent Slobberbone's lead singer looks like Neil Young - as do most of their middle-aged fans. Count two and a half hours, which includes lots of tuning up.

11pm: Head for the Dublin Castle in Camden Town to catch the end of DJ Downfall, two young men playing drums, gongs and synthesisers to a small, spacey audience. I have no idea what genre this is - techno, trance, garage, slightly poky third bedroom - and find it difficult to assimilate. (The fact that I am drinking my sixth pint of Kronenbourg is not helping.) A young technophile at the bar assures me that the music's fine, but the venue is wrong. "You want a place that stinks of poppers," he assures me gnomically.

Midnight: Take a cab back to Soho. A notice next to the driver says: "Thank you for not smocking", so I assume the cab is pretty old. Fifteenth century perhaps. I have heard less than nine hours of live music (not including the slow beat of the protesters' drums and the frenzied whirr of police helicopters), and my cause is looking lost. I settle into Ronnie Scott's for some late-night jazz and a steak sandwich. The sandwich is great; the music - an engaging saxophonist from Cameroon called Manu Dibango - a bit too sophisticated for my taste. I had assumed the jazz would go on until 3am, but the final set ends at 2.15. I make half-hearted efforts to find another venue, try out a few dodgy bars, refuse various offers of drugs, sex and battered minicabs, and get a black cab home just after 3am, weary, drunk and a little deflated. I have stopped at the musical equivalent of Tower Bridge, 105 minutes short of my 760-minute target. Next year, the Savoy had better watch out for an anarchist in a stetson intent on settling an old score.

Cultural endurance: 10 hours, 55 minutes

Merope Mills does films

11.45 am: "Don't be shy," says Annette in the box office, sensing that there are yet more questions ahead. We've been through it a dozen times but still I'm not quite sure. Can I squeeze in Traffic and The Hole? Could I handle both Spy Kids and Rugrats? For my 12 hours 40 minutes of planned cinema viewing putting together a feasible timetable is a job in itself.

It has been hard to find an early morning billing - most cinemas don't start screening until early afternoon. In order to save valuable viewing time, I settle on spending the bulk of the day at UCI Whiteleys in Bayswater, west London. Popcorn and ice cream in hand it seems only sensible to start the session with some eye candy (Brad Pitt) in The Mexican (15). Annette has come to the conclusion that I am some sort of irrepressible film buff with no friends and proffers a leaflet. "It's our ladies' night," she says. "Every Wednesday for £2." I thank her and vow never to set foot in this cinema again.

2.40pm: Post-The Mexican and still feeling fine. A timetable overlap means I am running late for Rugrats In Paris: The Movie (U). No great loss, but I make a mental note to save time by buying in bulk. Dennis is now manning the box office and seems bemused by my request for two tickets - one to Rugrats and one to Bridget Jones. "You're going to watch both films?" he asks. "You must be in a movie mood today."

I spend the next hour wondering at the storyline of some animated babies traversing Paris with the help of a giant reptile and pleading that, next time, the overly amorous couple on my left will get a room rather than a U-rated cinema ticket.

4.30pm: One hour into Bridget Jones' Diary (15): Number of mobile phone rings interrupting shows so far: four (v bad). Number of times have repositioned self in uncomfortable seats in last five minutes: 23 (dreadful).

Cinema head count increasing through out the day. Conclude that most of audience is composed of sad singletons and spend rest of film wondering why said singletons have not got jobs to go to. Soon realise that, on third film of day, am biggest tragic spinster of the lot. Realise horrible thought about film-watching comrades makes me completely unworthy of Colin Firth, Brad Pitt or similar movie gods. Resolve not to be so cruel to fellow cinema- goers henceforth.

6pm: With half an hour to spare to my next film I realise I have been stuck in a cinematic bubble without light or speech for the past six hours. I call friends, desperate for some sort of human interaction. When they ask how I am bearing up I realise that the prospect of another six hours of films fills me with dread. Reluctantly, I blag my way into a preview screening of Captain Corelli's Mandolin (15) which starts at 6.30pm.

8pm: Please, no. I can already see where John Madden is taking me on his interpretation of Louis de Bernière's bestseller and I'm not sure I like it. The thought of having to endure my fourth happily-ever-after ending of the day is making me nauseous. Then it occurs to me: perhaps the sickness is real and deep vein thrombosis has been quietly setting in throughout the day. Spend the rest of the film jigging my legs about like a deranged dog on heat. Everyone else in the cinema hates me.

9.15pm: Both Dennis and Annette are working at the box office and, on seeing me again, Annette throws me the look of a concerned landlady, as in, "Haven't you had enough yet?" I, drunk on moving images, defy her concern and head straight back in. I might as well not have moved - it's straight back to screen five where I'm feeling rather territorial about the sudden influx of people. Nod off in the epic Traffic (18) for 15 minutes but dream about Michael Douglas so decide this little discrepancy still counts.

11.37pm: Eleven hours down but there is a hefty one hour, 40 minutes still to fill - all the more testing since it's Tuesday and there are no late showings. Colleagues insist there is only one thing for it: I am to be taxied to the Soho adult cinema in order to reach my quota.

Midnight: Soho adult cinema is shut.

12.05am: When I ask for another cinema, the Raymond Revue bar doorman points me in the direction of Leicester Square. "Er, no. A cinema like this ," I say flapping my hands at his infamous establishment. "An adult cinema." He looks at me as if I am mad. "Adult cinemas?" he says. "They all shut down years ago."

12.30am: It's no good. Wherever I ask I get the same answer: there is no money in celluloid - it's all live girls. One seasoned punter in a suspicious-looking bookshop unhelpfully suggests I try Boston. But with time and money running low I'm not sure I can stretch to a transatlantic flight. Instead the only option is a small screening of Wet and Wild (XXX) downstairs at a video shop. Here I stand, avoiding raised eyebrows in faux captivation for the remainder of my time, reflecting on the day gone by, with a renewed wondering at who is more perverse - them or me.

Cultural endurance: 12 hours, 15 minutes
fields.bodyText: Tim Dowling does art If you are going to do anything for 12 hours and 40 minutes, it seems sensible to get an early start. Standing at a bus stop at 7:45am, copy of Time Out in hand, I am determined to look at as much art as possible before the rush, if there is a rush. 8.55am: Piccadilly Pret a Manger. While not strictly an art gallery, Pret a Manger does at least have the distinction of being open at 8:55am. By common consent, virtually all galleries and museums open at 10am and shut at 6pm. My task has gone from uphill struggle to impossible mission in the space of an hour. Now I'm looking at a poster and drinking latte. Does this count? 9.30am: Agnew's Gallery, Old Bond Street. Agnew's is the only gallery in the West End which opens at 9.30, getting a half-hour jump on the competition. I push the buzzer, pull the door and find myself face to face with the tapestries of Louis Le Brocquy, "Ireland's most important living artist". A woman comes up the stairs and says, "Can I help you?" in a tone which unmistakably means: "Please go away." She tells me the exhibit doesn't open until Thursday. I attempt to spin out this conversation for another 26 minutes, until the Royal Academy opens. It lasts a further 45 seconds. I am reduced to walking up and down Duke Street examining paintings of ships through security grilles. 10am: Royal Academy, Piccadilly. At last, some art. There are extra security guards laid on in anticipation of today's May Day riots, but my art lover disguise (rucksack, wind cheater, sensible shoes) fools them all. Tickets to see Botticelli's drawings for Dante's Divine Comedy cost £7, but it's nice to be indoors. The Sackler wing has been divided into three galleries, Hell, Purgatory and Heaven, and the seven quid entitles me to headphones. I wander through Hell, listening to the commentary and congratulating myself for having never committed the sin of simony (the buying or selling of ecclesiastical pardons, offices, or emoluments). The drawings are beautiful, but most are quite small, and the lighting in the gallery is low. An elderly woman and I are almost cheek to cheek as we examine a tiny sketch of a devil farting. By the time I get to Heaven I am fast-forwarding through the commentary. The later drawings look a bit dashed off. Frankly, if Botticelli can't make the effort, neither can I. 10.50am: National Portrait Gallery, Charing Cross. Every horrible painting featuring the Royal Family that you have ever seen is here, which makes for utterly compelling viewing. One particularly spooky portrait has eyes which seemed to follow you round the room. Unfortunately, it's of John Major. 11.20am: National Gallery, Trafalgar Square. The National Gallery currently has a special exhibition selected by the children's illustrator Quentin Blake, which is better than it sounds: 26 illustrative works arranged in alphabetical order by artist's surname. After just 35 minutes I have to leave to get to my only pre-arranged appointment of the day - lunch. 12.30pm: Tate Modern, Bankside. Roast cod and half a bottle of wine at a table overlooking the Thames. Does this count? Yes, I think so. Afterwards the Mondrians and Warhols whizz by in a pleasing blur. I sit for a few minutes watching an old silent film by Fernand Léger, Le Ballet Mécanique, in a stupor. What next? 3.10pm: Green Park station. A defective train has halted service in both directions until nobody knows when. Note to tourists: do not attempt to use the London Underground. It's broken and at present there are no plans to fix it. 3.55pm: Tate Britain, Millbank. Out of breath after my sprint from Green Park, I pay £4.50 to watch Tacita Dean's exhibition of stately 16mm films, guessing there will be chairs. By now my back aches, my feet hurt and my eyes itch. One film in particular, a 44-minute excursion through an evening at a German revolving restaurant, turns out to be just my cup of tea. I could stay here all day. Not really. 5.40pm: I arrive at the White Cube2 gallery for the new Tracy Emin show, 20 minutes before closing, queuing up before the open door of an outhouse to watch a video in which two Tracey Emins (hell's teeth!) argue about whether one is going to let the other into her flat. The bloke in front of me says: "She's a very angry young lady." Idiot. 6.55pm: Portland Place. Most galleries have a day when they open late, but it isn't Tuesday. I discover that the Royal Incorporation of British Architects has an exhibition about recent lottery-funded buildings, which is open until 9pm. I go to Great Portland Street instead and walk down Portland Place past legions of idle coppers, still there because of the May Day demonstrations. On arrival, a security guard informs me that the Riba building is closed. "Because of this?" I ask, indicating the silent, deserted streets all around us. He says yes. I give up. 7:45pm: I arrive home exactly 12 hours after I set off, and spend 40 minutes staring at the painting above the television. Does that count? Cultural endurance: 12hrs, 00 mins Emma Brockes does television 8.30am: I have been training for this all my life: 12 uninterrupted hours of soaps, panel shows, phone-ins, Moira Stewart, a history of the U-boat, and that blissful slide into evening in the company of William G Stewart and the cast of Neighbours. Other people are arriving at work, but I am learning how to make a wrestling ring from a pizza container and some red insulation tape (Blue Peter repeat, BBC2). "Video the Wombles for me," says my flatmate, choked with envy, and slams the outside door as I sink further into the sofa and assume a position I am confident of maintaining for the rest of the day. 9.30am: Ricki Lake is just visible through the snow which passes for Channel 5's picture. I can't make out what she's saying. Nausea prickles through me as I deal with the fact that, if C5 dies, it blows Beachcomber Bay, Oprah, The Bold and the Beautiful and the Wonder Years out of my schedule. Grabbing the extension cord, I reel in the phone and place a panic call to my flatmate. "Reception clears up as the day goes on," he says, relating the time he tried to watch Team Knight Rider on a Sunday morning, but could only comprehend half of it. It is a moment of unexpected pathos. I flick over to Kilroy for a discussion on "sex and the over 50s", where a woman is saying, "We have it five times a week, but I know my husband would like me thinner." The day suddenly darkens. At 9.50am I sit up and am knocked flat by the blood rush. 10am: Thank God, a double episode of ER. It's the one where Dr Carter leaves the surgical programme and Dr Green trashes the day room after being assaulted in the gents. At 10.08 a charge nurse turns to an exhausted Dr Benton and says: "Why don't you go and take a shower?" I get the weirdest sensation that my television is talking to me, but decide to wait for further signs before acting. Twenty minutes later, Jeannie, the nurse with HIV, turns to Dr Weaver. "I'm not afraid," she says. "To die?" says Dr Weaver. "To live," says Jeannie simply. Inspired, I take a shower. My relationship with the television is definitely changing. 11.04am: A woman rings the flat with a wrong number and I try to keep her talking. "Richard doesn't live here, but maybe I can help?" Does she think I'm a slob, I wonder, or someone vital to the machinery of capitalism who has been kept off work on account of the riots? I have grown a little insecure since noticing that all the adverts at this time of morning are for weight-loss products and debt relief. "Please," I say. "Don't go." "Sorry?" she says. "I just, er, want to chat." The line goes dead and I am forced to return to Raj Persaud, who is steering a phone-in on bereavement entitled, "get over it". Competing with him for insights is an American psychologist named Rhonda. "The night before my father killed my mother and then killed himself ..." she begins. Persaud looks gutted. I am momentarily cheered. 1pm: I haven't heard the sound of my own voice for hours. People walk purposefully past my window and I hate them, albeit listlessly. A children's programme called Songcatcher is on, in which a woman ambushes young children and makes them listen to her singing. "Sandwiches, apples, biscuits, juice," she trills. "Now, you sing." "Sandwiches, apples, biscuits, juice," I chime. Then Floella Benjamin comes on in a blue jumpsuit. Only one thing can save me: satellite. 3pm: My local TV shop can send an engineer around this afternoon. "You mean, I could be watching old episodes of Neighbours on UK Gold by evening?" I ask, scarcely daring to believe it. "Sky will send you a card, yes, and you can be up and running in three days." There is a short, hysterical pause. "You don't understand. I need it NOW." The telephonist laughs a little nervously. "Of course, there are two channels you can access instantly." And they are? "Sky News and the shopping channel." Is she mocking me? I hang up in despair. 4.30pm: "A nice ball of wool," the children's presenter soothes. I think I am loosing it. 9.10pm: Ten fuscia crescents on the arm of the sofa, my fingernails. It is dark in here. The TV fluoresces in the corner. Talk, talk, talk, they never stop talking or wait for an answer or show any sign of acknowledging MY needs. I crave reality, but I can't remember where I put it. Huw Edwards is doing the news, pretending to ignore me. These people aren't my friends, I know that now. But when will the voices stop? When? Cultural endurance: 12 hours, 40 minutes Stephen Moss does music 10am: Sporting a stetson (for reasons which will become clear), I begin my musical odyssey in Covent Garden. London is empty and edgy, with the police and May Day protesters already camcordering each other. While other minds turn to anarchy, mine is focused on art. Unfortunately, the buskers who usually throng Covent Garden aren't in evidence so far. Valuable time is being lost. Worryingly, the opera house is boarded up, and St Martin's in the Fields has cancelled its 1pm organ recital. I hear the distant thrum of what I think is a bass guitar to the north of the piazza, and rush around to embrace the player. Unfortunately, it turns out to be an electrical generator on a building site; desperate, I listen for 15 minutes and pretend it's a piece of Stockhausen. Noon: At last, action. The Sigma string quartet are playing in the well of the market. They whoop along to Bolero and the William Tell overture, and the audience loves them. A pleasurable, coffee-fuelled half an hour. 1pm: Head for St James's Piccadilly in the hope that there might be a lunchtime recital, but no show. Just when I'm starting to despair, I hear celestial voices from the paved area in front of the church. A market trader and a middle-aged woman are singing songs from My Fair Lady to keep their spirits up. This counts, I tell myself, and I go over to encourage them to continue. The stall-holder turns out to be Malcolm Holland, who used to be in Edison Lighthouse (number one with Love Grows Where My Rosemary Goes in 1970, remember?). A God-given half an hour. 2pm: Head back to Covent Garden. An all-female string trio called Oopsie Mamushka are now in residence in the market. The violinist spends much of her time lying on the floor, which does not improve bowing. Did Jascha Heifetz ever play while supine? I don't think so. The Sigmas are back at 2.30, so this is a highly successful hour, though I never want to hear Pachelbel's canon again. 3pm: Cats in Drury Lane, playing to a small but enthusiastic house comprising elderly women, schoolgirls in neat uniforms, and Japanese tourists. Memory is wonderful, on all six occasions it is sung. Close to three hours, and suddenly I'm back in the game. 6pm: But not for long. I was relying on having a meal in the Savoy's American bar while listening to the pianist, but my highly respectable pair of jeans are deemed inappropriate by some bloke in a bow-tie. Distressed, I head for Oxford Street to join the demo, stopping to take in 10 minutes of reggae (courtesy of a somnolent busker) in Leicester Square. 8pm: Last chance saloon. The Borderline off Charing Cross Road (jeans more or less obligatory) for some Texan country-rock. This is why I wore the stetson, though I needn't have bothered as there's only one other cowboy hat in the house. What's wrong with these people? The excellent Slobberbone's lead singer looks like Neil Young - as do most of their middle-aged fans. Count two and a half hours, which includes lots of tuning up. 11pm: Head for the Dublin Castle in Camden Town to catch the end of DJ Downfall, two young men playing drums, gongs and synthesisers to a small, spacey audience. I have no idea what genre this is - techno, trance, garage, slightly poky third bedroom - and find it difficult to assimilate. (The fact that I am drinking my sixth pint of Kronenbourg is not helping.) A young technophile at the bar assures me that the music's fine, but the venue is wrong. "You want a place that stinks of poppers," he assures me gnomically. Midnight: Take a cab back to Soho. A notice next to the driver says: "Thank you for not smocking", so I assume the cab is pretty old. Fifteenth century perhaps. I have heard less than nine hours of live music (not including the slow beat of the protesters' drums and the frenzied whirr of police helicopters), and my cause is looking lost. I settle into Ronnie Scott's for some late-night jazz and a steak sandwich. The sandwich is great; the music - an engaging saxophonist from Cameroon called Manu Dibango - a bit too sophisticated for my taste. I had assumed the jazz would go on until 3am, but the final set ends at 2.15. I make half-hearted efforts to find another venue, try out a few dodgy bars, refuse various offers of drugs, sex and battered minicabs, and get a black cab home just after 3am, weary, drunk and a little deflated. I have stopped at the musical equivalent of Tower Bridge, 105 minutes short of my 760-minute target. Next year, the Savoy had better watch out for an anarchist in a stetson intent on settling an old score. fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Looking back at the old Caral | Plants glow to Mars
fields.body:
Looking back at the old Caral
The oldest city in the Americas has been dated using reeds. The ancient Peruvian site of Caral was built in 2627BC at the same time as the pyramids, according to the journal Scientist. The date is highly accurate as it was derived from radiocarbon dating bags made from reeds. The reeds only lived in the wild for a year; workers transported stones in these reed bags before placing them, rocks and all, inside the structures' retaining walls.

Plants glow to Mars
Scientists have engineered plants to glow blue on the red planet. A team headed by Rob Ferl, from the University of Florida, have created mustard plants (Arabidopsis) capable of communicating with scientists by splicing genes from jellyfish into their cells, which produce an iridescent blue protein. The plants fluoresce when they are stressed; different versions of the genetically engineered plants signal different problems, be it water deprivation, heat intolerance or a reaction to heavy metals. In 2007, Arabidopsis seeds will be planted in Martian soil and grown inside a mini-greenhouse on the landing vehicle. The long-term goal is to terraform Mars by using plants to reduce the carbon dioxide and produce oxygen to help make the planet habitable for humans.

No flies on lady flycatchers
Female flycatchers have conned males from another species of bird to help look after the youngsters. Normally mating between two different species results in sterile offspring, such as mules, the union of a horse and a donkey. The study, published in Nature, has shown that in the Czech Republic female collared flycatchers have taken to mating with male pied flycatchers. The females are able to produce relatively fertile male hybrids, and fertile, pure collared flycatcher babies as, when the male pied flycatcher is not looking, the females mate with male collared flycatchers. The pied stepfather helps raise the fledglings, most of which are not his.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Our review of On Green Dolphin Street, page 8, Saturday Review, April 28 said the film of Sebastian Faulks's earlier novel, Charlotte Gray, was directed by Gillian (X-Files) Armstrong. The director is indeed Gillian Armstrong, director of films including My Brilliant Career and Little Women, but she does not appear in The X-Files. The actress Gillian Anderson does.
fields.body:
Our review of On Green Dolphin Street, page 8, Saturday Review, April 28 said the film of Sebastian Faulks's earlier novel, Charlotte Gray, was directed by Gillian (X-Files) Armstrong. The director is indeed Gillian Armstrong, director of films including My Brilliant Career and Little Women, but she does not appear in The X-Files. The actress Gillian Anderson does.

The 1939 Timeless Test was not a legendary victory by the South African cricket team over the English, as we said in a report, Selling the same old story, Media, page 8, April 30. The match was abandoned as a draw after 10 days of play because the English team had to leave to catch their boat home.

The photograph of the disability rights activist Paul Darke, Society, page 4, yesterday, was wrongly captioned John Darke.

Our profile of Daphne Obang, Britain's first black woman social services director, Society, page 13, February 21, said she had trained as a psychiatric nurse. Ms Obang is a qualified psychiatric social worker, but has never claimed to be a trained psychiatric nurse. Two question marks were mistakenly left in the article in place of Ms Obang's age, which might have given the impression she was coy about revealing it. Ms Obang, who has no such reluctance, is 52.

fields.headline: Young Tories want Hague
fields.trailText: The views expressed in your article (Young Tories speculate on demise of Hague, May 2) are certainly not those of Conservative Future nationally.
fields.body:
The views expressed in your article (Young Tories speculate on demise of Hague, May 2) are certainly not those of Conservative Future nationally. We are fully supportive of William Hague and believe he is the best leader for our party. The comments quoted are from a closed private discussion board for our members and do not reflect the discussion in its entirety. Our membership has increased substantially during William Hague's leadership and many of our members are campaigning to win the election .

Conservative Future are proud to encourage open debate among our members and believe that it is a way to ensure we are an inclusive and proactive organisation.
Hannah Parker
National chairman, Conservative Future
hannahparker@conservativefuture.com

fields.body:

Worst of all is the constant, meaningless harping on "the people's ..." As Spin Doktor Goebbels said: "Ein Volk, ein Reich, ein Führer."

 The slogan may be trite, but to liken it to the Nazi concentration camp motto manages to be both juvenile and offensive. Mr Nairne should go away and learn some history - and you should stop selecting letters just because they fit the available space.

London

Taunton

Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester

Jill Theis

fields.headline: Bush's unguided missile
fields.trailText: As your leader (May 2) suggests, the Bush speech at the National Defense University raises serious concerns about the future of arms control.
fields.body:
As your leader (May 2) suggests, the Bush speech at the National Defense University raises serious concerns about the future of arms control. The main problem is that the decision to go ahead with some form of national missile defence (NMD) system threatens the traditional basis of strategic stability before any consensus has emerged on the form that a new system of stability might take.

The anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty of 1972 is widely regarded as the cornerstone of strategic stability. American officials in recent months, however, have indicated that the treaty is now "ancient history" and, although President Bush has yet to spell out what form of NMD system the US would like to employ, it is clear that any "national" system will undermine the treaty. What is now needed is a serious debate about how strategic stability is best achieved in the new post-cold war conditions. At present, there is no consensus and, if the US goes ahead unilaterally, the chances are that nuclear proliferation will accelerate and the existing, rather fragile, basis of global stability will be eroded.
Prof John Baylis
University of Wales Swansea
J.Baylis@swansea.ac.uk

 Your leader leaves out a key factor which was covered on your Finance pages yesterday. The US multinational, Boeing, the world's largest planemaker, is "in crisis"; it needs new areas for business so is now focusing on its "space and communications achievements and its missiles systems, which are thriving". Boeing will be the company which stands to make the most profit from NMD. And if the system doesn't "work" at present, so much the better for Boeing. The Bush administration will throw more and more dollars at it.
Rae Street
Littleborough, Lancs
raecnd@gn.apc.org

 Bush's defence schemes rely on UK-based facilities (such as Fylingdales) and places thus Britain in a strong position to influence the US administration. The gravest long-term threat to the US (and everyone else) is far more likely to come from the ravages of climate change. We must say no to cooperation with Bush and urge him instead to address the real threat of climate change.
Martin Hughes-Jones
Tiverton, Devon
martin.h@virgin.net

 A nuclear defensive shield only makes sense if it can intercept all missiles. If an enemy launches 100 and all but one are neutralised, then that is not a 99% success rate, it is a complete failure. At the same time, the system must not be used against civilian aircraft, weather balloons, or anything else non-aggressive that the radar detects. To deploy a system of that nature would require computer software that would have to be guaranteed to work all the time. That is something that cannot be envisaged at present, let alone achieved.
Chris Jager
Malmesbury, Wilts
chrisjage@cwcom.net

 Wide-ranging analysis of the credibility of a missile defence shield and its likely repercussions is urgent, but wouldn't your leader have been stronger without its emotive personal references? Did these result from an editorial pen changing a writer's wish to say that US policy on MD is becoming a menace to the snappier version that Mr Bush is? Most of us in the discipline of conflict research aim to focus on the problems while keeping personal references strictly friendly. Otherwise fruitful communication is put in jeopardy.
David Maxwell
Conflict Research Society

fields.headline: Arts chief puts his case
fields.trailText: Between them Madeleine Bunting (Comment, April 30) and Fiachra Gibbons (Comment, May 2) paint conflicting pictures of the arts council and the 10 regional arts boards. The reality lies in between.
fields.body:
Between them Madeleine Bunting (Comment, April 30) and Fiachra Gibbons (Comment, May 2) paint conflicting pictures of the arts council and the 10 regional arts boards. The reality lies in between. The council and the boards all agree that the current arts funding system does not work.

The arts council has made a radical, but we believe logical, proposal to join up the 11 separate organisations into one. This single organisation will have a smaller central office and a network of strong regional offices. It will give more funds to the regions, allow greater regional influence on national policy and speak for the arts with a united voice, while ensuring regional distinctiveness is maintained. We believe this will make the current complex system simpler and reduce the £36m administration cost, returning the savings to the arts.

The regional arts boards have achieved a huge amount for the arts, but we believe we can achieve much more together by becoming a single organisation. Ultimately, what matters most is that artists and arts organisations will get a better deal.
Gerry Robinson
Chairman, arts council of England

 The arts council forwards government money to the boards, but has no legal jurisdiction over them. Board members are trustees of independent charities and we can only act in the best interests of our charitable aims. It is unlikely many will find abolishing the only regional voice for the arts consonant with those responsibilities. Gerry needs to withdraw his diktat and then we can all sit down and work out how to cut bureaucracy in the arts.
Stephen Phillips
Member, south-east arts board

fields.headline: Sweet FA
fields.trailText: Adam Crozier of the FA says "Everyone agrees that we would like a national stadium" (Wembley project nears collapse, May 2). Well, I don't.
fields.body:
Adam Crozier of the FA says "Everyone agrees that we would like a national stadium" (Wembley project nears collapse, May 2). Well, I don't. As a pensioner I do not want one penny of taxpayers' money used to help build a new £640m football stadium at Wembley, where £20,000-a-week footballers can prance around. There is quite enough money in football to pay for it, with clubs like Manchester United and Arsenal Inc becoming some of the biggest businesses in Europe. The Dome should have shown us that what might start out as the call for a £150m loan will inexorably swell.
John E Moger
Braunston, Northants

 Why can't the Dome become the new Wembley stadium?
Jana Valencic
London

fields.headline: Wanted: a proper grassroots protest movement
fields.trailText: Many of the issues the May Day protesters were raising are of vital relevance to working people around the planet (Police set trap for protests, May 2).
fields.body:
Many of the issues the May Day protesters were raising on the environment, world debt, global warming, the privatisation of the public sector and the unaccountable power wielded by corporations are of vital relevance to working people around the planet (Police set trap for protests, May 2).

Unfortunately, as a trade unionist, I have to agree with Seumas Milne (No, prime minister, May 2) that the response from the so-called "official" union movement in Britain to these issues has been pathetic, being to uncritically support Labour party policies (often in defiance of their own conference policies) in return for the occasional crumbs thrown to them by Blair. We need a grassroots protest movement that everybody can feel comfortable in attending with their children without the fear of being beaten up by helmeted cops for demanding a better world.
Michael Herbert
Mossley, Lancs

 Jonathan Freedland's otherwise excellent analysis of the spread of globalisation (In place of violence, May 2) falls short when he tries to answer his own question: what should we do? Neither public demonstrations nor shareholder actions are enough. We need a coherent policy package to bring corporations and international finance back under democratic control. Such a package would include competition policies to restrict the market share of any one company, together with a "site here to sell here" policy for manufacturing and services, domesti cally or regionally, reducing the power of companies' threat to relocate by making access to markets dependent on physical presence.

The Green party is the only political party campaigning on a comprehensive alternative to the policies of globalisation. Mainstream politicians are powerless in the face of major corporations because they have chosen to be. It is a direct and logical consequence of deliberate decisions to hand over power to undemocratic, unaccountable bodies like the World Trade Organisation. It is time to take that power back.
Dr Caroline Lucas MEP

 I was one of the thousands of people detained at Oxford Circus by riot police for six hours without access to food, water or toilet facilities. Amongst those detained were tourists, workers on their lunch break, elderly people and children. I saw a woman with a baby in a pram and another small child unsuccessfully begging the police to be allowed out. Another man asked several different police officers for a drink of water so he could take some medicine - all refused.

Despite this, the mood was stoical and good humoured, with people chanting "We want out". Upon our eventual exit, many of us were photographed. Was the Tony Blair who condoned these incredibly restrictive measures the same Tony Blair praising the British history of peaceful protest at the South African Freedom Day celebrations?
Miranda Lewis
London

fields.headline: Fine tuning
fields.standfirst: Neil McIntosh  shows you how to listen to radio stations around the world - on your PC
fields.trailText: Neil McIntosh shows you how to listen to radio stations around the world - on your PC
fields.body:
The view out my window might be of a railway line in central Swindon on a damp weekday afternoon, but the sounds coming out my speakers are from a different world.

I'm listening to the early-morning sounds of KBSU AM, a radio station based in the American mid-west. A smooth voice reminds listeners, between records, that this is the only station to bring jazz 24-hours a day to northern Nevada and surrounding areas. She doesn't mention they serve the world too, via the internet, but then the locals would only be jealous if they knew. Thanks to a new cable modem connection, I'm hearing KBSU - an AM station - with near FM clarity, more clearly than the locals.

How is all this possible? Thanks to the wonders of streaming audio, an internet technology that has been around for a few years now, but which is reaching a level of maturity that makes it of much more interest to the mainstream net user.

With streaming audio, a radio station's output is broken up into bits and compressed for transmission across the net. At the user's end, software reassembles the bits and plays it back to you in "real time", as if it were a normal radio. There is only a few seconds' time lag.

The company that has led the way for streaming - both in terms of technology and user numbers - has been Real Networks, which now has 170m registered users around the world. Its RealPlayer software, which has now reached its eighth generation, runs equally well on PCs and Apple Macs.

Real has always supplied a free player to net users, but makes its money from selling enhanced players and the software that allows broadcasts to be made over the net.

Because of its need to make some money, getting a free RealPlayer has been a tricky exercise for a few years. Real is keen - make that very keen - for you to buy its top-end player, which, at the moment, is called RealPlayer 8 Plus. That costs $29.70 (around £21) and - lest I be accused of being a cheapskate - is a perfectly fine piece of software. It is just that if you are new to the world of internet audio and video, and you have a 56k modem or perhaps even slower, the paid-for software is unnecessary. The paid-for version adds enhancements, including a graphic equaliser and some cosmetic improvements, but Real's more basic, free player is perfectly adequate. It is just a question of finding it.

1 Go to www.real.com and you will be confronted with countless advertisements for the Plus version. You need to scroll to the bottom of the page where you will see links to "top free downloads". Choose the top one, for RealPlayer 8 Basic.

2 You would think that would put you on the way. Not so. This link then takes you to another page dominated by a plug for the Plus version. You will spot a tiny link (depending on the size of your screen, you might have to scroll down a little to find it) saying, begrudgingly, "RealPlayer 8 is our basic player". Click on this, and a screen will appear asking you a few details about who you are, what speed your connection to the internet is (this is the speed of your modem) and where you live.

3 After you have entered this, you will be asked to pick a download site - pick the one nearest you which, for readers in the UK, is London, and the software will download on to your hard disk.

4 Further straightforward instructions on what to do next, to complete installation on your PC or Mac, are also on this page.

Tip : it's a good idea to print this page out, as the installer software you have just downloaded will want to close your internet browser during the installation process. That way, you will still have the instructions to hand.

5 After you choose a download site the software will, finally, appear on your machine - a 56k modem will take around 20 minutes to download it. Follow the instructions you just printed out to complete the (straightforward) installation process.

After downloading: After you have successfully downloaded your software (and filled in a questionnaire that, annoyingly, repeats a lot of the questions asked online earlier), what next? It is time to go and explore the content available to you.

There are thousands of online radio stations from which to choose - and a few methods to start listening to them. You could click on the radio tuner button on the RealPlayer itself, which will load a web page in your browser with links to listings of thousands of stations. You could also call the page up directly in your browser by going to http://realguide.real.com/tuner.

Either way, you will be confronted with three highlighted stations of the day, and then it is a simple task to choose the genre of music or programming you want. When you see a station you want to listen to, click on the station heading, and RealPlayer will load, take a few seconds to tune in and "buffer" the content (to smooth out any interference over the internet), and then start playing.

You can also go directly to the station you are interested in. For instance, if you go to www.bbc.co.uk/radio1 (replace the number for radios one to five) you will find a link to let you listen to the station "live".

Net radio troubleshooter
The programme I'm listening to sounds terrible and/or keeps breaking up...

Net radio needs a smooth, fast connection to work well. You really need at least a 56k modem for it to work, and even then a number of factors could hamper its performance.

Your choice of ISP, the time of day and the quality of your telephone line could all determine the quality of your net connection. Check out http://webservices.cnet.com/bandwidth to test the speed of your connection (ignore the questions and just click on "go" to run the test). You need at least 40kbps for net audio to work properly, although the best results - including quite respectable sound - are reserved for those lucky enough to have a broadband cable or ADSL connection.

I get an error message, or nothing happens, when I try to launch a new radio station

There are other, less popular audio formats - Microsoft's Media Player ) and Apple's QuickTime at www.apple.com/quicktime are two - which some stations use. Follow the links above to install their free players.

Check out http://webservices.cnet.com/bandwidth to test the speed of your connection (ignore the questions and just click on "go" to run the test). You need at least 40kbps for net audio to work properly, although the best results - including quite respectable sound - are reserved for those lucky enough to have a broadband cable or ADSL connection. I get an error message, or nothing happens, when I try to launch a new radio station There are other, less popular audio formats - Microsoft's Media Player ) and Apple's QuickTime at www.apple.com/quicktime are two - which some stations use. Follow the links above to install their free players.

fields.headline: Phone games: next generation
fields.standfirst:
Star Trek fans are one of the many targets for an embryonic industry, writes Tim Green
More internet news
fields.trailText: Star Trek fans are one of the many targets for an embryonic industry, writes Tim Green
fields.body:
What is the most played electronic game in the world? Gran Turismo? Quake? Tetris? Pokémon Gold? Guess again. The answer, according to educated guesswork, is probably Snake. A simple black and white puzzler played on a mobile phone.

It is hard to prove this, of course. But consider the facts: it took Nintendo 10 years to sell 100m Game Boys whereas Nokia sold 128m handsets last year alone. And then look around the train carriage and see for yourself how many fingers are twiddling across phones that are otherwise not in use.

The amazing rise of the handset as a gaming device has got the video games industry in a flap. As recently as 1998 the notion of gaming on a phone had never occurred. By last week it was a big enough deal to warrant its own exhibition and conference.

Mobile Entertainment 2001, in Paris, was a fascinating showcase for this embryonic industry. The first thing that struck, however, was just how different it is from the "conventional" games business. There was no razzmatazz here. It is hard to justify pole dancers and Ferraris when your roster of games includes draughts and hangman.

But it is the simplicity of the "products" that has got everyone so excited. They appeal to everyone. Around 40m people in the UK now own a mobile and that means women, the over 40s, teenage girls - all those groups that conventional video games cannot reach.

At present the size, grey colours and graphical resolution of handsets, limit what can be done technically. But there are social restrictions to bear in mind, too. A good mobile game should be dipped into for five minutes at a time. It should also have a community element.

Chris Wright, business development manager of the Scottish mobile games company Digital Bridges, sums it up: "Wireless games should be competing with the crossword, not Quake. People will never sit for hours playing a game on a phone," he says.

Which is why the games on demonstration at Mobile Entertainment 2001 included simple golf simulations, football management, parlour games and quizzes. The latter proved the most interesting with Finland's Codeonline, one of many Nordic developers attending, previewing Who Wants To Be A Million aire? and Trivial Pursuit. Millionaire? has already been launched in Finland and will appear on a small screen near you later in the year.

It is easy to see why these major brands would want to hijack the handset. It gives fans a chance to buy into the phenomenon, form communities around them and thereby prolong their appeal. Indeed Riot-E, another Nordic studio, has already signed the mobile rights to Marvel and even Bridget Jones's Diary.

The community element in these games is critical. Crushed by 3G debt, the phone companies know that handset entertainment will only make them money if it involves sending data. Solo Snake does not earn anyone cash. Playing two-player hangman or post ing Millionaire high scores in an SMS does.

The French developer In Fusio is already bagging healthy sums this way. It embedded simple puzzle games on France Telecom handsets and invited users to play them offline and then compete for prizes by posting their progress in an SMS competition that costs 10p. Hundreds of thousands regularly do.

More typically, however, the networks simply host games (if you have a Wap connection, go to games on the screen menu) and tempt users to play them online. And as technologies such as general packet radio service (GPRS) improve data transfer rates, the hope is that games will move on to full colour action.

In the meantime, we can look forward to the first Star Trek game on a mobile. Star Trek First Duty will be launched later in the summer, an important release even if it does show that this new market can't quite shake off its nerdy roots. There has already been a request to translate the game into Klingon.

fields.headline: Anger at £500 fine for ruined building
fields.trailText: Heritage campaigners have criticised a decision by magistrates to impose what they say is an unacceptably small fine on two brothers who demolished a centuries old farmhouse.
fields.body:
Heritage campaigners have criticised a decision by magistrates to impose what they say is an unacceptably small fine on two brothers who demolished a centuries old farmhouse.

Dennis and Edwin Crane, both from Bawdrip in Somerset, were each fined £500 by Bridgwater magistrates' court after pleading guilty to "failing to give notice of intention to demolish" under the Buildings Act.

Glebe farmhouse, built some time between 1200 and the first record of its existence in 1578, was not a listed building. It was demolished in October last year, just days before English Heritage were due to inspect it. It was also the subject of a council planning application to build 16 houses on the site.

Donald Rayner, of the Council for the Protection of Rural England, said: "It sends a very dangerous message with regard to our heritage which isn't listed."

Jeremy Orchard, defending the brothers, said that the charge was purely a technical matter, and that they understood planning permission was to have been given for their application.

Jessica Mason, prosecuting on behalf of Sedgemoor district council, said the council would have preferred to preserve the farmhouse, but that a planning application could not be turned down on heritage grounds because it did not have listed building status.

A full archeological assessment is likely to be carried out before any new houses can be built.

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Game time | Penguin alert
fields.body:
Game time
The British computer industry will soon be packing its bags and jetting off to sunny Los Angeles for E3, the games trade exhibition and conference, which opens on May 16. Publishers will be showing off hundreds of games in progress - Sony is expected to show more than 100 titles for the PlayStation 2 - but insiders will be looking at Microsoft's Xbox console in particular. Microsoft will be under pressure to tell the trade when it will ship its forthcoming console, how much it will cost, and how many games will be finished in time. As usual, developments will be covered in E3 Show Daily at www.e3daily.com/v21/index.cvn

Penguin alert
In Japan, Sony is releasing a version of the GNU/Linux operating system for its PlayStation 2 games console (see www.jp.playstation.com/linux/). The system, based on Red Hat Linux, includes a 40 giga byte hard drive that connects via the PC Card slot, a keyboard and a mouse. Sony plans to release a thousand units in June, to gauge demand. However, the system is not compatible with European versions of the Play- Station 2, and at the moment there are no plans to market it in the US or the UK.

Linux is not new to the PlayStation 2, however: it is used in Sony's software development kit.

Survivor
Television shows seem to be hot properties in the games business at the moment. Eidos Interactive has made a fortune out of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? Activision is hard at work on a videogame version of The Weakest Link. Now Infogrames is getting excited because it has signed a licensing deal with CBS to produce a series of games based on the huge US hit, Survivor. The first title will be based on the current series, which is set in the Australian outback, and should be out by the end of the year.

In season
PlayStation 2 owners will eventually get a football management game, but they will have to wait until next year. Codemasters is developing a version of its popular Play-Station title, LMA 2002, for the PS2. (LMA is the League Managers Association.) PS2 owners are promised "a much improved match section with heightened Artificial Intelligence, detailed animations, action replays and after-match analysis".

fields.headline: Working the web: Vegans
fields.standfirst:
From recipes to which E numbers are made from sperm, the net is great for vegans, says Sanjida O'Connell
More internet news
fields.trailText: From recipes to which E numbers are made from sperm, the net is great for vegans, says Sanjida O'Connell
fields.body:
When I accept an invitation to a dinner party, my host's response is not usually one of unadulterated joy. It is not that I dribble, or talk incessantly about Ikea, it is just that I am vegan. Vegans do not eat animal products - that is no eggs, dairy, meat or fish.

By this stage my host has swallowed hard and is wondering how to disinvite me and this is when I usually have to say that no, ha, ha, ha, Iam not from the planet Vega, I and other vegans do not look like Kate Moss (if being skinny were that easy we would all be vegan), and yes, I would like more than a lettuce leaf and a sultana.

Thanks to CJD and foot and mouth, I feel that maybe, just maybe, people will not think I am quite so weird. After all, that something is seriously wrong with the farming industry is a belief long held by vegans and vegetarians. What most people do not understand is why anyone should want to be a vegan - vegetarianism is quite enough halo-polishing for one mortal. The reason it is not obvious is to do with the way in which food production has been removed from our everyday lives. The simple fact is that if you believe killing animals is wrong, then vegetarians are hypocritical - for instance, to get milk from a cow, she has to have a calf a year. This involves lots of hormones and arguably a bit of cruelty, but the point is, those baby cows then end up as veal. Even if they were kept and used as dairy cows themselves (which is unlikely in a non-organic farm), half will be males and they are just no use. They do not have udders and you only need one bull around. Most vegan sites have the lowdown on what is wrong with eating meat (and cheese, and eggs, and milk) - see www.vegansociety.com/info/infohome.html .

I do not talk about my diet much, but I do like cooking for people (but then get annoyed when they accuse me of slipping cheese in the tofu "cheesecake"). The point of cooking for others (apart from fun and the challenge of making Nigel Slater's recipes vegan) is that, contrary to popular opinion, not only can you buy substitutes for nearly everything (from mayonnaise to yogurt to ice cream) which taste as good as the real thing and are twice as healthy (lower in fat and cholesterol and higher in protein), it is possible to cook nice food that is cruelty free. Honest. The Vegan Chef site has a huge range of recipes; some even sound vaguely normal, such as fettucine and peas Alfredo. But where they really go to town is on the desserts, which range from baklava to bourbon, pumpkin and spiced pecan tart at www.veganchef.com.

Usually in restaurants you have to sweet talk the chef into leaving out butter and Parmesan, but in San Francisco they have opened a gourmet vegan restaurant. Fortunately for us, there is a book and recipes online, such as Thai green curry eggplant stack - vegetables sautéed in green curry with layers of crunchy, herb encrusted aubergine (www.millenniumrestaurant.com). Other gourmet recipes can be found at the Vegetarian Society's Cordon Vert site which I am glad to say tells us loud and clear how wonderful tofu is - you can make it into a steak or cheesecake, it only has 90 calories per 100g and more protein than meat. I was not sold on all the recipes though - tofu and peaches in brandy sounded delicious until I realised you also needed an onion and some stock to complete the meal.

For all those people out there faced with the scary prospect of dating a vegan (as one man said to me, "What no meat or ham?") there is Veganism for the Meat Eater. It does not cater to gourmets, but does have recipes that will make the average junk food meat eater feel at home - shepherd's pie, pizza, chicken fajitas and chocolate peanut-butter pie.

The official macrobiotic site features recipes from a book at www.montsebradford.com/recipes.htm that even I would blanche at - lemon mousse (from Cooking with Sea Vegetables) and pasta with beetroot sauce (from the Oh No, I've Ruined My Shirt School of Cooking) but I guess Madonna finds it appetising.

For the uninitiated, finding food you can eat can be trying, attempting to find anything else can be a real pain, even if you have been vegan long enough to know all the labels in Sainsbury's by heart - www.veganvillage.co.uk has information on vegan restaurants, travel, health and where to shop for cruelty-free cosmetics, and vegan shoes.

Now any good cook (or guest going to a dinner party) will have thought about drinks and this is where being vegan can frankly be annoying. Wine and beer are clarified after fermentation with a whole range of nasty substances - milk and egg proteins, dried blood, bones, swim bladders from fish - some sugar is even whitened using animal bones. http://sbvdesigns.com advises on which wines and beers are vegan, as well as providing information on other products. Did you know how many E numbers are made of sperm? Gin and champagne are fine, though, so here is to peach Bellinis and being a normal dinner party guest.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Extra ice | Plane risky
fields.body:
Extra ice
The Titanic Deckchair Rearrangement Corporation (TDCRC) has launched a new corporate website at www.tdcrc.com, which means Chris Locke has another book to flog. In this case it is Gonzo Marketing: Winning Through Worst Practices, which is due out in October. However, for those who missed The Cluetrain Manifesto or are too humour-challenged to read Entropy Gradient Reversals, the first chapter is available online at http://205.178.173.189/gonzomarkets.com.

Plane risky
What are your chances of surviving your next flight? Every air traveller wants to know the odds, and nobody is willing or able to say. However, you can get a good idea from the UK-based website at www.amigoingdown.com. Its calculations are based on published information such as the airline, the type of plane, the time of the flight, and so on. Since the odds are very small, the site can even be recommended to fearful flyers.

Webbies feat
Well done, the BBC. The nominations for the fifth annual Webby Awards have just been announced, and BBC websites have been nominated in two categories: News (http://news.bbc.co.uk) and Radio (www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice).

Other notable nominees include Fucked Company, Gamasutra and a lot of familiar old favourites.

Unfortunately, thanks to a bizarre bit of bloated programming, the web addresses for the various contenders do not link to their sites, only to the Webbies page www.webbyawards.com/nominees.

Nominations for two more categories, arts and technical achievement, will be announced on June 20, and the awards will be presented on July 18. Voting for the People's Voice winners should be open now.

Swamped
Which new website attracted more than 26m visitors in its first 54 hours online - and might have had many more if it had not been swamped? It was nothing pornographic, political or even pontifical. It was, in fact, the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation's site. Ellis Island has the arrival records of 22m immigrants who entered the port of New York between 1892 and 1924. If your ancestors came or went that way, the site at www.ellisislandrecords.org should have the details.

Brain power
In the early 80s, an outliner or "ideas processor" called Brainstorm attracted some attention. Now it has returned in a free trial version for Microsoft Windows, which can be downloaded from www.brainstormsw.com. In between, the program has been "Tebbo's mysterious hobby", David Tebbutt having been one of the people who helped popularise microcomputing in the UK. He says: "Apart from its original purpose, which was to enable high-speed thinking, planning and organising, it can now be used to publish 3D web pages of your thoughts and to blend the work of teams together."

Sight test
Politicians are notorious for their inability to understand or use the internet. The Stationery Office and a bunch of thinktanks hope to change that with a new website, Vox Politics www.voxpolitics.com). However, it is hard to say if it will have any impact, because a large proportion of its potential audience may well find it unreadable.

For Curlers Curl is a new computer language and CurlSurge a browser plug in that is going to revolutionise the web. "Curl technology is the next step in the evolution of our communication," according to Curl's founder, David Kranz. Yes, it may be just the usual rubbish. On the other hand, Curl has been bubbling away at MIT since 1995. The initial funding came from America's Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency, which started what became the internet, and the technology team includes the web's founder, Tim Berners-Lee. The first finished version of CurlSurge can now be downloaded from www.curl.com.

New & noted

 Master origami the Yamaha way: www.yamaha-motor.co.jp/eng/papercraft

 Teaching food safety in primary schools: www.nutrition.org.uk/eufoodsafety.htm

 A long-term degree project that is getting there: www.confluence.org

 And so are the beans: www.geocities.com/beansaroundtheworld

 Don't miss this: http://members.aol.com/fdipiazza/stickybaby.htm

Six of the best Chess

Kasparov Chess

www.kasparovchess.com

Weekly news

www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic.html

Ratings

www.fide.com

About guide

http://chess.about.com

Play online

http://w3.chess.net

www.chesslab.com

Links

He says: "Apart from its original purpose, which was to enable high-speed thinking, planning and organising, it can now be used to publish 3D web pages of your thoughts and to blend the work of teams together." Sight test Politicians are notorious for their inability to understand or use the internet. The Stationery Office and a bunch of thinktanks hope to change that with a new website, Vox Politics www.voxpolitics.com). However, it is hard to say if it will have any impact, because a large proportion of its potential audience may well find it unreadable. For Curlers Curl is a new computer language and CurlSurge a browser plug in that is going to revolutionise the web. "Curl technology is the next step in the evolution of our communication," according to Curl's founder, David Kranz. Yes, it may be just the usual rubbish. On the other hand, Curl has been bubbling away at MIT since 1995. The initial funding came from America's Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency, which started what became the internet, and the technology team includes the web's founder, Tim Berners-Lee. The first finished version of CurlSurge can now be downloaded from www.curl.com. fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Mobile operators might want to consider a mission to Mars, says Dave Birch. It might have a better chance of success than 3G.
fields.body:
Only weeks ago, the so-called third generation mobile networks seemed like the romantic new frontier. Now, denouncing them has become the latest fashionable sport. All the critics seem to agree that mobile phone operators face a perilous financial future.

Even before they start to earn money, mobile phone operators in Britain have indebted themselves to the tune of $40 billion for licences and other investments. This is roughly the same amount Nasa estimates it would cost to put a manned base on Mars. Not a few think that Nasa's plans stand a better chance of success.

If you consider the wider European market, the sums are staggering. In addition to £120bn for the licences, mobile operators face another £100bn of expenditure on infrastructure. European mobile operators now labour under about twice as much debt as Argentina.

And it is still not clear how they intend to pay for it. Most industry observers cannot foresee how revenues - from advertising, sponsorship, subscriptions and so on - are going to generate enough money to pay for infrastructure and service the debt.

According to Forrester Research, revenue per user - at present driven by voice and SMS - will fall by more than a third over the next four years. Clearly, the operators will have to come up with some interesting new services that require third generation technology to generate cash.

And the problem may get even worse. Many observers think 3G may constitute only a small part of the networked future, which envisions 4G mobile internet seamlessly interconnected with Bluetooth, 2G+ and other technologies. Moreover, not everybody is convinced that higher bandwidth will provide internet access and sell content to users. That is because content is not the answer to the 3G problem.

Consider the Wap experience. Wireless application protocol was designed to deliver content to wireless devices, but early experiences have proved disappointing. But the short message service has been a runaway success. SMS provides a way to send short text messages ("g-mail") between users.

In Norway, revenues generated by g-mail already exceed web-based advertising revenues. In Switzerland, Swisscom alone handles 10 times as many g-mails as the banking system does retail card transactions. In the UK, traffic is heading toward a billion g-mails per month, and the British Repetitive Strain Injury Association is warning that usage poses "massive risks".

We should not be so surprised. SMS provides connectivity, Wap provides content. As the history of interactive networks (eg, the telephone) shows, connectivity always wins. No wonder SMS is more popular than Wap: people value human beings more than third-party content.

So if content isn't the killer application and new revenue sources won't make enough to balance the books, is 3G doomed? I don't think so.

Firstly, operators will never have to face the entire cost of building 3G infrastructure, choosing to share costs instead. New mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs), like Virgin Mobile in the UK, will increase the range and variety of services built on top of that infrastructure.

Secondly, the old way of making money - through voice and data traffic - will grow more than many anticipate when the ability to exchange multimedia gets added into the voice and g-mail mix. Imagine, for example, SMS being superceded by some sort of extra-large message service - let's call it the BEMS, for bloody enormous message service - that would send maps to my car, video clips from my kids to my mum, and MP3 tracks to me while I am sitting bored on a train.

Third, mobile phones will inevitably become transactional devices, used to pay bills. It makes perfect sense. After all, everybody has a phone, everybody carries it with them all the time, and all phones have a tamper-resistant computer chip inside them - the perfect place to store personal data. Identity, authentication and payments will become central to 3G and other mobile propositions.

This trend towards mobile phones as mobile transactors is already visible in Asia, where mobile penetration far outstrips the internet and credit cards. Japan's i-mode system already collects money via subscribers' bills and passes it on (minus a healthy commission) to mobile content providers. This service is about to be extended to vending machines.

Similar services are just getting off the ground in Europe. In Spain, Movilpago is launching a service where shoppers can pay by punching in their phone number. In Finland, Sonera has been offering payments via mobile phone at vending machines, car washes and other outlets for some time. In Sweden you can pay for car parking with your mobile phone. Back in the UK, the ticket machines at Woking don't even take £20 notes.

I think it would be fun if BT, Orange, Hutchison and the rest would band together to fund the Mars base. But assuming that's not going to happen, it's still too early to declare that 3G is dead.
