fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Gungriffon Blaze | Silpheed | Virtual Kasparov
fields.body:
Sony PlayStation 2 £39.99 Swing/Virgin ***
Sometimes playing games can get a bit too serious. Whether it is fretting over your creature in Black and White, gathering resources in Command and Conquer or losing a last-minute goal in Championship Manager, there are times when your patience will be stretched to the limit.

Thankfully there are two new releases that rely on reflexes, weapon upgrades and sheer adrenaline. Gungriffon Blaze and Silpheed are the two latest titles to replace plot, strategy and forward planning with old-fashioned blasting.

Gungriffon Blaze is a typically Japanese take on the future, with giant mech-robots battling it out in a war-torn environment. As you would expect from the PS2, the graphics are decent but you will barely notice as you get straight into the action.

Your task is to destroy all enemies and installations while gathering up the goodies left behind. The controls are initially tricky, with beginners likely to spend much of the time shooting the ground. But persevere and you will be strafing and flying like an anime legend. Radio crackle and realistic smoke effects add to the experience, making Gungriffon a pleasant, if short-term, destroyer.

However, if even this sounds like too much hard work then another Japanese shoot-em-up may appeal. Silpheed offers a reminder of simpler days. The backdrops are pretty (as you'd expect on PS2) but this a 2D blaster that, graphics aside, could have been produced anytime since the early 1980s.

Controlling a spacecraft your aim is to shoot everything. There are no intricate plots or subtle nuances - this is pure finger-on-fire-button blasting. Which makes it marvellous stress relief, and a welcome change from strategy and 100 page manuals.

Neither game will last forever - perhaps a week or two for both - but they are a reminder that gaming does not have to be hard work. (GH)

Virtual Kasparov
Sony PlayStation £19.99 Titus/Virgin ***
Absolute beginners can start with the tutorials, learn the moves and, within a couple of hours, be thrashing this program at chess. It is not that the tutorials, though reasonably well done, have any magical qualities.

Nor has Garry Kasparov, the world's best chess player for the past two decades, lost his touch. It is simply that the program kindly starts you off at beginner's level 1, where it does not seem to know much more than the moves itself.

Players with just a smidgeon of talent or commitment should then be able to make rapid progress. There are 23 levels in all, and it is not until you get to the champions section, which starts at level 18, that the game becomes hard to beat. At the highest level, it is certainly far too good for every one who is likely to play chess on a PlayStation, apart, perhaps, from the odd child prodigy.

As usual there is a huge selection of virtual chess sets, most of them unusable, and a 3D graphics option that you would have to be mad to use. But a couple of the 2D sets are very good indeed.

Virtual Kasparov also has sections on chess history and famous chess champions, with nine commented games, plus a section on Kasparov with more than 50 of his best games.

In fact, Virtual Kasparov has just about everything you would expect from a good PC program, the unusual thing being that it is running on a PlayStation.

And by both PlayStation and PC standards, it comes at an attractive price. (JS)

fields.headline: Inventor's toolkit
fields.standfirst: Trevor Baylis invented the Freeplay self-powered radio and is hoping to establish an Inventors Academy in the UK
fields.trailText: Trevor Baylis invented the Freeplay self-powered radio and is hoping to establish an Inventors Academy in the UK
fields.body:
Is the UK holding its own in terms of technology and innovation? Teaching kids about invention should be part of the national curriculum. I went to Hoover years ago and suggested they place an ioniser in the back of a vacuum cleaner but they did not even pay me the courtesy of a reply. This made me realise how many inventors are facing that same indifference. Before, if I said I was an inventor, people would look at me like I had a disease, yet artists and designers are never questioned. Design is the thing that sells the concept of the invention but it is invention that it is all about. If we manage to establish an Inventors Academy we could teach how necessary a prototype is and, more importantly, explain intellectual property, patents and design registration. We have to make sure that the venture capitalists do not keep ripping off inventors in this country.

What was your first encounter with computers? It was a BBC B. I was intrigued because you could play snakes and ladders on it, but not much else. It was extremely useful as a word processor. At present we have an Acer and a Compaq linked in holy matrimony and we are having an ADSL line put in because I do so many radio interviews.

Any plans for a clockwork PC? When I was in Botswana there was an eMate on the Apple stand next to me. We took power from one of my radios and managed to get about 14 minutes of play time from the computer. As time passes the energy requirements of these gizmos is coming right down - 10 years ago you needed a car battery to run a mobile phone and now they are the size of a smart card. As we accelerate the performance of the output of these little generators there is no doubt that computers will come into the frame. At home I have a pulley with a bucket on a rope over a tree. When it is released it drives a gearbox and dynamo, which powers my radio. When people say, "How long does the radio run?" I say, "How tall is the tree?"

Are there any gadgets you wish you'd helped invent? My house is known as the graveyard of a thousand domestic appliances. I would love the facilities to do Cadam design where you can produce holograms on a screen then reproduce them in a vat of some kind. A lot of colleges have amazing rapid prototyping machines, which fuse your holographic image into plastic. It would be rather nice to have your idea on the screen then be able to see your dream 20 minutes later.

Any favourite websites? I use the AOL site for keeping up on internet matters. I use PowerPoint for presentations, so the net is useful for researching those.

Visit: www.freeplay.net

fields.headline: Apple unveils all new iBook
fields.trailText: Apple has unveiled a "thinner, lighter and cheaper" version of the iBook, the portable aimed at education and home users.
fields.body:
Apple has unveiled a "thinner, lighter and cheaper" version of the iBook, the portable aimed at education and home users.

The new laptop bears little resemblance to its colourful but bulky predecessor. The old iBook's rounded corners and rubberised edges have gone, to be replaced by an all-white case which bears a closer resemblance to Apple's new Titanium PowerBook laptops, launched earlier this year.

The iBook, previously criticised for its weight and size, feels different too - two pounds lighter at 4.9 pounds, and thinner, at 1.35 inches.

The machines sport a 500MHz PowerPC G3 processor, with 10GB hard drive as standard. Buyers will have the option of versions with a CD-Rom drive, DVD-Rom drive, CD-RW (for creating music CDs) or a combo drive that has CD-RW and DVD playback capability.

Reflecting Apple's drive into multimedia, all models will have a FireWire port to connect to devices such as digital video cameras, two USB ports, a video output port to attach external displays and an AV port to output to TVs.

The bottom-end CD-Rom version will have only 64MB of memory as standard, which means it will not be able to run the new OSX operating system without extra memory, but all other versions will have 128MB included in the price.

The new iBooks will start at $1,299 in the US. As Online went to press, details of UK availability and pricing were not known.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Googled out
Unfortunately SA Mathieson's description of Google's UK site is unintentionally, but seriously, misleading (Online, April 26). Google implies that by selecting "Pages from the UK" it is listing only those pages originating from UK sites and weeding out all those from abroad.

All that happens is that clicking UK pages removes from the list all pages which do not have UK as part of their URL. So authors who have chosen to show that their sites are not-for-profit and internationally relevant by choosing .org as a domain, are excluded.

My own site is the only one dealing comprehensively with the history of the Victorian Turkish bath, and lists the few which remain open. Many of its hits are from the US and the Commonwealth.

On Google.com it rates first from 712 sites under "Victorian Turkish baths", and first from 12,700 sites under "Turkish baths". In "Pages from the UK" it does not appear at all. A friend from Sussex University runs thespasdirectory.com and his top relevance rating on Google.com is similarly replaced by absence from the UK pages.

In fact, Google, which has always been the best for relevance in information searches, has, at a stroke, thrown away the benefit of its unique rating system. It is important that searchers should realise that "Pages from the UK" actually means some pages.
Malcolm Shifrin
malcolm@victorianturkishbath.org

Gender free
As a mum of three and like many women of my age, I have become computer literate after a stage of panic and sweat at the mere sight of a computer. I regularly use the internet and I found it so interesting that I taught myself and set up a website called www.welfed.com.

We started from scratch and now, after six months and a tiny investment - which helped buy the computers - we have totalled 220,000 hits, we have been visited by 30,000 people and we get lots of letters from women and from men who like the site because it is quick, easy to navigate, full of information and there is no talk about nappies or make-up.

I found Deborah Bee's article patronising (Online, April 19). There are many sites for women, as well as for men, that offer a virtual space for chat and gossip; some people enjoy spaces like that. There are many sites, for women and for men, which are design rich and very slow to download; some people like them too. On the other hand there are many sites, like ours, that offer quick access to the information needed, help and a sense of sharing.

The internet is a wonderful tool but as with everything else it needs practice and it becomes easier to search and find what you are looking for once you know how - it makes no difference if you are a man, a woman or a mum.
Cristina Adams
cristina@welfed.com

More Pogo
I was delighted to read Bill Rivers's letter (Feedback, April 26). In particular, the fact that Mr Rivers concurs with our view that "[Pogo] could definitely become the handset of choice compared to Wap over GSM". This is most encouraging.

Nevertheless, the letter raised an issue regarding one aspect of our approach which requires a response. Mr Rivers refers to "images" as our "Achilles heel" and suggests that to provide access to the internet over the restricted bandwidth of GSM, Pogo must surely process web content into "slimmed-down versions" without JPEG image files.

Mr Rivers is absolutely correct that images and graphics are a key part of the web but his scepticism of our ability to deliver images at usable speeds is misfounded. It is exactly this ability to deliver full web pages to mobile users as they would expect to see them that we believe differentiates the Pogo product.

Our compression system does transmit JPEGS - approximately 3.5 times faster using our technology than without - and we have patents filed to protect the way that we do this. Our business is founded on the belief that effective use of compression in an affordable handset provides the mobile industry with a very real step towards 3G.

The key word is "effective", as compression in itself is not the answer. It is what you do with it that counts, and for all our technological innovation, our focus has always been to provide mobile users with usable, affordable access to the real internet and to web-based services which add value to their daily lives. Anything short of this will risk disappointing an expectant and eager marketplace.
Tim Critchley
Pogo Technology Ltd tim.critchley@pogo-tech.com

Film head
Yes, William Gibson got in before Neal Stephenson, and plainly The Matrix is a retread of themes he did first (Online, April 26). But Gibson has (just) inspired more than one movie. Johnny Mnemonic and New Rose Hotel were both full-length features adapted from short stories in Burning Chrome, while a third, The Gernsback Continuum, was filmed as a short, and shown with Johnny Mnemonic in Britain. David Roy
david.roy@computerchannel.com

Lavatorial
The Tyneside word for toilet is netty, so, is Netiquette (Online April 19) the correct way to behave in the toilet? Bob Davenport
bob.davenport@lineone.net

I found Deborah Bee's article patronising (Online, April 19). There are many sites for women, as well as for men, that offer a virtual space for chat and gossip; some people enjoy spaces like that. There are many sites, for women and for men, which are design rich and very slow to download; some people like them too. On the other hand there are many sites, like ours, that offer quick access to the information needed, help and a sense of sharing. The internet is a wonderful tool but as with everything else it needs practice and it becomes easier to search and find what you are looking for once you know how - it makes no difference if you are a man, a woman or a mum. Cristina Adams cristina@welfed.com More Pogo I was delighted to read Bill Rivers's letter (Feedback, April 26). In particular, the fact that Mr Rivers concurs with our view that "[Pogo] could definitely become the handset of choice compared to Wap over GSM". This is most encouraging. Nevertheless, the letter raised an issue regarding one aspect of our approach which requires a response. Mr Rivers refers to "images" as our "Achilles heel" and suggests that to provide access to the internet over the restricted bandwidth of GSM, Pogo must surely process web content into "slimmed-down versions" without JPEG image files. Mr Rivers is absolutely correct that images and graphics are a key part of the web but his scepticism of our ability to deliver images at usable speeds is misfounded. It is exactly this ability to deliver full web pages to mobile users as they would expect to see them that we believe differentiates the Pogo product. Our compression system does transmit JPEGS - approximately 3.5 times faster using our technology than without - and we have patents filed to protect the way that we do this. Our business is founded on the belief that effective use of compression in an affordable handset provides the mobile industry with a very real step towards 3G. The key word is "effective", as compression in itself is not the answer. It is what you do with it that counts, and for all our technological innovation, our focus has always been to provide mobile users with usable, affordable access to the real internet and to web-based services which add value to their daily lives. Anything short of this will risk disappointing an expectant and eager marketplace. But Gibson has (just) inspired more than one movie. Johnny Mnemonic and New Rose Hotel were both full-length features adapted from short stories in Burning Chrome, while a third, The Gernsback Continuum, was filmed as a short, and shown with Johnny Mnemonic in Britain. David Roy david.roy@computerchannel.com Lavatorial The Tyneside word for toilet is netty, so, is Netiquette (Online April 19) the correct way to behave in the toilet? Bob Davenport bob.davenport@lineone.net

webTitle: Mobiles that must be on steroids

fields.headline: Mobiles that must be on steroids
fields.standfirst: It may look like a phone, but the ultimate personal digital assistant will also be as good as the best personal organisers and stop you getting lost too.  Jack Schofield  reports
fields.trailText: It may look like a phone, but the ultimate personal digital assistant will also be as good as the best personal organisers and stop you getting lost too. Jack Schofield reports
fields.body:
We all love our gadgets, but you can have too much of a good thing. Once you are packing a mobile phone, an electronic organiser, an MP3 music player and a digital tape recorder, it is hard to find pockets or purse-room for the electronic book, the Game Boy, the digital camera, the portable radio, the pocket calculator, the satellite positioning system and the handy translator that lets you type in an English word and look up the Russian equivalent.

Do not worry, the consumer electronics giants have a solution: combine half a dozen gadgets into a single device. This idea is seen as the salvation of the mobile phone industry, which is suffering from a slump in handset sales. (Ericsson and Motorola are closing factories, while Siemens is shedding staff.)

It is also seen as prime territory by computer industry giants such as Compaq and Hewlett-Packard, which are looking for new markets as growth slows in the PC sector.

Adding extra functions could give many people the incentive to buy a new mobile phone or handheld computer. And the ultimate PDA (personal digital assistant) will do just about anything. It will handle both voice and data calls, send SMS text messages, and access the internet to collect email and faxes and surf the web. It will have a built-in electronic book reader, an MP3 player and it will play games. It will keep track of where you are, using location services and on-screen street maps.

In the future, you may well use it not just to keep track of your spending, but to pay for things via its "electronic wallet" facility. And if your PDA-phone on steroids does not have a built-in camera, you will be able to plug one in, either to take snapshots or to use for videoconferencing.

We are not there yet, but we are getting close. Mark Squires, Nokia's business development manager, says his new Nokia 9210 Communicator phone can already do most of those things, "and I haven't even started to load software on it yet".

The Compaq iPaq and HP Jornada palmtop computers are also being sold as multifunction devices. The built-in software includes pocket versions of Microsoft Word, Excel, Internet Explorer and Money, and users who buy Microsoft's Autoroute package can load Pocket Streets.

These PocketPCs also include an electronic book reader, a voice recording facility and a Windows Media Audio player as standard. What they do not have is built-in mobile phone communications, but that is the sort of thing that could be added via a plug-in module. The VisorPhone, which plugs into a Handspring palmtop running Palm OS, is one example.

The resulting competition should be good for consumers: all sorts of gizmos will be competing for the space in your pocket, and the pound in your pocket. (More likely several hundred pounds.) But it may also create a lot of confusion.

Of course, everyone agrees the future will be mobile and wireless. However, there are broad battle lines being drawn between two camps. On one side are the voice-centric products, such as mobile phones. On the other are data-centric devices, such as PDAs. But both will have similar functions, and may well use the same software. The leading candidates include Palm OS, Symbian's version of Epoc, spun out of Psion, and Microsoft's PocketPC. Some suppliers are also expected to use mobile versions of GNU/Linux, the free "open source" clone of the Unix operating system.

Ultimately, many people expect the market to "shake down", as Squires puts it, to a small number of devices. The biggest, heaviest and probably the most expensive will be "clamshell" devices with built-in keyboards and screens, such as the Psion-based Nokia 9210 Communicator and Hewlett-Packard Jornada 720, which runs Microsoft Windows CE (originally, Consumer Electronics). Screen resolution should be about 640 by 240 pixels: half a PC's standard VGA screen.

These devices appeal to people who really need to enter data on the move, not just look up information downloaded from a PC or the web.

The next class will be multimedia devices that replace the keyboard with handwrit ing recognition on a touch-sensitive screen, which should be at least quarter-VGA (320 by 240 pixels). You will not hold these devices up to your ear to make phone calls - that makes it hard to see the screen - but use an earpiece instead. So far, this category is populated mostly by "concept phones" and reference devices such as Symbian's Quartz. However, PocketPC-based phones such as the Sagem and Trium Mondo, and the Handspring VisorPhone, come close.

The third category is the "smart phone". This is basically a smaller and lighter version of the multimedia device but in the shape of a conventional mobile phone. The screen will be about half the size (and less than half the price), but could have the same resolution. The smart phone uses a numeric keypad instead of handwriting recognition. Examples include the Ericsson R520, and a string of forthcoming devices based on Microsoft's Stinger reference phone, such as the Sendo 100.

The smallest, lightest and cheapest device is the ordinary mobile phone, but it will become increasingly less ordinary.

Steve Walker, Ericsson's marketing and new business director for consumer products, says: "There will always be an entry level segment, but what's included in that will increase as the cost of implementation falls."

Walker points out that most phones can now handle Wap (wireless application protocol) for limited internet access, as well as text messaging. In the future, he thinks they will also include Blue tooth networking, so they can connect wirelessly to other devices such as notebook computers.

Of course, not everyone will want a device that does everything, and Squires, from Nokia, points out that different products have different usage patterns. The PDA you might want to carry in a briefcase or use in the car may not be what you want to slip into your pocket when you nip down to the pub.

Walker agrees that "one size definitely does not fit all", and adds that putting everything into a single device makes it hard to upgrade one element without changing the others.

Stacey Wu, a senior analyst with Mobile Insights in Mountain View, California, thinks the people who are most likely to buy a "convergence device" - one that combines a palmtop computer with a mobile phone - will be the ones who already use PDAs.

"I think there will be a desire to have everything in one device, but maybe after trying it, some people will want to back down and have two or more," says Wu. "Right now, multifunction devices take a lot of power and you may need to recharge them every day or every other day." She thinks that "technology-savvy" types will like multifunction devices but most people don't want the bother involved in using them.

Wu also thinks the different markets may develop differently. In Europe, for example, we have more people who use clamshell devices such as the Psion handhelds. In Japan, where the i-mode data service is dominant, they are much keener on phones with big screens, whereas in the US, Palm handhelds are popular.

There is also evidence that, to an extent, different types of product are being adopted in different markets. Many big companies, for example, are buying PocketPC systems, especially Compaq's iPaq, because it is expandable and programmable and fits into their IT systems. Smaller organisations are using cheaper Palm and Palm-compatible handhelds, which are often bought by individuals and claimed back "on expenses". People who don't need devices to handle business data tend to go for smart phones.

However, there is no doubt that both the handset manufacturers and network operators would like us to upgrade to more powerful devices. If we don't, we won't be able to make full use of the new 2.5G and 3G data services that the networks want to sell us. Some analysts expect these enhanced data services, including music and games, to generate half their total income by 2004-5.

Mark Edwards, sales and marketing director at Symbian, which is developing "converged" Psion-based software for mobile phones, says the networks are watching their ARPUs, or average revenue per unit.

Originally, the operators were under pressure to sign up as many subscribers as possible, he says, "but now they are starting to ask themselves 'which customers do we want?' " The answer is the smaller number of big spenders who are most likely to use data services.

So it is not just a question of delivering features simply by building them into phones. The networks also have to deliver services that people will use in preference to the alternatives. And as Wap has shown, that may not be as easy as it sounds.

As Walker observes laconically: "We've had clocks built into mobile phones for a long time, but I haven't seen too many people who've given up their watches."

fields.headline: Mr Bush's bad dream
fields.trailText: That Field Of Dreams is George Bush's favourite film provides a clue to his presidency, now 100 days old. Set in mid-west Iowa, the movie is about baseball, Mr Bush's abiding passion. And it is about fantasy as, one by one, the all-time greats of the game's bygone eras emerge from the towering maize, to live and play again. Picking up the theme, Mr Bush's main concern since taking office has been to put the clock back. He seems set in a time-warp, harking back to a United States that he thinks existed in his 1950s childhood but has long since disappeared back into the corn.
fields.body:
That Field Of Dreams is George Bush's favourite film provides a clue to his presidency, now 100 days old. Set in mid-west Iowa, the movie is about baseball, Mr Bush's abiding passion. And it is about fantasy as, one by one, the all-time greats of the game's bygone eras emerge from the towering maize, to live and play again. Picking up the theme, Mr Bush's main concern since taking office has been to put the clock back. He seems set in a time-warp, harking back to a United States that he thinks existed in his 1950s childhood but has long since disappeared back into the corn.

Mr Bush's inherited political fantasy is of a nation that is homogeneous at home and dominant and unchallengeable abroad. It is of a society that is God-fearing, uniform and structured, that upholds the old values because they are simply the best, that leads the world because the world simply knows it is right. That Mr Bush is not a deep thinker has become apparent to all. But what is more troubling is that this president does not seem to question or delve beneath the superficial images that flicker across his screen, be they of China (atheistic communists), Iraq (evil dictatorship), or environmentalists (anti-business liberals). He is beguiled by fatuous ideas of the make-believe past, by its false certainties and old totems. Mr Bush pays lip service to multiculturalism and other aspects of a modern, changing US. But that is all. He has a sure grasp on what never was but little purchase on what may be in future.

Mr Bush portrays himself as a moral man. He is a regular churchgoer, a fitness fanatic who sees in a healthy body the foundation of a healthy mind. Having vowed to give the Oval Office a "good scrubbing" after Bill Clinton's depredations, he has has invited faith-based groups to play a role in government and banned overseas aid for organisations offering abortion services. He repeatedly justifies his decisions as "the right thing to do".

Were he a more insightful man, Mr Bush might glimpse the contradictions between reality and this risible self-righteousness - and the outrage that results. What is remotely moral about the systematic rollback of industrial, business, environment and workplace regulations and safeguards? How does Mr Bush square his sworn duty to lead the nation as a whole with his regressive tax cuts and his abject surrender to special interests such as Big Oil, Big Tobacco and what used to be called the military-industrial complex? When he blithely tears up the Kyoto global warming protocol and instructs his treasury secretary to block IMF-World Bank bailouts for developing world economies, little wonder many ask what ethical universe Mr Bush inhabits. These and other Bush actions in the first 100 days have been deeply immoral. They proceed not from faith and principle but from arrogance and ignorance.

Living with Mr Bush in future will require a clear understanding of his limitations but also of these self-deceptions. Let us bury that "compassionate" tag. This is conscience-less conservatism. And it is dangerous to your health.

webTitle: Hague fails to end Tories' race row rift

fields.headline: Hague fails to end Tories' race row rift
fields.trailText: William Hague has forced the maverick MP at the centre of the Conservatives' latest race row to apologise, but that wasn't good enough for the party's leading black figure, Lord Taylor. He refused to accept that the public humiliation of John Townend was sufficient punishment, and demanded that the Yorkshire East MP be suspended from the party.
fields.body:
William Hague has forced the maverick MP at the centre of the Conservatives' latest race row to apologise, but that wasn't good enough for the party's leading black figure, Lord Taylor. He refused to accept that the public humiliation of John Townend was sufficient punishment, and demanded that the Yorkshire East MP be suspended from the party.

Mr Townend started the row in March when he said immigration was undermining Britain's "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society", and praised Enoch Powell's notorious "rivers of blood" speech. He stirred the pot again last week, saying the British were becoming a "mongrel race".

Mr Hague repudiated Mr Townend's comments, but refused to discipline him, because he will not be standing at the next election. However, on Monday, after coming under increasing pressure from within his party, including the shadow cabinet, he forced Mr Townend to sign a statement apologising for his "ill-chosen words" and undertaking "not to repeat them under any circumstances".

But Lord Taylor called the move "too little, too late". He accused the Conservative leader of "treating the electorate like idiots", adding: "Mr Hague has really been forced into this position, which is pretty weak anyway. He has vacillated over a number of days." The peer said Mr Townend would, "by signing a piece of paper, just go away laughing".

Having previously demanded that Mr Townend be expelled, Lord Taylor's proposal that he lose the Tory Whip was a retreat, but most MPs believed that Lord Taylor had won enough ground not to carry out his earlier threat to quit the party in protest. However, his determination to make the Tories sweat by not immediately saying so left has Hague aides nervous.

Lord Taylor, who endured racist abuse when he stood unsuccessfully as a Tory candidate in Cheltenham in 1992, had said last week: "The leader of the Conservative party prides himself on his judo and 14-pints-a-day macho image. Now is his chance to demonstrate real macho leadership by withdrawing the Whip from Mr Townend and booting him out of the Conservative party . . . The Conservative party may be a broad church, but it cannot contain both Mr Townend and people like me."

Lord Taylor did make one immediate gesture of conciliation on Monday. He agreed to sign an open letter - also signed by 11 black and Asian Tory MEPs and candidates - urging people of all communities to back the party at the general election.

However, the issue shows no signs of going away. The MP for Tewkesbury, Laurence Robertson, told BBC2's Newsnight that Mr Townend's remarks had been "basically true, but rather offensive in the way they were put forward".

"Having too many people in different multiracial groups makes society very difficult to manage, especially in certain parts of the country," Mr Robertson added. "It is about how successful can you be in cramming people together from differentcultures and expecting them all to get on in a very harmonious way. It is not that easy to manage that kind of society." Judith Edwards, the black Tory candidate for Liverpool Riverside, said Mr Robertson's comments "will need to be studied very closely, and he will also possibly be required to give an explanation".

Mr Hague's hopes of drawing a line under the row were further damaged when Sir Edward Heath contrasted his handling of the current situation with the way Sir Edward had immediately sacked Mr Powell from the shadow cabinet over his 1968 speech.

But the former prime minister added: "Of course, with an opposition which is placed in the position that they are, which is on the extreme right, you can't expect them to do what I did. So many of them feel and think the same way."

The Asian Conservative peer Lady Flather, who had also called for Mr Townend's expulsion, said the matter should be allowed to rest, although she was critical of Mr Hague's inaction: "He always talked about firm leadership, and then he let this happen."

webTitle: Dome no match for festival of 51

fields.headline: Dome no match for festival of 51
fields.standfirst: The rousing memory of the Festival of Britain, which opened 50 years ago today, only illustrates the poverty of public endeavour today, says Guardian architecture critic Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: The rousing memory of the Festival of Britain, which opened 50 years ago today, only illustrates the poverty of public endeavour today, says Guardian architecture critic Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
The Festival of Britain opened on London's South Bank 50 years ago today. It poured with rain as the great British public passed through the turnstiles, all 6m of them, over the next five months.

There was much to see and enjoy. Concerts in the brave new Royal Festival Hall. Marvels of modern engineering and science in the flying-saucer shaped Dome of Discovery. Then there was the Skylon, a sculpted needle of steel and aluminium, touching the ground as economically as a ballet dancer and appearing to disappear into the ether (or was it the low London clouds?) as visitors gazed up its 300ft height.

Improving, educational, whimsical and ever-so-slightly kitsch, the Festival was judged a big success even though teased by critics and satirists. "Don't make fun of the Festival/Don't make fun of the fair", mooed a distinctly cowish Noel Coward, while a nation which had tightened its collective belt through six years of war and six more of Austerity, with its ration books and powdered-eggs, shortages of coal and basic building materials, set out to enjoy itself under the paternalistic gaze of Clement Attlee's do-gooding Labour government.

In comparison with last year's hapless and patronising Millennium Experience, one decidedly unamazing day, held in the dome on the wind-whipped north Greenwich peninsula, the Festival of Britain had been a colourful symbol of a country that was trying its best to reach the broad sunlit uplands Churchill spoke of in one of his inspiring wartime radio broadcasts. The really big difference between the failure of the former and the success of the later is that in 1951 Britain really was, more or less, a united nation.

It was possible to pull off an event like the Festival at such an economically inauspicious time because people were willing to pull together. The whole country had been militarised until only recently in the fight against Hitler and Hirohito.

Of course there were spivs, cynics, lazy gits and ne'er-do-wells, as at any time in history, yet there was a touching innocence about the boy-scoutish, girl-guideish spirit that underpinned the Dome of Discovery and the Skylon. "Together we'll build tomorrow today", sang choirs of schoolchildren during the Festival.

Forty-nine years down the line - the poor old Millennium Experience was a year early and not even held in the Millennium year - and Britain was decidedly untogether, socially speaking. What most people wanted after the consumer-crazy, privatisation-mad Thatcher years seemed to be shopping, frocks, holidays, shares, celebrity gossip, shopping malls, stereos, junk food and baseball caps.

What they wanted to do, above all, was their own selfish thing. Look after number one, squire. Aggressive individualism had all but eradicated the collective spirit that informed the Festival of Britain. All things private were good: all things public, bad.

The Labour government had itself abandoned socialism and was a more fervent believer in privatisation, even when nonsensical as with the London Underground (in 1951, the recently nationalised London Transport was still the world's finest integrated public transport system; it had performed impeccably even in the darkest days of the Blitz) than even Mrs Thatcher's government had been.

We had been taught and had allowed ourselves to become deeply, if hopefully not irrevocably, selfish. Today, it gets harder and harder to believe in major public works, whether a national stadium funded by the state at Wembley or new railways like Crossrail, that would see mainline trains burrowing under central London and making direct connections between the City, West End and major airports.

Together we find it very hard to build tomorrow today unless there's something in it for shareholders. Our pleasure is that of fumbling in the greasy till rather than celebrating the most enjoyable elements of the collective culture, needed from time to time to build structures, infrastructures, stadiums and festivals we can all enjoy and remember, 50 years down the line, and with affection.

fields.headline: Freedman flings Palace a lifeline
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace turned their recent form on its head to leapfrog above Portsmouth and out of the relegation zone.
fields.body:
Palace fans must be wondering what might have been had Steve Kember been in charge all season. Promoted from chief scout on Saturday after the sacking of Alan Smith, the stand-in manager last night oversaw a deserved win that took Palace out of the bottom three and dropped Portsmouth into the relegation places.

Defeat would have meant relegation for Palace but two goals from Dougie Freedman ensured that - despite managing only six goals and one win in their previous 13 matches - they looked more like the side who had beaten Liverpool in mid-season cup action.

That said, with only goal difference keeping them out of the drop zone, they travel to Stockport for their final match on Sunday far from safe.

Even victory will not suffice if Portsmouth win at home to Barnsley by a margin two goals better. But Kember, who steered Palace to safety in his first spell as manager 20 years ago, was upbeat. "We've given ourselves a chance," he said. "If we go to Stockport and win by two or three it will be hard for Portsmouth to catch us."

Pompey will have to improve markedly. They can overhaul Grimsby or Huddersfield as well as Palace, but last night earned only chants of "You're not fit to wear the shirt".

"I'm disappointed, to put it mildly," said the manager Graham Rix. "To play with a lack of spirit and passion was unforgivable. The supporters had every right to boo us off."

Where Kember's players seemed galvanised by their plight, Rix's looked fearful in front of their first full house of the season. They knew a win would ensure safety but fell two goals behind inside 25 minutes to a committed Palace side showing no little skill.

Bravely starting with Hayden Mullins behind the two strikers, Palace had already gone close when Dougie Freedman's run and chip allowed Mikael Forssell to score. Soon afterwards Mullins crossed for another Finn, Aki Riihilahti, to cash in on more poor defending.

Pompey replied against the run of play on half-time when Alex Kolinko dropped a Kevin Harper cross unchallenged and Lee Mills bundled it over.

Within a minute, though, Freedman restored Palace's two-goal cushion with a low shot and the Scot sewed up the points on 51 minutes by heading in a Mullins cross. Carl Tiler's late header for Pompey could at least prove crucial in the goal-difference equation.

fields.headline: Jansen lifts Blackburn into Premiership
fields.trailText: A late goal from Matt Jansen was enough to guarantee Blackburn Rovers Premiership football next season.
fields.body:
A late goal from Matt Jansen was enough to rubber-stamp Blackburn Rovers' return to the Premiership last night as they made good their promise to win promotion in memory of their benefactor Jack Walker, who died last August.

Their supporters sang Walker's name on the final whistle and the former owner's millions will allow the manager Graeme Souness to strengthen a team who already look well capable of holding their own in the top flight.

"It was nail-biting stuff," Jansen said afterwards. "We had to come here and get a result and it was a grind, but we got it.

"There's no better feeling than this. The lads have done brilliant and deserve a drink tonight."

For long periods it seemed as if they were intent on taking the promotion race with Bolton Wanderers to the final day, but Jansen's 72nd-minute header changed the whole picture and, after Jon Macken had rattled their post with a low shot in stoppage-time, Blackburn's destiny was secured.

One school of thought beforehand suggested that Preston, despite the clubs' rivalry, might prove accommodating opponents for Blackburn. Having already guaranteed themselves a play-off place, an astonishing feat for a newly promoted club, David Moyes's team had nothing more than local pride to play for, and cynics suggested that they might prefer to face Bolton in the play-offs.

A series of injuries forced Moyes to field a less than full-strength team, but any thoughts that Preston would offer only token resistance soon dissipated. A number of strong challenges in the opening minutes were testimony to the home team's commitment.

Gradually, though, Souness's team began to pick their way through the home defence. Damien Johnson had an effort disallowed after committing a foul in the build-up, and a delightful dummy by Mark Hughes in the 20th minute almost unlocked the door for Garry Flitcroft but the captain's shot was deflected wide.

Preston may have been restricted to counter-attacking but that tactic would have reaped dividends for Lee Cartwright had the midfielder kept his composure after sprinting clear of John Curtis. Iain Anderson came within inches of finding the net with a free-kick from 35 yards and Mark Rankine, with a shot from the edge of the penalty area, forced Brad Friedel into his first demanding save.

It could have been worse still for Souness's increasingly agitated team just before the interval. Brian Barry-Murphy had the ball in the net but, like Johnson's earlier effort, his attempt was disallowed for a foul in the build-up.

After the inevitable half-time rollocking, Blackburn began the second period as eagerly as they had the first. Once more, though, the breakthrough proved elusive. An unsuccessful penalty appeal by Jansen, who seemed to be felled as he tried to run clear of Sean Gregan, was the cue for Souness to bring on Marcus Bent, who made such an impact as a substitute against Portsmouth three days earlier.

Bent did offer greater movement in attack, but his composure was sadly lacking. From David Dunn's cross he sent a free header wide from six yards, and another effort moments later went out for a throw-in.

fields.headline: Rovers down but Carlisle survive
fields.trailText: A full round-up of Second and Third Division action.
fields.body:
Bristol Rovers lost their battle for Second Division survival last night when they went down 2-1 to two late goals against Wycombe Wanderers at the Memorial stadium.

Rovers fought it out to the end, with the centre-half Mark Foran - on for the injured Steve Foster - having two efforts cleared off the line and Nathan Ellington seeing a shot turned on to a post.

But it was not to be their night as Danny Senda's deflected shot on 73 minutes left Rovers' goalkeeper Nick Culkin stranded and he was beaten again from long range six minutes later by Dannie Bulman.

Although Kevin Gall pulled one back with 10 minutes to go, the final whistle signalled an end to their 11-year stay in the division.

The substitute Carl Heggs was the hero as Carlisle escaped the drop to the Conference by drawing 1-1 at Lincoln. He volleyed home a left-wing cross from Lee Maddison in the 66th minute, sparking a pitch invasion.

webTitle: Here's a remedy: put new stadium in the Dome

fields.headline: Here's a remedy: put new stadium in the Dome
fields.trailText: First, before dealing with Wembley, a little story concerning foot and mouth. A local farmer, attending the slaughter of his stock, was asked by the ministry man to drive his tractor into the infected field to help block off the exit to a pen in which the sheep were being held.
fields.body:
First, before dealing with Wembley, a little story concerning foot and mouth. A local farmer, attending the slaughter of his stock, was asked by the ministry man to drive his tractor into the infected field to help block off the exit to a pen in which the sheep were being held.

"Are you sure I should be driving in?" the farmer asked. "Yes," came the reply. The sheep were duly killed and the farmer jumped aboard his tractor to drive off. "Oh, you can't do that!" he was promptly told, and the tractor was impounded in the field for four days until more ministry men came to spray it.

A little later the farmer, who clearly never wanted to enter the field in the first place and did so only because he was told to, received an official letter, valuing his animals and offering additional compensation of £20 for every hour his tractor had been left in the field.

Such accounts of governmental profligacy will surprise nobody and I tell the tale only because, by the time the epidemic has run its course, enough money will probably have been squandered on inefficient bureaucracy to have bailed out the FA twice over in the great Wembley stadium fiasco.

Not that the FA should receive another penny piece from the taxpayers. For the whole Wembley shambles must be viewed in light of its wasteful 2006 World Cup bid which England never stood a chance of winning.

Having not even finished second, and now having singularly failed to convince private entrepreneurs that the Wembley scheme is worth backing, the FA has the gall to take the begging bowl to Tony Blair, no doubt hoping that the imminent election might sway the judgment of a man who coughed up £800m for the Millennium Dome. Not so. Blair immediately set up a holding committee. Perhaps this will be the Straw to break the Wembley stadium's back.

Of course the FA and the government could always do a straight swap, with Labour building low-cost homes on the Wembley site and the FA taking over the Dome. Just cut a hole in the roof; what could be simpler?

And it really is no good the FA limply arguing that the French and Australian governments stumped up cash for new stadiums, because unless those at Soho Square have fewer brain cells than they appear to possess they will remember that France actually won their bid to host the World Cup, as did Sydney the Olympics.

But there does not seem much point having a national stadium anyway, particularly if it is limited to soccer. Italy and Germany don't bother. Far better to play internationals at Anfield, Old Trafford, St James' Park or the Stadium of Light in the heart of real soccer country.

The odd England friendly might also be taken to Highbury or White Hart Lane - clubs that from time to time manage temporarily to break the northern grip on the game - but otherwise let football steer well clear of the congested capital with its overpriced hotels and heavily polluted air.

In this respect rugby league should have known better, having lost Wembley, than to take the Challenge Cup to Twickenham, thereby enhancing its inferiority complex instead of celebrating the fact that the game is northern to its roots.

Pele referred to Wembley as the church of football and many would still prefer to see it revamped and refurbished, just as Hampden Park has been. This has never been any part of the "progressive" Football Association's plans - for these are the men who allowed Manchester United to opt out of their own FA Cup, thereby tarnishing the trophy forever.

Perhaps the Churches Conservation Trust, which keeps buildings in repair and accessible, even if unused, could be persuaded to take Wembley under its wing. More seriously, the government must not allow the FA to have the custodianship of any national stadium. The Wembley farce has underlined this in triplicate. Of course, they may yet decide to build one in Sweden.

fields.headline: Hitting the jackpot
fields.standfirst: Hetty Hughes was inspired by her gran, writes Victor Keegan
fields.trailText: Hetty Hughes was inspired by her gran, writes Victor Keegan
fields.body:
Hetty Hughes was on a bus travelling from Leeds to Bradford on Monday night - a replacement for a train that wasn't running - when her mobile phone rang. "Oh my God, how wonderful," she replied on being told that her submission had won first prize (£1,000) in the Guardian's text message poetry competition - from almost 7,500 entries.

Hetty, 22, who was on her way back from the Nelson Mandela concert in Leeds, is a second-year undergraduate doing a degree in peace studies. She said that she liked reading poetry but had never actually written a poem since she was young.

How did it happen? She remembers the moment. She had read about the competition in Online and was sitting in her bedroom trying to come to grips with an essay on the role of the United Nations as the major collective security organisation in the 21st century.

Her eyes strayed to a photograph of her grandmother. Suddenly she started thinking about essays and texting. Ten minutes later her poem was finished. She will count herself fortunate if she earns so much money so quickly again.

Hetty's favourite poet is Alice Walker, but she also likes Maya Angelou. Among her other interests are music, reading and development studies. She sheepishly admitted she had given her entry 10 out of 10 when it was texted back to her as part of the interactive side of the competition, but added that she had marked the other six on the short list fairly generously from 6.5 to 9.0.

The second prize of £500 went to Steve Kilgallon, aged 22, who was promoted last week to be the sports editor of the Wigan Observer. A graduate of St Anne's College, Oxford ,where he read English and modern history, he is writing a history of rugby league at Oxford and Cambridge. He played rugby league while at Oxford and was watching a league game when told he had won second prize.

Marissa is doing a doctorate in engineering and classics, part of which involves using computers to read old documents. She already has an MSc in computing and humanities in addition to two other degrees.

The final prize of £100 goes to Carole Bromley of York, a teacher doing an M Phil in writing at the University of Glamorgan. She is the only regular poet among the winners and was runner-up in this year's BT Stay in Touch competition, part of the Poetry Society's annual competition.

Hetty, 22, who was on her way back from the Nelson Mandela concert in Leeds, is a second-year undergraduate doing a degree in peace studies. She said that she liked reading poetry but had never actually written a poem since she was young. How did it happen? She remembers the moment. She had read about the competition in Online and was sitting in her bedroom trying to come to grips with an essay on the role of the United Nations as the major collective security organisation in the 21st century. Her eyes strayed to a photograph of her grandmother. Suddenly she started thinking about essays and texting. Ten minutes later her poem was finished. She will count herself fortunate if she earns so much money so quickly again. Hetty's favourite poet is Alice Walker, but she also likes Maya Angelou. webTitle: 'This game is not over, far from it'

fields.headline: 'This game is not over, far from it'
fields.trailText: Writing off Leeds has become a perilous occupation this season and, even if it is now advantage Valencia, David O'Leary was quick to emphasise that it would be dangerously premature to dismiss his side's chances.
fields.body:
Writing off Leeds has become a perilous occupation this season and, even if it is now advantage Valencia, David O'Leary was quick to emphasise that it would be dangerously premature to dismiss his side's chances.

It will require a thunderous effort in the Mestalla stadium next Tuesday, but Leeds have already shown themselves to be intrepid travellers and O'Leary insisted he was not fazed by the prospect.

"I will always remember when I was playing for Arsenal and we played Juventus in the Cup Winners' Cup," he said. "It was a similar type of thing because they came over to Highbury and held us to a goalless draw.

A lot of people would have been thinking: 'Oh well, that's it.' But we went to Turin and got the away goal that got us through.

"I know Valencia will be delighted with this result but, if I was them, I would be wary as well. They will be flying home happy and, yes, people will look at the result and think that they are in the driving seat.

"But on our day I am confident that we are a side who can score an away goal and I know from experience that it's amazing how much that would change everything. This game is not over, far from it."

If the tie is at its halfway point, O'Leary was clearly half satisfied. "I'm a great believer in faith. God is good and we could have a great night in Valencia yet," he added.

"We would have loved to have gone over there with a lead but I always knew it was going to be close. At this stage of the competition you just don't win games by three or four goals. They are usually settled by a lucky break or a moment of genius. Not being able to call upon Robbie Keane is a real nuisance."

On the positive side, Leeds have scored in five of their eight European trips this season. "We will go there thinking we can do it," said O'Leary. "That's been our mentality all season. People always bang on about our 4-0 defeat in Barcelona but we had eight players out that night and you don't go into war with a water pistol."

Next Tuesday they will need the full artillery. "It will be a very different game," observed the Valencia coach Hector Cuper. "We will have more space to play because Leeds will not have such an attacking philosophy."

At 10.40pm, in the bowels of Elland Road, a group of friends and relatives gathered to sing Happy Birthday to O'Leary, 43 yesterday. He was all smiles, as always, but for all his bravado there was no disguising that the celebrations were somewhat empty.
